fields.headline: Lambert fumes
fields.trailText: Paul Lambert may not be ready to become a manager but he already speaks the language that will be needed by the next Celtic boss.
fields.body:
Paul Lambert may not be ready to become a manager but he already speaks the language that will be needed by the next Celtic boss.

The only current Scottish footballer to possess a European Cup winner's medal fumed after his club could only draw against Hibs to present the title to Rangers.

"We can't keep on going like this. We weren't good enough and have never been good enough to win it. The sooner the new guy is here the better. The club needs continuity and I've worked under a different manager every year."

 Falkirk's 2-0 win against Morton assured them of third place in the First Division and ended the possibility of play-offs, as their Brockville Park ground does not meet Premier standards. It meant promotion for the prospective champions St Mirren and Dunfermline.

 Hamilton Academical will appeal against the 15-point penalty imposed on them for not playing at Stenhousemuir after a players' strike. If it fails they will be relegated. Alloa Athletic and Ross County were promoted to the First Division while the amateurs of Queens Park go up to the Second.

fields.headline: Teachers warn of summer action
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: David Blunkett, the education secretary, was warned yesterday of a summer of legal and industrial conflict if he pushes ahead with plans to pay a £2,000 bonus in September to experienced teachers whose pupils score well in national tests and exams.
fields.body:
David Blunkett, the education secretary, was warned yesterday of a summer of legal and industrial conflict if he pushes ahead with plans to pay a £2,000 bonus in September to experienced teachers whose pupils score well in national tests and exams.

After a stormy debate at the National Union of Teachers' annual conference in Harrogate, the union's general secretary, Doug McAvoy, said he was confident there would be a ballot on a work to rule, involving a boycott of duties going beyond teachers' basic contractual commitments.

This is expected to threaten sports coaching, drama clubs, school trips and other initiatives adding value to children's education during the summer term.

Graham Lane, Labour education chairman of the Local Government Association, forecast a rash of legal action from disappointed teachers who thought they had been unfairly denied the performance bonus. When local education authorities were forced to defend themselves before employment tribunals they would have to name Mr Blunkett as a co-respondent.

The authorities would have no responsibility for decisions about performance pay increases that were made by headteachers and assessors appointed by the government.

"If teachers said they had been denied a performance increase for reasons of sexism or racism, we could face unlimited fines. The only way we could sort this out would be to name Mr Blunkett as a co-respondent. This would cause the whole scheme to unravel," Mr Lane said.

The warnings came after NUT moderates appeared to have outsmarted leftwingers trying to win conference support for a one-day national strike against performance pay.

Debate on tactics for pursuing a £2,000 pay increase for all teachers without performance strings attached ran out of time and the key votes may not be reached before the conference closes tomorrow.

There was strong pressure from delegates who thought Mr McAvoy was not robust enough in defending the profession against a pay scheme that they claim would threaten teamwork and discriminate against newly qualified teachers.

Bob Sulatycki, a teacher from Kensington and Chelsea, accused the general secretary of collaborating with ministers by sending out guidance encouraging teachers to apply for performance pay if they were eligible.

"We are 200,000 strong," he said. "We have the strength if we are prepared to use it. A one-day strike would transform the mood. We can win parental support on this."

Mary Compton, a teacher from Radnor, won a standing ovation after she said: "The strike weapon is as much to protect children as teachers. The only way this will become a live issue is if we get off our knees and take some action.

"If we can't fight to defend teachers against the greatest threat to the profession in our lifetime, then what are we in a union for? League tables have set school against school. Now performance pay will set teacher against teacher. Don't let them do it."

Mr McAvoy said after the debate: "It is finely balanced whether conference will back strike action."

But even if it did, the executive would have to decide whether to go ahead without overwhelming support from teachers at the grassroots.

It was "almost certain" there would be a ballot for industrial action short of a strike.

On Saturday, the conference voted for local industrial action to protect teachers refusing to inform on each other to help headteachers with performance reviews.

About 400 delegates walked out in protest at the start of a speech by Estelle Morris, the school standards minister, and others persistently heckled her. Mr McAvoy told them: "I am not aided one bit by heckling, shouting and booing. You boo the good as much as you boo the bad."

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, said the NUT was bringing teachers into disrepute by threatening industrial action against performance pay while encouraging its members to apply for it.

"That's utter nonsense," he said. "If you decide to go for it, it seems daft to take industrial action against it."

webTitle: Bevan better than best of Hartley

fields.headline: Bevan better than best of Hartley
fields.trailText: Shane Warne's first wicket for Hamshire was not enough to beat Sussex
fields.body:
"Loads of pasta, 15 fags a day and the occasional blow-out with Robin Smith" - thus did Peter Hartley, 40 last week, describe his novel recipe for longevity. On the evidence of his B&H Cup performance for Hampshire yesterday, he may do untold damage to the reputation of the fitness gurus. What he could not do, however, was deny Sussex and Michael Bevan, for whom the improbable is always possible.

Bevan's decisive 65 not out from 102 balls was small beer compared with his breathtaking unbeaten 185 for the Rest of the World against Asia earlier this month, but Sussex will not bother with such aesthetic considerations. His cat-and-mouse duel with his fellow Australian Shane Warne ended in an honourable draw, where-upon the Gold Award winner did much as he pleased.

Guiding and gliding, driving and dabbing, the placement exquisite and the brain perpetually whirring, the chances of Sussex sauntering home with four balls to spare had nevertheless seemed highly unlikely while the oldest out-swinger in town was strutting his stuff. Having rallied Hampshire from a precarious 102 for eight with an astute 32 not out, Hartley proceeded to grab four cheap wickets as the hosts plunged to 29 for five.

He then returned to have the belligerent Robin Martin-Jenkins caught behind, ending a 97-run stand with Bevan that had turned the tide. How many other players have set competition bests with bat and ball in the same match while in their fifth decade?

After sending down 19.3 overs in two outings Warne, whose march to the crease before his innings was greeted with eerie silence, finally nailed his first county scalp, trapping Umer Rashid. Yet, with Warne and Hartley bowled out, Bevan had no reason to feel downcast.

Jason Lewry chipped in until run out by Dimitri Mascarenhas going for a second - Bevan's stealth between the wickets is seldom matched by anyone, let alone lumbering pacemen - but Nick Wilton filled the breach. With 16 runs needed and the contest in the balance, 13 were taken from the penultimate over from Mascarenhas, leaving Bevan to apply the coup de grace with an extra-drive off Alan Mullally.

The Sussex captain Chris Adams hailed Bevan as "the ultimate professional", which may be news to Steve Waugh, but this was no time to dampen ardour.

Nottinghamshire are now the only county with no hope of reaching the quarter-finals. Wins today for Yorkshire, Derbyshire, Surrey, Worcestershire and Northamptonshire will ensure their passage.

 Mushtaq Ahmed's four for 22 helped Pakistan wrap up the triangular tournament, beating West Indies by four wickets in Trinidad to win the best-of-three finals 2-1.

fields.headline: Stomp away Saturday
fields.standfirst:
The Charlatans
Empress Ballroom, Blackpool
****
fields.trailText: Just back from a successful tour of America, the Charla tans played this sold-out date in the dusty glamour of a ballroom that was all stucco balconies, corinthian columns and sticky carpets. It's not exactly LA, where Tim got married seven months ago, but a Saturday night in the copping-off capital of the north-west finds stag nights and hen parties flirting their way along the seafront. The Charlatans dutifully turned in a set which combined the urgent, lifting melodies of their singles with the mid-tempo, folksy tracks of their most recent album, Us and Us Only.
fields.body:
Just back from a successful tour of America, the Charla tans played this sold-out date in the dusty glamour of a ballroom that was all stucco balconies, corinthian columns and sticky carpets. It's not exactly LA, where Tim got married seven months ago, but a Saturday night in the copping-off capital of the north-west finds stag nights and hen parties flirting their way along the seafront. The Charlatans dutifully turned in a set which combined the urgent, lifting melodies of their singles with the mid-tempo, folksy tracks of their most recent album, Us and Us Only.

With Martin Blunt's rumbling bass and Jon Brookes's drums together providing the best rhythm section in the business, it's no wonder that from the opening bars of Forever, singer Tim Burgess crouched as if his centre of gravity was in his kneecaps. Telling Stories, one of their best songs, blended Burgess's rising-falling lyricism with Mark Collins's engagingly simple guitar, while Crashing In knocked everything up a gear to get the crowd stomping on the wobbly wooden dance floor.

To a backdrop of petals, spirals, and passing clouds, they also played their forthcoming single, the Dylanesque Impossible, which had Burgess plucking the harmonica from his pocket to accompany another Collins riff. Indeed, Collins's melodic, grainy guitar has done much to define the Charlatans' sound over the last few years. Yet it was the thumping insistence of One to Another and How High that finally had everyone pogo-ing beneath the gilded chandeliers.

April 24, Shepherds Bush Empire, London; April 25, Colston Hall, Bristol; April 30, Dublin Castle, Dublin

fields.headline: Homage to backbeat
fields.standfirst:
Lou Donaldson/ Lonnie Liston Smith
Jazz Cafe, London
***
fields.trailText:
Lou Donaldson/ Lonnie Liston Smith
Jazz Cafe, London
***
fields.body:
Lou Donaldson, the 74-year-old Carolina-born alto saxophonist, is one of the heroes of the acid-jazz movement. He had hit records with catchy, blues-infused pop-jazz in the 60s and combines an earthy expressiveness with the fluidity and urgent sound of his first model, Charlie Parker.

There were a few occasions when the still fluent Donaldson abandoned backbeat-whacking funk for some flat-out classic bebop. On the funky Gravy Train, the saxophonist stretched a snaky melody that sounded like a mutation of Flight of the Bumble Bee over the obligatory backbeat. Lonnie Liston Smith, an inspired melodramatist, delivered all the authentic Hammond favourites: from stabbing, drumlike single lines to hisuhis, like the balefully churning trills that taunt the audience into endless anticipation and the stabbing, drumlike single lines. He also took his volume down to imperceptibility from time to time, conveying the silent music only by a snake charmer-like undulating of the fingers.

Donaldson sang hilarious blues in a strangulated warble and though his biggest hit, Alligator Boogaloo, sounded no more interesting a melody than it ever has, everybody took to it as if it were sheer magic.

Lonnie Liston Smith, an inspired melodramatist, delivered all the authentic Hammond favourites: from stabbing, drumlike single lines to hisuhis, like the balefully churning trills that taunt the audience into endless anticipation and the stabbing, drumlike single lines. He also took his volume down to imperceptibility from time to time, conveying the silent music only by a snake charmer-like undulating of the fingers. Donaldson sang hilarious blues in a strangulated warble and though his biggest hit, Alligator Boogaloo, sounded no more interesting a melody than it ever has, everybody took to it as if it were sheer magic.

fields.headline: London exchange eyes triple tie-up
fields.trailText: London, New York and Frankfurt are in talks which could lead to a three-way tie up between the centres' stock exchanges.
fields.body:
London, New York and Frankfurt are in talks which could lead to a three-way tie up between the centres' stock exchanges.

As merger discussions continue between the London stock exchange and Deutsche Börse, it emerged that there are parallel negotiations going on with Nasdaq, the successful American exchange for hi-tech stocks.

Sources close to the talks said Nasdaq could become a minority partner in the newly formed company in a move which would help it establish a strong foothold in Europe.

"Plans for Nasdaq Europe have not really gone anywhere. They might achieve Nasdaq Europe via this link," said a source.

If the Germany-London merger goes ahead, senior managers stand to share £8m in free shares and options, with Gavin Casey, London's chief executive, standing to gain most. Senior managers were awarded the options as part of the market's plan to demutualise - a move approved by members last month before the Frankfurt talks were known about.

The end of London's independence as a share trading centre is regarded as inevitable, given pressure from its biggest customers, including US investment banks Merrill Lynch, Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley, for rationalisation in Europe.

But it is determined to avoid being portrayed as the junior partner in the proposed merger with Deutsche Börse. Yesterday, sources said the deal was not done and added that London had received a number of approaches from potential suitors.

"London is bizarrely seen as the prettiest girl at the party," said one. "We have been lobbied very strongly by Euronext to consider joining them." Euronext combines the French, Belgian and Dutch bourses.

"We are in talks with Deutsche Börse and there's a will to do a deal but as yet there is no clear agreement." Crucial progress towards a deal was made over the weekend when the Germans offered concessions which would make the tie-up appear less like a takeover by the Deutsche Börse of the 200-year-old London stock exchange.

It is possible that London will be named administrative centre of the combined entity and retain the primary responsibility for leading blue chip stocks. This might calm concerns about jobs in the increasingly demoralised London exchange.

Frankfurt, however, is likely to be the technological centre of the exchange from where IT staff will run all the computer systems, which would be German rather than those developed by the British at vast expense.

Frankfurt will also house the fast-growing market for technology stock and integrate London's new Techmark market with its more successful Neuer Markt. London is thought to have little ground to argue that its trading systems be adopted after the breakdown earlier this month.

More important is a move to exclude the ownership of any share settlement from the discussions, one of the factors which would make the Germans appear to have a larger stake in any combination because of its 60% holding in the Luxembourg clearing house.

webTitle: Standard Life braced to resist float resolution

fields.headline: Standard Life braced to resist float resolution
fields.trailText: The board of Standard Life, Europe's largest mutual insurer, faces a battle tomorrow as an action group attempts to force a resolution for it to float at the insurer's annual meeting.
fields.body:
The board of Standard Life, Europe's largest mutual insurer, faces a battle tomorrow as an action group attempts to force a resolution for it to float at the insurer's annual meeting.

Demutualisation of Standard Life could see the insurer valued at £15bn and potentially deliver the 2.3m qualifying policyholders a £6,000 windfall each. The company has rejected these valuations as "speculative and theoretical".

The group of rebels, known as the Standard Life Members' Action Group and led by former fund manager Fred Woollard, conducted a poll last week of 500 policyholders. The group claims to have membership of the same number. The action group used research body NOP to carry out the poll which showed 58% in favour of demutualisation.

The board considered the issue of demutualisation last September but opted against it. "If you have got to make returns to both shareholders and policyholders you have to perform at a different level," a Standard Life spokesman said. "Standard Life is already performing at a high level."

The spokesman said the action group had not presented a solid business case for demutualisation apart from money.

Mr Woollard, who stands to reap more than £150,000 from demutualisation, denied he was a carpetbagger. "I'm certainly not one of those. I have no other plans to get involved with any other mutual company in the UK."

Monaco-based Mr Woollard admitted the evidence was mixed that mutual companies which converted to a listed status performed better. A demutualisation of Standard Life could take up to two years.

A vote on such a matter would have to be scheduled by the board within three months after Mr Woollard puts forward a resolution at the annual meeting. Mr Woollard made an unsuccessful attempt in February to force a resolution on the board for a vote on flotation. The action group has recruited legal advice for the submission of five resolutions.

"The company belongs to with-profit policyholders who would be better off with conversion," Mr Woollard said. "Clearly the company has too much capital, they have one of the strongest balance sheets in the sector and they are not using it." The board will be forced to call a meeting if 50 qualifying policyholders back the resolution.

fields.headline: Wal-Mart plans UK store debut
fields.trailText: Wal-Mart, the US retailer, is about to make its official stamp on the British supermarket industry.
fields.body:
Wal-Mart, the US retailer, is about to make its official stamp on the British supermarket industry.

The world's biggest retailer is to open its first British superstore in July and has plans for another 10, with three to be operating before Christmas.

Wal-Mart, which snapped up Asda for £6.6bn last July, said it would rebrand Asda's Patchway store in Bristol as well as undertaking refurbishment which will see the store selling a greater range of non-food items.

Wal-Mart sells a large range of electrical goods, music products, health and beauty items and intends to have Asda adopt the same format.

Asda stores operates with a ratio of 70% food and 30% other items.

A range of high street stores revenues may be under threat if Wal-Mart does begin discounting in these areas, using the strength of its buying power to offer such goods at cheaper prices.

Among the retailers which may be vulnerable are Boots, WH Smith and Dixons.

Earlier, this month stockbroker Credit Suisse First Boston warned investors to sell Boots shares on the grounds that competition from the likes of Wal-Mart would depress further its poorly performing share price.

Wal-Mart is expected to keep its superstores co-branded for a period before it drops the Asda name.

webTitle: Rover unions demand more time as Towers bid teeters

fields.headline: Rover unions demand more time as Towers bid teeters
fields.standfirst: Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: Unions tomorrow set out on a last-ditch effort to save thousands of jobs at Rover amid signs that the government-backed bid for the ailing car manufacturer being mounted by John Towers is on the verge of collapse.
fields.body:
Unions tomorrow set out on a last-ditch effort to save thousands of jobs at Rover amid signs that the government-backed bid for the ailing car manufacturer being mounted by John Towers is on the verge of collapse.

With the company due to be sold to venture capital group Alchemy on Friday unless Mr Towers can raise the necessary finance, Tony Woodley, national officer of the Transport and General union and Duncan Simpson, of the AEEU are to appeal to Rover's owner, BMW, for Mr Towers to be given more time.

"They want to see the money upfront but you can't get the money until you have carried out due diligence," said Mr Woodley. "It's like being asked to buy a house before the survey has been carried out."

Mr Towers, a former Rover executive, is understood to have met Hagen Luderitz, BMW's head of corporate strategy, in London last Thursday to discuss the financing of his bid, which, he claims, will maintain Rover as a mass market car producer and save thousands more jobs than Alchemy's proposal.

Alchemy plans to turn Rover into a niche sports car producer, although reports on Sunday suggested it might also allow Volkswagen use spare capacity at its Longbridge plant to build the Golf.

While telling Mr Towers that his bid is credible, BMW is understood to be concerned about a shortfall in his funding which he claims can only be plugged once the German firm has opened its books on Rover. BMW, however, is refusing to open its books until Mr Towers' funding is in place.

"It's a chicken and egg situation," Mr Woodley said.

Alchemy, headed by John Moulton, has been in talks with BMW since October and has had ample time to complete due diligence. Mr Towers has had to assemble his bid in a matter of weeks.

Sir Ken Jackson, head of the AEEU, said: "We will be asking for an extension from BMW so that Towers can be given a fair crack of the whip. Alchemy has had six months. It's only fair that he's given more time."

BMW isto hold a shareholders' meeting early next month and is thought to be keen to draw a line under the Rover affair before then to avoid a revolt. Sections of Germany's media refer to Rover as the "English patient" because of its heavy losses.

If Rover is taken over by Alchemy, unions fear it will lead to the loss of up to 19,000 jobs in the Longbridge area among Rover workers, suppliers and the wider economy. It would also come as a blow to trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers, who has publicly backed the Towers bid.

A DTI spokesman said: "BMW has always said that they will give the Towers bid detailed consideration. Now is the time for them to honour that commitment."

Under Mr Towers' plans, all Rover's managers and many of the workforce would either invest in the buyout or be granted options in the company. The options would be triggered if Rover met certain performance criteria. Reports suggest Mr Towers is asking BMW for £400m to take Rover of its hands but that he needs an extra £250m in finance and equity to clinch a deal.

webTitle: Mandelson set to quit as Ulster Secretary

fields.headline: Mandelson set to quit as Ulster Secretary
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson is set to quit as Northern Ireland Secretary, according to informed sources in Belfast and Dublin.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson is set to quit as Northern Ireland Secretary, according to informed sources in Belfast and Dublin.

In a remarkable development just six months after his arrival in the province, Mandelson will return to London to spearhead Labour's election campaign.

Senior sources told The Observer yesterday that David Trimble, leader of the Ulster Unionists, expects Mandelson to leave by the summer. Bertie Ahern, the Irish Prime Minister, is also said to have 'received messages' that Mandelson will quit, if and when the Northern Ireland Assembly has been reinstated.

Irish sources said that Mandelson had taken an increasingly backseat role in the past three weeks as Tony Blair and Downing Street chief-of-staff Jonathan Powell took over the detail of the negotiations to reinvigorate the peace process.

'The Government wants Mandelson back and all the indications are that that will happen,' a senior Unionist source said. 'Blair still has confidence in him and wants him to run the campaign in London. That cannot happen if he is in Belfast two or three days a week. We are realists. When he came here we fully expected that it would only be for a short time.'

The fact that both the Unionists and the Irish government are predicting his departure is highly damaging for Mandelson, who is desperately trying to rebuild the Assembly which was suspended earlier this year. 'What we need is stability both in the policies and the personalities,' said a well- placed Irish source.

Sinn Fein sources, who said that Mandelson was 'damaged goods', pointed out that it was the Unionists who first suggested that Mo Mowlam would be moved to make way for him.

If Mandelson returns to London, as Trimble predicts, it will mark the final return from the wilderness following revelations that he had agreed a secret £373,000 home-loan from fellow Minister Geoffrey Robinson.

Commentators said that Mandelson had now served a final period of penance in a post that is seen as one of the most difficult and thankless in the Cabinet.

webTitle: Labour row looms over Grant's seat

fields.headline: Labour row looms over Grant's seat
fields.trailText: Labour was last night facing a bitter battle over race after Sharon Grant, the widow of black MP Bernie Grant, confirmed she was considering standing for his seat.
fields.body:
Labour was last night facing a bitter battle over race after Sharon Grant, the widow of black MP Bernie Grant, confirmed she was considering standing for his seat. Mrs Grant, who is white, is consulting friends about the likelihood of a political fight breaking out over whether the Tottenham MP, who died this month, should be succeeded by a white or black candidate.

The row could involve senior black figures, including Trevor Phillips, Labour's candidate for deputy mayor of London, who is thought to be sympathetic to Mrs Grant, and Diane Abbott, the London MP, who wants a black candidate to stand.

'This will dramatically divide the party,' said a senior party source. Mrs Grant's task is made harder by the revelation that, before he died, Grant wrote to Tony Blair attacking Labour's record on promoting black and Asian candidates. The Prime Minister said he would set up a working party to look at how Labour could encourage more such candidates.

At a meeting of Asian community leaders at the House of Commons last week, Mrs Grant said her husband was angered by Labour's failure to adopt more black and Asian candidates for the new Greater London Assembly. Of the 25 GLA seats, only two are likely to be won by black or Asian Labour candidates. Black and Asian people make up a third of the London electorate.

If she stands, Mrs Grant, a tireless campaigner for black and Asian rights, could be faced by a slate of ethnic minority candidates. They include David Lammy, a young black lawyer; Peter Herbert, leader of the Society of Black Lawyers; and Kingsley Abrams, who heads a grant-making body and is close to party general secretary Margaret McDonagh.

fields.headline: Be I ever so humble
fields.standfirst: Why has Tony Blair suddenly discovered that humility is such a virtue for a Prime Minister?
fields.trailText: You can rarely fault his timing. At this moment in the Christian calendar when we contemplate sin and repentance, Tony Blair is in penitential mode. In his Easter sermon to his parliamentary flock, the Rector of Downing Street tells his MPs that they must abase themselves before our Lord, the voter.
fields.body:
You can rarely fault his timing. At this moment in the Christian calendar when we contemplate sin and repentance, Tony Blair is in penitential mode. In his Easter sermon to his parliamentary flock, the Rector of Downing Street tells his MPs that they must abase themselves before our Lord, the voter. It is time for New Labour to descend to its knees. 'We have to tell people that a lot has been done, but we also accept with humility that there is a lot more to do.'

Humility? Good heavens, what next? Perhaps we can anticipate the spectacle of the Prime Minister leading a shaven-headed Cabinet along Whitehall as they scourge their backs with rolled-up copies of the latest polling data from Millbank HQ. John Prescott will say three Hail Marys, though I suspect the Mouth of the Humber would express himself more industrially, for each cone every frustrated driver encounters on the congested roads this bank-holiday weekend.

Alan Milburn will prostrate himself before every patient who has suffered a cancelled operation or delayed appointment. There is a particularly grisly ritual in the Philippines at Easter in which participants parade with crosses to which they are then nailed. Even the most passionate supporter of freedom of information and the most determined champion of the right to trial by jury would not be so uncharitable as to wish such an awful fate on Jack Straw.

Still, for Tony Blair, so it has seemed lately, you can't have too much of repentance. He used the pages of this newspaper just a fortnight ago to make a full confession that he had strayed from the path of righteousness when he adulterated devolution. The Prime Minister pledges - we have his Holy oath on this - that he will go away and sin no more.

This is passing strange. Margaret Thatcher, whose clarity of purpose and tungsten skin has often attracted the present Prime Minister's open admiration, never knowingly admitted to a mistake. Well, just the one - entering the Exchange Rate Mechanism. And that was all the fault, she said, of her other error - John Major. He wasn't a man given to apologising, either, not even for Black Wednesday. Even in retirement, Ted Heath remained a granite monument of self-justification. When rats were gnawing through the piles of stinking refuse in Leicester Square, Jim Callaghan returned from the Caribbean to declare that he could see 'no signs of mounting crisis'. Harold Macmillan didn't go into an election telling the country: 'You've Never Had It So Sorry.'

What's more, compared with the record of that crew, Tony Blair has nothing to apologise for. He hasn't presided over an economic calamity. He hasn't perpetrated a poll tax. He hasn't switched off the lights. He hasn't left the dead unburied. By the standards of most occupants of Number 10, he is presiding over a highly successful and stable administration with several large achievements already to its name. Conservative Central Office, so a leaked memo reveals, agrees with everyone else that Tony Blair will win his second term with a majority which, even if reduced, will be of a size to attract the envy of most Prime Ministers.

So why are we suddenly so 'umble, ever so 'umble at Number 10? It's partly because Blair genuinely acknowledges a mistake over Rhodri Morgan in Wales. He doesn't think he was wrong about Ken Livingstone and still expects to be proved right about how he will perform as Mayor of London, but does, at least privately, concede that New Labour made a monumental mess of handling the newt-charmer.

I think the Prime Minister has also, if belatedly, realised that the Government has become the victim of its own spin. The bombastic school of presentation - billions spent on this, billions spent on that, these billions too often funny money produced by creative accountancy - rebounded badly by inflating expectations which could never be fulfilled. A little maturer and wiser now, New Labour may be learning to treat the voters as grown-ups who know that difficult things with years of inherited problems, like health, education and transport, do not get solved overnight.

There is more to these apologias than that. The Prime Minister's exercise in humility is also an illustration of Tony Blair the electoral cynic. His pollsters have been telling him for some months that he is regarded as a haughty control-freakist. He tried to dispel that notion in his last party conference speech when he told us that, though he walked with Presidents and Kings, he was just a Dad with kids at the end of the day. It clearly didn't do the trick then. So he's having another go now at deflating the perceived size of his own ego.

Oddly enough, it is nearly all perception. The truth about Tony Blair is that, as Prime Ministers go, he is a man pretty untouched by arrogance. He may go swivel-eyed in the end - quite a lot of them do - but he's not power-addled yet. Here's one of the striking reasons he is not like Margaret Thatcher. When arrogance was attached to her, and the label was applied very early on, she just got more so, and won three elections in a row before hubris finally became nemesis. Thatcher couldn't give a stuff if people thought she was arrogant. She correctly calculated that, though the voters might moan about it, they didn't really care about it.

Whereas she took it as a compliment to her strength, Tony Blair reacts with fright at being called arrogant, not something you would do if you truly were. So another aspect here is Tony Blair, the curiously insecure, who is already working himself into a fret about a general election he isn't compelled to call for another two years.

Incidentally, I'm not utterly convinced by the universal assumption that he will call that election in May 2001. I guess it to be just as likely that, following the Thatcher pattern of elections, he'd want to wait to see that year's local election results before steeling himself for the big one in June or July.

For Blair is a bit of a nervous Nelly about elections, a reflex which served him well until the last one. He privately predicted every Labour defeat, including the one that surprised most people in his party in 1992. The election he got wrong was May 1997. He anticipated winning, but never by so much. He must expect to win next time, but the fear rippling through the inner commands of the Government is that a combination of a high turn-out by the Tory core and apathy among Labour voters could drastically reduce his majority.

New Labour is getting into a terrific, energy-sapping twist about this. I hear some people around the Prime Minister arguing that New Labour's biggest problem is Tory unpopularity. If only, they sigh, the Conservatives weren't so unelectable, then William Hague would present a threat plausible enough to frighten natural Labour people to the polls. Get it? The better Hague does, the better Blair does. Well, these people do keep mobile phones close to their heads for many hours of the day.

You can do this sort of tortuous theorising until you disappear up the fundament of your own focus group. Alan Milburn will prostrate himself before every patient who has suffered a cancelled operation or delayed appointment. There is a particularly grisly ritual in the Philippines at Easter in which participants parade with crosses to which they are then nailed. Even the most passionate supporter of freedom of information and the most determined champion of the right to trial by jury would not be so uncharitable as to wish such an awful fate on Jack Straw. fields.headline: Book tells of 'bored, bullied' Queen
fields.standfirst: Authors clash as one portrays a sad monarch while others insist that she  is happy and fulfilled. Who are we to believe, asks Vanessa Thorpe
fields.trailText: The Queen is bored by her work and bullied by her husband, according to a new biography which claims to have had unprecedented access to information from inside the royal household.
fields.body:
The Queen is bored by her work and bullied by her husband, according to a new biography which claims to have had unprecedented access to information from inside the royal household.

The controversial book, Elizabeth: Behind the Palace Doors, which is published on Thursday, will argue that the Queen is struggling in an unsatisfactory marriage as she grows increasingly unhappy in her work.

Buckingham Palace has condemned the book as fantasy but author Nicholas Davies is adamant that his information has come from a variety of sources close to the royal family - including a former personal secretary to the late Earl Mountbatten.

'I am very confident of my sources,' he told The Observer . 'My book will show what her life is really like. It is not a chocolate-box biography.'

Davies is no stranger to accusation and counter-accusation. He worked for the Mirror Group of newspapers as a foreign editor under Robert Maxwell until, in 1991, he was accused of working for Israel as a spy.

He decided to write this book on the Queen's life, he says, to show what a remarkable woman she must be to cope with marriage to Prince Philip. Davies and his publisher, Mainstream, believe the author has new evidence that Mountbatten felt Philip bullied the Queen, as well as their children.

'One of my sources is John Barratt,' said Davies. 'For 20 years he was the personal and private secretary to Earl Mountbatten, right up until his death. He was totally in Mountbatten's confidence and helped him write all his letters. He was also party to letters the earl received.

'The royal marriage was undeniably a love match at the start,' said Davies. 'But it has been very difficult since. It is just that the Queen is someone who has set her face against divorce.'

To back up his bleak picture, Davies gives a story told to him by Barratt. During a trip to a polo game in Cowdray Park, Philip drove at his customary breakneck pace. 'When the Queen commented on his speed,' said Davies, 'he replied, "If you speak once more you will get out and I will leave you here".' Mountbatten is said to have asked the Queen why she let the Prince treat her in that way. She replied: 'Well, you heard what he said and you know he would carry it out.'

But Davies's inside view of the working life of the Queen will soon have some competition. A second book, The Queen's Daily Life: An Artist's View , is due out in September.

Published by Ebury Press, the book is the result of a unique project in which the Palace agreed to allow a husband and wife team, Michael and Vivien Noakes, to travel with the Queen to all her engagements for a year. Michael Noakes, a portrait painter for whom the Queen and her family have sat, has made a series of paintings and sketches to illustrate the book, while his wife, a biographer, has written the text. Both strongly contradict the picture of the Queen's marriage put forward by Davies.

'Philip and the Queen are together an enormous amount of time and he obviously supports her continually,' said Vivien Noakes. 'They seem to have a way of complementing each other. She is surprisingly shy in certain situations whereas, when it comes to walking into a room full of new people, Philip will make sure there is laughter. This is why he sometimes makes gaffes, I think.'

The Noakeses found no evidence to support Davies's claim that the Queen is bored with her job. 'She appears not only to enjoy herself, but to involve herself. Either that or she is an extremely good actress.'

They also cite a walkabout in Lancashire as evidence that she still finds her work rewarding. 'Everyone was laughing and nobody can tell me she was not enjoying her job.'

Davies is not convinced. He suspects the public are being deceived. 'The Queen is in her mid-seventies and has done this job very well for a long time. But, from what I have been told, she has been visiting members of the aristocracy to find out what they think about the idea of abdication - although she would not consider it until after the death of her mother.'

Geoffrey Crawford, a Buckingham Palace spokesman, said he had no knowledge of Davies's sources and doubted his bona fides. 'These two books are chalk and cheese,' he said. 'I don't know where Mr Davies gets his information. The press team at the Palace have barely come across him and I don't think I have ever met him.'

vanessa.thorpe@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Hard man Hague in quick shift to the right

fields.headline: Hard man Hague in quick shift to the right
fields.standfirst: Andy McSmith on how the Tory leader's latest outburst about asylum-seekers is driven by fear of his party's right wing
fields.trailText: Whatever happened to the nice William Hague we used to know? The right-wing hard man who wants all asylum-seekers interned in detention camps is a long way removed from that young Tory leader who promised to reach out to new voters and transform his party into one people would flock to join.
fields.body:
Whatever happened to the nice William Hague we used to know? The right-wing hard man who wants all asylum-seekers interned in detention camps is a long way removed from that young Tory leader who promised to reach out to new voters and transform his party into one people would flock to join.

Last week's speech on asylum-seekers, crafted to position Hague firmly to the right of Home Secretary Jack Straw, provoked unease among Tories who served in John Major's government. Even Gary Streeter, a member of Hague's Shadow Cabinet, balked at using asylum-seekers as an election weapon, warning that 'we're talking about human beings, many of them persecuted and fleeing for safety'.

But, outside London, activists have taken up Hague's battle cry. Tories campaigning against the Liberal Democrats have been encouraged to claim they would 'allow a flood of bogus asylum-seekers' and 'make Britain a soft touch'.

This is very different from the sentiments that pervaded Hague's first speech as leader to a party conference 30 months ago, when he said: 'I want to see men and women from our ethnic minorities playing their full part in the mainstream of our national life.'

And it is not the only example of the gulf between Hague now and Hague back then, when he believed the Tories could absorb in a few months all the lessons it took Labour more than a decade in opposition to learn, and overturn Tony Blair's massive majority. But now Hague's own advisers have stopped believing all that. A leaked internal document shows that they know that the next general election is probably lost.

On the day he was elected, Hague talked euphorically about getting party membership up to a million, with many more black and Asian Tory MPs. In fact, membership is stuck at 350,000 on the party's official figures. Unofficially, it is said to have fallen. And out of more than 200 Tory parliamentary candidates chosen so far, the only black or Asian with a realistic hope of winning a seat is Shailesh Vara, standing in the Labour-held marginal of Northampton South.

In January 1998, Hague promised a new brand of 'popular conservatism', declaring: 'Our watchwords will be openness and tolerance. The Conservative Party I lead will welcome people into its ranks regardless of their colour, race, creed, or sexuality.' But within two years, he had put himself at the head of the campaign to retain Section 28, which makes it illegal for councils to 'promote homosexuality'. Tory peers are simultaneously fighting legislation to equalise the age of consent for gays and heterosexuals at 16.

Hague's headline-grabbing proposal in last week's speech to the Social Market Foundation was to send all new asylum-seekers straight to detention camps - which he called 'reception centres' - until their cases are processed.

The uproar which followed disguised the fact that Straw is already opening new detention centres - but these will hold only about 800 people, barely half the number who arrive in the UK each week. Hague is prepared to spend millions interning them all.

According to Tory strategists, the speech earned praise from the Daily Mail, Daily Telegraph and Sun. An ICM poll for the Labour Party, released yesterday, says that 41 per cent of voters think the Tories under Hague are 'too right-wing'. For now, Hague's strategy is to go for the two-thirds who don't share that view.

But if it seems to outsiders that Hague is now a junior version of his mentor, Margaret Thatcher, that is not how Tories on the inside see him. They say that where Thatcher was driven by ideology, Hague is a pragmatist. Hague inherited a party where the Right is ascendant, and is trying to minimise the risk that he will be ousted by a right-winger after the election.

One former adviser said: 'In Thatcher's day, Central Office was full of people who believed in her. Now it is run by the equivalent of a Tory civil service - people who don't believe in anything much, except a general loyalty to the party.'

One Shadow Minister said: 'It's focus group politics - no more than that. There's nobody you would describe as a conviction politician in the inner circle.'

webTitle: Cook warns Mugabe: no cash without order

fields.headline: Cook warns Mugabe: no cash without order
fields.trailText: The foreign Secretary, Robin Cook, has rejected calls for Britain to give millions of pounds of land-reform aid to Zimbabwe, despite pleas from Africa's most senior leaders.
fields.byline: Kamal Ahmed and Jason Burke  in Murambinda
fields.body:
The foreign Secretary, Robin Cook, has rejected calls for Britain to give millions of pounds of land-reform aid to Zimbabwe, despite pleas from Africa's most senior leaders.

Writing for The Observer, Cook insisted that he will release the funds, promised in 1998, only when President Robert Mugabe returns the nation to law and order.

As hundreds of farmers demonstrated against Mugabe in the district of Buhera, near where two opposition activists were murdered, Cook said: 'Britain has always been willing to help with land reform. Moreover, we are ready to take the lead in coordinating international funding, involving our partners in Europe and the World Bank.

'But nobody is going to help with the programme of confiscation backed by murder. There must first be an end to the illegal occupations and the violence they have produced.'

Four people have died in the farm invasions and three others in political violence.

Cook was reacting to a joint statement by the presidents of South Africa, Namibia and Mozambique calling on Britain to act. The leaders met for crisis talks on Friday. Cook will meet ministers from Zimbabwe on Thursday to discuss aid.

webTitle: Stay loyal or or be sacked, BBC staff told

fields.headline: Stay loyal or or be sacked, BBC staff told
fields.trailText: For years some of the BBC's biggest stars have publicly lambasted the corporation for dumbing down and wasting licence-payers' money.Yet they have kept their jobs, drivers and expense accounts.
fields.body:
For years some of the BBC's biggest stars have publicly lambasted the corporation for dumbing down and wasting licence-payers' money.Yet they have kept their jobs, drivers and expense accounts.

But now some of the best-known names in broadcasting could find themselves sacked if they speak out. Greg Dyke, the new director-general, has told staff that criticism must stay within the soundproofed walls of Broadcasting House and Television Centre.

The BBC has been too slow to clamp down on dissent, Dyke has told staff. One BBC source says: 'Greg thinks people get away with saying things that would not be tolerated in the private sector. He wants to encourage debate, but people have got to realise that criticising the BBC in public damages our commercial interests and harms the brand.'

Dyke's move will anger some of the BBC's heaviest hitters who regard the corporation as a national institution rather than a business. One senior broadcaster said: 'The BBC is more than a bloody brand.

"It is an essential part of British life. If people honestly feel things are going wrong, they should be able to say it without worrying a P45 will land on their desk.'

Dyke, BBC sources say, has expressed astonishment that his predecessor, John Birt, tolerated very public criticism during Birt's seven-year reign.

John Humphrys, the radio presenter, and Mark Tully, the veteran India correspondent, accused the BBC of chasing ratings by replacing serious investigation with cheap consumer-driven news and documentaries. Humphrys described Panorama's interview with Louise Woodward, the au pair convicted in the US of killing a child, as 'pure soap'.

Jeremy Paxman has critcised - on air - corporate decisions about his own Newsnight programme, and Anna Ford has condemned the BBC for not giving women journalists a chance to tackle serious stories.

Explaining Dyke's move, a BBC source said last night: 'The BBC is the only truly global brand Britain has. We are not some little organisation. We are competing in a more and more competitive world where image matters. We need to look united and professional.'

Despite the move, one senior broadcaster insisted he would continue to voice criticisms. 'You should not slag off staff, but Greg Dyke must remember that the BBC is owned by the public. It is not a private company competing tooth and nail forcommercial advantage, where one word out of place can mean the difference between success and failure or cost millions of pounds. We are not pissing on our own patch, we are doing what is right.'

webTitle: If spit were wit, Prescott would be PM

fields.headline: If spit were wit, Prescott would be PM
fields.trailText: Tony's latest tantrum about the baby ('Of  course I've booked the time off, darling.  Provisionally.') coincides rather unhappily, I have to say, with the news that every woman in Europe is descended from one of seven valiant original sisters.
fields.body:
MONDAY: Awkward moment when John Prescott spat at Putin, but I think the interpreter convinced him that we simply have different gustatory habits here in terms of rigidity of separation between eating-mouth and speaking-mouth, which sounds a bit convoluted but probably better than my suggested 'He's from Hull.'

Still, a long and fraught day, and one I suspect will come back to haunt us in the way that everything since the announcement of our 'ethical foreign policy' has come back to haunt us. Why on earth didn't we just announce a 'murderous greedy trade-led bastards foreign policy' then take the kudos afterwards for everything that fell short of genocide? But I still think it was nasty for the Tories to start drawing comparisons about the lengths to which people would go to cling on to power. True, maybe, but way below the belt, surely.

TUESDAY: Oops. I've just realised the comparison was with Mugabe, not Tony. Feel rather shamefully disloyal, especially after he has so bravely opposed Hague's plan to sell off all asylum-seekers to rendering yards and give the profits to Harrods shoppers.

WEDNESDAY: Ken has won, I realise, when I find myself referring accidentally to 'Nobson and Doris'. Everyone knows, of course, that the whole thing is an accident waiting to happen: what's sad is that it's not even that unexpected an accident: more like a collision between two milk floats.

Still, good to see Frank's team still working away tirelessly. I have come to the conclusion that Frank's team would follow him anywhere, albeit only out of a sense of morbid curiosity.

THURSDAY: Tony's latest tantrum about the baby ('Of course I've booked the time off, darling. Provisionally.') coincides rather unhappily, I have to say, with the news that every woman in Europe is descended from one of seven valiant original sisters - Xenia, Catwoman, Cherie, that kind of thing - and so I find myself wondering precisely which seven men first begat the sorry specimens that pass for our spouses today. The smart money would seem to be on Grumpy, Sleepy, Bashful, Doc, Sneezey, Happy, Dopey, Dozy, Beaky, Mick and Titch. Still, at least I suppose men can count.

FRIDAY: So Tony did have another girlfriend at Oxford! I knew there was something he was hiding. I find myself feeling both immensely sorry for her - someone else had to listen to his late-night attempts at 'More Than a Feeling' by Boston, on the sitar - but also immensely cheered. You have no idea what an advantage this gives me. Revenge, blackmail, coercion, victimisation, shameless emotional grandstanding before the crowds. Happy Easter!

fields.headline: Drug habit grips Asian teenagers
fields.trailText: For most Asian families, travelling between Britain and the Indian subcontinent to visit relatives is commonplace. But a trip to the old country may prove disastrous for some young British Asians, as a growing number fall victim to a disturbing new drugs phenomenon dubbed the 'holiday habit'.
fields.body:
For most Asian families, travelling between Britain and the Indian subcontinent to visit relatives is commonplace. But a trip to the old country may prove disastrous for some young British Asians, as a growing number fall victim to a disturbing new drugs phenomenon dubbed the 'holiday habit'.

Drugs counsellors have also found that when Asian parents discover their children have been using drugs in Britain they panic and send them to family in Pakistan for help, without realising that use of the drug is rife and they are in danger of coming back with an even worse habit.

During their visits the young British Asians are often exposed to bargain-basement, readily available supplies of heroin and dangerous pharmaceutical drugs such as morphine and temazepam, according to counsellors in this country.

Experts say a gram of pure heroin, which would cost upwards of £100 in Britain, can change hands in Pakistan for 30p. Drugs charities say the authorities have failed to provide prevention and treatment services for ethnic minority users.

A report to be published this month of a conference organised by Scottish drugs charities will highlight the holiday habit and demand more resources for supporting Asian users. There is only one specialist service north of the border, and English services report similar pressures.

Kamlesh Patel, an expert in Asian drug use from the University of Central Lancashire in Preston, said: 'Among young males especially, the holiday habit is a growing problem. Young people are going to Pakistan for a few months and getting involved in heroin. When they get back to Britain they have a habit which is not only dangerous but costs them at least £50 a day.'

For years drug abuse among Asians was hidden behind a veil of community pressure and official ignorance, but research by Patel and others has revealed that it has more than quadrupled over the past decade in inner-city Asian communities.

Last week The Observer spoke to Shabir, 25, who asked that his real name not be used. He was taken to stay with relatives in a village near Lahore by his mother in 1997, to get him away from the 'bad crowd' he was hanging around with in Glasgow.

'The idea was to get me away from drugs,' he explained, smoking a medicinal joint in his bedsit in a dank tenement in the city. 'But the stuff was everywhere. There were guys coming up to me and offering pure heroin for less than 60p a gram. It was too tempting to say no.

'You could just walk into a chemist and get drugs over the counter; methadone, diazepam, you name it, they had it. It was too easy. '

Like most Asian users, Shabir smoked the heroin, using silver foil from cigarette packets. 'I was a wreck and I was needing loads of stuff just to get a dunt [hit] out of it. I realised I had to clean myself up.'

He managed to give it up and, three months after leaving Britain, returned home with his mother to Glasgow. For two months he has been clean, but the danger of sliding back is always there.

The true extent of the problem is unknown, says Nagina Malik, a counsellor with the Glasgow-based Eshara project. 'People don't get the support they need because of religion, culture and the fact that the community is often in denial,' she said. 'They don't know how to cope and they don't want to deal with it, so the attitude is get them over to Pakistan. That is probably the worst place they could be sending them.'

webTitle: We can help only if violence stops

fields.headline: We can help only if violence stops
fields.standfirst: Robin Cook explains that Britain wants progress on land reform - but first the farms must be safe
fields.trailText: Robin Cook explains that Britain wants progress on land reform - but first the farms must be safe.
fields.body:
When I saw President Mugabe in Cairo, I told him of my concern at the breakdown of the rule of law in Zimbabwe. I pressed him to enforce court orders, and to stop the illegal occupation of farms. I warned that failure to do this would encourage a descent into anarchy.

Recent events are precisely what I had feared and predicted. Farmers and members of the opposition have been murdered, and farmers' wives and daughters have been raped. Zimbabwe is in danger of sliding into mob rule.

Britain's response has been a twin strategy. First, we have taken the lead in mobilising international pressure for the return to the rule of law. Second, we have sought to draw the government of Zimbabwe into a dialogue leading to a peaceful and legal resolution of the crisis.

Our approaches have produced universal support from the international community and a rising tide of pressure on Mugabe. The Commonwealth secretary-general, Don McKinnon, shared a platform with me and shared the same demand for a return to the rule of law. He agreed that Zimbabwe must be high on the agenda of Commonwealth Ministers when we meet in a week's time.

The European Union has already unanimously supported a British text calling for an end to the illegal occupations and a start to free and fair elections.

In Africa itself we have found ready allies in leaders who know only too well that chaos in Zimbabwe is a menace to stability and confidence in Africa. President Obasanjo of Nigeria served long years in arbitrary arrest under military rule and knows the true value of the rule of law and democracy. I greatly appreciate his role in brokering the meeting between Mugabe and me in Cairo, and his recent action in sending his Foreign Minister to Zimbabwe with a personal message.

The discussion on the crisis this weekend between the leaders of Southern African states was prompted by my conversation last week with Kofi Annan which led to our approach to their regional organisation, the Southern African Development Community.

I spoke to President Chissano of Mozambique and President Mbeki's Foreign Minister before their visit and gave them a clear message for Mugabe that Britain is willing to help with land reform.

Moreover, we are ready to take the lead in coordinating international funding, involving our partners in Europe and the World Bank. But nobody is going to help with the programme of confiscation backed by murder.

There must first be an end to the illegal occupations and the violence they have produced.

It must also be a fair programme which helps the rural poor who have no land. Answers in the Zimbabwean parliament show that half the farms reallocated in the past three years have gone to public officials with the right connections, not to farmers with no land. We can help with land reform only if the programme is helping to reduce poverty.

We will work for a solution. Confrontation is not the course being pressed on us by opposition leaders or by those most at risk from the thugs. When I speak to the farmers' leaders, they urge Britain to keep our rhetoric 'cool and level-headed'. If we turn up the temperature, it is they who will feel the heat.

The leader of the Movement for Democratic Change, Morgan Tsvangirai, has publicly warned us against making Mugabe the martyr, which he craves for his own electoral calculations. When I saw Tsvangirai, he told me that he had also urged on the Conservatives bipartisan support for a solution.

Calls to end all aid are particularly counter-productive. What is the sense in stopping Aids projects, for example, in a country where a quarter of the population are HIV-positive?

It would hurt the people, not Mugabe. It might even convince them that Mugabe is right in his campaign to convince them that Britain is the problem, not his policies.

I cannot know in advance whether the Zimbabwean delegation that comes here on Thursday will be looking for a solution. If they are, we can together agree on the principles that would end the occupations and restart land reform. If they do not, they will be condemning their own country to more violence, more economic decay, and to isolation even within Africa.

fields.headline: Deadwood Stagecoach?
fields.standfirst:
The bus and train operator has either lost the plot - or it is all part of a cunning plan Heather Connon reports
Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The bus and train operator has either lost the plot - or it is all part of a cunning plan Heather Connon reports
fields.body:
Is it, asked one analyst, a cock-up or a conspiracy? Events at Stagecoach in the past three months suggest it has to be one or the other. Less than two months after the bus and train operator announced that chief executive Mike Kinski was departing after just two years in the job, it issued a profits warning, citing cost pressures in both its British and its US bus companies.Then, on Thursday evening, the company announced the resignation of Jim Leng, a non-executive director who joined the board a mere two months ago.

Has Brian Souter, founder and executive chairman, lost his touch? Or is he plotting to take the group private? Leng's departure, reportedly over corporate governance issues, is evidence of the latter. The departures and profits warnings have made this option much cheaper should Souter have a buyout in mind. The shares have dropped more than two-thirds this year, and the company is valued at little over £1.2 billion, a quarter of its value in 1998.

As further evidence for the buyout theory, the conspiracists point to the sale of Porterbrook, its train leasing company. This was expected to contribute half the group's operating profit this year, but it also needs large amounts of investment. The sale to Abbey National was sparked by the forecast that Porterbrook would get more hungry for cash which Stagecoach would find difficult to provide. But it also makes Stagecoach far easier to take private. Not only does the sale make the group far less profitable, it will also mean it has more cash available to satisfy the demands of venture capitalists.

Few analysts quibble with the decision to sell Porterbrook, although some wonder at the timing. The Government guarantees much of Porterbrook's lease income, a legacy of rail privatisation, but these guarantees run out over the next few years.

Stagecoach, concerned that that would reduce Porterbrook's value, decided it had to sell now. Roger Elliott of Salomon Smith Barney points out that this has the maximum impact on Stagecoach's profits: train operating companies are stepping up their train purchases. Also, had Stagecoach waited until it had won some of these, it could have fetched a higher price.

Some of the money will be used to buy back shares. At an extraordinary general meeting last Thursday, shareholders approved a resolution increasing the maximum permitted buy-back to 15 per cent

That has provided more ammunition for the conspiracy theorists. Souter and his sister Ann Gloag hold almost 20 per cent of the shares between them. If Stagecoach buys back much more than the 15 per cent currently permitted - the siblings' holding could get close to the 30 per cent limit which triggers an automatic bid. The company denies the buyout rumours, but Souter has said nothing.

There is plenty of ammunition for the cock-up theorists too. The City has always been suspicious of Coach USA, the US bus and taxi company Stagecoach bought last year, paying £770 million and taking on £400m of debt. Coach had grown rapidly by acquisitions, and there was concern about its ability to integrate these deals. Its margins were already high compared with the rest of the industry, though Stagecoach insisted it could get them higher still.

Stagecoach is the product of a string of acquisitions so, the optimists argued, it should be able to manage a company like Coach. But Stagecoach admitted it had been slower than it should have been in integrating Coach.

Chief executive Keith Cochrane says that has involved consolidating the financial reporting so that all 10 companies in the area work on an integrated basis.

The City was surprised that this is still being put in place in just one region when Coach has been under Stagecoach's ownership for eight months. Cochrane says the delay reflects the time it took to conduct an initial review, and the need to act first in the North East - the largest and most concentrated part of the Coach business. But if it has taken this long to do that, how long will it take to get the others into shape?

It is essential that it does. Stagecoach bought Coach because its British bus business has little growth potential. It bought into rail companies and Swedish buses, and acquired Prestwick airport, for similar reasons. The consolidation it expected in Sweden did not happen, and the business there has been sold. Prestwick's biggest customer pulled out of the airport and it is writing £30m off the value of its investment. In trains, there is concern that its joint venture with Virgin's West Coast Mainline will need huge investment yet produce poor returns.

The risk is that Stagecoach is a Nineties version of the conglomerate. At first, acquisitions translate into better performance, for shares and profits. But the bigger the group gets, the bigger the acquisitions it needs to make a difference to its results. In the meantime, when integration of the old acquisitions is complete and the provisions have been used up, the true - and often pedestrian - performance of the acquired businesses is revealed. When one analyst wrote that five years ago, Souter was furious. Now, that analysis looks prophetic.

webTitle: 'They said that next it  would be our grave'

fields.headline: 'They said that next it  would be our grave'
fields.standfirst: White farmers are not the only victims of the President's thugs.  Jason Burke tells how an opposition politician, hidden in  The Observer's  car, escaped their clutches in a dash across 'bandit country'
fields.trailText: White farmers are not the only victims of the President's thugs.  Jason Burke tells how an opposition politician, hidden in  The Observer's  car, escaped their clutches in a dash across 'bandit country'
fields.body:
When they came for Richard Chadya he knew what to do. As the thugs battered on the front door of his tiny tin-roofed cottage Chadya, 37, a would-be politician, slipped out of a back window and ran swiftly through the dark, dusty streets of his township to its post office. There, he knew, was a deep basement where he would be safe.

A week later he escaped - hidden in the back of The Observer' s car for a hair-raising hour-long high-speed dash through 'bandit country'. Now he is 130 miles away in a safe-house in the capital, Harare. Chadya, who hoped to win his home town of Karoi for the newly formed Movement for Democratic Change (MDC), is still shaken by his ordeal. He is worried about his wife and family who are still stranded there. But more than anything he is bitter that the violence is winning.

The thugs who came for Chadya were from the ruling Zanu-PF party. Little more than a vehicle for President Robert Mugabe, they have been in power for 20 years and hold 147 out of 150 seats in parliament. Now, for the first time, Mugabe and his henchmen are threatened by a credible opposition with growing political support. Their reaction has been cal culating and vicious. So far at least 10 people have died, hundreds have been injured, millions of pounds of damage has been done and the country is in chaos. Elections, brought on by Mugabe's failure to win a referendum entrenching his powers in February, may still be months away.

Though most of the international press has focused on the attacks on Zimbabwe's white farmers, Chadya and his colleagues in the MDC have suffered a horrific campaign of brutality and intimidation.

Last week two party members were burnt alive when their car was petrol-bombed by Zanu-PF supporters. An Observer investigation has established that such attacks are far more widespread than previously thought.

MDC activists are routinely followed and threatened with violence, MDC officers' house have been firebombed after rallies and dozens of activists have been abducted and beaten. In three attacks in the south of the country at least 10 party candidates have been hospitalised and scores were injured when a rally in the northern town of Mount Darwin was attacked.

In Harare last week a funeral for one of the MDC officers killed in their car was raided by Zanu youths and several mourners were seriously hurt. At least eight MDC activists are now thought to have died.

Chadya believes it is only a matter of time until someone is killed in Karoi. Dozens of MDC workers in the town have been badly injured after Zanu-PF spies infiltrated the local party and drew up lists of local members to attack. At least eight MDC activists have been seized, held for days in the Karoi Zanu office and beaten bloody. Others have been taken to the township's 'beerhall' and have had their heads smashed into its walls until they pass out. Armed Zanu activists are conducting house to house searches looking for MDC members and have dug a pit on the outskirts of the town.

'They threw all our posters and T-shirts and membership cards into it and burnt them and then they said that next it would be a grave for us,' said Chadya last week.

When The Observer arrived in Karoi Chadya was con tacted through a series of mobile phone calls to intermediaries. The atmosphere in the town was tense and Chadya was terrified of emerging from his hiding place. Gangs had formed in the streets each night, he said later, chanting songs about cutting off his head. Finally - after a destination had been agreed - Chadya was rushed by two friends into the car and we drove off, fast, on the road south. Clutching a plastic bag with pathetically few possessions, he lay flat below the rear seats as we sped past groups of Zanu-PF men on the verges of the road.

What would happen if they saw us and stopped us? we asked. 'For all of us, it would be the end of our problems,' Chadya replied grimly.

Within an hour of handing Chadya over to friends at a petrol station 50 miles away, we headed back to Karoi. We had arranged to spend the night in the relative safety of the home of Kelvin Weare, who runs an agricultural machinery hire business and a makeshift security network for farmers. Karoi is in prime farming country. Beyond the black townships on its outskirts enormous fields, lakes and patches of scrubby bush stretch to a huge horizon.

Seventy per cent of the best agricultural land in Zimbabwe is owned by 4,200 white farmers - a minuscule proportion of the total population. Their whitewashed ranch-style homesteads with swimming pools and tennis courts and immaculate lawns dominate the landscape. Close by are the 'compounds' where the farmworkers - often paid less than 60p a day - live in rows of small huts. In recent weeks more than half the 230 farms around Karoi have been invaded by squatters. In some cases the farmers have been allowed back on to their land, in others they are still living with relatives and watching and waiting.

The farmers are caught in a political trap that is only partly of their own making. Almost all support the MDC and many have given substantial amounts of money to fund the party's campaign against Mugabe.

The President has been incensed by such activities and is worried that the farmworkers will follow their bosses' examples and vote for the opposition. This could swing crucial rural districts - many of the urban centres are already MDC strongholds - against the government.

To forestall any such development Mugabe, who is 76, has launched the carefully orchestrated campaign that has sparked such violence in recent weeks. It is no coincidence that the farms targeted by the flying columns of Zanu thugs have been in strong MDC areas. Farmers singled out for attacks - such as David Stevens, who died last weekend - were members of the opposition.

By raising tensions over land - an unresolved issue since Zimbabwe won its independence from Britain in 1980 - Zanu also hopes to win back votes that they have been losing due to their dire mismanagement of the economy. And, as a last resort, the instability could provide a good excuse for Mugabe to postpone the elections by declaring a state of emergency.

'This bastard knows what he is doing,' said Kelvin Weare in a break between fielding calls on two radios and two phones. 'People are really scared. He really has us under the cosh.' The farmers are a rugged breed, with their bush hats and moustaches and tans, and are committed to their way of life. They believe their possession of so much of Zimbabwe's best land is justified.

We find out when at 5.30am the radio crackles back into life. A nearby farm has just been invaded by a group of 200 heavily armed squatters. The farmer is calling for help. But, as Zimbabwe staggers closer to anarchy, everyone is losing sight of peace.
