fields.headline: KGB returns to stalk Russians
fields.standfirst: The persecution of a reporter raises fears that Putin is reviving the bad old ways of the security service
fields.trailText: The persecution of a reporter raises fears that Putin is reviving the bad old ways of the security service.
fields.body:
When Russian war correspondent Andrei Babitsky was released after six weeks of beatings, incarceration and mental torture in Chechnya, he hoped he might be allowed to get on with his life.

His arrest by the military as he reported from the Chechen capital, Grozny, his spell in Chechnya's most brutal detention centre, the sinister prisoner swap orchestrated by Russian troops that ostensibly saw him handed to the enemy, his harrowing departure from the region, locked in the boot of a car - all took a heavy toll on his health and he retreated to hospital to recover.

But almost two months later he has revealed that he continues to be persecuted by the Russian government - still caught up in the jaws of what he sees as a continuing campaign by the FSB (the reformed KGB) to silence him.

Charged with the relatively trivial offence of carrying forged documents - a fake passport he says those who arrested him forced on him - Babitsky remains under close investigation. A second prosecutor has been assigned to his case and the prosecution team has been granted a two-month extension to its work.

Babitsky, who was arrested in Grozny after filing highly critical reports on Russia's campaign, has been prevented from returning to report on the war. His right to travel abroad has been withdrawn, he remains deprived of a passport and needs to obtain permission just to visit his weekend cottage 20 miles from Moscow. At the end of the month he is to undergo psychiatric and psychological tests to establish the extent to which he can be held responsible for his actions.

'I'm not a legal expert, but the whole situation strikes me as extremely strange,' he said. 'I'm in no doubt about my mental state. There's no logic to the investigation.'

An investigative reporter based in Moscow claims to have evidence that the Interior Ministry procured the passport at the heart of the case from the Moscow passport office - explaining that it was required 'for service needs' - and used the document to frame the reporter. The Ministry has denied the allegations.

Babitsky's mysterious disappearance at the height of the Chechen war unsettled Russia for several weeks, but amid the upheaval of presidential elections the country has virtually forgotten about him. This is an amnesia, he says, officials at the highest level are keen to cultivate. Colleagues at several Russian media outlets have told him 'friendly high-level pressure' has been exerted on their editors to discourage them from reporting on his case.

As President Vladimir Putin develops his strategy for reforming Russia's security services, Babitsky's declarations that he has been the victim of a bungled silencing attempt by the FSB have been an unwelcome distraction.

Babitsky's version of events is doubly damning to the government because it hints at both the lengths to which Putin's FSB was prepared to go to achieve its aims and the incompetence with which it set about the task.

He argues that, when Russian soldiers were shown on national television handing him to Chechen rebels in exchange for imprisoned Russian soldiers (in a piece of footage filmed and released by the security services), he was in fact handed over to pro-Moscow Chechen forces, in the pay of the FSB. But with international outrage about his disappearance mounting, the plot to 'neutralise' him backfired and he was released.

Still wan and drawn after his experiences, he sees himself as the victim of the new culture of strong (if not always entirely efficient) security service activity that has come to Russia with the arrival of Putin - once a KGB spy and the former head of the FSB.

But the long-term role the FSB is set to play in Putin's new Russia continues to perplex analysts. In this intermediate period between the election of the new President and his official inauguration next month - when he will be forced to indicate his true intentions by his choice of Cabinet appointments - speculation about the power he plans to give Russia's security services has become feverish.

In an alarmist piece in the Moscow Times last week, Konstantin Preobrazhensky, a disaffected former KGB lieutenant-colonel, declared: 'The KGB is being resurrected in Russia. After Vladimir Putin's election, fear has taken hold... democracy in Russia is threatened today. Once again the KGB is coming to power.'

Babitsky's own view is more circumspect. 'Democratic freedoms for Putin are synonymous with chaos. The role of the FSB has already strengthened under his control and I think it will become stronger still. What happened to me would not have occurred under Boris Yeltsin's regime,' he said.

Signals from the Kremlin continue to be contradictory. As Putin fills up his diary with meetings with European heads of state, he is determined to emphasise his democratic leanings. But an assessment of his past and his actions since coming to power paint a different picture.

Putin's own precocious enthusiasm to join the KGB at a tender age is well-documented and he pursued his ambitions singlemindedly. Since his appointment last year he has repeatedly and loyally praised the work of the KGB without stopping to qualify his comments with any recognition of the cruelties of its past repressions. He has also honoured Yury Andropov, former KGB head and Soviet President, restoring a monument to him on the walls of the FSB building - torn down with the 1991 reforms. He has spoken on several occasions of the need to 'consolidate' the power of the secret services.

In recent months there has been widespread speculation over the role of the security services in the bombing campaign that started the Chechen war. Meanwhile, Putin has promoted a handful of former KGB colleagues to senior roles in the government - a move which KGB veterans hail as a welcome sign that his priorities are in order.

General Valery Velichko, president of the State Security Veterans' Association, believes Putin will re-create a strong unified force from the underfunded, demoralised, divided bodies. 'Putin understands that the resurrection of Russia is impossible without the resurrection of the security forces.'

Babitsky agrees - with less enthusiasm. 'I hold Putin responsible for what happened to me. The FSB is part of his culture. He believes that the use of force can resolve most problems.'

webTitle: Stay logged off the Net shares frenzy

fields.headline: Stay logged off the Net shares frenzy
fields.trailText: Is it all over for technology stocks? The signs look ominous. The FTSE Techmark 100, Britain's 'new economy' barometer, is more or less back where it was when it launched last October
fields.body:
Is it all over for technology stocks? The signs look ominous. The FTSE Techmark 100, Britain's 'new economy' barometer, is more or less back where it was when it launched last October. Nasdaq, the US equivalent, has dropped by more than a third since its high in March.

Companies such as QXL, Freeserve and Baltimore Technologies, stock market darlings only a few weeks ago, are trading at as little as a third of their peak value. Many of the new economy companies which burst into the FTSE 100 index in March look likely to be thrown out again in June.

Should you be selling shares in every company whose directors have mentioned the word Internet? Or is the current weakness in the market an excuse to buy yet more technology shares?

John Pullar-Strecker, head of the global technology desk at Aberdeen Asset management - which, as one of the leading managers of technology stocks, has a vested interest in maintaining the momentum - asks us to focus on the fundamentals:

 Internet traffic is doubling every 100 days, and the number of people using the Net doubles every 10 months.

 Up to £9.4 trillion of transactions between companies could be conducted over the Internet by 2003.

 'Corrections' of up to 25 per cent in technology shares are not uncommon, yet the return on the US technology index has averaged 30 per cent a year for the past 10 years.

The technological revolution, in summary, is not going to go away; it is going to get even more pervasive. But accepting this argument does not mean we have to buy the shares. As William Valentine, a US investment manager who sold half his technology shares earlier this month, said: 'The companies are just dandy, the outlook for their stock prices, however, is not.'

Technological revolution or not, the decision on whether to buy or sell a share should always rest on its valuation. In the past six months, the shares of the best technology companies have been pushed to unsustainable levels. More worrying, however, is that these good companies have dragged the rest of the technology sector up with them, and many of their valuations look positively insane.

Many of these - QXL, lastminute.com and even Freeserve are some of the better known examples - have much further to fall.

Jim Wood-Smith, an analyst with stockbroker Greig Middleton, says the stock market should be split into three. First, there are the consumer Internet stocks, which have had their day. Then come the 'old-economy' stocks, which make up the rest of the stock market. These have had a bit of a renaissance, but there are still opportunities to invest. Try Unilever, Legal & General, P&O, Bass or, for the patient, Marks & Spencer.

Finally, there are the technology stocks which will come good. Wood-Smith picks Logica, Sage and CMG as three examples.

The trouble is, many technology stocks still look expensive, and even the most switched-on private investor will find it hard to sort the winners from the losers. I usually recommend a technology trust, but the prices of many of these has been inflated. Private investors would be best to wait until the dust settles.

Many of these - QXL, lastminute.com and even Freeserve are some of the better known examples - have much further to fall. Jim Wood-Smith, an analyst with stockbroker Greig Middleton, says the stock market should be split into three. First, there are the consumer Internet stocks, which have had their day. Then come the 'old-economy' stocks, which make up the rest of the stock market. These have had a bit of a renaissance, but there are still opportunities to invest. Try Unilever, Legal & General, P&O, Bass or, for the patient, Marks & Spencer. Finally, there are the technology stocks which will come good. Wood-Smith picks Logica, Sage and CMG as three examples. The trouble is, many technology stocks still look expensive, and even the most switched-on private investor will find it hard to sort the winners from the losers. I usually recommend a technology trust, but the prices of many of these has been inflated. Private investors would be best to wait until the dust settles.

webTitle: When opting out kept us in

fields.headline: When opting out kept us in
fields.trailText: One of the most influential public figures in Britain has just retired, and most people have never heard of him. That is just as he would like it. Indeed, it probably gives Sir Nigel Wicks a certain wry satisfaction that he is more honoured abroad than in his own country.
fields.body:
One of the most influential public figures in Britain has just retired, and most people have never heard of him. That is just as he would like it. Indeed, it probably gives Sir Nigel Wicks a certain wry satisfaction that he is more honoured abroad than in his own country.

As the Treasury's top international financial official since 1989, Wicks believes he has been privileged to have a ringside seat for one of the most interesting periods in international financial diplomacy.

His feat was to be the widely respected chairman of the European Union's influential Monetary Committee for most of the Nineties and retain the respect of the other EU countries, despite Britain's chronic intransigence on most of the big issues. They insisted he carry on chairing vital preparatory meetings for the single currency, despite the absence of the pound.

When learning of his resignation, one EU finance minister said the British could not be serious about the 'structural reform' they preach to the rest of Europe if they were prepared to let Wicks retire at the tender age of 60.

It is fashionable from time to time to say that Whitehall is out of touch with industry, and that there should be more secondments of high-flying officials. One of the problems is that it is precisely when officials begin to fly high that ministers and permanent secretaries do not want to let them go. Wicks got his secondment in early, spending 10 years with British Petroleum before he even applied for the civil service.

At his farewell Group of Seven meeting in Washington last weekend Wicks was accorded glowing tributes. By all accounts the Washington streets were livelier than the official meetings, and for some the tributes to Wicks were the high point of what went on indoors. Otherwise the item Gordon Brown and his retiring official are most likely to remember is the banner, 'worldwide campaign against globalisation'.

Despite being a pillar of the Thatcher and Major governments, Wicks has got on famously with Brown and his team since 1997. David Lipsey, in his book The Secret Treasury, describes him as 'very much Gordon Brown's kind of official; genuinely expert, with the right contacts and a willingness to pursue the ministerial agenda loyally'.

Wicks was at Margaret Thatcher's side as her principal private secretary when the 1985/86 Westland crisis nearly brought her down. But it was with the Major government that he saw his most active service; he was at the centre of the Maastricht negotiations of 1991, and heavily involved in the ultimately futile attempt to keep sterling in the exchange rate mechanism before Black Wednesday on 16 September 1992.

New Labour had it in for some of the officials involved in the Major/Lamont years; Wicks, however, not only survived but prospered after 1997. The fact that the Continental Europeans continue to regard him as a demigod is a remarkable feat, when one considers the fraught relations Brown has had with Brussels since Britain's exclusion from the inner sanctum meetings of the 'Euro XI' finance ministers.

To understand Wicks it is helpful to contrast him with another high-flying British official, Sir John Kerr, permanent Secretary at the Foreign Office, who was also in the thick of the Maastricht negotiations. In his book In Office Norman Lamont (Chancellor from 1990 to 1993) quotes Kerr as having told him: 'There are two sorts of civil servants. Those who do what they are told, and those who try to save ministers from their folly. I am the second.' Lamont adds: 'Of course opinion may differ as to what constitutes "folly".'

Another distinguished Treasury man - not Wicks - once quipped: 'Ministers do foolish things. My job is to see they do foolish things properly.'

Wicks is the quintessential civil servant, who keeps his private views to himself. One of his colleagues said: 'I have travelled thousands of miles with him, and I'm still not sure what his real views are.'

He has been intensely loyal to everybody he has served. I first met him at the Treasury in the mid-Seventies, when he brought his BP experience to the oil crisis. He has equally inspired loyalty in his bosses. Denis Healey, Chancellor during some almost impossible times for economic policy in the mid-Seventies, turned up at Wicks's farewell party last week.

People said that Thatcher, no less, had recently told him 'you were always right' and that Lamont, who had behaved oddly during the Maastricht negotiations, has told him 'Maastricht was not such a bad deal'.

For it was Maastricht that gave Wicks his place in history. Both John Major and Lamont, who do not agree on everything, credit Wicks in their memoirs for thinking up the idea of the British 'opt-out' from the single currency. With that, this anonymous civil servant became the man who has really dominated the political agenda of recent years, and will do so for the foreseeable future.

It is a measure of Brown's (and the Treasury's) respect for Wicks that he will have two successors: his duties will be shared between high-flying official Gus O'Donnell and chief economic adviser Ed Balls.

webTitle: Bandhogs? Stick that in your fat pipe

fields.headline: Bandhogs? Stick that in your fat pipe
fields.trailText: One of the great moments in the movie The Graduate is when a chap whispers the secret of success into Dustin Hoffman's ear. 'Just one word, Benjamin,' he hisses. 'Plastics.' Very 1960s, that. But analogous scenes are currently enacted whenever people from the television business gather to celebrate. 'Just one word,' they whisper. 'Broadband.'
fields.body:
One of the great moments in the movie The Graduate is when a chap whispers the secret of success into Dustin Hoffman's ear. 'Just one word, Benjamin,' he hisses. 'Plastics.' Very 1960s, that. But analogous scenes are currently enacted whenever people from the television business gather to celebrate. 'Just one word,' they whisper. 'Broadband.'

Ah, broadband. It's shorthand for 'wide bandwidth', which is to say, large communications capacity. And the TV folk are obsessed with it because they see the Internet as a way of pushing their digital pap at punters and are driven crazy by the fact that most of these punters have a very low-bandwidth pipe to the Net - a humble telephone line.

Transmitting moving pictures means shifting colossal amounts of data: even with a fast modem it takes hours to download a short TV programme. Which is why TV executives have fastened on broadband like ravening wolves. It will give them the fat pipe to the punter that they crave. And they are much cheered by the thought that engineers are busy dreaming up new ways of creating those fat pipes.

The fattest of all pipes is fibre-optic cable. You can already shift three hours of high-definition TV signal down it in the blink of an eye. The trouble is that there's no prospect of replacing domestic telephone lines with fibre-optic in the near future.

Then there are cable modems. At first sight these seem quite fat - sufficient anyway for some kind of video-on-demand service. But when you attach a lot of them to a cable network, the capacity of individual modems drops. The whole is less than the sum of the parts. The other drawback is that lots of people in the UK don't have cable.

That leaves the asymmetric digital subscriber line, or ADSL. When today's TV executives are subjected to post-mortems after inhaling too much coke, these four letters are often found engraved upon their hearts. Why? Because ADSL can be provided over a normal telephone wire. No digging up of roads required.

The 'asymmetric' bit comes from the fact that it offers different download and upload capacities - eight megabits per second downloading from the Net and 0.6 when uploading. But that doesn't bother the TV industry because eight megabits is adequate for moving pictures, and they don't care about the punters sending anything back - except their credit card numbers.

TV nirvana then? Not exactly. A few places in the world have had ADSL for a while and some interesting lessons are beginning to emerge. One is that many subscribers, doggedly refusing to become couch potatoes, are brazenly using the technology for other purposes. In fact, many of them would like the asymmetry to be the other way round - providing more bandwidth to the Net than from it.

Why? Because they want to use the technology to run their own Web servers from home, rather than paying fees to an ISP. Instead of becoming passive consumers of video on demand, in other words, they are becoming what one provider angrily described as 'bandwidth hogs'.

Well I never. TV executives should stick to coke, if only on the grounds that it's something they understand, and leave the Net to the rest of us.

fields.headline: Furious teachers snub Minister
fields.trailText: Members of England's largest teaching union dealt Schools Minister Estelle Morris an extraordinary snub yesterday when they staged a mass walkout as she addressed their annual conference.
fields.body:
Members of England's largest teaching union dealt Schools Minister Estelle Morris an extraordinary snub yesterday when they staged a mass walkout as she addressed their annual conference.

Speaking to the National Union of Teachers for the first time as a Minister, Morris was forced to endure furious heckling as around 400 delegates stormed out in protest at Government proposals to introduce performance related pay for teachers.

The dramatic scenes were reminiscent of the NUT conference five years ago when, as opposition spokesman for education, David Blunkett announced that Labour had withdrawn its opposition to opt-out schools.

Amid cries of 'Pay us all' and 'we will have your salary' from a group of left-wing militants who remained in the hall, Morris, a former teacher and herself an NUT member, refused to be drawn into a direct slanging match.

At one point, however, she directed her comments to the hecklers: 'There are some teachers that can shout louder than others and some who represent their members better than others,' she said.

Under the performance related pay scheme, from September classroom teachers will be given a £2,000 pay rise if they meet the criteria.

Morris emphasised that under the present system teachers could only earn over £25,000 if they were prepared to take on management responsibilities. She said that during her 18-year career as a teacher she had always felt it was unfair that colleagues who wanted to stay in the classroom could not command as good salaries as those who became managers.

In a robust speech she also referred to the fact that the NUT was the only union to oppose the principle of performance related pay. 'Whether you like it or not,' she said, 'there are many teachers' organisations who have said this is the opportunity of generation.'

NUT General Secretary Doug McAvoy slammed the delegates who walked out of the conference hall. Saying that they would lose the union the respect of the public, he added: 'I am not aided one bit by heckling, shouting and booing.'

But the union yesterday voted unanimously for locally-organised strikes over plans to ask teachers to judge each other's performance as part of the assessment process for the new pay scheme. Delegates said they opposed teachers being asked to inform on one another.

Earlier, delegates also voted for strike action unless jobs were guaranteed to be safe under the Government's Fresh Start initiative. Under this scheme schools judged to be consistently failing are closed and reopened under a new name with existing staff having to re-apply for their jobs. NUT members also voted for industrial action over their increased workload.

Education Unlimited

fields.headline: Holocaust book fraud inquiry
fields.trailText: Swiss police have searched the home of Bruno Doessekker, the author of a contested award-winning account of childhood survival in Nazi concentration camps.
fields.body:
Swiss police have searched the home of Bruno Doessekker, the author of a contested award-winning account of childhood survival in Nazi concentration camps.

Deception charges were filed last November by Manfred Kuhn, a Zürich-based lawyer, who claims that Doessekker defrauded him and about 12,000 other readers of the cost of the book.

A district prosecutor, Lucienne Fauquex, who is examining the case, confirmed the search at Doessekker's Swiss flat, and said the investigation would take several months to complete.

Upon publication in 1995, the alleged autobiography, Bruchstüke (Fragments of a Childhood, 1939-1948), was hailed as a moving account of a three- to four-year-old Latvian-Jewish boy's life in concentration camps in Poland.

Copies of the book were withdrawn by Suhrkamp-Verlag, the German publisher, during last year's Frankfurt book fair.

After the work was first challenged by a Swiss journalist, Daniel Ganzfried, in 1998, research commissioned by Suhrkamp and Does-sekker's agent appeared to back up the allegations that the author presented a fictitious childhood as an orphan, and was neither Latvian nor Jewish.

For more than a year Ganzfried cast doubt on the account, starting a high-profile debate in the interna tional press. The book received Jewish literary awards in the US and France. Doessekker made speaking tours in the US as a guest of the Holocaust memorial museum.

Writing as Binjamin Wilkomirski, which he claimed to be his original identity, Doessekker described the horrors of Auschwitz and Majdanek death camps and how he saw his father beaten to death.

The bulk of the evidence presented by his critics indicates that Doessekker was indeed adopted, but was born in Biel, Switzerland, on 12 February 1941 as Bruno Grosjean to a single mother, a Christian. He was brought up during the Second World War by his adoptive family, the Doessekkers, near Zürich.

The publisher's subsequent research is said to have shown that Bruno did not leave neutral Switzerland during the war.

The Zürich prosecutor has questioned Doessekker, but declined to give further details on the case.

fields.headline: Life and Saul
fields.standfirst: Saul Bellow based the protagonist of Ravelstein on his friend, the philosopher Allan Bloom, who died of Aids. But how far has fiction borrowed from real life?
fields.trailText: Saul Bellow based the protagonist of Ravelstein on his friend, the philosopher Allan Bloom, who died of Aids. But how far has fiction borrowed from real life?
fields.body:
Ravelstein
Saul Bellow
Viking £16.99, pp233
Buy it at BOL

Saul Bellow's thirteenth novel is a quietly wayward piece of work, dealing with last things as befits an octogenarian (illness, death, the persistence or other wise of the soul) but resisting the temptation of a late style, those cadences of farewell. If the whole book is an elegy, it turns all the while, stubbornly, gratefully, towards life.

There's no plot as such. Chick, the narrator, an elderly writer, played a part in making Abe Ravelstein, a rather younger and distinctly idiosyncratic professor of philosophy, into a figure of world eminence by suggesting he put down his ideas in book form. Originally this was a financial stratagem - the advance would go some way to staving off Ravelstein's chronic and proliferating debts - but in fact he produced a stunning polemical book, which made him rich and influenced those thoughtful leaders Thatcher and Reagan.

When Ravelstein was dying of Aids complications, he made Chick agree to write a biographical sketch of him. Ravelstein isn't linear enough to be the promised eulogy (six years after the death Chick has still to write it). Instead, it testifies to the depth of the fierce, late-blooming friendship that prompted the request.

A meditative structure allows for the legitimate presence of repetition, refinement of insight. But if there is sometimes an impression of energy being conserved at the heart of the book, then it is lavishly expended at the edges. A huge, peripheral forcefulness throws off brilliant formulations: 'He looked a lot like a big sandstone bluff with an overhang of bleached grass.' The figure on whom this description is bestowed is less than a minor character, hailed and bidden farewell in the course of two paragraphs.

There's a strong element of drawing from life in the portrait of Abe Ravelstein (as the New York Times reported last week). Bellow's friend Allan Bloom did indeed stir things up with his book The Closing of the American Mind, was indeed fêted and vilified for pronouncing education in his country dead.

But if this is a roman à clef, it isn't undertaken in the usual spirit. Though there is plenty of intimate detail given, which would seem jarring in a memoir (the fact of Ravelstein's increased libido in illness, for instance), there is discretion also. Bloom was a controversial enough figure, but in the eyes of the world certainly a lesser celebrity than Bellow, Nobel laureate and survivor. The choice of fictional space over any other kind enables Bellow to step down, for the duration of the pious though not exactly reverent task, from being Saul Bellow. The alterity of 'Chick' is marginal - he's not a full alternative persona. The abdication of a set identity is the important move, not the assumption of another.

Chick specifically disowns a last-days-of-Socrates atmosphere, but can't altogether avoid it. Ravelstein, who had previously divided his loyalties between Athens and Jerusalem, at the end of his life favours Jerusalem, dwelling on religious questions rather than politics.

What Ravelstein sought from Chick was a portrait, not an exposition or a critique, but the Bloomian repertoire of values and aphorisms ('American nihilism is nihilism without the abyss' being a fine example) necessarily features. Chick mentions in passing Ravelstein's opinion that a biological drive towards stability, 'together with a mass of other things', disables women for the serious study of philosophy. In this respect, Ravelstein is, if anything, less stern than his model - Bloom extended a doctrinaire exclusion to children of divorce, listeners to rock music and those no longer virgins, since the teacher-pupil relationship is Eros sublimated, upstaged and ruined by any physical expression.

Chick sees in Ravelstein an unsparing intelligence housed in 'a bald, cranial watchtower', and a loving stricture which insists on wrestling reality to the mat. His friend's life has 'more inner structure' than his. Chick's own sensibility is less confrontational - but then 'taking note' rather than passing judgment is part of his 'job description'. His alignment with reality is less critical, almost sensual. He speaks feelingly of 'the impulse to put your loving face to it and press your hands against it'.

Ravelstein sets himself to argue Chick out of his lifelong tendency to value impressions, particularly childhood epiphanies, over opinions, however steely. The to-and-fro between them, the muffled dialectic of their friendship, gives the book its whisper of drama. By asking to be commemorated, though, in a memoir rather than a peer assessment, Ravelstein significantly retreats from his stated position.

Of course, Bellow's artistic personality, his steadfast attachment to details, prevails on the level of the sentence. While Ravelstein is a great consumer of art, in the form largely of Italian music (Rossini, Frescobaldi on original instruments) relayed by plutocratic sound systems, his obsessions are actually politics and religion. It is left to Chick to formulate some sort of theory of art. As we age, time seems to hurry past us: 'Art is one rescue from this chaotic acceleration. Metre in poetry, tempo in music, form and colour in painting. But we do feel that we are speeding earthward, crashing into our graves.'

In the late part of the book, Chick suffers a breakdown which has its physical aspect (he has been infected by a fish eaten on holiday) but may also represent the surfacing of a hidden fear - that if he completes the memoir, his own life will be at an end. Bellow takes the risk of describing Chick's hallucinations in detail ('fictions' which for once 'did not have to be invented'). Even in an altered state, Chick, like his creator, holds on to reality by tenacious reflex and, despite their status as illusions, figures like his ex-wife don't lose their waspish pertinence ('You never fall back on religion except to win an argument,' she says).

The images of cannibalism which Chick can't get out of his head may be connected to Ravelstein. Mourning a friend can be an act of acquisition, an incorporation of the other's essence as much as an acknowledgement of loss. The great service Ravelstein rendered his disciples, and also Chick, was to turn their faces 'again towards the original' in a world of secondhand responses, forcing them to reopen what they had closed. The great last gift that Allan Bloom gave to Saul Bellow was to allow him to resign, in this supremely vigorous meditation, from the most sapping role that a novelist can find himself playing, the role of sage.
fields.bodyText: Ravelstein Saul Bellow Viking £16.99, pp233 Buy it at BOL Saul Bellow's thirteenth novel is a quietly wayward piece of work, dealing with last things as befits an octogenarian (illness, death, the persistence or other wise of the soul) but resisting the temptation of a late style, those cadences of farewell. If the whole book is an elegy, it turns all the while, stubbornly, gratefully, towards life. There's no plot as such. Chick, the narrator, an elderly writer, played a part in making Abe Ravelstein, a rather younger and distinctly idiosyncratic professor of philosophy, into a figure of world eminence by suggesting he put down his ideas in book form. Originally this was a financial stratagem - the advance would go some way to staving off Ravelstein's chronic and proliferating debts - but in fact he produced a stunning polemical book, which made him rich and influenced those thoughtful leaders Thatcher and Reagan. When Ravelstein was dying of Aids complications, he made Chick agree to write a biographical sketch of him. Ravelstein isn't linear enough to be the promised eulogy (six years after the death Chick has still to write it). Instead, it testifies to the depth of the fierce, late-blooming friendship that prompted the request. A meditative structure allows for the legitimate presence of repetition, refinement of insight. But if there is sometimes an impression of energy being conserved at the heart of the book, then it is lavishly expended at the edges. A huge, peripheral forcefulness throws off brilliant formulations: 'He looked a lot like a big sandstone bluff with an overhang of bleached grass.' The figure on whom this description is bestowed is less than a minor character, hailed and bidden farewell in the course of two paragraphs. There's a strong element of drawing from life in the portrait of Abe Ravelstein (as the New York Times reported last week). Bellow's friend Allan Bloom did indeed stir things up with his book The Closing of the American Mind, was indeed fêted and vilified for pronouncing education in his country dead. Though there is plenty of intimate detail given, which would seem jarring in a memoir (the fact of Ravelstein's increased libido in illness, for instance), there is discretion also. The choice of fictional space over any other kind enables Bellow to step down, for the duration of the pious though not exactly reverent task, from being Saul Bellow. The alterity of 'Chick' is marginal - he's not a full alternative persona. The abdication of a set identity is the important move, not the assumption of another. Chick specifically disowns a last-days-of-Socrates atmosphere, but can't altogether avoid it. Ravelstein, who had previously divided his loyalties between Athens and Jerusalem, at the end of his life favours Jerusalem, dwelling on religious questions rather than politics. Chick mentions in passing Ravelstein's opinion that a biological drive towards stability, 'together with a mass of other things', disables women for the serious study of philosophy. His alignment with reality is less critical, almost sensual. He speaks feelingly of 'the impulse to put your loving face to it and press your hands against it'. Ravelstein sets himself to argue Chick out of his lifelong tendency to value impressions, particularly childhood epiphanies, over opinions, however steely. The to-and-fro between them, the muffled dialectic of their friendship, gives the book its whisper of drama. By asking to be commemorated, though, in a memoir rather than a peer assessment, Ravelstein significantly retreats from his stated position. Of course, Bellow's artistic personality, his steadfast attachment to details, prevails on the level of the sentence. While Ravelstein is a great consumer of art, in the form largely of Italian music (Rossini, Frescobaldi on original instruments) relayed by plutocratic sound systems, his obsessions are actually politics and religion. It is left to Chick to formulate some sort of theory of art. As we age, time seems to hurry past us: 'Art is one rescue from this chaotic acceleration. Metre in poetry, tempo in music, form and colour in painting. But we do feel that we are speeding earthward, crashing into our graves.' In the late part of the book, Chick suffers a breakdown which has its physical aspect (he has been infected by a fish eaten on holiday) but may also represent the surfacing of a hidden fear - that if he completes the memoir, his own life will be at an end. Bellow takes the risk of describing Chick's hallucinations in detail ('fictions' which for once 'did not have to be invented'). Even in an altered state, Chick, like his creator, holds on to reality by tenacious reflex and, despite their status as illusions, figures like his ex-wife don't lose their waspish pertinence ('You never fall back on religion except to win an argument,' she says). The images of cannibalism which Chick can't get out of his head may be connected to Ravelstein. Mourning a friend can be an act of acquisition, an incorporation of the other's essence as much as an acknowledgement of loss. fields.headline: Paperbacks
fields.trailText: An examination of the circumstances surrounding Yitzhak Rabin, plus Ink, The Mighty Walzer and Rebel Hearts
fields.body:
Murder in the Name of God:
Michael Karpin & Ina Friedman
Granta £8.99, pp306
Buy it at BOL

Rabin's assassin doesn't talk about murder. Instead, Yigal Amir says he took the Israeli Prime Minister down in November 1995. The authors argue persuasively that Amir sprang from an extremist opposition movement whose anti-peace process rhetoric created a climate in which murder came to be seen as justifiable.

The book documents the campaign of incitement against Rabin involving settlers, right-wing politicians and Orthodox religious leaders. Outraged Israeli and American rabbis revived an obsolete Halacha rule - the duty to kill a Jew who imperils the life of another Jew - and applied it to Rabin. The book substantiates Amir's claims to have acted with rabbinical approval. A penetrating investigation of a society still riven by its failure to resolve the conflict between religion and secularism, tradition and modernity.

Ink
John Preston
Black Swan £6.99, pp379

Buy it at BOL

Preston's tale of lives made in the wreckage of dead dreams is told in addictive, flash-gun prose. Hugh is a journalist in crisis: he suffers acute writer's block, lives alone in London's Kensal Green ('immune to gentrification') and cannot escape the nocturnal crooning of the dead.

It is 1989 and, against the turbulence of his newspaper's move from Fleet Street to a glass cathedral, Hugh needs a story to save his career. When an unidentified man is washed up in the Thames, Hugh uncovers a sequence of disappearances creeping ever closer home. Like Waugh's Scoop, Ink captures the absurdity of newsroom neuroses: the unfulfilled desire to be a real writer, the smouldering envy of success. Unlike Waugh, Preston evokes the futility of ambition and the poignancy of settling for less. A good read, both funny and bleak.

The Mighty Walzer
Howard Jacobson
Vintage £6.99, pp388
Buy it at BOL

Oliver Waltzer wonders if, in an earlier life, he was Victor Barna - 1929 table tennis world champion - so adept a player is he. In the miserableness of 1950s Manchester, ping-pong fuels grandiose dreams and offers Oliver an escape from his overbearing family. His youth is a 'history of embarrassments': intense awkwardness at weddings, conspicuous hours of elaborate masturbation locked in the bathroom.

Playing for the Akiva Social Club, Oliver first tastes defeat (becoming 'the very mollusc of mortification') and gets off with girls like Sabine Weinberger, 'with her prominent bust and glass eye'. Jacobson writes like a player at the top of his game: alive to the comedy and sadness of the mundane, shifting the mood effortlessly. Part rites-of-passage novel, this book is also an exuberant reclamation of minor sporting history.

When They Lay Bare
Andrew Greig
Faber and Faber £6.99, pp322
Buy it at BOL

Greig has created a complex mesh of narrative voices to relate a young woman's mysterious return to the Scottish Borders - all steep-sided glens, plunging torrents, forests ripe for ambush. Drawing on a rich Scots vernacular, the resulting harmonic interplay articulates grand themes: passion, guilt, revenge, death.

Marnie arrives on Sim Elliot's estate hoping to unlock her own past. The set of antique plates she carries depicts a Border ballad - a violent love story whose beginning and end exist simultaneously - framing the present-day setting with a deeper poetry. As the connections between Marnie, Sim and his son emerge, Greig describes 'fine wires' multiplying between them, crackling with emotional electricity. In these unsettled borderlands, place and character fuse - the boundaries between past and present, fact and fiction set in luminous flux.

Rebel Hearts: Journeys within the IRA's Soul
Kevin Toolis
Picador £7.99, pp426
Buy it at BOL

Toolis has updated his authoritative study of the IRA with new material on two key deaths. He argues that last year's murder of Eamon Collins, a one-time IRA killer turned vociferous critic of the organisation, shows that, despite the ceasefire, the IRA has still to embark properly on an internal peace process. Toolis sees the funeral of Ronan MacLochlainn, a Real IRA member shot by the Garda during an abortive armed robbery in 1998, as a call to renew the armed struggle - a staging post en route to the mass murder of Omagh. Because it is immune to the suffering it causes, Toolis insists that extremist republicanism cannot be suppressed, only rendered politically irrelevant. A compelling exploration of the Irish republican mindset pointing up the background to some of today's peace process difficulties.

fields.headline: Audio
fields.trailText: Tim Pigott-Smith gives an assured reading of this tale of death and fishing
fields.body:
Snow Falling on Cedars
David Guterson
Read by Tim Pigott-Smith

Running time 3 hrs
Harper Collins £8.99
Buy it at BOL

It is 1954. A local fisherman is found drowned, his skull crushed by a blow to the head, his fishing boat bobbing up and down, deserted on the morning waves. A Japanese-American, Kabuo Miyamoto, is arrested and charged with his murder. Throughout the trial he remains 'proudly upright with a rigid grace'.

Meanwhile, the petty insecurities and deep-seated bigotries of the white community of San Piedro island on the north-west coast of America seep out of the 'grey hue and bleak simplicity' of the courtroom - a scaled-down version of the small and isolated town of Amity Harbour. Hatred hangs as thick as the snow resting on the cedar trees.

As the story unfolds, we learn of an adolescent love affair between a white boy, later to become the local journalist reporting on the trial, and a Japanese girl, later to become the wife of the accused man.

We also learn of the treatment of Japanese-Americans during the Second World War, of their forced detention and the distrust and suspicion felt towards them by white Americans.

At times I strained, like the jurors at the trial, 'to make sense of matters'. But Tim Pigott-Smith knows exactly what he is doing. He seems not at all daunted by the wealth of voices and accents he is required to maintain throughout the reading - American and Japanese, male and female, plus some Nordic thrown in for good luck. Pigott-Smith savours every inflection.

fields.headline: Happy birthday, William
fields.trailText: April 22 is traditionally Shakespeare's birthday, and 436 years on the bard is still hot.
fields.body:
Today is the traditional date of Shakespeare's birthday. He is 436, and his stuff is still attracting the attention of the best literary critics alive. Last week saw the acquisition by the Borough of Islington of a replica of Shakespeare's Rose Theatre built for the film Shakespeare in Love. This month has also seen the launch of an enjoyable matinée film version of Love's Labours Lost, while over at Kew, the Public Record Office has been displaying Shakespeare's famous will, with the puzzling bequest of his 'second best bed' to his wife.

Elsewhere, on the literary stock exchange, shares in Bard plc are still trading at a profit. New editions of his plays and new critical studies continue to appear. Biographies continue to be written. The minutiae of the poet's life continue to yield new interpretations. In Britain, he was named Man of the Millennium.

As befits a national cult, it used to be said that the man was a mystery. In the absence of reliable historical evidence, all kinds of mad theories flourished. He never wrote the plays. They were composed by Christopher Marlowe (smuggled to France after the brawl in Deptford), or by Francis Bacon, or by the Earl of Oxford.

The view that virtually nothing was known about the man who left only one authenticated signature has a long pedigree. In the eighteenth century, George Stevens, a scholar, wrote: 'All that is known with any degree of certainty concerning Shakespeare is that he was born in Stratford-upon-Avon, married and had children there, went to London where he commenced acting and wrote poems and plays, returned to Stratford, made his will, died and was buried.'

Recent biographers tend to stress an exactly opposite point of view. In his fascinating study, Shakespeare: A Life (Oxford £11.99), Park Honan argues persuasively that 'the factual truth... is more exciting, suggestive, and tantalising than anything so far dreamed up about him'. Honan's brilliant study, which possesses the great virtue of being supremely understated and excellently researched, places Shakespeare squarely in a late-Elizabethan context and shows how the Stratford glover's son transmuted the experience of growing up in rural Warwickshire into verse drama set in the streets of Verona, or a wood near Athens, or even the coast of Bohemia.

No amount of scholarship, of course, is ever going to stop people arguing about his work and its importance. To those who work with the English language every day, he remains enigmatically universal: both vividly present in literally thousands of everyday words and clichés, similes and turns of speech, and at the same time tantalisingly absent from the Collected Works that carry his name. None of this should stop us celebrating his birthday or imagining that things will be much different in another 436 years.

robertmccrum@observer.co.uk

webTitle: So, Hal, do you have to be cruel to be king?

fields.headline: So, Hal, do you have to be cruel to be king?
fields.standfirst: John Sutherland and Cedric Watts put Shakespeare's monarch on trial in Henry V, War Criminal?
fields.trailText: John Sutherland and Cedric Watts put Shakespeare's monarch on trial in Henry V, War Criminal?
fields.body:
Henry V, War Criminal? And Other Shakespearean Puzzles
John Sutherland and Cedric Watts
OUP £4.99, pp238
Buy it at BOL

Henry V is one of Shakespeare's finest and most troubling plays. It tends to be undervalued, partly because it's not a tragedy and partly because it is regarded as endorsing Henry's ruthless foreign adventure in France. It is history, and dubious history at that.

It doesn't tangle with the eternal problems. It is not about love, or parricide, or old age. It is just about politics and the secular, grubby ambitions of kings. Its empire-worshipping was just about tolerable in Olivier's film version, when Britain was under threat of the Nazis. Then, its military triumphalism could be invoked in the national project of self-defence. But at any later date, and certainly nowadays, it is hard to swallow.

And so the title of this book, and the question that it poses, is only surprising to the extent that it asks about something that for a long time has been taken to be self-evident. Of course Henry was a war criminal. And the only real question has seemed to be: does Shakespeare know it? That is, is he covertly against Henry?

Henry is a man who surprises everyone. Frivolous as a prince, he suddenly becomes very serious once crowned. He takes being king very seriously, and to prove it, he behaves with great brutality to his friend Falstaff. It is a demonstration of that refusal to entertain ordinary human weaknesses that the twentieth century has learnt to expect of its dictators.

From the outset, then, we see that Henry thinks that being in charge means being cruel. He's the kind of person - the commercial world is full of them - who believes that if you want to be a boss you have to be a ruthless bastard. As with Falstaff, so with the French. The war that Henry brings to France is waged by a man who doesn't understand the meaning of friendship. And if he cannot treat a dear friend decently, what chance is there for his nameless enemies?

Henry's career as king is marked by a double achievement. He legitimises his family's claim to the throne and he conquers France. All this is of a piece. His father had a dubious claim to the throne. England has a dubious claim to France. Both are made good by a combination of time and force of arms. The legitimacy of the king and the legitimacy of his claim to the French throne are related. Uphold the one and, by implication, the other is endorsed. So the question posed by this book goes to the heart of the play.

There are two problems about Henry's expedition to France. First: is he entitled to be there? Second: is he entitled to do what he does when he gets there? If the answer to the first is no, then everything he does in France is also illegal. His very presence is objectionable. But if the answer is yes, then the only charge he has to answer is: was he entitled to order the death of his French prisoners during the climactic battle at Agincourt? Cedric Watts deals with the first question; John Sutherland deals with the second. They do not convict, but nor do they quite acquit. Their judgment is closer to the Scottish verdict of 'not proven'.

Shakespeare doesn't like lawyers. The assertion of Henry's right to invade France is made by one of the more dubious of them, the Archbishop of Canterbury. In the Olivier version, he fumbles and bumbles as he gives his tedious exposition of Henry's rights at equally mind-numbing length.

But this doesn't discredit his argument; it just discredits him, and makes Henry, by contrast, appear every inch the decisive man of action. Henry expects the archbishop to provide a justification for the expedition and he duly gets it. The thinness of the justification - the Salic law doesn't apply in France - is besides the point.

Lawyers are expected to provide justifications for their client's actions, however egregious. The archbishop's job is to give Henry some arguments to support his claim and he does. It is his contribution to the war effort, no different in kind to the banker's contribution of funds. Watts thinks that the play equivocates on the justice of Henry's claims. I don't agree. The play endorses them, while pointing out (in the epilogue) that his successes were short-lived. But then that was England's fault. Not being able to hold on to what you have won doesn't in itself mean that you held it wrongfully.

Fighting his way through France, Henry arrives at Agincourt. He wins the battle against absurd odds. It is a fine moment, which the play encourages us to enjoy. He also orders the death of a number of defenceless prisoners. This is not such a fine moment, and it's easy to overlook it (particularly when it is suppressed, as in both the Olivier and Branagh films).

The play encourages us to regard it as retaliation for a French attack on the English base camp. It thus has a rough kind of justice - instant revenge, in the context of a battle. But the play also gives us some evidence for regarding it as unprovoked murder, because the first time Henry gives his order is before he knows of the French attack.

It's just the kind of puzzle that John Sutherland likes and he nibbles away at it (as he does at other problems in Shakespeare). For those unsatisfied with his conclusions, I recommend the work of the American scholar Theodor Meron. For those interested in the jurisprudence of wars, I also recommend Geoffrey Robertson's Crimes Against Humanity, just out as a Penguin paperback.

In the Olivier version, he fumbles and bumbles as he gives his tedious exposition of Henry's rights at equally mind-numbing length. But this doesn't discredit his argument; it just discredits him, and makes Henry, by contrast, appear every inch the decisive man of action. Henry expects the archbishop to provide a justification for the expedition and he duly gets it. The thinness of the justification - the Salic law doesn't apply in France - is besides the point. Lawyers are expected to provide justifications for their client's actions, however egregious. The archbishop's job is to give Henry some arguments to support his claim and he does. It is his contribution to the war effort, no different in kind to the banker's contribution of funds. Watts thinks that the play equivocates on the justice of Henry's claims. I don't agree. The play endorses them, while pointing out (in the epilogue) that his successes were short-lived. But then that was England's fault. Not being able to hold on to what you have won doesn't in itself mean that you held it wrongfully. Fighting his way through France, Henry arrives at Agincourt. He wins the battle against absurd odds. It is a fine moment, which the play encourages us to enjoy. He also orders the death of a number of defenceless prisoners. This is not such a fine moment, and it's easy to overlook it (particularly when it is suppressed, as in both the Olivier and Branagh films). The play encourages us to regard it as retaliation for a French attack on the English base camp. It thus has a rough kind of justice - instant revenge, in the context of a battle. But the play also gives us some evidence for regarding it as unprovoked murder, because the first time Henry gives his order is before he knows of the French attack. It's just the kind of puzzle that John Sutherland likes and he nibbles away at it (as he does at other problems in Shakespeare). For those unsatisfied with his conclusions, I recommend the work of the American scholar Theodor Meron. For those interested in the jurisprudence of wars, I also recommend Geoffrey Robertson's Crimes Against Humanity, just out as a Penguin paperback.

fields.headline: Will's power
fields.standfirst: Frank Kermode isn't afraid to give the bard B minuses in Shakespeare's Language
fields.trailText: Frank Kermode isn't afraid to give the bard B minuses in Shakespeare's Language
fields.body:
Shakespeare's Language
Frank Kermode
Penguin £20, pp336
Buy it at BOL

What do you hear when you go to a Shakespeare play? How much of the 'linguistic detail' do you pick up? Are some speeches ('To be or not to be', 'Our revels now are ended') too familiar for us really to hear, 'too well known to be well known'? In the forward rush of action, do you understand every word or are you just hanging on to the general sense, 'like watching an opera in Czech'? And, if Shakespeare's language is often hard to follow now, how much more so was it for his audience?

Frank Kermode's book on Shakespeare's 'dramatic verse' is partly about how Shakespeare is, and has been, heard, and it suggests interesting questions about the difference between reading and listening, and about audiences. Kermode proposes that Shakespeare's audiences, used to listening to long, complex oratory (like sermons) grew up with Shakespeare and were 'trained' by him to listen to a language of increasing obscurity and difficulty. Even if they didn't follow every word, 'they had been taught by Shakespeare' to 'take in' such difficulties 'at a hearing'.

But this book isn't mainly about audience; it's about writing and about the changes and developments in Shakespeare's use of poetry in the theatre. This doesn't mean that it's relentlessly purist, only looking at words in a timeless vacuum. Kermode needs to bring in theatre history, textual variants and performers.

And he has to discuss the dating of the plays, since his argument is that around 1599-1600 (the period of Julius Caesar, 'The Phoenix and the Turtle', Twelfth Night and Hamlet ) there is a turning point, a revolution in Shakespeare's language from a more artificial, rhetorical, ornamental style into something tougher and more rugged, and also more free, various, difficult and inward. (The two styles can overlap, he acknowledges, within single plays, and the Elizabethan audiences also liked nostalgic revivals of plays in the older manner alongside newer plays.)

After a rapid survey of the 1590s plays, Kermode gives a brief, intense chapter to the language of every play from Julius Caesar to The Tempest. This approach he describes, rather haughtily, as 'writing against the current'. A recent account by Catherine Bates in the Times Literary Supplement of new Shakespeare criticism said that 'to ask what it felt like to be Shakespeare, with a head full of words' would now be 'so démodé as to be professionally suicidal'.

But, at 80, Sir Frank doesn't have to worry about professional suicide. He sets himself against what to him are two equally detestable approaches to Shakespeare - the idolatrous and the deconstructionist. Resisting the approach to Shakespeare as 'somehow sacred' (no names are mentioned, but Harold Bloom seems to loom large), Kermode frequently allows for Shakespeare to collaborate and make mistakes, be dull or excessive.

He gives out a lot of B minuses. So Hotspur is 'capable of rant'; Jacques on melancholy is 'tedious'; The Two Gentlemen of Verona has 'tiresomenesses'; The Merchant of Venice has 'some passages we might now wish away'; Measure For Measure is 'a truly great play for about half its length'. But he likes to see Shakespeare struggling with 'excess of energy' or in 'compositional trouble', because it gives the lie to Bardolatry.

On the other hand, 'it cannot be wicked or stupid to make occasional allusion to [Shakespeare's] presence'; he exists 'as the corpus of plays we agree to call by his name', and he has value. 'You can't get rid of Shakespeare without abolishing the very notion of literature.' Kermode has no time for Shakespeare as a collection of competing discourses or a product of 'imperialistic brainwashing' and 'unexamined bourgeois valuations'.

You won't find discussions here of post-coloniality or cultural history, gender or feminism, identity or hegemony. Instead, Kermode deliberately reinstates the tradition of the dead white male writer-critics who have paid most attention to Shakespeare's words: Johnson, Coleridge, Hazlitt, de Quincey, Auden, Eliot and Empson.

Attention to language also means attending to what's not said. Kermode is very good on silence. He shows us how much deeper Shakespeare's silences get by comparing the aghast, elaborate rhetoric which greets the sight of Lavinia with her hands and tongue cut off in Titus with the terrible silence of blind Gloucester, left on stage during the battle in Lear, or the 'competing silences' at the end of A Winter's Tale, when the statue of Hermione is revealed and at last breaks into speech, after long silence.

Silence can co-exist with a tremendous amount of noise, too, like Virgilia, Coriolanus's 'gracious silence', in the thick of military din. Shakespeare's astounding variety of language is made much of, from Romeo and Juliet's wild, wide range of rhetorical levels to Hamlet's 'bazaar' of transformations and variations. And his odd juxtapositions are well noted: Desdemona's sudden, strange remark about Lodovico ('a proper man') just after her cruel humiliation by Othello, or the effect of putting clowns' malapropisms next to great griefs: 'They bring serpents or pigeons on demand, or make plebeian jokes over an open grave, demonstrating totally unheroic attitudes to the posturing of the mighty'.

But under or alongside variety and disjunctions, Kermode recognises an increasingly obsessive reiteration of words, an 'intense brooding over words'. This, quoting Virginia Woolf, he calls the 'little language' of the plays: the use of 'a particular word or set of words to give undercurrents of sense to the dramatic narrative'. In Othello, the word is 'lie'; in Troilus and Cressida, it's 'opinion'; in Anthony and Cleopatra, it's 'becoming'; in Lear, it's 'addition'; in the porter scene in Macbeth, it's 'equivocation'.

And Macbeth is all about equivocation: false promises and false choices, uncertainty about time and the future, the struggle between action and consequences, the price of success. For Kermode, that idea of equivocation in language reaches out beyond Macbeth: 'All may be said to equivocate, and on their equivocal variety we impose our limited interpretations.'

It's on the (often equivocal) relationship between thought and action that Shakespeare brings his most obscure and oblique language to bear. This writing about thinking is often very difficult. Shakespeare 'is an author whose business it was to present character in all its inaccessibility, in language at least as opaque as necessary'.

Kermode is at his very best when deeply involved in Shakespeare's presentation of characters locked in their processes of thought, like Aufidius (in the long speech on his dangerous ally, Coriolanus, beginning: 'All places yield to him ere he sits down'), 'trying to make clearer to himself just how mixed his feelings are, how difficult he finds it to take a determined position'. Contradiction, confusion, obscurity and, above all, inwardness are what energise Shakespeare's greatest language.

'Greatness' and 'genius' are permissible concepts in this book. Those who reject such terms are going to find it autocratic and old-fashioned. And there is something at times irritating about its handing out of grades, its occasional withdrawals into wonderment ('easier to applaud... than to explain'; 'qualities that are in the end beyond description') and its frequent unarguable references to 'a famous speech', 'a tremendous passage', 'a celebrated response', 'the most venerated lines in the play' or 'one of the most miraculous moments'.

But at a time when what's been called Big-Time Shakespeare is being energetically re-popularised for a new generation through movies which package him as action, romance, song and dance and showbiz, when Bardolatry sentimentalises him and some academic criticism turns him into a cultural construct, this concentrated, lucid, attentive book comes as a valuable reminder that, as the director Richard Eyre says here: 'The life of the plays is in the language.'

webTitle: Hello, darling, I'm not on the train

fields.headline: Hello, darling, I'm not on the train
fields.standfirst: Ann Widdecombe does not like mobiles. As if we needed The Clematis Tree to find that out
fields.trailText: Ann Widdecombe does not like mobiles. As if we needed The Clematis Tree to find that out
fields.body:
The Clematis Tree
Ann Widdecombe
Weidenfeld & Nicholson £9.99, pp277
Buy it at BOL

If you want to know Ann Widdecombe's views on the vagaries of mobile telephones, read her new book, The Clematis Tree. The scene is Waterloo Station. Mark Wellings, a man with a lot on his plate, including a handicapped child and a loveless marriage, is waiting for a train which is endlessly delayed. That's because the trains in Britain are largely rubbish.

Mark is queueing for a public telephone because he doesn't own anything as vulgar as a mobile. You can't imagine Ann Widdecombe having anything as vulgar as a mobile, either.

The book develops the scene: ' "Sorry, darling, I'll be la-ate," sang a voice near him. Mark turned irritably and directed a baleful stare at a young man talking earnestly and lovingly into a mobile phone. He jauntily continued the conversation as if the embarrassment had not happened.'

You can imagine Ann going through the same pain as she waits for the train to her home in Maidstone.

If you want to know Ann's views on marriage, even one as loveless as that of Mark and his wife Claire, read her new book. Mark is thinking about setting up his own business when he hears his daughter, Pippa, and some friends, singing. 'After a pause the voices rose again but this time in a very different theme. "Peace, perfect peace, is the gift of Christ our God." Mark wondered if Pippa were among the singers and if so whether she understood what she was singing, whether she believed it. He found himself hoping that she did.'

Ann thinks people should stick with a marriage, even one as loveless as that of Mark and Claire. The comfortably rich couple live an idyllic life until their young son, Jeremy, is mown down by a sports car outside their home. He was chasing a white rabbit.

Although the car was travelling at 60mph, it doesn't kill Jeremy (I would have checked if that's actually possible, Ann) but leaves him paralysed and severely brain damaged. Mark and Claire's marriage can't cope. Mark tries his best; he turns down two chances of affairs, but in the end sticks with the loveless marriage.

The Clematis Tree contains a long list of things you imagine keep Ann awake at night. The struggle of broadly decent folk to deal with all the problems life throws at them - mad family members, late trains, people with mobile telephones, the lot.

Some passages are overlong (Mark's wait for the train) but some parts are surprisingly affecting. Mark's attitude to his disabled son wavers between love and ambivalence. Claire seems constantly on the verge of breakdown.

The book is shot through with Widdecombe's views on life and love, a moral indignation on life's iniquities that befall those just trying to do their best. She doesn't like people smoking on trains or drunk-drivers. The driver of the car that hits Jeremy was drunk. Of course he was.

One newspaper review said: 'The Book of Job written for the High Church, High Tory matrons of the shires.' That about sums it up.

fields.headline: Too much too young
fields.standfirst: Adolescents want to know about sensitive subjects like bullying - and trainers. Then there's love...
fields.trailText: Adolescents want to know about sensitive subjects like bullying - and trainers. Then there's love...
fields.body:
A teenager's life is a messy one. Priorities go in a descending spiral starting with sex, ending with parental respect. With their anarchic hormones, teenage boys may seem - from an adult vantage point - to be an unsavoury sight. But girls, mysteriously, still find them hard to resist. There are many teenage books - some light and unpalatable as candyfloss - that devote themselves to romance; but also many more issue-driven books covering topics such as bullying, drinking and peer pressure. Some are good and informative. But one stands out above the rest.

In Louis Sachar's Holes (Bloomsbury £10.99, pp233), magic and hard realism come crashing together. This is an extraordinary and unconventional novel about a young boy wrongly convicted of stealing a pair of trainers. Stanley Yelnats comes from a poor family and has never been on holiday. So when the judge offers him jail or a spell at Camp Green Lake, Stanley opts for the latter. But there is no lake. There is hardly any water. Only yellow-spotted lizards and the endless daily task of digging a five foot-square hole in the ground under a scorching sun. The landscape of Sachar's story may be parched and barren, but his imagination is exceptionally fertile.

Away from the desert, and set in the gentler climate of England's south-west coast, is Zillah & Me by Helen Dunmore (Scholastic Press £4.99, pp147). Before Katie has even reached her teens, her father is killed in an accident and her mother, desperate to escape their London home, drags her only daughter to the cold, damp Cornish countryside.

Katie fits in well at school and adjusts to the hardships of country life. But along with their rented cottage comes the mysterious Zillah, a sullen, solitary girl who wears a diamond ring around her neck and claims her father is a murderer. Dunmore is a wonderful storyteller. Her company is calming and her empathy is touching: 'I really wish adults could have the experience of being introduced in the same way as children,' comments Katie as she is pushed into an unwelcome alliance with the non-communicative Zillah.

Bullying is a subject which requires skilful handling both in life and in fiction. In Getting Rid of Karenna by Helena Pielichaty (Oxford University Press £5.99, pp98), Suzanne has started a Saturday job at a local hairdressing salon on the insistence of her parents.

Her enthusiasm for the job is dampened on the first day not by curlers and colouring lotions but by Karenna Sheldon - a stylist, and a bully who made Suzanne's early school years a living hell. Pielichaty's book is about the importance of self-confidence and being able to discuss problems with friends. She also offers some intriguing insights into the nature of bullies: 'Nobody can be that cruel without being taught how.' It is an amusing, thoughtful story but a career advertisement for hairdressing it is not.

A proper look at teenage books would not be complete without a good love story. Love Street by Andrew Matthews (Red Fox £3.99, pp122) is a risky phenomenon - a male writer trying to see life from a teenage girl's perspective - but Matthews pulls it off. Suze is preoccupied with a soap opera of her own imagining. It takes over her mind in stressful situations. She and her friends are besotted with Tony Beckwith, the school heart-throb. Oh, and add to that a boy weirdly called Hallo who is obsessed with Suze. There's sex, pregnancy, divorce - all the ingredients of a drama that will send shivers down the spine of any parent with a daughter on the cusp of adolescence.

Girl in Red by Gaye Hiçyilmaz (Dolphin £4.99, pp186) is a book that, at last, tackles the problem of a teenage boy with a weight problem. Frankie eats fish and chips in secret and has an appetite for a pretty girl. He lives on Poet's Rise, a rough, city-centre estate, and becomes infatuated with a gypsy, one of a band of refugees who arrive on the block. As his feelings for the girl grow, Frankie's relationship with his mother (an outspoken advocate of sending asylum seekers home) is slowly eroded. Hiçyilmaz tackles the sensitive, topical issue of refugees, as well as taking an upsetting, all-too-familiar look at relationships between parents and children that go wrong.

Buy Holes at BOL
Buy Zillah & Me at BOL
Buy Getting Rid of Karenna at BOL
Buy Love Street at BOL
Buy Girl in Red at BOL

fields.headline: Paperback of the week
fields.trailText: JM Coetzee's subtle and compulsive novel is a defining novel of our time
fields.body:
Disgrace
J.M. Coetzee
Vintage £6.99, pp 220
Buy it at BOL

Last week, our televisions and newspapers were full of this: a white man falls to the red earth and dies, killed by black men in a country where, to most eyes, he has always looked out of place. His white wife grieves as she, her white children and all they have are bundled from the land they thought was theirs, but is now claimed by a black government on behalf of its people.

Meanwhile, a white government thousands of miles to the north relaxes the membership rules of its cold island fortress - drawn up to keep out black people - to accommodate the widow and her kin. Black and white, it seems, reclaim their own. Thank you Robert Mugabe; thank you Jack Straw... and exeunt all.

Colonialism at best is the tyranny of the paternal. Disgrace is not knowing when to let go. And it lies in the central character of J.M. Coetzee's subtle and compulsive novel, last year's Booker Prize-winner issued in paperback this month.

Middle-aged and twice-divorced David Lurie disregards the students of the Cape Town university to whom he teaches Romantic poetry - until Melanie, whom he seduces and by whom he is then denounced.

Lurie admits the abuse of his office but refuses publicly to embrace the truth and reconciliation of his position. He resigns and heads for the hills, to the farm run by his daughter Lucy. At first, Lucy and the open land - his land seen through his city eyes - soothe him. But a vicious assault soon lays bare his increasing irrelevance to both.

Disgrace is a defining novel of our time, its apparently simple lyricism belying a grave incomprehension that threatens to sever our world in two. There is an answer, but it is very hard and painful to come to.

webTitle: The man who told the world

fields.headline: The man who told the world
fields.standfirst: Mendel Grossman's photographs of the Lodz Ghetto during the second world war are almost unbearably terrifying
fields.trailText: Mendel Grossman's photographs of the Lodz Ghetto during the second world war are almost unbearably terrifying
fields.body:
My Secret Camera: Life in the Lodz Ghetto
Photographs by Mendel Grossman
Text by Frank Dabba Smith
Frances Lincoln £12.99, pp40
Buy it at BOL

These are photographs that were taken from under a raincoat, and 55 years later they retain a peculiar intimacy: they are oblique memorials, images of restrained and hushed beauty. It is their context, rather than their content, that make them terrifying, tender, painful beyond belief. We look at the faces, the caught expressions, and know that shortly after these people were extinguished.

Mendel Grossman was a photographer, imprisoned in the Lodz Ghetto in the war. He secretly photographed the people around him; his fellow Jews, distant ranks of Nazi soldiers, faces that are scared, eager, innocent, knowing, alive. He hid the negatives in tin cans and packed them into a wooden crate which he hid during the liquidisation of the ghetto in 1944.

The men, women and children that he had recorded were sent to Auschwitz. That woman, wearing her yellow star, who is scrubbing the streets and unaware that a camera is recording her solitary figure; that boy in a peaked cap, with a thin, solemn face and wide eyes, that mother talking through a wire fence to her son, trying to smile, that joyful group of women in short sleeves, squinting into the sunlight and laughing, that young man with a sweet, clever expression who is Grossman himself: they all went into the dark. We see them now, from beyond their grave. They look back at us, lost.

Grossman himself died in 1945 on a forced march. His sister later rescued the negatives, but most were destroyed when the kibbutz where they were housed was ravaged during the War of Independence in 1948. Yet some still survive, and of these Frank Dabba Smith, a rabbi and a photographer himself, has selected 17. Beautiful images, in spite of the terror of their subject matter: grainy black and white and soaked in a soft, strong light.

'Grossman's photographs make us look with exquisite pity and affection, as into the eyes of people we love,' writes Howard Jacobson in his introduction. The final image - of a young woman staring through a camp fence, her fingers clutching the wires, her eyes gazing out at us dolorously, her figure slightly blurred, as if she is already half gone from us - is almost unbearable.

All of the images are almost unbearable. Yet this is a book meant for young people. The simple, first-person text by Frank Dabba Smith asks children to imagine what it was like. Asks all of us to imagine again. It would seem to be the job of all parents and all teachers to make sure that children grow up knowing about the Holocaust.

This book, suffused with tenderness, is a good place to start. That little girl with the skinny legs and the huge bow in her hair; that mother leaning towards the son who has been separated from her for ever; that laughing day in spring that will not come again...
