fields.headline: Slick on the draw
fields.standfirst: Dads, dogs and dancing guinea pigs - all life is to be found in the best illustrated books
fields.trailText: Dads, dogs and dancing guinea pigs - all life is to be found in the best illustrated books
fields.body:
Grown-ups have self-help books, children don't. Or do they? Writers offer children their services; they second guess children's sorrows and, sometimes covertly, prescribe cheerful solutions. A new baby in the family, a new school, making (or failing to make) new friends... there is a literature devoted to these problems. But it is only recently that I have noticed the growing number of picture books that focus on broken homes and extended families.

The Visitors Who Came to Stay by Annalena McAfee, illustrated by Anthony Browne (Walker £9.99) is one of the best examples of its kind. Its emotional temperature is perfectly judged. Katy lives alone with her dad and has mixed feelings when Mary and Sean show up. Mary is not wicked stepmother material; she is complicated and convincing. She wears a wide smile and a short skirt. Her son, Sean, is an irritant, a walking joke shop. Gradually, Katy learns that sometimes it is possible to be friends with the people you expected to be enemies for the rest of your life. Anthony Browne's bold, loud, clearer-than-life illustrations cannot be ignored, any more than the potential step-relatives can (five+).

Rainy Day by Emma Haughton, illustrated by Angelo Rinaldi (Doubleday £9.99) is a more sentimental approach to a broken family but none the worse for that. Rinaldi's moody, grey-skied, rain-splashed illustrations seem somewhere between paintings and photographs. Ned is visiting his dad. There is nothing obvious for them to do. They walk to the sea, get tired, get soaked, eat broken biscuits and when Dad says that rainy days don't last forever, you know he is comforting himself as well as Ned. I read on with a lump in my throat (four+)

Dads are getting a great press elsewhere this spring. Anthony Browne shows up again with a book that is all his own work. My Dad (Doubleday £9.99) is a surreal tribute to a father who, although he is seen by his son as a paragon, is never seen out of his tweedy dressing-gown. He sees off a wolf, jumps over the Moon, wins the father's race and swims like a fish (picture of fish/Dad with tweedy belly tied with dressing gown cord). Perhaps he is just too busy to get dressed. The book is simple and splendidly entertaining: Daddy worship at its best (three+).

You can judge Clever Cat by Peter Collington (Cape £9.99) - and this cat - by its cover. Look at the marvellously neat orange fellow standing on two legs with a bunch of keys depending from his wrist and two blue tins of cat food between his paws. The cat does not seem to need his owners - at first. The moral of this witty book is obscure but I believe it is about the advantages of underachievement, of lazing on a sun-drenched step when you get half the chance (for older children and indolent adults).

Dogs can be clever, too. Dog's Night by Meredith Hooper and Allan Curless (Frances Lincoln £10.99) is about the dogs in the paintings in London's National Gallery, who get together for a pow-wow on one night, every year. The hairy brown dog who looks like a burr in Jan van Eyck's Arnolfini Marriage breaks free of his frame along with the hunting dog from Gainsborough's portrait of Mr and Mrs Andrews. Then the dogs climb back into the wrong paintings. My audience was curious and delighted. So was I (four+).

Helen Ward's The Hare and the Tortoise (Templar £9.99) is a beautiful book. I often find retellings of old stories a downer; why not find a new story to tell? But this is a ravishing exception to the rule. Chardin would not be ashamed of the hare that leaps across these pages, leaving a decorative tangle of animals in his path. The tortoise is handsome, too, worthy of this spirited new version of his story (three+).

The Hidden Forest by Jeannie Baker (Walker £9.99) is a knock-out. It is a marvellous companion piece to Baker's haunting book, Where the Forest Meets the Sea. She is passionately devoted to preserving endangered environments. Here, she concentrates on Tasmania's Tasman Peninsula and its kelp forests. Her artwork is constructed 'using a multitude of collected natural materials including seaweeds, sponges and sands'. The result is pure poetry: a billowing saffron and jade underwater forest, a hitherto undiscovered country (four+).

The Elf's Hat by Brigitte Weninger and John A. Rowe (North-South Books £9.99) is an immediately striking book. North-South Books specialises in painterly work and this is no exception. Rowe's idea of an elfin hat is anything but twee; it is more like some colossal, red chilli pepper. The elf loses his hat and then a bizarre assortment of animals move into the hat like squatters but none, as we shall discover, is more tenacious than the flea. The story is constructed in a powerful way. It grows like a good, long joke (three+).

In Ruby the Ballet Star: a Twirly Whirly Pop-up Book by Harriet Griffey, illustrated by Anne Holt (Tango Books £8.99), Ruby is a fat guinea pig, an unlikely ballerina and this season's star pop-up character. Watch her at the barre, her tongue out in concentration next to elegant vermin in pink ballet shoes. She is, surely, never going to make it. But she practises and practises and when the shocking pink curtains part, Ruby is transformed. The last pages of this uninhibitedly enjoyable success story feature her twirly-whirling centre stage. (two+)

Picture This by Alison Jay (Templar £9.99) is a lovely book, subtitled 'A child's first picture book'. Each page introduces an object. Each object looks as if it has been painted on old china, which lends it romance. It has an archetypal feel. 'Dog' is a slightly misshapen chap with a tiny head and cowlike body but he jumps zestfully above the heads of a skipping boy and girl. I can think of no more joyous first encounter with 'kite' than this one, a burnt orange shape above the sea making its way towards a distant lighthouse (one+).

There are many nostalgic reprints in children's publishing but Eloise (Simon and Schuster £12.99) by Kay Thompson, who made her name in the Fifties, is new to me. The book is subtitled: 'For precocious grown-ups' and is pink, black and white, as if drawn in ink and lipstick. Eloise leads a dysfunctional life. She kills time in the Plaza Hotel in New York, has her hair done, does headstands and calls on room service ('Ooooooooo I absolutely love Room Service'). I hated her - and yet could not resist her. Catch her in the elevator and see which way you go. (Girls only; eight+).

And, finally, for parents who want to scoop up some of first-rate, reprinted children's picture books in slim paperback form at £2.99 each, it is worth looking out for the delectable Kid-Sized Puffins. These include Meg's Car by Helen Nicoll & Jan Pienkowski about a witch who really ought to think about joining the AA or give up driving; Dinosaur Roar! by Paul & Henrietta Strickland, a must for dino-fanciers; Funnybones by Janet & Allan Ahlberg, an endearing and most unscary haunting by frisky skeletons and - my absolute favourite - The Elephant and the Bad Baby by Elfrida Vipont, illustrated by Raymond Briggs .

The story may not reform bad babies, but it will definitely keep them and their parents happily out of trouble for as long as the story lasts.

webTitle: Going into battle with Stan Laurel

fields.headline: Going into battle with Stan Laurel
fields.standfirst: From the horrors of Bosnia to the conflicts in Northern Ireland and Vietnam - two tales of martial lore
fields.trailText: From the horrors of Bosnia to the conflicts in Northern Ireland and Vietnam - two tales of martial lore
fields.body:
Trusted Mole: a Soldier's Journey into Bosnia's Heart of Darkness
Milos Stankovic
HarperCollins £19.99, pp476
Buy it at BOL

Going to the Wars
Max Hastings
Macmillan £30, pp400
Buy it at BOL

The otherness of war. If there is one theme that unites these two compelling books, by two wildly different characters, it is the surreal and separate world of battle. Milos Stankovic was a British soldier from old royalist Yugoslav stock who left Tito's communism. He grew up in Zimbabwe, joined the Parachute Regiment, did heroic service in Bosnia and ended up being arrested for spying for the Serbs. His arrest and long agony spent swinging in the wind was an appalling betrayal by the British Army of a good soldier dreadfully wronged. Max Hastings is a warrior manqué.

Stankovic was the victim of a double jeopardy. His Serb language made him as gold dust to the British Army. He worked as an interpreter and, more importantly, as a fixer to Generals Sir Mike Rose and then Sir Rupert Smith. Anticipating trouble, the British Army gave him a cover name and called him 'Mike Stanley'. Two other Brit-Serb soldiers were called 'Abbott' and 'Costello'. 'Stanley' came from Stan Laurel. Very droll, very British Army. But once the Bosnian Muslims had worked out his origins, Stankovic-Stanley was under a perpetual cloud of suspicion. One of their newspapers called him a 'trusted mole' of the Bosnian Serb authorities.

The charge is grotesquely untrue once you read his vivid description of the twilight zone of the Bosnian Serb leadership in Pale. The butcher of Sarajevo, General Ratko Mladic, comes across as a fascinating monster, a force of nature with bewitching eyes. Mladic tricked US three-star General Wesley Clark into swapping hats and the moment was forever caught by Serb TV. (Mladic was later to play exactly the same trick with the poor, doomed commander of the Dutch battalion in Srebrenica. After the Dutch allowed the Serbs to overrun the enclave, condemning 5,000 Muslims to their deaths, Mladic arranged a toast of champagne. As the Dutch commander raised his glass, in walked Serb TV.)

Stankovic's book is far more than the outcry of an innocent man foully accused. He has a wonderful eye for detail and a natural storyteller's gift, and passion, to get across the bizarre and terrible cruelty of what the people of Bosnia went through. At times, I laughed out loud; at times, horrible moments of my spells there came swimming back, brilliantly evoked in Stankovic's fresh prose.

Here is his description of crash first-aid to a sniper victim : 'She's gone a grey-white and is no longer moaning. There's a medic outside the vehicle with a stretcher so I give him the drip-set as he's the expert. But he mucks it up and tries to stick the canula into a vein in her hand, à la classroom. But there's no vein because it's collapsed, as veins do in the extremities when someone's in shock. Anyway, this needle goes in and produces nothing more than a bloody great bubble of saline solution under her skin. There's nothing going into her system. Then the medic faints.'

This description had me roaring my head off in a Tube train. She lived. Trusted Mole is rich in comic scenes, the best of which is the arrival of two baby incubators, one to the Serbs, one to the Muslims. The first didn't work; the second was used to grow marijuana. And then there's finding fly-fishing spots for the general in the middle of a war.

But the comedy switchbacks with the tragedy. The muddle of the UN's failed peacekeeping mission is nailed to the wall in a way - strangely, because Stankovic worked incredibly hard for General Rose to deliver a kind of peace. But the forces of hatred were stronger, and 'peacekeeping' collapsed in favour of peacemaking, which meant bombing the Serbs. This man was a hero, caught in the middle and discarded by a military bureaucracy that should be shot at dawn for its betrayal. No doubt a film is in the offing.

Hastings's book has its own surprises. As a rookie reporter in Northern Ireland in 1969, he saw the RUC act with grotesque violence, machine-gunning Catholic homes: 'Anyone who was there that August night in Belfast... understood how the revival of the IRA became possible, and why the Royal Ulster Constabulary forfeited for ever the trust of Catholic Ireland.' Perhaps Hastings's successor as editor of the Daily Telegraph should take note.

In Vietnam, we read that his own personal store of courage had run out. Having determined to stay on in Saigon, he swayed at the last moment and rushed to the American embassy to hitch a ride on one of the last choppers out. He went on to cover yet more wars - a Fleet Street hack who ended up beating the British Army to Port Stanley and liberating the Upland Goose.

The charge is grotesquely untrue once you read his vivid description of the twilight zone of the Bosnian Serb leadership in Pale. The butcher of Sarajevo, General Ratko Mladic, comes across as a fascinating monster, a force of nature with bewitching eyes. Mladic tricked US three-star General Wesley Clark into swapping hats and the moment was forever caught by Serb TV. (Mladic was later to play exactly the same trick with the poor, doomed commander of the Dutch battalion in Srebrenica. After the Dutch allowed the Serbs to overrun the enclave, condemning 5,000 Muslims to their deaths, Mladic arranged a toast of champagne. As the Dutch commander raised his glass, in walked Serb TV.) Stankovic's book is far more than the outcry of an innocent man foully accused. He has a wonderful eye for detail and a natural storyteller's gift, and passion, to get across the bizarre and terrible cruelty of what the people of Bosnia went through. At times, I laughed out loud; at times, horrible moments of my spells there came swimming back, brilliantly evoked in Stankovic's fresh prose. Here is his description of crash first-aid to a sniper victim : 'She's gone a grey-white and is no longer moaning. There's a medic outside the vehicle with a stretcher so I give him the drip-set as he's the expert. But he mucks it up and tries to stick the canula into a vein in her hand, à la classroom. But there's no vein because it's collapsed, as veins do in the extremities when someone's in shock. Anyway, this needle goes in and produces nothing more than a bloody great bubble of saline solution under her skin. There's nothing going into her system. Then the medic faints.' This description had me roaring my head off in a Tube train. She lived. Trusted Mole is rich in comic scenes, the best of which is the arrival of two baby incubators, one to the Serbs, one to the Muslims. The first didn't work; the second was used to grow marijuana. And then there's finding fly-fishing spots for the general in the middle of a war. But the comedy switchbacks with the tragedy. The muddle of the UN's failed peacekeeping mission is nailed to the wall in a way - strangely, because Stankovic worked incredibly hard for General Rose to deliver a kind of peace. But the forces of hatred were stronger, and 'peacekeeping' collapsed in favour of peacemaking, which meant bombing the Serbs. This man was a hero, caught in the middle and discarded by a military bureaucracy that should be shot at dawn for its betrayal. No doubt a film is in the offing. Hastings's book has its own surprises. As a rookie reporter in Northern Ireland in 1969, he saw the RUC act with grotesque violence, machine-gunning Catholic homes: 'Anyone who was there that August night in Belfast... understood how the revival of the IRA became possible, and why the Royal Ulster Constabulary forfeited for ever the trust of Catholic Ireland.' Perhaps Hastings's successor as editor of the Daily Telegraph should take note. In Vietnam, we read that his own personal store of courage had run out. Having determined to stay on in Saigon, he swayed at the last moment and rushed to the American embassy to hitch a ride on one of the last choppers out. He went on to cover yet more wars - a Fleet Street hack who ended up beating the British Army to Port Stanley and liberating the Upland Goose.

webTitle: Artists fight to stop property prices forcing them out

fields.headline: Artists fight to stop property prices forcing them out
fields.trailText: In a week of triumph for Scottish art, fears are growing that artists working in Edinburgh might be priced out of the city by the very cultural renaissance they have helped to generate.
fields.body:
In a week of triumph for Scottish art, fears are growing that artists working in Edinburgh might be priced out of the city by the very cultural renaissance they have helped to generate.

With Roddy Buchanan winning the lucrative Beck's Futures prize last week for his video installation 'Gobstopper', and nine Scottish artists being included the British Art Show, the art world north of the border is enjoying a rosy period.

Edinburgh galleries such as the Ingleby say shows are selling faster than ever before, as new money pours into the city. But that cash may be making it harder for artists to live and work in the city as property prices continue to rise at an alarming rate.

The threat is demonstrated by uncertainty over the long-term future of the Patriothall studios, a converted bakery used by 80 artists in Stockbridge, once thought of as Edinburgh's bohemian district. The studios all have the desirable 'New York loft' chic fashionable for trendy apartment developments, raising fears that the building's owners might be tempted to take it back and convert it into flats. With house prices rising by 20 per cent a year in the capital, each flat could sell for £150,000 or more.

The artists say the issue raises important questions about Edinburgh's development. 'It's time we had a proper debate about how we use our city,' said Alan Kilpatrick, one of the residents. 'Artists give Edinburgh the cultural life of a proper capital but that may die if property continues to rocket.'

Many is the artist who has wished Scotland was more like New York, but in this instance the effect is purely negative. 'It's the same problem that has happened in New York and London. Artists take run-down areas and make them fashionable, only to see property prices rise and force them out of the area,' said David Cook of Wasps, which runs the studios.

The building's owner, Scotmid, denies it has any plans to evict the painters and sculptors when the lease is up in 2005, but has rejected an offer from the artists to buy the building.

Wasps is a successful organisation, running 14 studio buildings across Scotland, used by 750 artists. But expansion plans may be scuppered by the property boom. 'Edinburgh needs mixed communities,' said Cook. 'A cultural heart as well as a commercial heart.'

The artists in Stockbridge say Scotmid has been a good landlord and both sides are trying to negotiate an amicable solution, but the problem is not confined to the wealthy fringes of the New Town. Housed in the old bus station behind Waverley station, the Out Of The Blue community gallery has the same problem, with development plans threatening its future

'We run social inclusion programmes; we are largely self-funded,' said spokesman Rob Hoon. 'We are culturally, economically and socially useful.'

The struggle for workspace irritates many artists. Amid concern over their lack of political clout, they will attempt next month to form as a trade union, provisionally called the Scottish Artists Association. The aim is to show that visual arts make a vital contribution to the economy and deserve greater support. Bill Spiers of the Scottish TUC and Rhona Brankin, Scotland's Arts Minister, will address a launch conference at the Royal Concert Hall in Glasgow.

There have been similar attempts in the past, but David Cook believes devolution might have provided the vital spark.

'People are listening to us and are accountable like never before. We aren't asking for handouts, only recognition of our part in the knowledge economy,' he said.

webTitle: Now the psychologists must find a way to heal a boy's mental scars

fields.headline: Now the psychologists must find a way to heal a boy's mental scars
fields.standfirst:
Elián's removal from his surrogate home will only add to his trauma, warns Susie Orbach
More about the Elian Gonzalez case
fields.trailText: The focus now must be on the traumatic effects on Elián González of being seized by hooded and armed agents, whose menacing look and actions tore him away from the security he has been able to create for himself over the last few months, especially with his surrogate mother, Marisleysis González.
fields.body:
The focus now must be on the traumatic effects on Elián González of being seized by hooded and armed agents, whose menacing look and actions tore him away from the security he has been able to create for himself over the last few months, especially with his surrogate mother, Marisleysis González.

The highly skilled psychologists and psychiatrists aiding the Attorney General, Janet Reno, will also have to think how to help Elián find a way to live with the multiple traumas that he has experienced.

They will do so by setting the more florid examples of inappropriate treatment received by Elián in the context of what his life was like before as well as since he left Cuba. I believe their main concern will be to see how Elián understands the situation.

But I doubt they will feel much confidence about the task ahead. We are talking of a boy who has had multiple traumas, each one acting almost to conceal the previous one - as though his rescue from sea was the solution to the loss of his mother, and this latest federal rescue the solution to the loss of his father.

If it is psychic overload for a five-year-old to go through the divorce of his parents, the unchosen departure from the home he has known, survival at sea for two days and the death of his mother: how will it be for Elián to manage what he has experienced since arriving in the States and becoming a political pawn for three competing ideologies?

Children who have been separated from their parents need a lot of help to engage with the reality of loss. Like adults, they feel helpless.

They develop defence mechanisms which attempt to deny what has happened; or which situate themselves as active agents, causing the child to believe that they have caused the loss and are in some way capable of bring the loved one back.

Feelings of loss and helplessness are extremely hard to countenance. But an acceptance of them is the main hope any of us has for coming to terms with the loss of someone we love.

If that helplessness cannot be faced, then in some measure the bereaved child or adult can withdraw from the real world to an inner world in which they will try to sever themselves from what has happened to them.

It is here that any psychotherapeutic clinician has grave concern for Elián. For the loss of his mother and separation from his father were immediately converted by the community who found him first into a triumphal rescue and then into a quasi-religious experience.

He was given a new mother and a new caring family - as though his father and where he came from and the death of his mother could be effaced. And in an inversion of his own loss, he has been encouraged to represent himself as a little Jesus who can bring healing and hope to Miami Cubans who see him as El Nino Milangro (Miraculous Child, symbol of Christ).

His seizure by federal agents compounds the problem for a child who one can only imagine is clinically terrified. Rescue and drama has now become the idiom in which his psychological life is being honed.

While there will shortly be a resolution of where Elián is to end up, his problems have just begun. And it is this that the psychologists and psychiatrists will be aware of.

They know that there is no easy psychological return to his father, to his life before, to the attachments in Cuba before he and his mother left.

Nor is there an easy psychological solution in letting him stay in the States. Elián's recent life has been marked by loss, by death and by exploitation - and the psychologists will be hoping to find a way to help him acknowledge the perverse ways in which his personal loss and terrors have been taken advantage of.

fields.headline: Holocaust debate
fields.trailText: In his otherwise helpful article on the Lipstadt-Irving libel trial (Focus, last week), Neal Acherson dodges one of the most troubling issues that the case raises. Acherson speaks of Lipstadt's refusal ever to act as if there were two sides to the question of whether the Holocaust happened.
fields.body:
In his otherwise helpful article on the Lipstadt-Irving libel trial (Focus, last week), Neal Acherson dodges one of the most troubling issues that the case raises. Acherson speaks of Lipstadt's refusal ever to act as if there were two sides to the question of whether the Holocaust happened. Acherson reports, without comment, that most British commentators found this repugnant. But it is Lipstadt who is right on this matter.

What is clear is that if 'the old liberal way' requires us to treat such questions as open to debate there is something wrong with that way. Serious thought about any matter - for example, about how to respond to the current catastrophe in Ethiopia - requires that some things are not regarded as open to debate. If the case of the Holocaust is thought to be different that, I fear, is a reflection of the inroads that Holocaust deniers - and, above all, writers such as Irving - have made on our collective psyche.

Professor David Cockburn
Dept of Philosophy
University of Wales
Lampeter

fields.headline: Stressful tests
fields.trailText: If the tragic suicide of a dedicated teacher can be linked to the activities of 'a failed headmaster who had been struck off the list of registered inspectors' (News, last week), action should be taken against the person or persons who appointed him to that inspection team.
fields.body:
If the tragic suicide of a dedicated teacher can be linked to the activities of 'a failed headmaster who had been struck off the list of registered inspectors' (News, last week), action should be taken against the person or persons who appointed him to that inspection team.

Under normal circumstances it takes years to get rid of an incompetent head. If this person was so incompetent that he had to go after eight months, it beggars belief that he could be appointed to a position where he was passing judgment on others.

It is right that teachers should be accountable for their work, but it has become painfully evident that the present Ofsted inspections are placing teachers, and indirectly pupils, under so much stress that they have become counter-productive and are doing more harm than good.

Eddie Ross
Colchester

fields.headline: Baby death car identified
fields.trailText: The parents of a six-month-old baby killed in a suspected road rage incident were finally able to describe the vehicle involved in the attack to police yesterday.
fields.body:
The parents of a six-month-old baby killed in a suspected road rage incident were finally able to describe the vehicle involved in the attack to police yesterday.

Four days after the car carrying Robbie Millar and his family was forced off the M8 motorway in Renfrewshire, detectives heralded a major breakthrough as they issued a detailed description of the vehicle they are hunting after interviewing his parents who are still in hospital in Paisley.

Officers now want to trace the driver of a dark blue Renault Megane Scenic people carrier with the letter 'P' contained in the registration. They believe the car, thought to be driven by a man with a female passenger, was closely involved in the incident on Tuesday evening which left Robbie dead, and his parents and two elder brothers seriously injured.

The family were travelling in their Rover 214 car to Edinburgh for a short Easter break with friends when they became involved in a seven-mile chase with the people carrier along the eastbound carriageway of the M8. Half a mile from the St James' interchange near Paisley, their car was forced off the road, plunging down an embankment and smashing into a tree.

Passers-by managed to pull Robbie, his father, Craig, and his brothers, Steven, seven, and Sean, nine, from the wreckage, before firefighters were able to cut his mother, Mary, from the wreckage. But Robbie had suffered terrible injuries and died later at Glasgow's Yorkhill children's hospital.

Yesterday's breakthrough comes after a massive police investigation. Hours of CCTV footage have been examined and more than 100 witnesses have come forward with information. One driver told police that he had been involved in a tailgate incident with a similar vehicle on the A8 near Greenock shortly before the horror crash.

Officers have also appealed for the driver of a dark 4x4 vehicle which joined the M8 just before the crash to come forward. Police believe the driver could be a key witness.

Since the accident, overhead gantries on the M8 have carried appeals for witnesses to come forward and a section of the nearside lane of the motorway was closed off yesterday as officers searched the scene for more evidence. Forensic experts hope that a fleck of paint or a fragment of broken glass recovered from the scene could help trace the people carrier.

But detectives say they are in a race against time amid fears that the driver involved will hide or destroy the vehicle. There are also fears that he may already have left the country.

Chief Supt Jim Gilmour, Strathclyde police head of traffic, who is leading the investigation, yesterday reiterated his appeals for infor mation. 'While I remain anxious to speak to anyone who was on the roadway last Tuesday, I am anxious to trace the driver or any occupants of the Renault Scenic, as I have reason to believe that this vehicle is closely linked to the investigation.'

Detectives hope that the Millar family will be able to add more detail to their description as they recover. Last night Gilmour told The Observer : 'This is a very very difficult time, it is a tragedy for the family and that is why we are are not pushing them too hard. But with any incident like this, it will revolve around in their minds and some things will stay below the surface until something happens to jog their memories.'

People with information on the incident are urged to call the incident room at Paisley police station on 0141 532 6413.

webTitle: Is our dental health in good hands?

fields.headline: Is our dental health in good hands?
fields.trailText: Anthony Browne's article about dentists (News, last week) fully supports my efforts with my four children and six grandchildren over many years to avoid dentists unless they have a problem.
fields.body:
Anthony Browne's article about dentists (News, last week) fully supports my efforts with my four children and six grandchildren over many years to avoid dentists unless they have a problem. Most of the real problems I've had with teeth have been inflicted directly or indirectly by dentists and generally it is asking for trouble to visit a dentist for a 'check-up' because usually some unnecessary treatment will be undertaken at no small expense - NHS or private - to the patient.

There are two sources of totally reliable and quite inexpensive dental treatment in my experience - the military dentists I saw during the war and school dentists, both of whom can be relied upon not to do anything that is not absolutely necessary. The moral is obvious.

Dennis Scott
Poole
Dorset

Professor Aubrey Sheiham's views are well-known within the dental profession. However, the vast majority disagree with him. It is widely recognised that the United Kingdom has the most cost-effective dental service in the western world.

The public are now advised by their dentist to go for check-ups at least once a year unless they need to go more often. Some people will choose to go more regularly. These visits are useful in reinforcing messages about good oral health.

Dentists have been heavily monitored by the Dental Practice Board since the inception of the NHS. A Harris poll for the BDA in 1999 found that nine out of 10 patients are happy with the care and treatment they receive from their dentist. If they felt that they were receiving inappropriate treatment, this figure would be a lot lower.

John Renshaw
Chair of the British Dental Association's Executive Board
London W1

I am concerned that you gave publicity to Professor Sheiham and his controversial views on fellow colleagues. The use of phrases like 'numerous dental procedures are ineffective, etc' can be seen almost word for word in a Daily Mail article as long ago as 1988.

Professor Sheiham and I crossed swords in a BBC television programme over his continuous and protracted attack on the British dentists, since coming to this country from South Africa in the 1970s.

A past President of the General Dental Council, the late Sir Rodney Swiss, said in response to one of Professor Sheiham's outbursts: 'It would be a pity if ground were to be lost by listening to advice given far from the experience of day-to-day dental practice.'

Having so little respect for his British colleagues, I wonder why he stays. Certainly, in his role as an academic he will be spared the danger of stress (UMIST research shows dentistry to be the highest stress factor of all health care professions) and suicide, where dentists come second to the veterinary profession.

L.B. Lux
Past President General Dental Practitioners Association
Altrincham
Cheshire

fields.headline: More trial jurors claim intimidation
fields.trailText: At least four separate incidents of alleged harassment and intimidation of jurors on the Tony Martin trial were reported to the trial judge,  The Observer can reveal.
fields.body:
At least four separate incidents of alleged harassment and intimidation of jurors on the Tony Martin trial were reported to the trial judge, The Observer can reveal.

All four events, including one in which a juror said she called 999 after believing she was being followed, were discussed after the public were excluded from the court.

The farmer shot two burglars who had broken into his farm in Norfolk. One, 16-year-old Fred Barras, was killed while 30-year-old Brendon Fearon was seriously injured. Before the trial, police discovered £60,000 had been put on Martin's head by supporters of Barras.

Because of this, the jurors in the trial were referred to by numbers throughout.

On the last Friday before the end of the trial, the judge, Mr Justice Owen, had told the jurors that if they were approached about the case they should dial 999. It later transpired that a juror had in fact made a call to the authorities over the weekend.

Two other incidents of alleged interference were also discussed. In one case 'aggressive eye contact' was reported between jurors and relatives and friends of Barras. It was also reported that a woman juror was warned that she would be harmed if Martin was acquitted.

The conviction of the 55-year-old bachelor could be quashed and a re-trial ordered if the claims of jury tampering are proved.

fields.headline: War's hypocrisy
fields.trailText: It seems that OAPs who fought in the war and are now living on meagre pensions are beginning to realise that they were simply cannon fodder.
fields.body:
It seems that OAPs who fought in the war and are now living on meagre pensions are beginning to realise that they were simply cannon fodder.

The establishment talks a lot of hypocritical rubbish about those who fought and gave their lives for their country in WWII. The truth is that most of those who fought and died were conscripts who had little choice about dying for their country. In 1939 millions were living lives of poverty and deprivation. They had little reason to give their lives for a country that cared little about them. They no more gave their lives than the babes burnt alive in their cots as a result of fire bombing. They were sacrificed by the establishment in the interests of its own survival. Cannon fodder.

W. Soley
Thornton-Cleveleys
Lancs

webTitle: Death waits in his every glass

fields.headline: Death waits in his every glass
fields.standfirst: Martin Bashir  spent  weeks talking to George and Alex Best for his remarkable TV interview last week. Here he warns friends and family that they hold the key to the star's survival
fields.trailText: Martin Bashir  spent  weeks talking to George and Alex Best for his remarkable TV interview last week. Here he warns friends and family that they hold the key to the star's survival.
fields.body:
I confess to having the greatest admiration and respect for George Best - the footballer. The television archive of his exploits is all one needs to see for confirmation that the man was, at a moment in history, one of the greatest players on the earth. But the name Best has a dual resonance around the world.

He is worshipped as a one-time footballing genius at the same time as he is denounced as a flaming drunk. His name still burns brightly in the firmament... but for how long?

Thirty years of non-stop alcoholism is worthy of a place in the Guinness Book of Records. Instead, he paid for a place at the exclusive, private, Cromwell Hospital in London. He has undergone five weeks of intensive care after collapsing at home with liver failure in February. Before being admitted to hospital he had barely eaten for 10 weeks and was drinking wine, with brandy 'chasers', from 8am almost daily. Even his refusal to consult a doctor collapsed under the sheer weight of his addiction.

While George received the best treatment that money can buy, a colleague and I from ITV's Tonight programme had regular meetings, and meals, with his wife Alex and his agent Phil Hughes, the two closest and most trusted people in Best's life. They have much in common. George met Phil in Blondes, a late-night bar, and he first saw Alex at Tramp nightclub.

We were seeking an interview with the European Player of the Year of 1968 on his discharge from hospital. Although we hoped that any interview might prove to be revelatory, those five weeks spent getting to know Phil and Alex provided an interesting insight into why George Best is now just a drink away from death.

If George likes a drink then the same can safely be said of his two best friends. Our regular meeting place was PJ's bar and restaurant on the fashionable Fulham Road in London. Every meeting was marked by the rapid consumption of beer and wine.

On one occasion Phil Hughes drank around eight bottles of Becks in just over 45 minutes. He had begun at 4pm. Over dinner at Scalini's, he almost drank our budget dry with beer and white wine. Alex showed a fondness for sauvignon blanc, drinking several glasses as we discussed her husband's sclerotic liver. Of course, the stress of coping with George's hospitalisation may have forced both Phil and Alex to seek solace in the same place as their loved one, but it was hardly an encouraging sign.

The day after George was discharged from hospital his tastebuds had started to function for the first time in six months. Delighted to be back at home and hungry for food, he asked Alex to pop around the corner for some fish and chips. She took longer than usual because she dropped into the pub for a drink or two before collecting her husband's favourite takeaway.

And this after hearing from Professor Roger Williams, the country's leading liver expert, that all George's friends must protect him from even the sight and smell of alcohol. Perhaps Mrs Best restrained herself from kissing George on her return from the chip shop, but there are worrying signs that his nearest and dearest may ultimately prove less than helpful in his fight.

Williams based his judgment on the medical facts that he confronted when Best was admitted to hospital. 'There is a simple statistic that says a great deal,' he explained. 'Bilirubin is the main pigment in bile. It is yellow and is produced by the breakdown of haemoglobin. The normal bilirubin level would be around 20 in a healthy adult. When George Best was admitted... his bilirubin was 620.

'That was just one statistic among a range of symptoms. This is why we have had to be so categoric on alcohol. He cannot touch another drop. If he does, he will kill himself. This is why his life needs to be radically altered.'

But how? Is it possible to change 30 years of continuous consumption? What strategies do George, Alex and Phil have in place to change the habit of a lifetime?

When I put these questions to them, the absence of any premeditated plan was staggering. Worse still was their apparent misunderstanding that wine does not constitute an alcoholic substance.

Was Alex confident that George would be able to stop drinking? 'Yes,' she said, 'I'm sure he will because he's so stubborn! Of course I've got to be careful. And I'm sure I won't be drinking in front of him. I'll obviously have a couple of glasses of wine but I'm sure he'll be okay.'

Said his agent, Phil: 'I've got my faith in George, in George's word that he won't drink. I certainly won't be drinking in front of George. The odd glass of wine or whatever.'

How will George himself avoid drinking, given that his life has revolved around clubs, pubs and restaurants? 'There's no answer to that,' he said. 'I want to take my dog for a walk and go to the park. Plus I want a family.'

That, in a nutshell, is the strategy to keep George off the booze. It does not amount to very much but many, including his ex-wife Angie, believe he won't survive.

Perhaps starting a family will give George and Alex a motive for living. They appear to cling to this as the gateway to a happy future. But if total abstinence is to be achieved, then nursery rhymes will have to be amended: 'Georgie, porgy pudding and pie, another drink and you will die.' It's as serious as that. Best's mother died of alcoholism at 54. He is 54 next month, and one more drink may mean he doesn't live beyond her age.

fields.headline: Sleight of hands in education
fields.trailText: Andrew Marr's timely and cogent article (Comment, last week) on the spurious use of audits of public sector activities by both the main political parties was more than welcome.
fields.body:
Andrew Marr's timely and cogent article (Comment, last week) on the spurious use of audits of public sector activities by both the main political parties was more than welcome. It is true that there is 'a fantastic range of dodges used to achieve the Government's targets' and not only by hospitals and schools.

Performance indicators should not be used where those measured can change the measurement not by working harder or better but by diverting time and effort to out-manoeuvring the system. This problem - known as 'moral hazard' to economists - has long been known. Forty years, during an HMI visit, ago my school French teacher told a class to raise their right hand if they knew the answer to a question and their left hand if they did not. The school inspector must have inferred that we were an enthusiastic and able class at the sight of a forest of hands.

John Oliver
London EC2

fields.headline: No cover-up on breast-feeding
fields.trailText: Unlike Pamela Armstrong (Comment, last week), I did not breast-feed my two children, finding the process primitive and abhorrent, but would agree that mothers should have the choice.
fields.body:
Unlike Pamela Armstrong (Comment, last week), I did not breast-feed my two children, finding the process primitive and abhorrent, but would agree that mothers should have the choice. However, the public should also have the choice of whether we want to watch this process. Not all mothers cover up.

Ms Armstrong is in the very privileged position of being able to do as she wishes with regard to breast-feeding. I don't think female assistants on the check-out at Tesco, female structural engineers, bus drivers or bank clerks have the choice. And I regard breast-feeding a child of four and a half bordering on the obscene. It is certainly nothing to be proud of.

Trisha Sygrove
Sheffield

Pamela Armstrong's self-righteous piece was more about proselytising for breast-feeding than about how to accommodate breast-feeding into a career - or even a job. Indeed, she writes about breast-feeding itself as if it were a career - four and a half years in her case. But what has an argument about long-term breast-feeding to do with the serious question of how Parliament or any other workplace make itself more woman-friendly? Armstrong says: 'I could shoot my milk a good five feet.' This smacks of little boys' peeing contests. Let's have proper argument, not smug exhibitionism.

Ruth Evans
Cardiff

As a social worker who successfully breast-fed both my sons till they were nearly three years old, I find it sad that Pamela Armstrong feels the need to include in her defence of breast-feeding a gratuitous attack on Social Services ('the Social will have them off you'). I would add that 'the social' refers to the Benefits Agency, not Social Services.

Ruth Crate
Liverpool

webTitle: Louvre hit by looted art row

fields.headline: Louvre hit by looted art row
fields.standfirst: New primitive collection puts Chirac under fire as experts call for return of 'stolen' items
fields.trailText: Days after it was inaugurated by President Jacques Chirac, the Louvre's remarkable new collection of primitive art has come under attack from experts who say some of the pieces are almost certainly stolen.
fields.body:
Days after it was inaugurated by President Jacques Chirac, the Louvre's remarkable new collection of primitive art has come under attack from experts who say some of the pieces are almost certainly stolen.

Comparing the 120 sculptures, masks and other items from Africa, Asia, Oceania and the Americas with the Louvre's greatest treasures, such as the Mona Lisa and Vermeer's The Lacemaker, Chirac said it would be 'unfair to keep whole civilisations' out of the world's biggest museum.

But museum experts and international organisations such as Unesco have openly questioned the ethics of the Louvre's decision to open the new £18 million extension.

'Smuggling is now so large-scale that Africa is in danger of losing its cultural heritage altogether,' said Manus Brinkman of the International Council of Museums.

The council has published a list aimed at alerting dealers and curators to the many genres of African art that are threatened by smuggling. The list is topped by the extraordinary 1,500-year-old Nok terracotta sculptures of Nigeria, two newly purchased examples of which are highlights of the Louvre's new collection.

'Works of this type have been banned from sale or export from Nigeria since 1943,' Brinkman said. 'It's a dreadful situation: the sites have been plundered to such an extent that Nigerian museums have only a very few pieces and no single complete sculpture. That means the Louvre works are by definition smuggled, and should be considered untouchable by any museum.'

Paris-based Unesco, the United Nations body charged with safeguarding the world's cultural heritage, has also written officially to the French authorities expressing its concern and demanding a full explanation.

Chirac, who has battled for years to see his passion for primitive art reflected in the Louvre, conceded some of the exhibits had been looted by European powers at 'a time of humiliation and suffering for colonised countries'.

But the President, who was forced to return a statue smuggled out of Mali that he was given as a present last year, promised to make the restitution of plundered works a priority. And he said those countries that had lost valuable pieces would now be proud that their cultures were recognised as worthy of the Louvre.

France also believes it has covered itself, in the case of the Nok statues, by signing an agreement with the Nigerian government under which - in exchange for keeping the works - it will train Nigerian curators in restoration and museum management.

But those arguments failed to impress Brinkman. He pointed out that several Nigerian curators had complained bitterly about the deal.

'Any country that wants to display the works of another culture must be absolutely sure of their origin,' he said.

Brinkman criticised the notion that it was better to have the works of ancient civilisations on display in western Europe than hidden away in native museums or in the hands of collectors.

'It's a very, very dangerous view,' he said. 'It's a licence to start buying smuggled artwork. Museums must be completely irreproachable - if they start buying dubious pieces, it will only encourage further pillaging. The message must be quite clear: never buy or accept a stolen piece. And if you find one, return it.'

webTitle: Japan's star-maker accused of sexually abusing boys

fields.headline: Japan's star-maker accused of sexually abusing boys
fields.trailText: The boss of Japan's biggest talent agency, a man who spent 37 years plucking teenagers from obscurity, is at the centre of a scandal that could bring his empire down.
fields.body:
The boss of Japan's biggest talent agency, a man who spent 37 years plucking teenagers from obscurity, is at the centre of a scandal that could bring his empire down.

Johnny Kitagawa, 68, has been accused of sexually abusing many of his young male charges, including one aged 12. Police, abandoning a traditional reluctance to pursue such cases, have announced an investigation.

Alumni of Johnny's Jimusho (Johnny's Office), are everywhere on Japanese TV. A survey showed they appeared in 80 shows and commercials in one year alone. At the peak of the boy band boom in 1995, Johnny's, by then known popularly as the 'Pretty Man Factory', registered earnings of 2.9 billion yen (£17 million). Since Kitagawa's first success with a boy band, the Four Leaves, in 1963, he has produced a steady stream of dancers, singers and actors, many now household names in Japan.

The allegations surfaced last October in Shukan Bunshun, a respected weekly magazine.

Kitagawa vehemently denied them, and launched a libel suit. His lawyer says he is the victim of rumours spread by former clients who lacked the talent to succeed.

The magazine refuses to back down. It has made further accusations in graphic weekly instalments. It claims to have spoken to 12 teenage boys who took part in the agency's residential training programme. They tell of sexual abuse, including rape, allegedly carried out by Kitagawa.

As long ago as 1988, a former member of the Four Leaves published diaries which contained claims about the mogul's predatory behaviour among young recruits. And in two books published in 1996, another former Johnny's talent, Junya Hiramoto, said he saw Kitagawa rape a boy in one of the agency's dormitories.

Newspapers, magazines and commercial TV stations, all of which depend on the agency for new stars to indulge the lucrative youth market, ignored the revelations. The authorities took action only after Yoshihide Sakaue, a Liberal Democratic MP, raised the Shukan Bunshun campaign at a parliamentary committee.

Signs are now emerging of a change in Japan's attitude towards sex crimes involving minors.

In November, following pressure from America, Germany and 12 other countries, a new law made it an offence, punishable by up to three years in prison, to pay for sex with under-18s. The sexual exploitation of children in the entertainment business is nothing new, but social attitudes in Japan discourage public discussion of such matters.

Whatever the outcome of the impending investigation, the fact that such a high-profile figure is at its centre may provoke a debate on how effectively Japan is protecting the rights of its children.

fields.headline: Our currency crisis
fields.trailText: Is the government going to do something about the over-strong pound? Or will it stand idly by, washing its hands Pilate-like, while the rest of British industry goes the way of Harland & Wolff, Rover and now, apparently, volume car production at Ford of Dagenham?
fields.body:
Is the government going to do something about the over-strong pound? Or will it stand idly by, washing its hands Pilate-like, while the rest of British industry goes the way of Harland & Wolff, Rover and now, apparently, volume car production at Ford of Dagenham?

Certainly, the strong pound is not the only reason that Ford intends to launch its next-generation Fiesta in Cologne. Dagenham has a history of productivity and labour-relations problems. The European car market has capacity to produce 20,000,000 cars a year but the demand is for only 16,000,000. Nevertheless, as with Harland & Wolff and Rover, the strong pound is the straw that has broken the camel's back. And a heavy straw it is, as even Nissan with its showpiece 'inward investment' factory in Durham, recently complained.

This time the wider economy prospers and the damage from the high pound has been less obvious. Why worry, some say, we've got boom conditions and cheap foreign holidays?

But if the industrial chaos caused by our overvalued currency is allowed to persist, in years to come there will not be a big enough manufacturing base to support a working population the size of Britain's, let alone provide the wherewithal for foreign holidays.

People ask: 'What good has devaluation ever done us? Look at the Germans' successful D-mark.' But the strong D-mark reflected Germany's high productivity and low inflation. Our productivity is still poor internationally, and the high pound disguises an underlying inflation rate that is not as low as it should be. An overvalued pound puts industry at a competitive disadvantage.

The Bank of England and the Treasury blame the 'weak' euro. If they think it is so cheap, they should buy it. Not only would they make a profit: this would send a strong signal to the financial markets that we want the pound down to a more competitive level.

fields.headline: DIY? Knock it off!
fields.trailText: Quiet weekend at home? Take care! It's a jungle in there - especially if you're using the Easter break for a little decorating or gardening. Up to 70 people are killed every year doing jobs around the house. A quarter of a million more are injured and these figures are rising every year. We fall off ladders, electrocute ourselves while mowing the lawn and drill holes in ourselves.
fields.body:
Quiet weekend at home? Take care! It's a jungle in there - especially if you're using the Easter break for a little decorating or gardening. Up to 70 people are killed every year doing jobs around the house. A quarter of a million more are injured and these figures are rising every year. We fall off ladders, electrocute ourselves while mowing the lawn and drill holes in ourselves.

Safer to watch television? Probably not. According to Kim Howells, Consumer Affairs Minister, this is where the trouble started. All those garden and house 'makeover' programmes undertaken with great hilarity and energy by psychedelically fleeced gangs of youths, have misled us into believing that it is mere child's play to turn our chintzed living rooms into a Sultan's hookah-smoking quarters overnight.

So the Minister has arranged for two million Government safety warnings to be distributed in DIY shops instructing us on the right tools to use and how best to protect ourselves from the perils of home improvement. Our advice is more cautious. Don't even start. Relax, turn off the goading television and remember Hilaire Belloc's excellent instruction to gentlefolk of means:

Lord Finchley tried to mend the Electric Light

Himself. It struck him dead: And serve him right!

It is the business of the wealthy man

To give employment to the artisan.

webTitle: Boys should be boys, not political pawns

fields.headline: Boys should be boys, not political pawns
fields.trailText: The pictures of armed officers seizing the six-year old Cuban castaway Elian Gonzalez from the house of the relatives who were sheltering him in Miami's Little Havana will rightly shock the world. Most detached observers who have watched the unfolding of America's own farcical version of  The Caucasian Chalk Circle will agree with President Clinton and the US Attorney-General Janet Reno that Elian should be reunited with his father while the courts decide whether his surviving parent can take him back to Cuba. The uniqueness of this tragic case - a child pulled from the Straits of Florida where he had spent two days clinging to an inner tube after his mother had drowned - does not alter the principles involved. He is better with a loving parent than with the relatives who have cynically used him as a pawn in their struggle with Fidel Castro.
fields.body:
The pictures of armed officers seizing the six-year old Cuban castaway Elian Gonzalez from the house of the relatives who were sheltering him in Miami's Little Havana will rightly shock the world. Most detached observers who have watched the unfolding of America's own farcical version of The Caucasian Chalk Circle will agree with President Clinton and the US Attorney-General Janet Reno that Elian should be reunited with his father while the courts decide whether his surviving parent can take him back to Cuba. The uniqueness of this tragic case - a child pulled from the Straits of Florida where he had spent two days clinging to an inner tube after his mother had drowned - does not alter the principles involved. He is better with a loving parent than with the relatives who have cynically used him as a pawn in their struggle with Fidel Castro.

But the fact that the authorities had justice on their side in wishing to unite Elian with his father does not justify the way in which the US Immigration Services and police carried out their military-style raid. The only consolation is that it did not end in tragedy. And if the pre-dawn raid ordered by President Clinton seemed inevitable, it was only because, in allowing Elian to remain so long in a potentially abusive situation, the authorities had redoubled the risk of violence.

What seems so extraordinary is that the world's most powerful democracy has handled the case of Elian so badly, allowing the welfare of an orphaned child to be trampled over by those more interested in political point-scoring over the redundant issue of US-Cuban relations. For the truth of the case of Elian Gonzalez is that it has become an unpleasant metaphor for America's relations with its Caribbean neighbour, still economically blockaded, after four decades, for having the temerity to pursue an alternative political vision. That is not to approve of the human-rights abuses of Castro's regime, but America enjoys constructive relationships with many countries with similar records.

In truth, the US policy of exclusion, including the Helms-Burton Act which seeks to fine foreign countries that trade with Cuba, is driven by the same minority which grasped the fragile figure of Elian as a weapon in its continuing war with Cuba. If there is any lesson to be learned from the spectacle of the dogfight over Elian, it is that it is long overdue for the US to accept Cuba's right to autonomy and to renegotiate its relationship with a noisy, but insignificant, minority that has for too long dominated American foreign policy on the issue.

fields.headline: Killings haunt cabbies
fields.standfirst: After the murder of seven drivers, New York's street crimes unit has been called in to stop the massacre, reports  Ed Vulliamy
fields.trailText: After the murder of seven drivers, New York's street crimes unit has been called in to stop the massacre.
fields.body:
The muscles in Juan Reyes's face tighten as he drives across 181st Street in mid-Bronx. Over his radio comes the signal 10-25, meaning: 'Take a break to eat.'

There's a 24-hour burger joint nearby but Juan, a driver for the Premium livery car company, is in no mood to stop. It was here that he dropped a passenger who pulled a gun when he couldn't change a $100 bill.

'He was pointing it right at my face,' Juan recalls. 'I said don't pay me nothing. Just go on.'

Juan is a lucky man. Already this year seven livery car drivers in Manhattan have been killed. Last week another was attacked with a machete.

In response New York's mayor Rudy Giuliani has deployed every officer serving in his controversial Street Crimes Unit to a single assignment with a single order: to stop the massacre. And this time the squad has the support of the very minorities who have con demned its readiness to open fire on unarmed suspects.

Livery cars - leather-lined Lincoln Town saloons - compete against New York's Yellow Cabs, usually at a lower price. They operate from radio dispatch offices and are not licensed. The livery drivers are not supposed to pick up on the streets but, says one, 'if you don't, you don't make money. Everybody picks up on the street.'

Last week the tight-knit Hispanic community of Washington Heights sent Luis Francesco Perez home to his native Dominican Republic in a white coffin - the sixth livery cab driver to be murdered this year. The following day Haitian Jean Robert Scutt became a seventh victim, shot dead by a passenger in Brooklyn.

Perez would have been 30 last Monday. The celebrations in Washington Heights - 'Little Santo Domingo' - were ready. He had arrived in New York 10 years ago and was married with two children. He loved baseball and played for his company, Premium Cars, in a livery-company league.

Last weekend he had made his last drop and was heading home with his dry-cleaning for the party hanging in the back of his car. He was hailed at the corner of Aldous Street and Whitlock Avenue in the mean part of the Bronx, but when he did not stop shots were fired. His car mounted the kerb and crashed into a fire hydrant.

At 2.30am, two hours after the murder, the dispatcher at Premium cars, Carlos Molina, picked up the phone. It was someone asking for the driver of Car 149. Molina told the caller he was dead. 'OK,' said the caller, and hung up.

The motorcade that left the Ortiz funeral home on Monday afternoon had no precedent. Chauffeurs behind the wheels of more than 3,000 livery cars followed the hearse. It paused beside the fire hydrant, now decked with flowers.

The following evening Scutt picked up a man who had gone to the headquarters of the Commodore car company in Brooklyn. Scutt had joined Commodore only two weeks before.

After 20 blocks his passenger opened fire. His Lincoln freewheeled for two more blocks before ploughing into a gated store-front. Scutt had been shot in the throat.

The Scutt family live along Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn that has become 'Little Haiti', and they had arrived in dribs and drabs from their dark island in the sun to escape from persecution and support their families back home.

It is a community that has had its share of recent tribulation: from its number came Abner Louima, sodomised and tortured in police custody, and Patrick Dorismond, shot dead by police last month. There had been riots at Dorismond's funeral; Little Haiti needed a break.

In his little home on Friday, Scutt's brother Alterne Albury wrung his hands and remembered he had been 'afraid every day Jean went out to work, but he looking for some bread for his family and children'.

On the night of Scott's death, Alterne and his wife told him not to go out because of the danger. He replied: 'What else am I supposed to do?'

The drivers have found a powerful leader in Fernando Mateo, a self-made Hispanic millionaire who once lead his community in a successful 'Toys for Guns' exchange scheme which swept 3,000 weapons off the city's streets. He is head of the Federation of Livery and Taxi Drivers.

Last week he took a party of drivers and relatives of victims to City Hall. The spate of attacks has signalled a return to the city's bad old days, before Giuliani. Between 1990 and 1994, 139 drivers were killed or stabbed, but only eight were attacked last year.

Mateo believes the surge in violence comes from a new sense of power by criminals emboldened by the police 'getting hesitant' after the killing of West African immigrant Amadou Diallo last February. He wants the police to seize the initiative once more.

Giuliani has assigned public funds to help livery cars fit bullet-proof safety partitions and video cameras. But most of all, Mateo and the grieving relatives want the police to take the offensive on the streets once more. Driver Raymond Henriquez said: 'Cops used to stop us all the time to check for suspicious passengers. I wish they'd start again.'

webTitle: Gang wars fuel Lisbon club terror

fields.headline: Gang wars fuel Lisbon club terror
fields.standfirst: A night out in Portugal can feature guns, gas and grenades. And last week seven clubbers paid with their lives, reports Eduardo Gonçalves
fields.trailText: Tucked away on one of the countless cobbled backstreets of Lisbon is the Luanda club. Its glass front and awning give it the appearance of a grocer's shop. But last week pools of blood, shards of glass and shreds of clothing were clues that it has become the latest battleground in the vicious turf war of Portugal's night scene.
fields.body:
Tucked away on one of the countless cobbled backstreets of Lisbon is the Luanda club. Its glass front and awning give it the appearance of a grocer's shop. But last week pools of blood, shards of glass and shreds of clothing were clues that it has become the latest battleground in the vicious turf war of Portugal's night scene.

An attack on the club which claimed seven young lives has been blamed on rivalries fanned by ethnic tensions. It may even have been in revenge for an outrage three years ago to the day, when 13 people were burnt alive in a northern bar.

Last Sunday's attack killed four men and three women aged between 16 and 36 and injured up to 65. It was carried out with deadly precision. At 4.30am more than 1,000 people, mainly immigrants from Portugal's former colonies, were in the city's most popular African club when canisters of tear gas were set off on the dance floor.

Smuggled in from France, they were sophisticated devices with trigger mechanisms. They were placed next to the DJ's booth and near the toilets, ensuring maximum pandemonium.

At the same time the attackers cut off power supplies, which shut down the ventilation system and plunged the club into darkness. As those inside scrabbled desperately in the dark to find their way out, some tripped over the railings, with disastrous consequences.

'I was in the middle when it happened,' said Carmo Paiva, a student. 'People were choking and there was panic. Everyone went for the same door, the main exit, but it was blocked by people. I could see women on the ground being trampled on. Some were already unconscious.'

Those who died were asphyxiated and crushed.

The suspicion among Africans living in Portugal that this was a revenge attack became quickly apparent. Relatives of the dead refused to be identified in interviews on Portuguese television for fear of 'reprisals'.

'Whoever did this wanted to scare people away from Luanda, which was the in place for a lot of Africans,' said Nadia Cruz, 19, who survived the attack.

Others say the violence stems from traditional rivalries between Angolans and youths from another former African colony, Cape Verde. The Luanda - named after the Angolan capital - was popular mainly with the old colony's former residents, including five of those who died. Police sources say three suspects in the case are all Cape Verdeans.

'When I came out of the toilet and saw everyone run to one end, I thought it was another shoot-out between the two groups,' said Cruz. 'This has happened before.'

A doorman at the Luanda said violence between the two groups was common, and this was confirmed by people living nearby. 'My window overlooks the club and I often hear them arguing and there is always lots of shouting,' said Elisa Fernandes.

Another resident, who asked not to be identified, said the gangs often carried firearms. 'Every now and again shots are fired.'

One café owner claimed there had been a fight outside the club shortly before the gas attack. He said police were late on the scene because they no longer patrolled the area, fearing race-motivated confrontations with black youths.

Among the dead was Walter Bastos, 22, nephew of musician Waldemar Bastos, voted last year's 'World Music' artist of the year. Three years ago the musician lost his son in an incident at another Lisbon club.

The government is now considering stationing police officers outside every night club in the country in the wake of a series of dramatic dance-floor incidents in recent years, including the detonation of a hand grenade, the shooting of a man in the head, and running gun battles, fuelled by the increasing number of illegal handguns smuggled into the country.

The worst outrage was the burning alive of 13 people in a northern night club by the owner of a rival bar. It was three years ago to the day last Sunday that a hooded gang of heavily armed men carrying petrol cans entered the Mea Culpa in Amarante. They forced everyone inside on to the dance floor and set the bar alight. Two people who tried to escape were shot dead.

The owner of another nightspot was later found guilty of ordering the brutal attack and sentenced to 25 years in jail.

There are few signs that the tragic events at the Luanda will curtail the violence. Another two gas attacks - fortunately with no casualties - were made on popular Lisbon nightclubs last week.

webTitle: Manhattan's top dogs go barking mad

fields.headline: Manhattan's top dogs go barking mad
fields.trailText: Fur is flying in a snarling scrap over territory in one of Manhattan's most exclusive neighbourhoods. Divided denizens of Battery Park City, a leafy riverside haven of white affluence worlds away from the hustle of nearby Wall Street, agree only on one thing: their pristine pavements have gone to the dogs.
fields.body:
Fur is flying in a snarling scrap over territory in one of Manhattan's most exclusive neighbourhoods. Divided denizens of Battery Park City, a leafy riverside haven of white affluence worlds away from the hustle of nearby Wall Street, agree only on one thing: their pristine pavements have gone to the dogs.

More than a thousand pampered pooches now populate the small area opposite the Statue of Liberty along the Hudson, all leading politely leashed, well-groomed, scooped and neutered lives - banned from parks but sleeping on Gucci dog beds in luxury condos and being walked by $60-an-hour dog-walkers.

Dogs are big business in Battery Park City, supporting 10 full-time dog walkers, two doggie daycare centres, a vet, several pet stores and even a 'pet spa'.

But the inevitable 'dog business' has proved too much for one litigious resident who has caused a furore over where dogs can walk, pee, poop or play.

Gabe Sumner, described by neighbours as barking and abusive, often accosts and harangues dog-owners, his video camera catching any hapless pooch relieving itself on the street. 'Get a life!' they barked. Instead, Sumner did what comes naturally to many rich, bored New Yorkers: he took legal action, trying to keep dog urination areas at least 18 inches into the street.

His case, rejected in February since local laws cannot supersede New York City laws, leaked the 'urine' war on to the pages of the local TriBeCa Tribune and Battery Park City Broadsheet, where it raged on.

Some wags at the dog club said the BPC Authority had a secret deal with Sumner to ban dogs from the Esplanade, a tree-lined path along the Hudson which teems with tourists, cyclists, joggers and roller-bladers.

'A park officer stopped me and said all dogs are going to be banned from the Esplanade effective 1 May. There had been no consultation, no announcement, nothing. I told people, they told people, and I guess everybody just got fed up.'

A meeting last month attracted hundreds of wealthy dog-lovers; in a week a website was set up, letters were hitting the desks of Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, Parks Commissioner Henry Stern, US Congressmen and politicians. The newly-formed Battery Park City Dog Association packed a Manhattan Community Board meeting and their howls of protest forced a retreat.

Now Persephone, Psyche and pals are free to prance - and pee - along the Esplanade, Sumner's video camera be damned.

At Tuesday night's BPC community board meeting, members sidestepped the nasty dog business with more pressing debate: what tiles should be used in the city's new movie theatre? Texas pink granite, as it happens.

fields.headline: Butcher's revenge against Franco
fields.trailText: A Spanish butcher who lost his livelihood 31 years ago, when Franco suddenly closed the border with Gibraltar, has administered the latest judicial slap to Madrid over an issue no democratic government has resolved: how to compensate Spaniards who lost everything on 6 June 1969.
fields.body:
A Spanish butcher who lost his livelihood 31 years ago, when Franco suddenly closed the border with Gibraltar, has administered the latest judicial slap to Madrid over an issue no democratic government has resolved: how to compensate Spaniards who lost everything on 6 June 1969.

Luis Gil Gómez, with 34 compatriots, launched a claim for compensation when it was clear easy access to the Peak was gone for good, and with it the small businesses the men had built up. Last week the Supreme Court ruled, as it has in seven other cases, that Gil is entitled to government money for the loss of his butcher's shop, valued at 780,892 pesetas in 1970 but now worth around 11 million pesetas (£42,000).

Gil's lawyer, Alvaro Marín, spoke for him. The first person to win such compensation was Marín's father, Antonio, owner of a shop that sold radios and watches - a precursor of the shops that line the main streets today, thanks to lower duty in Gibraltar.

'In 24 hours my father lost his business and his life's work,' Marín says. By June 1969, tensions had risen between Britain and the Franco government over sovereignty of the Rock. Some 5,000 Spanish workers and shop owners held government passes allowing them to work on the Peak. They had to exchange their earnings (in pounds) at a rate the authorities determined. 'There was so much poverty in Spain, it was a privilege to work in Gibraltar,' Marín says.

His father grew up in La Línea de la Concepción, the Spanish town next to Gibraltar, and went to school across the border. In 1955, he opened his shop. 'And after many years of work, the family were told you have to get out,' recalls Marín, who was then eight. The Gibraltarians lost a labour force, but soon Moroccan workers moved in to fill the gap.

Few Spaniards stayed on the Gibraltar side. 'Anyone who stayed would never be able to return to La Línea for fear of imprisonment as a traitor,' explains Marín.

Marín's father tried to lodge a claim at the time. 'But with the arrival of democracy, the claims were re-initiated,' his son says. In February 1996, they reached the Council of Ministers - and were dismissed. Claimants then appealed to the Supreme Court, which ruled in favour of Marín's father in December 1997 - but too late for Antonio, who died that year.

There are 15 to 20 cases pending and Marín hopes the newly elected government will do the right thing, especially as it has just signed a deal to lessen tensions over Gibraltar.
