webTitle: Unions urge fight to save jobs at Ford

fields.headline: Unions urge fight to save jobs at Ford
fields.standfirst: Thinly veiled threats of strike action as company refuses to deny plans to axe 3,000 workers at Dagenham plant
fields.trailText: Britain's two biggest unions reacted with fury yesterday when Ford refused to deny reports that it would axe production at Dagenham East, with the potential loss of more than 3,000 jobs.
fields.body:
Britain's two biggest unions reacted with fury yesterday when Ford refused to deny reports that it would axe production at Dagenham East, with the potential loss of more than 3,000 jobs.

The latest threat to manufacturing provoked angry union bosses to call on the Government to 'fight to the death' to save jobs.

The threat of closure at Dagenham comes in spite of reduced losses for the company in Britain and record profits worldwide.

Unions accuse the Government and its wait-and-see policy on the single currency of failing to recognise sterling's impact on manufacturing.

The GMB said the reported closure would be a 'catastrophe' and called on the Government to take direct action. Union colleagues at the TGWU made thinly-veiled threats of industrial action which would damage Ford's European business.

There were fresh warnings that Labour's battle to retain heartlands support could fail as the 'perception that they don't care becomes a reality'.

John Edmonds, general-secretary of the GMB, said: 'We keep hearing about all this activity going on behind the scenes but the Department of Trade and Industry's German equivalent is explicitly protecting jobs. The DTI here appears to see its role as ensuring that regulations ensuring a free market are upheld.'

The DTI initially refused to comment on 'speculation' which was a 'matter for the company' but later changed tactics. 'Obviously officials are in contact with all the big players in the motor industry and people are aware that there are difficulties at Ford,' said a spokeswoman.

'Ford has made it clear to the Government that its present review is looking at the problems of overproduction and excess capacity across its operations throughout Europe. This review is not centred on issues which solely affect the UK. We expect an announcement from Ford within the next few weeks.'

Ford refused to deny reports that it will end car production at Dagenham after output of the current Ford Fiesta model finishes in November 2001.

'There will be an official announcement about Ford's restructuring plans in early May,' a spokesman said.

The TGWU said it would not tolerate the loss of 3,000 more jobs at Dagenham. The company has already announced 1,350 car assembly workers will be laid off.

'There is no smoke without fire,' said TGWU chief auto motive negotiator Tony Woodley. 'We met the chairman of Ford in Europe, Nick Scheele, last Wednesday. We were given no assurances but the company has an agreement with us and if they renege on it we will not put up with that.'

Edmonds called for an immediate cut in interest rates and a 'statement of intent' from Prime Minister Tony Blair to enter the single currency as soon as possible after the next general election in order to bring the pound into step with Europe. 'When we met Tony Blair and Stephen Byers about Rover I expressed my concern that it wasn't an isolated case,' Edmonds added.

The union believes Blair's approach to the single currency and the strength of the pound is putting off potential rescuers such as Volkswagen, reportedly interested in parts of Ford's UK operations.

The pound makes British products 20 per cent more expensive than European-made goods - but industry's pleas for a cut in interest rates have so far failed. The Bank of England's monetary policy committee is expected to put rates up after its next meeting in order to keep inflation low.

In Dagenham, the news caused concern. 'We knew there might be more lay-offs, and people round here are worried,' said Kay Boparai. 'My father-in-law is 47 and he is worried that he will not get his full pension benefits if he is laid off. The cost of living round here is high, so houses are expensive and people have big mortgages. If thousands more Ford jobs go there isn't any potential for other jobs. Dagenham would become a ghost town.'

London mayoral candidate Ken Livingstone backed demands for government action. He said: 'This is vital for the future of manufacturing in London. Thousands of jobs are at stake in the plant and tens of thousands in related industries in one of the poorest areas of London. Dagenham was Ford's most productive plant last year.'

webTitle: Rippon kicked her heels, now Ford lets it rip

fields.headline: Rippon kicked her heels, now Ford lets it rip
fields.trailText: Is this the new Angela Rippon moment? Twenty-five years after the BBC's first female newsreader broke down the barriers between news and showbusiness by high-kicking her way on to the  Morecambe and Wise Show, her former rival, Anna Ford, has recorded her first song.
fields.body:
Is this the new Angela Rippon moment? Twenty-five years after the BBC's first female newsreader broke down the barriers between news and showbusiness by high-kicking her way on to the Morecambe and Wise Show, her former rival, Anna Ford, has recorded her first song.

Ford, 57, who turned down requests from Eric'n'Ernie to follow Rippon out from behind the newsdesk, has recorded 'Here, There and Everywhere ' by Paul McCartney. She will perform it on television for the first time this week.

Ford recorded the track in London's Abbey Road studios, where the Beatles made their albums, as part of a BBC tribute to the band who released their first song 40 years ago this year. She agreed to sing it in front of a BBC1 studio audience because she had 'always wanted' to follow Rippon's career-changing performance.

'Morecambe and Wise asked me to appear on their show after Angela. I didn't because Angela had done her wonderful dance and I thought if I did it immediately afterwards it would seem derivative. But I regret not doing it. This time it feels right.'

She chose 'Here, There And Everywhere' after Chris Wright, the head of Chrysalis Records and an old friend, told her it was McCartney's favourite song.

It is not the first time the BBC's most popular newscaster has taken to the stage. When she was a student at Manchester University she toured pubs and clubs..

'There has always been a bit of the entertainer in me. I even had a job at a working men's club, singing alternate numbers with a stripper.'

She regrets giving up her singing career for journalism. 'I would have loved to have been a singer and more of an entertainer than a newscaster. Both my parents were actors in the West End of London, so it's in the blood.'

Rippon's surprise appearance on Morecambe and Wise's 1977 Christmas special has become one of the most celebrated moments in British broadcasting. Rippon shocked her starchy newsroom colleagues when she leapt from behind her desk during a sketch and started to dance in a thigh-splitting dress. She went on to present Come Dancing and chair the English National Ballet.

Although Ford is anxious to follow Rippon's success, she will not be copying her formula. 'I will not be doing the splits or showing my knickers.'

If it goes well, will she swap the autocue for the mike? 'I loved doing the song so much it makes me want to sing again - nightclub singing. But it would be quite hard to make the jump. I'd have to change my name, dye my hair and go to America.'

webTitle: Go abroad to buy your holidays

fields.headline: Go abroad to buy your holidays
fields.standfirst: Dublin must be first stop for British tourists keen to knock hundreds of pounds off the cost of their travel package
fields.trailText: British tourists can save half the cost of their package holiday if they buy it directly from an Irish travel agent. Last-minute offers available in April and May to popular destinations are cheap enough for a family of four to save more than £1,000 by travelling to Florida via Dublin on a two-week break.
fields.body:
British tourists can save half the cost of their package holiday if they buy it directly from an Irish travel agent. Last-minute offers available in April and May to popular destinations are cheap enough for a family of four to save more than £1,000 by travelling to Florida via Dublin on a two-week break.

The savings are even more astonishing because some of the holidays are offered by subsidiaries of the same British company, Thomson.

In one case, a fortnight at a three-star hotel in Orlando, Florida, with Dublin-based Budget Travel costs £786.61 for a family of four. The same family buying this holiday from Budget's parent company, Thomson, would pay £2,138 from Gatwick. Adding four air fares from Gatwick to Dublin with Ryanair, at a cost of £265.61, would still leave a saving of £1,085.79.

'The whole industry has blossomed in the past three or four years,' said Niamh Hayes, marketing director of Budget Travel. 'We have had a real increase of people trav elling from the North to travel from Dublin. It used to be that Irish families went on holiday via the UK because it was cheaper and there was more choice.'

Irish travellers make further savings because they no longer pay airport taxes since the government abolished them a year ago.

As more than 1.5 million tourists left Britain this weekend on last-minute breaks, there was evidence that holidaymakers were also paying more than they would in Germany and France for almost identical breaks and flights. Tourists with access to the Internet or ready to make a phone call to Ireland or Germany can save hundreds of pounds.

A package holiday in Kenya flying from Gatwick is advertised on the Internet by Thomas Cook's German subsidiary, TUI, for 46 per cent less than a trip sold on the bargain-basement website, lastminute.com, to the same four-star hotel. A holiday to the Dominican Republic, flying from Frankfurt, would be cheaper than a similar holiday from the UK, even after including the return airfare from Stansted to Frankfurt.

The pound's strength partly explains the price differences, but Ireland's booming economy has fuelled rapid growth in its own travel industry.

The Association of British Travel Agents admitted prices were higher in British brochures than at German travel agents, but was surprised by the savings avail able in Ireland. Yet Abta's head of corporate affairs, Keith Betton, defended the tour operators: 'There is no discounting in Germany. If you take a brochure from Britain, the prices are never what you pay. The operators don't want to do it, but customers say, "I don't want one at that price; I want one cheaper".'

Some companies make it virtually impossible for British residents to get the best bargains. British Airways will sell a French resident a ticket to Delhi from Paris via London for £454.28, including taxes. A British resident boarding the same flight at Heathrow pays £534.60. The Paris-based travel agent said she would sell the ticket to a British citizen, but it had to be bought in France.

Such ploys have infuriated the Consumers' Association. 'It comes down to how much they can get people to pay,' said Roger Lakin, assistant editor of Holiday Which?

Which? researchers are currently investigating Continental brochures that advertise identical holidays at lower prices than British consumers are charged.

Lakin rejected the industry's justifications: 'They say you have to factor in discounting, which is offensive, because that assumes people are being completely misled about the genuine price of a holiday. Can the brochure price be a genuine price if an agent can offer a discount of more than 30 per cent and still make money?'

He said that only a court case would test terms and conditions that prevent passengers from getting the best price.

UK Price: £2,138

German Price: (through Thomas Cook): £395.25 per person
UK Price (through Lastminute.com): £730 pp

MAJORCA - 67 per cent off

Two weeks for two adults staying in two or three-star accommodation in early May.
Irish Price: (through Thomson): £188.19 pp
UK Price: (through Thomson): £572 pp

webTitle: Boys' fatal fun caused rail crash killed a train driver

fields.headline: Boys' fatal fun caused rail crash killed a train driver
fields.standfirst: A Belgian train driver died after three children put a concrete slab on a track.  Andrew Osborn  in Tamines  reports
fields.trailText: A Belgian train driver died after three children put a concrete slab on a track.
fields.body:
The scene is bleak. The coal mines closed long ago and only the enormous slag heaps remain, along with the derelict warehouses.

Bored adolescents loiter on corners as pop music blares from public speakers lining the main street.

Household rubbish is dumped under almost every bush. Railway signal boxes are caked in graffiti. But now twisted debris lines the tracks as this dying industrial town grieves over a tragedy with disturbing echoes of the James Bulger case.

Three children - one just eight years old - derailed a train, killing the driver and injuring about 20 passengers. It shocked Belgium and set off a national debate about how 'innocent' children really are.

On Tuesday morning, two brothers, aged eight and nine, 'went out to play' with a friend, aged 13, from a nearby town in southern Belgium. The trio made for the railway line and placed rocks on the track 'for fun'. They watched, all morning, as passing trains pulverised the rocks, but soon became bored with their new 'game'.

So they dragged a large concrete slab on to the rails and jammed a switching device further along the track with shards of concrete. They then sat back at a safe distance and watched.

A train travelling at 60 miles per hour from Charleroi, a large industrial town nearby, hit the slab and came off the rails as it passed over the switching device.

A second train, travelling in the opposite direction, collided head-on with the Charleroi train moments later. The driver of the second train did not have a chance. Antonio Mastronardi, who had just celebrated 23 years of marriage, died later that afternoon.

The 13-year-old has been remanded in a young offenders' institution, while judges continue to deliberate over the future of the two brothers. No names have been disclosed.

Feelings are running high and one national newspaper put an image of the dead train driver on its front page next to a caption reading 'Killed by three children'.

A picture of the children's background is, nevertheless, beginning to emerge. But what is unsettling locals and psychologists alike is that the two younger boys seem to be relatively ordinary kids who have kept out of trouble and caused few ripples in the small towns where they live. They went to school, were not known as 'delinquents' and did not, it is claimed, come from broken homes or tough backgrounds.

The reputation of the older boy is apparently more colourful. A resident of one of the dreary blocks of flats which crowd Tamines, the town nearest to the crash site, said he is known in the area as an enfant terrible .

His family life seems to have been troubled. 'His parents have many problems,' says a neighbour who is keen to remain anonymous. 'They're both unemployed and on the dole. The mother is obviously disturbed and the father is an alcoholic. They drink their welfare cheque at the local café every month. We've seen the father drunk and collapsed in a hedge on more than one occasion.'

The boys' identities are unsurprisingly, a source of keen speculation and this has stirred up some unpleasant racial sentiment.

The three boys are, depending on whom you listen to, either '100 per cent pure Belgian and white' or 'troublesome immigrants from North Africa'.

An old man cycling under the bridge where the crash took place is adamant: 'They are African or Asian, but definitely not European. The Arabs are always throwing stones at the trains.'

The man, who says he set tled in Belgium himself in the Forties and is of Ukrainian extraction, said the area has become a haven for juvenile crime.

Another man surveying the crash site from afar with an undisguised look of disgust begs to differ: 'Everyone is shocked, but they were not even Moroccans or Turks, just ordinary Belgians. What's worrying is that they come from completely ordinary backgrounds.'

A supermarket worker, Mantellina Domenico, who has brought his family out to the crash site for curiosity's sake, blames Belgium's railway operator, SNCB.

'Look,' he says, 'you can just wander all over the track even now. There should be more security and it shouldn't be so easy for kids to gain access.' The boys cannot, he says, be held responsible.

'At that age they don't understand that their actions could result in the death of a man. I feel terribly sorry for the parents. This will stay in their heads forever.'

A sandwich shop worker agrees: 'It was just a game which went wrong. Just kids, that's all. At least I hope so.' Hundreds of column inches have been filled with attempts, often by child psychologists, to understand what drove the boys to play such a dangerous game.

'The objective was not so much to cause damage, but to experience violent emotions to feel alive,' suggested Dr Nicholas Zdanowicz in the daily Le Soir . Another psychologist, Jean-Yves Hayez, considered the boys' behaviour to have been the result of what he called 'Rambo syndrome'. This, he said, is when 'a small group of pre-adolescents play at being the most powerful man in the world for two minutes'.

Others claimed the boys may have been influenced by violence on TV and in the cinema. 'For them, causing a derailment is like recreating a scene from a video game. That is to say, violent but without any concrete consequences,' one commentator suggests.

Domenico, standing near the crash site, has another theory. 'Look around. There's nothing. The government has not invested in this area.'

webTitle: Phone chaos for one in three

fields.headline: Phone chaos for one in three
fields.trailText: The national telephone network was thrown into chaos this weekend as one in three callers failed to use the right new number, publicists behind the £20 million The Big Number campaign admitted.
fields.body:
The national telephone network was thrown into chaos this weekend as one in three callers failed to use the right new number, publicists behind the £20 million The Big Number campaign admitted.

The campaign cannot be blamed for the confusion, however, according to an expert in the human ability to cope with number combinations.

'Our brains are not designed to remember big sequences of numbers,' said Professor Mike Hall from the University of Exeter. 'We have only had to deal with big sequences for the last 5,000 years and our brains have not had time to evolve yet.'

The 11-digit sequences are so unwieldy that telephones should be redesigned to include electronic address books, he added.

Early analysis showed that callers using the new London numbers - representing 80 per cent of the total changeover - had either forgotten about the new system or were misdialling new codes.

'We are keeping a watching brief,' said a campaign manager, Sarah Turnbull. 'Those figures are in line with our expectations for the peak period on a Saturday and we are predicting those figures will decline.'

By breakfast, 10,000 people had called the helpline to find out their new number, The Big Number said. Telephone companies admit most customers do not know their own new numbers, let alone code changes elsewhere. Five cities and Northern Ireland are directly affected.

Critics of the numbers overhaul - the seventh national change since telephones were introduced in 1879 and the third revamp for London in a decade - included the Federation of Small Businesses which estimates the overhaul will cost industry about £2 billion to introduce.

People in London, Portsmouth, Southampton, Coventry, Cardiff and Northern Ireland lost their old numbers yesterday. People dialling wrongly hear a recording reminding them of the right number. There is no charge for those calls.

Demand for new lines is not the sole reason for today's number change - the huge increase in Internet connections is also a factor. The explosion in mobile communications has prompted the change in more than 24 million mobile phone, pager and premium rate numbers.

France has undergone alterations to its system as well as Germany, which is already facing 13, 14 or 15 digit dialling. America's system has also been changed as major cities reach 'number capacity'.

webTitle: Indians lead protests as Brazil parties

fields.headline: Indians lead protests as Brazil parties
fields.trailText: Brazil yesterday celebrated the first landing by Portuguese colonisers 500 years ago, amid growing protests by thousands of Indians and landless farm workers.
fields.body:
Brazil yesterday celebrated the first landing by Portuguese colonisers 500 years ago, amid growing protests by thousands of Indians and landless farm workers.

Thousands of police were assigned to the beach resort of Porto Seguro, about 500 miles north-east of Rio de Janeiro, where 13 vessels from the Portuguese fleet arrived on 22 April, 1500.

Indians have denounced the celebrations and the authorities have scaled them down.

President Fernando Henrique Cardoso, who was meeting his Portuguese counterpart, President Jorge Sampaio, later in the day, warned that 'the celebrations are not an invitation to a burial'.

He was referring to fears that protests could bring confrontations with police. Indian leaders were planning a march. They could be joined by some 2,000 members of the Landless Rural Workers Movement. About 2,000 peasant families have been occupying a makeshift camp on a roadside 40 miles to the west.

Indian leader Hugo Xavante said: 'What the government says is a lie. Brazil wasn't discovered; our land was invaded.'

Xavante is among more than 3,000 Indians from 186 Brazilian tribes or 'nations' who have been conferring at Coroa Vermelho, about 10 miles from Porto Seguro, and organising a counter-demonstration.

They have drafted a list of grievances. About 330,000 members of indigenous groups survive, down from as many as five million in 1500. Many died after the invasions from European diseases and others were killed in massacres.

They had hoped to present Cardoso with a document demanding speedy settlement of their land claims and better health care and education. Indians claim rights to 739 reservations, but the government has recognised only 231. In many areas white settlers and prospectors live in constant conflict with native residents, and in recent weeks landless campaigners have invaded 500 farms.

The Landless Rural Workers Movement is demanding Cardoso speed up agrarian reform in Brazil, where the richest 20 per cent of the people own 90 per cent of the land. The movement was incensed last week by the government's refusal to meet a delegation.

The Indians' document also calls for greater respect for traditional Indian medicine and better protection of intellectual property rights, threatened by the incursion of foreign drug companies seeking patents on traditional cures.

More optimistic observers said the unprecedented gathering of diverse tribes was a sign that Indians at last may be forging a united front to press for their demands. 'You have to realise there's a warrior history, a lot of these tribes have a historic distrust of each other,' said Saulo Feitosa, vice-president of the Catholic Church-linked Indigenous Missionary Council, which helped organise the conference.

Indian sympathisers are also worried about a Bill pending in Congress that would strip Indians of their traditional status as wards of the state and could open up their reservations to mining operations.

Police have deployed 5,147 security agents and said they would block the passage of anyone trying to upset the planned events.

'There is a limit to freedom of expression, and no one is free to offend the President,' said the Bahía state police chief, Colonel Cristovam Pinheiro.

fields.headline: World in brief
fields.trailText: Gunmen kill six in Johannesburg bar
fields.body:
Gunmen kill six in Johannesburg bar

Unidentified gunmen burst into a township bar in the Eastrand area of Johannesburg and shot dead six people. Police said the motives appeared to be criminal rather than political.

Algerian bomb attack

Algerian Agriculture Minister Said Barakat survived an assassination attempt when a bomb, planted by Muslim rebels, exploded in Magtaa Lazrag village, south of Algiers.

Missile goes AWOL

A Russian missile fired from a testing site went out of control and exploded near a village inside Kazakhstan. Nobody was injured and no damage was reported.

IMF protesters freed

The final 156 protesters arrested during World Bank and International Monetary Fund meetings in Washington last week were released after charges against them were reduced.

Families spur Korean talks

North Korea has agreed to focus on reunions of families, separated when war broke out a half-century ago, at the historic inter-Korean summit in June.

Arab boycott of 'terror' film

Yemen has called on fellow Arab nations to boycott the Hollywood film Rules of Engagement which it claims depicts Yemenis as 'killers and terrorists'.The film, starring Tommy Lee Jones and Samuel Jackson, shows Yemenis clashing with US Marines.

Jet mishap

The landing gear of a Qantas jet collapsed as it was preparing to take off from Rome for Melbourne. All 303 passengers disembarked safely.

Forty killed in Chinese mining disaster

A gas explosion at a coal pit in north China killed 40 miners. China has a disastrous safety record in mining, with thousands dying every year.

Rebels under fire in Philippines

The Philippines' military launched an assault on Abu Sayyaf muslim rebels who claimed to have beheaded two of 29 hostages they abducted from schools a month ago in the remote Basilan province. About 500 soldiers were fighting an estimated 250 rebels in the assault.

Burger chain condemns bombs

McDonald's ran full-page advertisements in French newspapers demanding an end to attacks on its restaurants after a bomb planted by Breton nationalists killed Laurence Turbec, 17, at a branch near Dinan. She was buried yesterday.

Pavarotti faces tax charges

Bologna prosecutors have asked for opera superstar Luciano Pavarotti to be sent for trial on £5m tax fraud charges. They claim he failed to declare his house in Monte Carlo for many years. A magistrate will decide whether he should face trial.

No loitering

Teenage Saudi boys face public flogging and prison sentences for loitering outside girls' schools in Dubai. The move follows complaints by pupils and parents.

webTitle: How I paid £350 bribe to be smuggled into Britain

fields.headline: How I paid £350 bribe to be smuggled into Britain
fields.standfirst: He had no passport or papers. But it did not take Observer reporter Burhan Wazir very long to find a driver in Calais prepared - for a fee - to hide him, two Pakistanis and an Iranian in his truck. In a few hours, they were safe in England
fields.trailText: He had no passport or papers. But it did not take Observer reporter Burhan Wazir very long to find a driver in Calais prepared - for a fee - to hide him, two Pakistanis and an Iranian in his truck.
fields.body:
A strong, chilly wind is whipping through the arterial motorway that feeds traffic into and out of the Calais ferry terminal on Tuesday morning.

Outside the main terminal building, a lone figure shuffles past the pavement that nudges against the dual carriageway.

Muhammad, an Iranian refugee, sports a thin, ugly scar that stretches down past his mouth from his eyebrow - a loosely tied headscarf does its best to disguise the wound.

What happened?

'The police did it,' he says, drawing the scarf tightly around his head.

Why?

'I was caught in truck. Two policemen caught me - they beat me up.'

Nervous, he starts walking away from the ferry terminal at a brisk pace. Over the next 50 metres, he will periodically turn round to see me following him.

'What?'

Is it possible to go to the UK?

'What?'

I want to go to the UK - no passport. Is it possible to go on a truck?

Muhammad seems to size up the question for a while; he is still walking away from the ferry terminal. After a minute's pondering, he throws his hands up in exasperation. He doesn't understand the question.

'What?'

I want to go to the UK - to London.

I point to a passing truck, whose driver suspiciously eyes the two Asiatic men standing at the side of the road, pointing at the rear of his vehicle.

I want to go in one of those. In the back of it to London. How much? £100_ £200_ £300_?

'I understand. Two hundred dollars,' says Muhammad. 'Come to Sangatt, come to the camp. You meet Afghanis, Pakistanis and Iranians. It will cost $200. Difficult, but can be done. My friends help with truck. Some days, too much police. Some days, not many.'

What is the camp, and where is Sangatt?

Muhammad searches for the right words, but can't find many. He looks at me in frustration, then finally says: 'Camp - for people like me. In Sangatt. Eight kilometres down the road.' He points in the direction we have just walked from.

Is it possible to go to London today?

Muhammad thinks not - the ferry port this morning has a high police presence, he says. He has already been moved on twice in as many hours for loitering.

'Too much police. Very difficult then. Problem. Police. Have to wait. Go to Sangatt, and ask there. People will help.' He ambles on down the carriageway, slowly disappearing into the distance.

The camp at Sangatt is a cavernous green shed, only eight miles from Calais. A detention centre for asylum-seekers waiting to be processed by the French authorities, the building houses about 700 applicants. It runs an open-door policy - its curious 'guests' are allowed to wander in and out of the building without restrictions.

Many of its residents can be seen walking around Calais itself - thin, huddled figures struggling to come to terms with their surroundings. Later on Tuesday afternoon, at a little past 3pm, Saftar, Ali and Wahid - three detainees from the centre - approach the lorry park adjacent to Calais's passenger terminal.

As streams of freight trucks drive past, the three look at the traffic with anticipation. A number of the truck drivers gaze at the trio.

Saftar and Ali - both originally from Pakistan - are in negotiations with a truck driver for a safe passage to the UK. Both look in their mid-thirties, plainly dressed in jeans and leather jackets. Both speak fluent Punjabi - and after much discussion, agree to a fee of £350 for a fourth person, me, to be smuggled on a truck with them into Britain.

The transaction is carried out with an almost matter-of-fact simplicity; few questions are asked, and no consequences are discussed. The money, it seems, will encourage the driver to turn a blind eye as we climb on board the truck.

These are the solemn, dignified faces of asylum-seekers entering the country. The trio are, at worst, escaping political violence from their homelands. At best, they aspire to the same decent standard of living achieved by generations of immigrants before them.

In their wake last week, the Tory Party has lurched further to the extreme right - with all the ugly hallmarks of racial intolerance and bigotry. Political marketing for fresh votes from an old message overlooks their plight.

Saftar and Ali both disappear to negotiate the whereabouts of the truck driver. Wahid - Malaysian in origin - sits on the corrugated fence that borders the lorry park. He speaks no English. Every few minutes, he rises to his feet and takes an anxious look down towards the terminal building for any sign of a police presence.

Always stern-faced, he allows himself a faint smile only when his companions return.

Theirs is a hateful existence - always waiting for an opening; hours are killed with nervous movements.

This late at night, the trio daren't walk into town to idle away the few remaining hours. Saftar explains a truck has been organised for a little past 9pm - we have yet another three hours to kill. As the wind whips up to a quiet storm, the trio pace around the vehicle parking grounds that border the terminal building.

Saftar and Ali eventually disappear again closer to 9pm. I want to speak to the driver. But the duo wave me back. On their return, they lead Wahid and I to a group of lorries idling at the far end of the park. It's a little past 9pm, pitch dark, and the port is almost deserted.

The loading door to a plain-looking truck has been left open, and the four of us clamber in and pull the doors shut. The lorry contains several rows of wooden pallets and, following the trio's lead, I move towards the front of the container, hiding near the back of the cab.

As we sit in the dark, Saftar starts to speak in low Punjabi tones. It's his first attempt at a conversation since we met more than six hours earlier: 'I have friends in England. They are in Kent, and I hope to find them. After a few months, perhaps I will go to London - there must be many jobs there.'

Saftar and his friends - like most of the 90,000 asylum - seekers in the UK - want to benefit from the country's open economy.

As asylum-seekers, they argue the right to fair and gainful employment. Saftar is escaping a land seizure that robbed him of his farm in Pakistan.

'The farm was taken by enemies,' he sighs. 'It was a political problem. So what am I to do? Starve? I just want to work - I think there will be work for me in the UK.'

There's an eerie silence in the lorry park - occasionally a truck rumbles past, presumably on its way into a ferry. Saftar and Ali are discussing the likelihood of entering Britain without passports.

'I know other people who have done this,' says Ali. 'They hardly ever check the trucks - they don't have time to. They can't open everything and look through it.' Saftar nods silently in agreement, but the duo's bewildered expressions give them the begging look of men hoping for divine guidance.

Ali tells me he used to live in a village outside Lahore. 'But with corruption, it's hard to make a living,' he says. 'I have relatives and friends over here - they make good money. I hope to make the same. I just want to be able to live and work in peace. In Pakistan, everything became too expensive. The cost of living was unbearable.'

'I have been told there are a lot of Asians in the UK already,' he continues. 'Maybe some of them will be willing to help me. Any kind of job will do - you have to work hard to make a living.'

Someone outside - presumably the driver - locks the doors. As we huddle closer, sinking into the lorry's floor, the truck starts to lurch to the right. Other vehicles in the lorry park start their engines and make their way over to the freight terminal.

What follows is an agonisingly slow journey through the lorry park and into the ferry. It's a debilitating experience - this reduction to only being able to use sound as an indicator. The truck barely stops at the loading bay - and Saftar, Ali and Wahid are visibly encouraged by the silence that seems to disguise their passage.

There is a faint sensation of the ferry making its way towards Dover, but we could equally have returned to the parking bay. The drivers, having parked their vehicles, have obviously made their way above deck.

Surrounded by wooden pallets, Saftar reaches into his rucksack and pulls out an apple, which he proceeds to gnaw silently.

Ali watches him with growing lack of interest, eventually pulling out an Urdu news magazine. It's too dark to read, so he lies down, closes his eyes and drifts into sleep. Occasionally, he will whisper tales of hope: 'There are jobs in the UK. I'll do anything. People like us can't be fussy - I think it's only fair that we work.'

The 60-minute Channel crossing seems to hurry by as the lorry gently rocks on the waves across the Channel. Saftar continues to chew silently on his apple, while Ali catches up on some lost sleep. Wahid, in characteristic form, remains silent - he seems to have been brought into the group purely on means of his financial ability to pay for the journey.

And it's hard not to feel sorry for the trio - having abandoned their homeland for a new life in Britain. They face certain detention or deportation if discovered. Almost 40 years before them, a wave of Asians arrived in similar circumstances - their evolution created a stable, prospering middle class.

As I look at Saftar, Ali and Wahid, with their earnest talk of meritocracy and hard work, it's hard to doubt they have any intentions to the contrary.

As the ferry stops, Saftar breathes a sigh of relief. 'I hope to find a job tomorrow,' he says, gleefully.

The lorry starts again, picking up speed as it moves off the ferry. There is no indication of a customs check - a noise rattles the walls, but the door is left locked. Saftar quietly starts to bemoan his stiffening legs, then stops himself.

The lorry driver gives no notice of an impending check; in fact, he has not been heard throughout the journey. A few gruff voices can be heard in the lorry bay, but none approach our vehicle.

Ten minutes after landing, the lorry starts up again and heads off the dock. Saftar, Ali and Wahid hug each other in delight. Had they been captured, would they, at a later date, have made another attempt? 'Yes,' says Ali. 'Anything is better than being put inside a detention centre.' Paradoxically, a smiliar fate probably awaits him if discovered in Britain.

A few miles from the centre of Dover, the lorry stops on the outskirts. There are few audible signs of traffic as the time approaches 11pm. The doors - loudly grating against the silence - are opened, and the lorry driver vanishes around the corner.

It seems a curious trade - of course, the lorry drivers accept money from their asylum-seeking passengers, but their gift in return amounts to economic freedom.

We're being let out, and as we scramble out of the back, Saftar trips and falls to the ground. He is helped to his feet by his fellow travellers, and, limping, he is moved to the shadows of the pavement. Saftar returns to the lorry to close the doors - and after a sharp slap against the side, the lorry moves off on its intended journey.

The trio stand blinking in the night. 'You come with us?' asks Saftar, but it's an invitation made out of politeness only. Having endured around six months each at the detention centre in Sangatt, the trio share a bond and common destiny no outsider could comprehend.

After a series of polite handshakes, they move away and begin to walk down back into the centre of Dover. They are in Britain. A new life has cost them £350.

webTitle: Yard to meet spy chiefs on Libya killing claim

fields.headline: Yard to meet spy chiefs on Libya killing claim
fields.trailText: Scotland Yard's anti-terrorist branch will hold an emergency meeting on Wednesday with members of Britain's intelligence services to discuss revelations in last week's Observer that a bungled operation by MI6 may have led to the assassination of a British citizen in London.
fields.body:
Scotland Yard's anti-terrorist branch will hold an emergency meeting on Wednesday with members of Britain's intelligence services to discuss revelations in last week's Observer that a bungled operation by MI6 may have led to the assassination of a British citizen in London.

Detective Chief Superintendent John Bunn called the meeting after a top-secret MI5 intelligence dossier appeared on an American website disclosing fresh information about the killing in 1995 of Ali Abuzeid - a prominent opponent of Libyan leader Colonel Gadaffi who was living in west London.

Detailing Libyan intelli gence activities in Britain, the documents revealed that MI5 had suspicions Khalifa Bazelya, Gadaffi's top spy in Britain, could have been involved in the murder. Bazelya was allowed into Britain by MI6, which gave him security clearance believing it could recruit him. He was expelled days after the murder.

Bunn said: 'This is a murder investigation that we have not yet solved. The documents on the website have given us new information and it is only right and proper we consider any fresh leads.'

Bazelya, now Libyan Ambassador to Cyprus, was never questioned by police. Bunn confirmed that they were now considering questioning Bazelya.

webTitle: Police to tap calls at May Day protest

fields.headline: Police to tap calls at May Day protest
fields.standfirst: Civil rights group attacks move as unjustified intrusion
fields.trailText: Police will be listening in when demonstrators use mobile phones to plan tactics during the expected 1 May demonstrations in London, The Observer has learnt.
fields.body:
Police will be listening in when demonstrators use mobile phones to plan tactics during the expected 1 May demonstrations in London, The Observer has learnt.

Scotland Yard has said it will 'pursue all legal avenues' to prevent and monitor crime. A number of legal loopholes give police the power to intercept conversations.

May Day is known to be the date of the next series of anti-capitalist protests, and Special Branch is believed to have kept alleged ringleaders under surveillance. The protests are expected to be organised by a few individuals in constant contact by mobile phone. This was the pattern at the 'N30' demonstration outside Euston station on 30 November last year, where organisers co-ordinated attacks on financial institutions.

Mobile phones may be legally monitored in two ways. The network to which the phones are connected can be tapped if the police obtain a warrant from the Home Secretary. But to do so, they must suspect that a crime may be committed which carries a penalty of more than three years or which involves a number of people. A warrant allows the police to intercept all communications to and from one individual. Riots such as those caused by the N30 protests involve sufficiently serious crimes for such warrants to be issued.

Additionally and more controversially, police may also intercept signals between a mobile phone and a phone mast. While it was all too easy to intercept old analogue phones, the vast majority of new digital phones send encrypted signals, and the equipment required to tap such phones is not publicly available. 'Technology of that sort would only be owned by the Government,' said an engineer with telecoms security firm Spymaster.

John Wadham, director of civil rights group Liberty, said: 'Listening in to someone's telephone conversations is a serious intrusion that should only be justified if police are investigating really serious offences. The planning of a peaceful protest should never be subject to such intrusive surveillance. The real solution for the future is to ensure that there is an independent check on this, and the only real way to ensure this is to have a judge - not a politician - issue the warrant.'

There are now 2,000 ministerial warrants approving phone and mail tapping every year, an increase of 50 per cent over the past three years.

The May Day 2000 protests will start on Friday with a Radicals' Walk of the East End, and conclude on 1 May with a series of demonstrations and 'direct action' around the capital.

Police consider the likely flashpoint to be the 'Guerrilla Gardening' action co-ordinated by the protest group Reclaim the Streets to 'reclaim open space'. This is scheduled to meet on May Day at 11am in Parliament Square. Protesters have been asked to bring gardening implements, which police fear may be used as weapons. A police officer is still recovering from a spinal injury caused, say police, by a blow from a rioter's spade during City demonstrations last June.

As well as preparing for attacks on buildings, firms across the capital are bracing themselves for cyber-attacks similar to those that damaged the internet sites of Yahoo! and Amazon earlier this year. Anarchist hackers are believed to be targeting large corporations with 'denial-of-service' attacks which bombard computers with e-mails.

Emma, 29, is an artist from London who intends to take part in planting seeds in Parliament Square and hopes it will pass peacefully. 'This protest is trying to be more conceptual. We're doing some real work,' she said. 'It's a very fluffy form of direct action. I've found the police reaction rather scary. I have a little girl who will come with me, and I hope she comes away from the day with a pleasant image of the bobby on the beat. There will only be violence if there's some provocation.'

Tony, 40, an unemployed former finance worker and organiser of one of the May Day events, said: 'People have started realising that Parliament does not represent them in the way they thought, and want to say something about that.'

Scotland Yard has said preparations for the May Day protests will amount to the biggest law enforcement operation in the capital for 30 years.

webTitle: One must lord it over the oiks

fields.headline: One must lord it over the oiks
fields.standfirst: The English have tugged their forelocks to peers for centuries.  John Sweeney  posed as a hard-up lord to see how far a title gets you in modern Britain
fields.trailText: The BMW whispered through London's streets, as outside the bogus asylum seekers, oiks and other scum stood snivelling in the driving rain, or screamed expletives at one another.
fields.body:
The BMW whispered through London's streets, as outside the bogus asylum seekers, oiks and other scum stood snivelling in the driving rain, or screamed expletives at one another.

Inside the luxury limousine the air conditioning was just a tad too cold, the leather upholstery a caress too soft on the buttocks. The car sashayed through a short cut and one arrived at the Savoy, which is not what it was, but still...

One had to wait an age for Gerry, one's driver-cum-bodyguard, to open the door. One cannot get the staff these days. It's always jolly to swagger through the Savoy, taking in the clientele. There was a Mrs Marcos lookalike, a Middle Eastern arms dealer with his gorgeous tottie from Essex and a fat English lord snoring his head off, his trousers at half-mast.

No riff-raff here, then.

One wasn't recognised. It was only when my assistant, Ms Jordan, informed the young woman at the entrance to the River Room Restaurant that Lord Sweeney had arrived that people started to look up to one, and one down to them.

The minion looked at one, paused, and ushered one to the best table in the house. The liquid history of the Thames flowed by. Nearby, a table full of toffs in pinstripes roared with laughter at someone's quip about the Inland Revenue.

One had arrived.

Another flunkey poured the Sancerre, and cringed agreeably while he waited for one's verdict. The age of deference is not dead yet.

Gerry parked at the front of the hotel. A doorman came over: 'I'm waiting for Lord Sweeney,' said Gerry.

'Oh, one of them arse holes. They always keep you waiting. Which bar is he in?'

But then, mysteriously, he allowed Gerry to stay.

Sadly, the world outside the Savoy was less obliging to a lord on the make.

One's cover is that one made one's money selling dual-use equipment to the Iraqis and developing vacuum bombs. A bit of dosh to the New Labour coffers, and it was 'Arise, Lord Sweeney of Sweeney Mountain'. (A hill in Shropshire, as much a snow-capped peak as I will ever be a nob.)

Pretending to be a lord is all the rage these days. Marc Philip Onslow Berkeley St Leger Curzon, the Marquis St Leger, got a lovely job off Wiltshire County Council and zoomed around in a Roller, until he was revealed as former publican and conman Keith 'Uncle Keith' Andrews, and received 18 months' jail for deception. Real New Labour lords can be a bit sly, too. Lord Alli - one of several life peers most unfairly dubbed 'Tony's cronies' - ran his business from his House of Lords address, to wry comment from old hereditaries.

Becoming a fake lord isn't that difficult. A website comes in handy. William Fahy, of Willsolvit, on www.willsolvit.com, knocked off a Lord Sweeney of Sweeney Mountain site double-quick, complete with snaps of Big Ben and the Dome and a bogus coat of arms - a severed arm holding a rapier atop three creepie crawlies rampant, with a dead rat recumbent, on a bed of custard and gangrene, beneath the motto: Sweeney Agonistes.

One picked up an accommodation address: Sweeney Towers, Suite 401, 302 Regent Street, London W1R 6HH. They send on one's post, for £50 a month. Fake address, fake website and fake crest in the bag, one's next step was some serious confidence trickery. One dreamt up a wheeze worthy of the Drones Club, mulching yew trees to find a major pharmacological breakthrough. First stop was Chase Manhattan in New York.

'How much money?'

'A lot of money.'

'How much is a lot, sir?'

'Fifty million, sterling, with a view to extend.'

One was swiftly passed from an impressed-sounding receptionist to the delightful Matthew in Private Investment Capital. Immensely polite, though sadly unable to help one in one's million- dollar search, he passed one on to the amiable John at Chase Capital Partners. Nice, but not even a dollar.

The Yank suggested a raft of other investment houses such as JP Morgan, Morgan Stanley and Merrill Lynch.

Not a cent. With the New World a dead loss, it was back to Blighty. How would one fare with our home-grown banks? First stop Coutts, the bank that likes to say yes. To snobs.

M'lord was put through to a puzzled marketing department, who gently explained that Coutts didn't do investment in dodgy start-up projects, and was really a private bank for people with large current accounts. Oops.

M'lord phoned the Big Bank, Barclays. A woman reluctantly agreed to send literature, though only under considerable lordly duress. She wanted to know the name of one's company. Hell, what was it called? 'Avanti,' one declared proudly. Bugger. Isn't that a brand of condoms?

Then, one fancied a trip to New York. On Virgin's Upper Class, naturally. But on the cheap. One called Virgin reservations and was put through to the Upper Class hotline. One gave the dates. Nothing before noon. Lord Sweeney is not one to rise early. 'I don't blame him,' came the understanding response. Dates and times agreed, one got down to the nitty-gritty.

An Upper Class return to New York, with driver on either side, costs £3,595.70. Knowing Lord Sweeney, one explained the dilemma to saleswoman, Melanie.

'Look, the problem is that Lord Sweeney, despite being a Lord, isn't exactly flush. Could he have it for less?'

Sorry, came the reply, but that's the standard fare and there's no haggling.

'But if he went for an economy fare, might he be bumped up to first class because he's a lord?' The upper classes firmly in their places in Upper Class and all that? 'No,' came the reply.

Melanie politely explained that this wasn't Virgin policy, it might only happen in cases of overbooking. She suggested premium economy - a bargain at £1,251.70. Basically the same service as economy, but seats are bigger and there's more legroom.

What about meals? Would they be served on china with proper cutlery? No. Meals are the usual 'cellophane, pre-packed' economy fare. Good God, Lord Sweeney would be horrified! 'He's very fussy,' one cried, 'one doesn't think he'd put up with that. He might make a scene. Couldn't they make an exception? 'No,' said Melanie.

'What if he is a friend of Sir Richard Branson?'

That would be different, came the reply.

Outside the House of Lords, things were little better. One donned one's ermine and cloak for a snap with the House of Lords in the background. Two working-class girls - one could tell because they used glottal stops - asked: 'What the fuck are you doing?' One found it quite discombobulating.

Happily, two Swedish skinheads, Hengist and Horsa, were happy to be convinced that Lord Sweeney was real.

The rest of London was more difficult to win over. One called on a man in a pub in Soho to buy a drink for Lord Sweeney of Sweeney Mountain.

'Lord Who? Bugger off, I'm drinking.'

Thus spake Everyman.

fields.headline: NEWS IN BRIEF
fields.trailText: Body of missing restaurateur found near King's Lynn
fields.body:
Body of missing restaurateur found near King's Lynn

Remains found near the A17 west of King's Lynn have been identified as those of a Lincoln restaurateur, Rumel Iqbal Bakar, 25, last seen by staff last December. Two men are on remand charged with his murder.

Gold medal for Glasgow poet

Glasgow's unofficial poet laureate Edwin Morgan, 80, has been awarded the Queen's Gold Medal for Poetry for the year 2000. Previous recipients include Ted Hughes, Philip Larkin, John Betjeman, Siegfried Sassoon and W.H. Auden. It is awarded on the recommendation of a committee chaired by the poet laureate Andrew Motion.

Kevin Macdonald: a correction

Kevin Macdonald, director of the documentary One Day in September, has asked us to point out that our report of 26 March contained two errors. The fake hijacking was not the work of Black September but of the Wadi'a Haddad of the PFLP. Haddad merely opted to use the Black September name as a cover. Second, information about the hijacking came not from Jamal Al Gashey but from Abu Daoud, a former member of Black September who had refused to have anything to do with it when approached by Haddad.

Men overboard

The annual Devizes-to-Westminster canoe race was abandoned when two competitors capsized in the Thames near Windsor and others had to be rescued from an island.

Jane Bown exhibition

Eye to Eye, an exhibition of photography by The Observer 's Jane Bown, opens today at the Foundation Gallery, Gate 13, Lamb Street, Spitalfields Market, London E1. The exhibition will run until 28 May. Admission is free. Open Tuesday to Friday 12-3pm and Sunday 10am-6pm. Please note: the exhibition will not be open on Bank Holiday Monday.

webTitle: Juan Miguel kept repeating 'I want to be with my son'

fields.headline: Juan Miguel kept repeating 'I want to be with my son'
fields.standfirst:
CNN journalist tells of Juan Miguel González's anger the night before his son was taken back Miami
More about the Elian Gonzalez case
fields.trailText: CNN journalist tells of Juan Miguel González's anger the night before  his son was taken back Miami.
fields.body:
Elian's father - Juan Miguel González - said hours before the boy was seized by immigration officials yesterday that he was prepared to fly to Miami to confront the relatives holding his son. The details of the last hours of frustrated waiting for González were revealed by a CNN journalist who dined with him the night before armed officials raided the house of Elián's uncle.

According to Bill Press, González had become increasingly angry and frustrated as it became clear that Elián's Miami relatives were still playing for time in their negotiations with the office of Attorney General Janet Reno.

At one stage, said Press, González left with the Federal Marshals who were protecting him to attend yet another meeting to decide on how he was to be reunited with his son. 'Two hours later he came back. He was very angry. He said it was one more round of talks. One more proposal.'

This time the Miami relatives were proposing that González and his wife - Elián's stepmother - should move to a secure compound outside Miami where the two families would share access to the boy, a proposal González described as 'ludicrous'.

Press added that when González left at around midnight he was in tears and appeared to have no knowledge of the impending raid to sieze his son.

'He was very frustrated. He was saying "I have the law on my side. I have the Attorney General on my side. I have the President of the United States on my side. But they still can't reunite me with my son".'

Press added: 'Juan Miguel kept repeating. "I want to be with my son". As long as he was to be with his son he was happy to wait as long as it takes to resolve these things.'

Press was impressed by how strong Elián's father was, and apparently free from any influence from the Cuban Interests Section, which has been accused by the Miami relatives of influencing him. 'I was impressed how passionate he was, that he was really speaking from the heart. There was no gun to his head. I do believe he is a man of integrity.'

The question now is how long González will have to wait until he can return with his son to Cuba. Some believe they may still be in America at Christmas; others that the case may still be going through the courts when Elián is 16.

webTitle: 'Give me the boy or I will shoot,' said the agent

fields.headline: 'Give me the boy or I will shoot,' said the agent
fields.standfirst:
Ed Vulliamy on a show of force that ended the stand-off over Elian Gonzalez but caused outrage in Little Havana
More about the Elian Gonzalez case
fields.trailText: Ed Vulliamy  on a show of force that ended the stand-off over Elian Gonzalez but caused outrage in Little Havana
fields.body:
In the end it was supercharged with drama. In a dawn swoop on Easter Saturday, Elian González was wrenched from the arms of Donato Dalrymple, the fisherman who rescued him from a floating inner tube last Thanksgiving Day, and delivered into those of federal government agents armed to the teeth and wearing riot helmets, bullet-proof vests and gas masks.

Yesterday, as Elián's Miami family cranked up the hysteria in and around the house, crowds gathered to express their outrage.

Hundreds of Cuban-Americans poured into the streets of Little Havana. Some threw rocks and shouted. Others waved signs and flags - Cuban and upside-down American ones. One man stalked through the crowd with a baby doll pinned to a cross, fake blood streaming from its hands.

The fisherman himself was comfortless: weeping tears of rage, he shrieked at the nearest of the TV cameras taken as much by surprise as everyone else: 'What you see was wrong Sir. On the day of the resurrection of our Lord Jesus Christ... Why? Why?'

The raid was carried out by about 20 federal agents armed to the teeth and arriving in white vans. After three knocks on the door and 'identifying themselves' [as the parlance insists], the agents used a battering ram to force their way in and pepper spray to get back out again. The only compromise with gentility was the fact that a woman was employed to carry the boy out of the steps and into a waiting van.

She spoke to Elián in Spanish: 'I know you are scared. This must be frightening but it will be over very soon. You are not going back to Cuba, you are not going on a boat, you are going to see your papa.'

The stand-off between the government and the Cubans of Miami is now absolute; the swoop was ordered as exasperated Attorney General Janet Reno abandoned negotiations with a family she said had continually 'move the goalposts' and was still defiant in obstructing the law.

Under a deal brokered by Miamia's Cuban leaders, the boy's father, Juan Miguel González, had been asked to accept, in exchange of custody of Elián, a continuation of the close relationship that had developed between the boy and his father's Miami cousin, Marisleysis González.

Around midnight the father and his lawyer made a counter offer, limiting the time that Marisleysis and her father, Lazaro González, could spend with them to a few weeks rather than for whatever time it takes for legal proceedings, at present preventing Elian's removal from the country, to be completed.

But Reno and the boy's father came to the conclusion that little was to be gained from further attempts at direct negotiation. The Miami relatives had defied an order from the Immigration and Naturalisation Service on 13 April to hand the boy over to his father. Instead, they insisted on a prior meeting with him, at the same time demanding an independent investigation of their allegations that he was unfit to have custody because he had allegedly abused the child.

Elian spent much of Friday on a swing in Lazaro González's back garden. As rumours that federal marshals were on their way ebbed and flowed, demonstrators reconstituted their human chain around the house in a crowd swelled by Cuban Americans coming from Good Friday church services.

In the end Reno was left with little choice but to send her team in under cover of darkness. As the INS team knocked at and then battered down the door, Elian was wrenched from his bed and hidden in a cupboard. But not for long. He was grabbed by a male agent, under the watchful barrel of his colleague's gun and handed over to the Spanish-speaking woman. Then it was off and away - first by helicopter and then by plane to Andrews Air Force Base in Maryland and his father.

Reno explained why she had had to abandon a promise the boy would not be taken under cover of darkness. 'We had hoped,' she explained, 'that it could have been done another way. But the crowds began to suggest they were going to prevent it from happening...

'[Elian's uncle] Lazaro had suggested people were going to have to run a gauntlet... With so much being unknown, the most important issue was to do it at a time that was safest for Elian, and safest for all concerned.'

Within an hour of the raid, suddenly in the limelight, talking and weeping, was Marisleysis González. Having acted as the boy's surrogate mother, Marisleysis had been hidden from public view as a quiet but pivotal figure - periodically collapsing and being taken to hospital suffering from exhaustion, Now she became the Miami family's spokesperson.

She displayed the boy's broken bed she claimed had been smashed by the feds, and invoked fire and brimstone on both the operation and President Clinton. 'If they had wanted to do this without violence, they would have made the father come to the house,' she began.

Then she described her version of what had happened: 'Give me the boy else I'll shoot,' an agent apparently said. She claimed the agents put a gun to her chest.

Savaging President Clinton personally, she shouted 'He has already dishonoured his family,and now he has dishonoured mine. And he has dishonoured this country.'

The Miami Cuban diaspora is not used to losing. For four decades it has managed to call the shots in US politics, and especially with the Clinton administration, from whom the exiles had extracted their best ever embargo deal against the Havana regime.

But on this one, the hardliners were doomed - doomed by the apathy for the old right-wing politics within their community, by American public copinion and above all by the law and Reno's determination to enforce it. This time, Havana and Washington were at one, with the Miami diaspora squeezed out, like a pip at the core of a Florida orange.

The US government declared itself focused above all on the welfare of the child - and this seemed to be more and more precariously placed in the hands of his Uncle Lazaro and cousin Marisleysis.

The psychiatrists and psychologists who had hitherto performed something of a charade were being taken seriously - the Miami Gonzalez family was not only defying the law, they were brainwashing the boy.

There was a 'play pack' waiting on Elián's plane to Washington, said Doris Meissner, the INS Commissioner. She had been told that squeezing play-dough was therapeutic for children under stress, and there was play-dough on hand. Elián was fine, she said, 'He is a real terrific, tough kid'.

The seizure of Elián enters the annals of heavy-handed but effective testosterone management by the US government. It's an illustrious line: from the 101st Airborne Regiment dispatched by Bobby Kennedy to desegregate Little Rock High School in 1958, to the debacle at Waco, Texas, in 1993.

Reno insisted t they were tough, and tender, too. 'We did this as sensitively as we could,' said Deputy Attorney General Eric Holder. Clinton was 'in agreement' with the raid; actually, he ordered it.

Who's who in tug-of-war

The mother: Elizabet Bortons Rodríguez

Drowned on voyage to US with Elián's step-father and nine others. Had been a waitress. Married Elián's father Juan Miguel González when he was 16 and she 15. Elián's name came from a combination of his parents' - 'Eli' from Elizabet and 'an' from Juan.

The father: Juan Miguel González

A national park worker. Although divorced from Elizabet, he had a good relationship with her and was devoted to Elián. Juan Miguel has denounced his Miami relatives on Cuban TV, berating them for turning Elián into a political symbol.

The surrogate mother: Marisleysis González

Elián's pretty cousin, 21, is a college drop-out who works as an assistant loan processor. The two have shared a room since Elián moved in with his Miami relatives. Marisleysis has been 'very stressed' about the prospect of losing Elián and has been hospitalised eight times since Elián's rescue at sea in late November, always for stress-related problems.

The great-uncle: Lázaro González

Marisleysis's father gained de facto temporary custody of Elián while the courts decided the boy's fate. He infuriated critics by allowing Elián to appear in media interviews and photoshoots. Things got nasty when Fidel Castro alleged Lázaro had sexually molested boys. He has a couple of drink-driving convictions.

The grandmothers: Mareila Quintana and Raquel Rodríguez

They travelled to the US in January and were allowed less than two hours with their grandson while fistfights broke out between factions outside. Anti-Cuban critics later accused the grandmothers of inappropriate behaviour when one admitted to 'biting' Elián's tongue because he was too timid to speak.

The psychiatrists and psychologists who had hitherto performed something of a charade were being taken seriously - the Miami Gonzalez family was not only defying the law, they were brainwashing the boy. There was a 'play pack' waiting on Elián's plane to Washington, said Doris Meissner, the INS Commissioner. She had been told that squeezing play-dough was therapeutic for children under stress, and there was play-dough on hand. Elián was fine, she said, 'He is a real terrific, tough kid'. The seizure of Elián enters the annals of heavy-handed but effective testosterone management by the US government. It's an illustrious line: from the 101st Airborne Regiment dispatched by Bobby Kennedy to desegregate Little Rock High School in 1958, to the debacle at Waco, Texas, in 1993. Reno insisted t they were tough, and tender, too. 'We did this as sensitively as we could,' said Deputy Attorney General Eric Holder. Clinton was 'in agreement' with the raid; actually, he ordered it. Who's who in tug-of-war The mother: Elizabet Bortons Rodríguez Drowned on voyage to US with Elián's step-father and nine others. Had been a waitress. Married Elián's father Juan Miguel González when he was 16 and she 15. Elián's name came from a combination of his parents' - 'Eli' from Elizabet and 'an' from Juan. The father: Juan Miguel González A national park worker. Although divorced from Elizabet, he had a good relationship with her and was devoted to Elián. Juan Miguel has denounced his Miami relatives on Cuban TV, berating them for turning Elián into a political symbol. The surrogate mother: Marisleysis González Elián's pretty cousin, 21, is a college drop-out who works as an assistant loan processor. The two have shared a room since Elián moved in with his Miami relatives. Marisleysis has been 'very stressed' about the prospect of losing Elián and has been hospitalised eight times since Elián's rescue at sea in late November, always for stress-related problems. The great-uncle: Lázaro González Marisleysis's father gained de facto temporary custody of Elián while the courts decided the boy's fate. He infuriated critics by allowing Elián to appear in media interviews and photoshoots. Things got nasty when Fidel Castro alleged Lázaro had sexually molested boys. He has a couple of drink-driving convictions. The grandmothers: Mareila Quintana and Raquel Rodríguez They travelled to the US in January and were allowed less than two hours with their grandson while fistfights broke out between factions outside. Anti-Cuban critics later accused the grandmothers of inappropriate behaviour when one admitted to 'biting' Elián's tongue because he was too timid to speak. webTitle: How the cowboy dentists are allowed to ruin our teeth

fields.headline: How the cowboy dentists are allowed to ruin our teeth
fields.standfirst: 'There's a dentist in the North we know is a rogue. We've reported him but they do nothing':  Report by  Anthony Browne:  * Nine out of ten root fillings fail to meet European standards * Four-fifths of crowns do not fit, causing gum disease * 10,000 patients a year have shards of drill left inside teeth
fields.trailText: The rip-off dentists
fields.body:
The rip-off dentists

The appalling dental work being inflicted on most of the British population is exposed today by an Observer investigation which has uncovered evidence that up to 90 per cent of work falls below international standards.

Whistle-blowing dentists describe it as a 'national scandal', accusing the Government and the profession of colluding to hide it from the public. Poor quality work means patients are more likely to get further tooth decay, suffer unnecessary pain, incur extra costs and need work redone years earlier than necessary.

Some reputable dentists complain that 'cowboy' dentists are destroying patients' teeth with near impunity, ignored by authorities.

Figures obtained by The Observer show that complaints against dentists have risen sharply, but members of the profession warn that, if the public knew of the scale of shoddy work, it could lead to a tidal wave of litigation.

The Observer reported last week that dentists carry out at least £200 million worth of unnecessary work each year. Today we reveal the appalling standard of the work done:

 Of the 1.1 million root fillings done each year, 90 per cent fail to meet standards set by the European Endodontic Society, according to a study by the University of Wales, to be published shortly in a recognised journal. For mandibular pre-molars, only 3 per cent of root fillings are carried out adequately.

 In 42 per cent of cases, dentists left holes in root fillings. In almost 5 per cent of cases, the drilled cavity was left entirely empty with no filling at all. In 1 per cent of cases - an estimated total of 10,000 a year - the dentist has left a shard of his drill or other instrument inside the tooth.

 A quarter of people who visit their dentist regularly have such bad gums they fall into the worst category registered by the World Health Organisation, according to a survey, even though 88 per cent of them were told by their dentist there was no cause for concern.

 More then four-fifths of crowns don't fit and have gaps of more tha half a millimetre, according to a survey by Professor Richard Elderton of Bristol University. Almost half have gaps of more than one millimetre.

Critics argue that the appalling level of most dental work in Britain is due to a system that rewards poor work; an almost complete lack of quality checking and the near impossibility of having dentists disciplined or struck off.

The study showing that nine out of 10 root fillings are inadequate was carried out two years ago, but has until now only been circulated within the profession. The author, Professor Paul Dummer of the department of Adult Dental Health, University of Wales College of Medicine, concluded: 'The data demonstrates clearly that the technical quality of root fillings... fell well below accepted European guidelines.'

Peter Gordziejko, a former dentist who became an assistant principal at a college, said: 'It is a national scandal. The public are completely misled about the quality of NHS dentistry. Up to 90 per cent of people with molar root fillings could potentially sue their dentists. There is a litigation timebomb.'

The chairman of the general dental services committee of the British Dental Association, Anthony Kravitz, admitted: 'The figures are shocking. But new techniques have been introduced in the last 18 months to improve standards.'

Most dentists blame the problem with root fillings on the fact that NHS charges are just not adequate to cover the amount of time they should take. Elderton said: 'I wouldn't have a root filled on the NHS, and I don't know a dentist who would.'

Many good dentists are outraged by the situation, but fearful of saying so publicly for fear of retribution from colleagues. Those doing NHS work also have a gagging clause in their contract, banning public criticism of NHS treatments. However, one dentist who has practised for 20 years, told The Observer : 'It's a disaster for the public. The worst part is that people are being told they are getting good treatment when they are not. The Government just don't care about quality, they are just happy that so many operations are being done at such a low cost.

'People are being given loads of cheap fillings which are having to be redone every three years. Do you think dentists redo their own fillings every three years? Of course we don't. They should last 15 years.'

Elderton, who carried out the study showing that four-fifths of crowns don't fit, said: 'It's professional incompetence. All the textbooks say make the crown fit. Otherwise it can lead to decay and gum disease, and the appearance can be affected'.

However, Kravitz insisted the work was competent: 'Research shows that the average length of life of a crown in Britain is 15 years, which is quite good.'

Many dentists complain that the NHS payment system encourages bad practice. One said: 'Many young dentists are arrogant. They work in a piecework situation with virtually no quality checks. They may start out good, but they generally work their way down to the lowest level. If you do two good fillings in the same time it takes to do 10 bad ones, you get more money for the bad ones. What would you end up doing? The bad guys win, and the good guys lose.'

However, the situation is exacerbated by the lack of quality control on dentists, and the near impossibility of showing malpractice. Elderton said: 'The work is slipshod, but a lot of dentists don't realise they are not that good. Inspections are few and far between; a dentist could go his whole career without an inspection. And who is to say the people doing the inspections are that smart?'

Kravitz insisted that the problem was being addressed: 'We're all agreed that the quality of care could be improved - just as they could in medicine and law. The techniques are there, but the money isn't.

'I am not going to say there is nothing wrong. We are not shrinking into a trade union shell, saying trust me, I'm a dentist. We are doing things.'

Clinical governance for dentistry - setting standards for the work - is being introduced, as is continuing pro fessional development, helping to make sure dentists remain up to date throughout their careers. The British Dental Association is setting up a 'poor-performers unit' so 'whistle-blowing' dentists can report on rogue colleagues. Quality inspections have recently been stepped up.

However, it is extremely unlikely that any dentist caught out will be disciplined. Figures disclosed to The Observer show that the number of complaints to the General Dental Council - the official disciplinary body which is made up almost exclusively of dentists - rose from 547 in 1996 to 782 last year. However, the number of dentists struck off or suspended for a short period rose from just eight in 1996 to 11 last year. 'I am amazed when I read that a dentist did this, that or the other and he was just admonished, not struck off. It's outrageous,' said Elderton, one of Britain's most respected academic dentists. Even when they are struck off, dentists can easily start practising again.

In 1995, Barry Garrett was struck off for doing huge amounts of unnecessary work on patients and was eventually sued by more than a hundred of them, including a successful prosecution for 'trespass' on the patient. His malpractice was not discovered by inspections, but when he sold his practice on to another dentist. However, Garrett is now legally practising again. 'It's shocking. His patients were damaged psychologically and dentally. It's just awful,' said Elderton.

One practising dentist said: 'The bad guys have nothing to fear. We all know it's so hard to get struck off, the bad guys have no qualms about their work. We should treble the number of inspectors. There's a dentist in the North we know is a rogue. Every aspect of his work is below acceptable standards - all his root canals are rubbish, all his crowns are rubbish, all his fillings are rubbish. We've all reported him to the General Dental Council, but they do nothing, and he's still there five years later.'

The British Dental Association points to its surveys, which show nine in 10 people happy with their dentists. However, Gordziejko said: 'Dentists earn an average of £50,000 and are very cosy. Everyone is happy, including the patient, but there is no way they can monitor the technical quality of the work.

'Patients judge their dentist by whether they are nice and it's pain-free, which is fairly meaningless. As a patient, you have no idea what's going on in your mouth.'
