webTitle: BNFL to woo City with rejig

fields.headline: BNFL to woo City with rejig
fields.standfirst: Controversial plan would fudge £62m loss by showing investment interest as operating income
fields.trailText: British Nuclear Fuels is planning to keep government proposals for privatisation on track by rejigging its accounts so as to present a £62 million operating loss as a profit.
fields.body:
British Nuclear Fuels is planning to keep government proposals for privatisation on track by rejigging its accounts so as to present a £62 million operating loss as a profit.

In an interview with The Observer last week, chairman Hugh Collum expressed his concern that operating losses give City investors a negative picture of the company which could jeopardise his chances of delivering the Government's Public Private Partnership plans by 2002.

Collum said he was asking auditors about reclassifying income BNFL gets from interest on investments as operating income.

His strategy will be highly controversial. Earlier this month, BNFL was heavily criticised by Martin O'Neill, chairman of the influential commons Trade and Industry Select committee, for producing unclear accounts.

Last week, BNFL finance director Ross Chiese was fired as part of a management and safety shake-up unveiled by Collum and chief executive Norman Askew. Collum said: 'From running the actual business, it's operating at a loss. The way it looks at the moment, people may feel that everything is going negative.' But he said BNFL gained interest from upfront payments for fuel reprocessing - payments currently classified as financial income.

'You could argue that some of the interest you receive ought to be given credit [as operating income],' he said.

The presentation of account was crucial, Collum said: 'This is our selling document for the PPP.' He added that any changes would be within accounting rules.

Nuclear economist Gordon MacKerron of Sussex University, whose analysis of BNFL's accounts was given as evidence to the Trade and Industry Select Committee, said: 'It seems remarkable. I don't think it will fool anyone into thinking that the business is viable as an operation rather than as a manager of funds it has not earned itself, but received through historical circumstance. The fact remains that the company is operating at a loss.'

MacKerron's evidence indicated that BNFL was able to turn its 1998/9 £62m operating loss into a £228m pre-tax profit only through interest on cash and investments.

These include upfront payments for reprocessing at its Thorp plant at Sellafield in Cumbria, as well as a £2.6 billion cash pile for decommissioning when it acquired Magnox nuclear power stations in 1998 and a £3.7bn IOU from the Government.

MacKerron criticised BNFL for crediting its accounts with £249m from this IOU, even though the Treasury has not yet paid over the money. Collum says this is normal accounting practice.

BNFL's accounts are opaque, and do not indicate which parts of the business - fuel manufacturing, Thorp, engineering, decommissioning, and Magnox - are operating profitably. Magnox is likely to be the biggest loss maker. It contributed a £34m loss in the three months of 1998 during which it was included in the group, and electricity prices have fallen since then.

Collum said more precise information would be provided when the company produces its next set of accounts later this year.

fields.headline: Games do make kids aggressive
fields.standfirst: The first definitive study by US researchers shows that violence in video games such as Quake and Doom can inflict psychological damage, reports Tracy McVeigh
fields.trailText: Playing violent video games does make children more aggressive, according to the first definitive studies of the subject, to be published this week.
fields.body:
Playing violent video games does make children more aggressive, according to the first definitive studies of the subject, to be published this week.

The research results show that psychological damage can be inflicted on even occasional players of video game nasties. It suggests for the first time that violence in interactive games is far more harmful than violence on television or in films.

The scientists found that aggressive behaviour, hostile thoughts and irritability rose steeply in males and females after playing violent games. Long-term exposure to video game nasties also 'disrupts academic achievement'.

The scientific evidence comes one year after the Columbine High School shootings in Colorado which drew widespread attention to graphic violence in games.

Teenagers Dylan Klebold and Eric Harris shot dead 12 classmates and a teacher before killing themselves. A recording they left behind describes how the slaughter would be just like their favourite video game, Doom.

It came as no surprise to Professor Karen Dill, a psychologist at Lenoir-Rhyne College, North Carolina, who co-authored both research projects. Doom, used to train US Marines in warfare, Mortal Kombat and Wolfenstein 3D, were the games used in her studies. All are widely available in the UK.

'What we have shown, for the first time,' said Dill, 'is that aggressive behaviour and hostile thoughts are significantly increased in players of violent video games. They are more harmful than violent television and movies because they are very engrossing and require the player to identify with the aggressor. In a sense they provide a complete learning environment for aggression. These results are very, very worrying.'

One study looked at occasional players; the other, led by Dr Craig Anderson, looked at the effect on people already prone to aggression. 'Our study reveals that young men who are habitually aggressive may be especially vulnerable to the aggression-enhancing effects of repeated exposure to violent games,' said Anderson.

The research could spark a rash of legal actions against the game manufacturers, and Louise and Barry from Sussex may be first in the queue. Their 17-year-old son, who cannot be named for legal reasons, is in a young offenders' institution. This normally affable teenager battered his best friend with a wooden staff after a row over who owned a magazine. His 15-year-old friend was left with brain damage. The public schoolboy told a social worker how he had just 'lost all control, it was like I wanted to smash him dead, like in a computer game'.

The teenager played Doom, and Carmageddon, a game where points are awarded for running people over, for up to four hours a night. 'I thought he was just being a normal teenager and we tried to give him some space,' said his distraught mother. 'The police were interested in the games, and that was the first time I thought to have a look - I was shocked to the core. These games are tantamount to child abuse, evil.'

Violent games make up around 6 per cent of all the video games sold in the UK. But many children will have access to the games even if they do not own them. Almost as soon as Dill and her team began looking at Doom and Mortal Kombat for the two-year project, the games were surpassed by more realistic titles.

One of the most graphically violent games is called Quake. Extra 'packs' for the game can be downloaded from the Internet should you wish to add more blood, more gore and bigger and better weapons. You can scan in a face of your pal and put it on the person you're shooting in the game. Some people have put in the face of their teacher from class photos,' explains 14-year-old Michael, a schoolboy from East Kilbride. 'Then you can cut off their heads and kick them around or use them as head grenades to explode another person.'

Michael owns a copy of Doom and is all too familiar with Quake. Despite the age 15 recommendation, he bought Quake from a reputable store with no questions asked. Dill, who studied 300 college students, said: 'These are adolescents in the process of developing their ideas and attitudes. A lot of parents think because it is a game it is a cartoon. But it is far from that. They should look at some of these things. They are graphically violent.

'Also disturbing is the role of the female characters in these games. Disturbingly like pornography, they are either helpless victims or scantily clad sex objects.'

Despite the age 15 recommendation, he bought Quake from a reputable store with no questions asked. Dill, who studied 300 college students, said: 'These are adolescents in the process of developing their ideas and attitudes. A lot of parents think because it is a game it is a cartoon. But it is far from that. They should look at some of these things. They are graphically violent. 'Also disturbing is the role of the female characters in these games. Disturbingly like pornography, they are either helpless victims or scantily clad sex objects.' tracy.mcveigh@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Slick shops are proof of villainy

fields.headline: Slick shops are proof of villainy
fields.trailText: The Liffy Valley Centre was humming yesterday - parents buying Easter eggs, toddlers covered in ice cream, teenagers buying summer outfits. There was little to show that this huge shopping complex, basking in the spring sunshine, has overnight become a byword for political corruption.
fields.body:
The Liffy Valley Centre was humming yesterday - parents buying Easter eggs, toddlers covered in ice cream, teenagers buying summer outfits. There was little to show that this huge shopping complex, basking in the spring sunshine, has overnight become a byword for political corruption.

Irish people have become accustomed to sleaze in high places. There has been a plethora of inquiries and tribunals to investigate allegations of wrongdoing in the beef industry, massive tax evasion by the banks, and dubious planning decisions. Revelations that ex-Prime Minister Charles Haughey took millions from businessmen to sustain his lavish lifestyle seemed shocking enough. But these have been followed by other stories which seem to show that corruption had riddled the body politic for 20 years.

Politicians have been quick to explain that cash received was to defray election expenses. But last week the Irish public heard of major planning decisions taken by Dublin County Council in return for money given to councillors from Fianna Fail and Fine Gael.

The Flood Tribunal was hearing evidence from Frank Dunlop, a former government press secretary turned lobbyist. He told how, in 1991, he made payments totalling £112,000 to l5 members of Dublin County Council to secure a vote to allow the building of a major shopping centre in Quarryvale, on the outskirts of Dublin. The decision to build what became known as the Liffey Valley Centre was taken against the advice of the council's own senior planners and in contravention of a scheme for the redevelopment of the area.

Dunlop's goody bags ranged from £48,000 to 'a leading player' to £500 for lesser mortals. Some was handed over in cash in plastic bags, often in pubs, but on at least one occasion in the Dail bar. Sometimes the money was in response to a request for a specific sum, on other occasions it was given as a 'contribution to election expenses'. The bill was met by a property developer who employed Dunlop and who later built the Liffey Valley Centre.

Controversy surrounded the site from the start. It had already been earmarked for a town centre for Clondalkin, one of the worst areas for social deprivation. This plan was overturned in l99l when Dublin County Council voted in favour of building the Liffey Valley Centre on the Quarryvale site, which is situated just off a major motorway, out of reach to most inhabitants of Clondalkin.

At the time a rival developer said the decision was a result of money changing hands. The police had been investigating other controversial planning decisions, but were prevented from taking action by lack of evidence. The media had been following the story. They too were hamstrung by the libel laws.

The first major break came in 1995 when a firm of Newry solicitors placed an advertisement offering a reward for information about corrupt re-zoning decisions in Dublin. The initiative was taken by two Dublin barristers who found that no firm of solicitors in the Republic was willing to place the advertisement.

Within weeks more than 30 people had come forward. The first of these was a colourful and angry pensioner, former employee of a major Irish construction company. He had a tale to tell about handing money to former Minister Ray Burke.

From the start the Flood Tribunal has dealt with determined resistance from property developers and politicians, often through the courts. The difficulty has always been to establish a direct link between money given and favours received.

That changed when Dunlop appeared. His evidence carries weight because of his record as a former government press secretary with excellent contacts among all parties. He fell ill while giving evidence, but will return next month.

What makes the Liffey Valley Centre decision vital is that it was clearly taken against both the advice of the planning experts and the interests of thousands of people who live nearby. Clondalkin needed basic facilities and their lack helped cause a rise in crime. Instead it got a glitzy shopping mall, where the prices are too high for ordinary shoppers. It was a betrayal. The route to national politics in Ireland is often through local councils. It has been noted that three councillors who voted to re-zone the Liffey Valley site are now Irish MPs.

Other planning decisions of the early Nineties are now under scrutiny. Last week the Dail was full of small groups talking anxiously about what may come out next. As a major property developer said: 'This isn't over. The big story is still to come.'

webTitle: F1 fans turned away from waterlogged Silverstone

fields.headline: F1 fans turned away from waterlogged Silverstone
fields.trailText: The richest and most glamorous event in the British motorsporting calendar descended into farce yesterday when up to 50,000 fans were kept away - by muddy car parks.
fields.body:
The richest and most glamorous event in the British motorsporting calendar descended into farce yesterday when up to 50,000 fans were kept away - by muddy car parks.

Only a few thousand racing enthusiasts managed to reach the Silverstone circuit after torrential rain prompted organisers to close all car parks for emergency repairs.

Around 75,000 spectators were expected to watch drivers such as Michael Schumacher, Eddie Irvine and 20-year-old British newcomer Jenson Button battling for pole position on the grid in the final qualifying session for today's British Grand Prix.

But only about 15,000 spectators made it to the Northamptonshire track after police mounted roadblocks and fans were warned not to bring their own cars. The recent downpours had turned around 200 acres of surrounding farmland - which usually take around 30,000 cars on Grand Prix weekend - into a quagmire. And more rain was expected last night to cause more problems today.

Contractors worked all day yesterday putting down 300 tonnes of concrete to improve the car parks. Race organisers pledged that car parks would reopen today. No further problems were expected.

Those determined to catch the action regardless of the chaos ended up parking in Northampton and Oxford, 14 and 25 miles away respectively. Taxi companies reported a roaring trade - and big fares - from disgruntled F1 followers. Silverstone spokesman Peter Morris insisted that 'many, many thousands' of fans had made it to the track. But television pictures showed largely empty stands during the morning practice session and lunchtime qualifying round, both marred by further showers.

Morris said fans had shown great ingenuity in getting to Silverstone. Some had walked long distances through the countryside, others had cycled, and 4,000 others - businesspeople enjoying corporate hospitality packages - came by helicopter.

Reg Watkins, one of the fans who made it to Silverstone yesterday, said: 'Conditions are appalling. There's water everywhere. The few punters who got their cars into the car parks before they closed have been watching their vehicles sinking further and further into the mud.'

With more bad weather forecast today, there are fears that much of the sell-out crowd of 90,000 could encounter problems.

Another veteran Grand Prix-goer, Charlie Vassell, said he was expecting the worst.

'The corporate hospitality mob who come in by helicopter and have a nice cosy seat under cover in the grand stand will be OK,' he said. 'But most spectators will be on the grassy banks around the track and it looks as if we'll have a terrible time.

'The banks will all quickly turn to mud because they're so waterlogged. Plus everyone will get splashed throughout the race by the drivers' cars chucking up spray. It'll be a complete mudbath.'

This is the first time since 1993 that the British Grand Prix has been held on the Easter bank holiday weekend. In recent years it has been staged in July. Fans have criticised the FIA, motor racing's world governing body, for moving the event to a time when the weather is uncertain and the roads are busy.

The chaos surrounding today's race may force a rethink. The race is due to switch from Silverstone to Brands Hatch in 2002.

fields.headline: Web watch
fields.trailText: First Active ( www.firstactive.co.uk ) is gearing up to offer a paperless mortgage when the Government introduces electronic signatures as a substitute for written ones.
fields.body:
First Active ( www.firstactive.co.uk ) is gearing up to offer a paperless mortgage when the Government introduces electronic signatures as a substitute for written ones.

People taking out First Active mortgages can already track their applications and use a calculator facility to see, for instance, how monthly costs would be reduced by lump-sum repayments.

But visitors to websites need to be aware that many sites are better at marketing themselves than at producing competitive products. www.propwise.com, the online property gateway, is selling itself on the basis that it can point you towards the better home-hunting, letting and other property sites.

As it says: 'There has been a plethora of sites in the last year, unfortunately not all of them are very good. Sites like propwise.com can help: they have analysed all the mortgage sites in an effort to make sense of it all for you...'

People who 'want to learn more about investing in stocks and shares' are being invited by the Corporation of London and the Stock Exchange to visit their new free educational site, www.equityeducation.com

If you already know about equities, have your own portfolio and want to screen it on an ethical basis, www.ethicalservices.co.uk is after your custom. Its 'ethical fund selector' allows you to specify your own ethical and financial priorities and then view a list of funds which most closely meet your priorities. The funds can be ordered online.

You may, as with other websites, prefer to see if you can buy the funds more cheaply directly or through other advisers and brokers, rather than taking the deals being offered here.

More experienced investors may be interested in the free Nokia 7110 Wap mobile phone (above) being offered to registered users of www.moneyextra.com . The phone will make it as easy as possible to view 'Wap-enabled' sites: these sites are stripped down to a minimal level of text when viewed on a handset that meets the Wireless Application Protocol (Wap).

A site launched last week, www.moneygator.com, aims to produce a wide range of information on mortgages, credit cards and personal loans and to let users apply for those products online.

Halifax takes another step into the Internet world this week when, on Thursday, it extends Halifax online ( www.halifax.co.uk ) to include savings products.

At the moment, its online services are restricted to sharedealing and banking. But further developments are expected over the next year - including the launch of mortgage products.

fields.headline: What's the catch?
fields.trailText: Foreign companies are continuing to bombard Observer readers with details of dubious lottery schemes. One of the latest offerings comes from the Worldwide Lotteries Financial Group in Halifax, Canada, which claims that you have won a prize without even entering a lottery or competition.
fields.body:
Foreign companies are continuing to bombard Observer readers with details of dubious lottery schemes. One of the latest offerings comes from the Worldwide Lotteries Financial Group in Halifax, Canada, which claims that you have won a prize without even entering a lottery or competition.

The company says that no purchase is necessary to claim your winnings of up to £7,500, but adds: 'As a result of your recent win, we have been authorised to include you in a select group of winners who are mounting an exciting play in the Australian Lottery. The Aussie Lotto was specifically selected because it offers substantial payouts and some of the best odds of any major national lottery.'

It goes on to explain that you were selected for inclusion in this group, known as the Strategic Stakeholders, because you play to win and you're smart - even though, at this point, all you've done is receive an unsolicited mailshot. The group claims that it 'collects no dues and no purchase is ever required. We simply alert you to the remarkable opportunities available via select interna tional lotteries'. To take part in the Australian Lottery 'play' you are asked to pay from £29.95 for 8,400 chances of winning to £99.95 for 36,400 chances.

The Advertising Standards Authority has contacted the WLFG, querying the legality of the scheme.

The ASA's Chris Reed says: 'We gave them an opportunity to defend themselves and they didn't respond. We feel their silence speaks volumes.' In other words - save your money.

Readers tired of receiving junk mail from foreign lottery schemes will be glad to hear the ASA is planning to talk to the Royal Mail and consumer protection bodies in other countries to see if specific schemes can be stopped from targeting British recipients.

webTitle: Truly, he was a son of Frank

fields.headline: Truly, he was a son of Frank
fields.standfirst: Who was the real symbol of Easter week - Ricky of Walford, Harry of Enfield, or Jesus of Nazareth?
fields.trailText: Harry Enfield's Real Kevins | Dateline Jerusalem | Easter Tales | EastEnders
fields.body:
Harry Enfield's Real Kevins BBC1

Dateline Jerusalem ITV

Easter Tales BBC1

EastEnders BBC1

In a spirited Holy Week race against the Son of God, Harry Enfield - busy spreading the Word on behalf of his very own bastard comedy son, Kevin the Teenager - crossed the publicity finishing line on Friday a clear baseball cap ahead of the thorn-crowned contender.

Take, for example, this smart bit of Enfieldian cross-fertilisation from last Wednesday's Guardian : 'In my teens... I became a Jesus-like figure. [My parents] were my Romans, out to persecute me.' By allowing Enfield to brazenly muscle in on His story and failing to secure Himself a suitably peppy G2 interview - much less a slot on Film 2000 with Jonathan Ross and a documentary ( Harry Enfield's Real Kevins, also featuring Jonathan Ross) - Jesus was never going to get much of a look-in when it came to promoting what was, after all, His same-old-same-old product. These days you gotta get with the programme-makers and talk yourself up a bit! Simply having a nice round-figured anniversary to commemorate isn't enough to get them slavering in the Carlton boardroom.

As a member of a generation who didn't see any conflict between being reduced to pious teen tears at the crucifixion of Robert Powell in Jesus of Nazareth and near-hysteria at Graham Chapman's musical demise in Monty Python's Life of Brian , the current climate of extreme Christ-avoidance - eat up your all your chocolate and go to church if you absolutely must, but for God's sake don't mention J.Esus Esq in public - seems bafflingly extremist.

Against all the modish holiday godlessness, Dateline Jerusalem reworked last year's Bethlehem Year Zero - the idea of biblical tales told as breaking news stories, potentially engaging even if anchored by Martyn Lewis. As the bunny-hugging bearer of bad news (and, presumably, The Good News, too) Lewis delivered the unfolding story of the dissident rabbi, Jesus (and his gang of 12 Galilean hotheads, financed by a shady Jerusalem businessman, Lazarus) with appropriate emphasis on the potential political and social upheaval during Passover. The way they told it, this hippie bachelor from the sticks with his unconventional approach towards women and his wussy sentiments about peace and love was a Daily Mail reader's worst nightmare. By the time Jesus had got what was coming to Him, I was thinking 'good riddance. Now... better get that nice leg of lamb in the oven'.

Though the 'correspondents' oozed gravitas, we needed some youthful presenter-totty (Johnny Vaughan? Jamie Theakston? Zoë Ball? Gail Porter? Are there really no gorgeous closeted young god-botherers capable of reading an autocue?) to convincingly balance the presence of veteran (and presumably rather Christian) reporters such as 'Rome Correspondent' Denis Tuohy and 'Special Correspondent' David Jessel, who also wrote the series and, it must be said, shamelessly gave himself some of the best lines on Good Friday: 'As for the unfortunate Jesus... well, he was drawing increasingly large crowds with his speeches about overthrowing authority, social equality, freedom, justice... it's the sort of talk, quite frankly, that could get anyone executed at any time anywhere in the world!' 'Quite,' said Martyn Lewis, soberly, in the studio.

For those who haven't followed the story all week, tonight (probably) sees the last dispatch from Jerusalem, during which somebody will announce that the madly controversial and idealistic (and, of course, very dead) dreamer-schemer-wheeler-dealer prophet guy will have been spotted alive! And that Monday's Jerusalem Post will carry accusations of sleaze at the Sanhedrin. Just a hunch.

Meanwhile, BBC1's Passion Week offering, Easter Tales, made Dateline Jerusalem look like a party political broadcast on behalf of the Hardline Extremist Christian Coalition for the Rapid Extermination of Everyone Who Doesn't Believe (excluding Cher), so stringently did it seek to avoid hinting that it might bear some relation to the possible existence of a belief system pertaining to a chap called Jesus who lived in the Middle East yonks ago.

To this end we got a starry cast of thesps performing monologues designed not to scare an atheist's horses and - for reasons best known to the directors, producers or satanist-schedulers - several of these monologues were performed on a set designed to represent a Victorian lunatic asylum, so that all the characters (James Cosmo's Centurion, Tony Robinson's Judas and Helen Baxendale's Servant Girl among them) were made out to be bonkers. Is this really the best way to sell even an abstract concept of Christianity to an already highly sceptical bunch of punters?

No such sales problems for Harry Enfield, of course, who was all over last week's schedules like Barabbas let loose in a Jerusalem mall, though I felt a bit sorry for the 'real-life Kevins' who were the (surely unwitting) subjects of his documentary about teenage boys and whose entirely predictable hormonal vileness was, after all, only being exploited to sell Enfield's movie. None the less, I had to laugh at Jo Brand's deadpan voiceover: 'Oliver is 14. He's walking down the middle of the road because he's just become too mature to use the pavement.'

In fact, Oliver was a delight - his dreadful band Inanimate got to play the show's 'theme' and there was some priceless footage of Oliver shouting 'Go away, go away, go away, go away, go away. Please! Go home, go home, go home, go home_' at his parents when they foolishly turned up to see an Inanimate gig that was anything but. Frankly, I was with Oliver. 'If they tone down the heaviness maybe it will be more acceptable to a larger populace,' said Oliver's dad.

On Thursday, in EastEnders, The Ricky Formerly Known As Bianca's finally left Walford, which will hopefully put him out of his misery. Poor Fick Ricky, EastEnders 's resident cuckold-cum-romantic dreamer - he's looked ever so lost since his wicked missus disappeared up to Manchester with little Liam last autumn. 'I ain't gonna be Bianca's cast-off or Frank Butcher's deadbeat son!' he shouted, passionately, at Phil Mitchell, before hitching a ride into a new life somewhere in the EU.

Farewell then Ricky - gone, soon to be forgotten and only narrowly beaten into third place in the Easter TV celebrity egg-and-spoon race behind Harry Enfield and Jesus Christ.

Are there really no gorgeous closeted young god-botherers capable of reading an autocue?) to convincingly balance the presence of veteran (and presumably rather Christian) reporters such as 'Rome Correspondent' Denis Tuohy and 'Special Correspondent' David Jessel, who also wrote the series and, it must be said, shamelessly gave himself some of the best lines on Good Friday: 'As for the unfortunate Jesus... well, he was drawing increasingly large crowds with his speeches about overthrowing authority, social equality, freedom, justice... it's the sort of talk, quite frankly, that could get anyone executed at any time anywhere in the world!' 'Quite,' said Martyn Lewis, soberly, in the studio. For those who haven't followed the story all week, tonight (probably) sees the last dispatch from Jerusalem, during which somebody will announce that the madly controversial and idealistic (and, of course, very dead) dreamer-schemer-wheeler-dealer prophet guy will have been spotted alive! And that Monday's Jerusalem Post will carry accusations of sleaze at the Sanhedrin. Just a hunch. Meanwhile, BBC1's Passion Week offering, Easter Tales, made Dateline Jerusalem look like a party political broadcast on behalf of the Hardline Extremist Christian Coalition for the Rapid Extermination of Everyone Who Doesn't Believe (excluding Cher), so stringently did it seek to avoid hinting that it might bear some relation to the possible existence of a belief system pertaining to a chap called Jesus who lived in the Middle East yonks ago. To this end we got a starry cast of thesps performing monologues designed not to scare an atheist's horses and - for reasons best known to the directors, producers or satanist-schedulers - several of these monologues were performed on a set designed to represent a Victorian lunatic asylum, so that all the characters (James Cosmo's Centurion, Tony Robinson's Judas and Helen Baxendale's Servant Girl among them) were made out to be bonkers. Is this really the best way to sell even an abstract concept of Christianity to an already highly sceptical bunch of punters? No such sales problems for Harry Enfield, of course, who was all over last week's schedules like Barabbas let loose in a Jerusalem mall, though I felt a bit sorry for the 'real-life Kevins' who were the (surely unwitting) subjects of his documentary about teenage boys and whose entirely predictable hormonal vileness was, after all, only being exploited to sell Enfield's movie. None the less, I had to laugh at Jo Brand's deadpan voiceover: 'Oliver is 14. He's walking down the middle of the road because he's just become too mature to use the pavement.' In fact, Oliver was a delight - his dreadful band Inanimate got to play the show's 'theme' and there was some priceless footage of Oliver shouting 'Go away, go away, go away, go away, go away. Please! Go home, go home, go home, go home_' at his parents when they foolishly turned up to see an Inanimate gig that was anything but. Frankly, I was with Oliver. 'If they tone down the heaviness maybe it will be more acceptable to a larger populace,' said Oliver's dad. On Thursday, in EastEnders, The Ricky Formerly Known As Bianca's finally left Walford, which will hopefully put him out of his misery. Poor Fick Ricky, EastEnders 's resident cuckold-cum-romantic dreamer - he's looked ever so lost since his wicked missus disappeared up to Manchester with little Liam last autumn. 'I ain't gonna be Bianca's cast-off or Frank Butcher's deadbeat son!' he shouted, passionately, at Phil Mitchell, before hitching a ride into a new life somewhere in the EU. Farewell then Ricky - gone, soon to be forgotten and only narrowly beaten into third place in the Easter TV celebrity egg-and-spoon race behind Harry Enfield and Jesus Christ.

webTitle: Crime is costing UK £60bn a year

fields.headline: Crime is costing UK £60bn a year
fields.standfirst: Controversial survey includes £2bn bill for keeping 65,000 in jail and £4bn NHS spending on crime-related injuries
fields.trailText: The annual cost of crime in Britain is £60 billion - more than £1,000 a year for every man, woman and child in the country, an  Observer  study has revealed.
fields.body:
The annual cost of crime in Britain is £60 billion - more than £1,000 a year for every man, woman and child in the country, an Observer study has revealed.

The figure, which represents the money that would be saved if Britain were crime-free, derives from a unique formula that calculates the direct cost of running services, such as the police and Customs, as well as the indirect costs, such as the effect on victims.

The formula is the result of a four-year study by the leading American economist David Anderson, whose paper 'The Aggregate Burden of Crime' was recently published in the Journal of Law and Economics . It is the first time the formula has been applied to the UK.

Among the major costs are running the prison service (£1.9bn), the police force (£7bn), the courts and criminal justice system (£9bn), and the private security industry, including suppliers of guard dogs and CCTV systems (£4bn). The figure also includes the proportion of NHS funding spent dealing with crime-related injuries and drug rehabilitation - a further £4bn. Billions more come from the production of goods and services that exist only because of crime, such as locks and safes and computer virus protection software.

There is also the £156 million it costs HM Customs and Excise to combat the smuggling of drugs and other contraband, the £195m awarded to victims of crime by the Criminal Injuries Compensation Board each year, and the £1.4bn paid out by the Legal Aid Board.

The most controversial element of Anderson's formula is the finite value it places on human life - £3.81m. Anderson argues that, if life were priceless, we would devote all our time and energy to maintaining it and not get involved in risky or non-lifesaving activity. Rather than spending money on leisure activities and pleasure, all our resources would be devoted to ensuring our safety.

'Putting a value on life is something economists don't like to do, but it is absolutely essential,' he said. 'In cases where a company's negligence has led to someone being killed, we need to know how much to award that person's family. When it comes to installing safety systems to prevent fatal accidents, we have to draw the line somewhere. You can't spend £1bn per person to make the world safe; you'd have to tell them never to leave their houses, not to get in their cars, never to take a plane.'

Anderson's figure is derived from a complex algebraic formula which looks at the compromises people are willing to make to reduce the risk they are exposed to.

His formula suggests the financial impact of the 750 annual homicides in the UK is £2.85bn, with major injuries adding a further £1bn to the total. Both figures are surpassed by the cost of drug-related deaths, almost £5bn.

The prison population, now more than 65,000, is a huge expenditure. Meals alone cost £33m a year; salaries for the 43,000 staff come to more than £930m. Anderson also takes into account the fact that, if the prison population were not incarcerated, the majority would be productive members of a crime-free society. Even allowing for unemployment, the financial loss to society is breathtaking.

In addition to the direct cost of resources devoted to crime, there is a sizeable loss of time by people who are potential victims and even those who have committed crime. According to Anderson, the average person spends two minutes a day locking and unlocking their home, car or office. They also spend on average another two minutes per day looking for their keys.

'Four minutes a day may not seem much until you multiply this by 365 days a year and the 45 million adults in the country. At the average wage, the cost of this wasted time is £8bn.'

The remainder of the figure is made up of the time spent planning crimes, the time spent by victims dealing with the result of crime. There is also a significant sum from 'transfers': the cost of property and money stolen or obtained through fraud then re-sold.

'Society will never rid itself of crime,' says Anderson, 'but when you take into consideration the resources that could be conserved or reallocated in a crime-free society, the costs are absolutely staggering.'

webTitle: Trust Boots managers to keep on polishing...

fields.headline: Trust Boots managers to keep on polishing...
fields.trailText: Throg Street
fields.body:
Shares in Boots, the high street retailer, have halved in the past 18 months. Surely a classic example of an old economy stock now ripe for a rerating? Not according to broker CSFB, which believes Boots' core chemist chain faces a bleak future.

Its sales, margins and profits are being squeezed on all fronts. Prices of its health and beauty products are falling; fewer customers are visiting its stores; competition from supermarkets is intensifying. Its Advantage loyalty card is not working as well as expected. And its profits face a further lurch downwards when the Restrictive Practices Court investigates the bizarre price-fixing of Resale Price Maintenance on many pharmaceutical products.

Boots accepts some of this analysis although not, predictably enough, CSFB's conclusion. And it is taking action to address all the potential threats. Its market share has been falling but not, it insists, in its core areas of health and beauty. It is phasing out some of the 'weaker areas' - CSFB points to gifts and homewares as likely casualties - so that it can devote more space to the stronger areas. Footfall through its stores has been declining. But, it points out, the launch of the Advantage credit card, in conjunction with Egg, gives holders a positive incentive to shop more and gain extra points.

Prices are falling, but it is passing some of that on to suppliers, and cutting £160 million from costs over the next four years. Supermarkets have always been fierce competitors, but Boots' research suggests customers prefer its strategy of three-for-twos and other special offers.

There is more: indeed, the pace of activity at Boots is positively frenetic. It is experimenting with new store formats - one, Boots Men, is already being tried out in Bristol and Edinburgh, but there will be others. It is opening more out-of-town stores, aiming to treble its current complement of 150, having found that sales through these are extra, not switched from high street shops. It is extending its range of services: adding dentists, GP surgeries and chiropodists as well as opticians. It will not comment on reports that it is also considering a chain of health clubs, but these would fit comfortably into its business.

CSFB accepts all of these, but questions whether the ini tiatives will quite compensate for the intense pressure on its core business. Others, JP Morgan for example, come to a different conclusion.

What is certain is that the climate for retailers has never been tougher. Boots is used to competition and has managed consistently to increase profits. But price deflation will make that much harder to achieve, even without other competitive pressures. In the summer Boots is losing a strong leader in Lord Blyth, although new chief executive Steve Russell knows the chemist business inside out.

On a prospective price/ earnings ratio of less than 12, the shares are discounting a lot of bad news. That makes it worth trusting the management to carry on delivering.

Get out Kwik
KwiK Save is not a dead brand; its owners simply haven't loved it enough. So said new chief executive Alan Smith as he announced a complete reversal of the strategy being pursued by his predecessor, David Simons. No more disposals - beyond the 41 larger Somerfield stores for which contracts have already been agreed. No more conversions of Kwik Saves to the Somerfield fascia.

In truth, had Simons stayed around a bit longer, he would also have had to admit that his strategy was not going to work. It is just a bit less embarrassing for Smith, as he had nothing to do with implementing it in the first place.

Simons's strategy for Kwik Save looked flawed from the start. True, the business was in decline when Somerfield bought it: the large superstores were encroaching further and further into its dis count market. Adding it to Somerfield, and doubling the combined purchasing power, looked an eminently sensible move.

Simons's mistake was to assume that Kwik Save's problems stemmed from failure of its brand rather than failure of its pricing power. The Kwik Save name is still much stronger than Somerfield's. At least customers know that it is meant to represent value shopping, even though the offer sometimes failed to meet the expectation.

If Somerfield stood for anything after numerous name and fascia changes, it was expensive convenience shopping. It is, therefore, hardly surprising that Kwik Save customers were not happy when their local stores became Somerfields. Simons may not have wanted to admit that conversions caused sales to plummet, but the new management can be more honest. Its opinion of the conversion programme shows in the fact that it is abandoning plans to rebrand 400 Kwik Save stores.

It is also hardly surprising that staff and management at the Kwik Save stores felt demoralised. Underperform ing stores with demoralised managements are not going to attract queues of buyers willing to pay astronomical prices. Hence the decision to abandon the sales process.

The challenge for the new management is to turn these stores around. Smith is probably right that brands are resilient, but nursing them back to health takes time and effort and the City is impatient for results. It also has to prove it can make a success of running Somerfield as a convenience chain.

Somerfield is a bigger chain and the market is even more competitive than when Budgens started its recovery. Investors should steer clear of the shares until there is evidence of achievement.

Bill did it himself
Wickes is a good example of what new management can do to reinvigorate a tarnished brand and a demoralised workforce. Bill Grimsey, who took over as chief executive in 1996, has reinforced Wickes' position at the heavy end of the do-it-yourself market, brought it to financial stability and embarked on a sensible growth strategy.

FDIA, as the combined Focus and Do It All chain is now called, knows this. It is bidding a cheeky 375p cash, hoping to take advantage of investors' dislike of retail. As a private company backed by venture capitalists, FDIA has to give only sketchy details of its performance and, while its growth looks impressive, there is nothing to suggest that its chief executive Bill Archer could do much to better Grimsey's performance.

FDIA will succeed only if it offers far more than the current price. Wickes deserves its independence.

fields.headline: A supper worth singing about
fields.standfirst: You don't need a cast of thousands to make a biblical epic, as Harrison Birtwistle's magnificent new opera demonstrates
fields.trailText: The Last Supper
fields.body:
The Last Supper Deutsche Staatsoper, Berlin

Bewitched by numbers, codes and ciphers, Harrison Birtwistle hears the world as an irresistible mystery of patterns and correlations. Their arcane beauty is built into the brickwork of his music in a way that our senses discern, even if our ears may not always hear.

His new opera, The Last Supper, which was given a resounding first performance in Berlin last Tuesday, is no exception. It opens with a dark fortissimo roar of tuba, timpani and synthesiser belting out 12 low D flats (which on a piano would be at that deep extremity of the keyboard where the ear begins to hear grumbles rather than notes). Out of this urgent, primeval sound, an eloquent trumpet fanfare emerges like light out of darkness. Of course, it's possible to read too much into this characteristic Birtwistle-esque juxtaposition of sounds. Yet it is not too far-fetched to see in those opening bars the seeds of the entire opera, whose subject matter is the encounter between the 12 disciples and Christ at the Last Supper.

Birtwistle has set his chamber opera to a specially written text by the Canadian poet Robin Blaser (b 1925), rich in allusion and magpie borrowings from Christian liturgy, the Metaphysical poets and other sources ancient and modern. On paper it looked worryingly over-burdened, with interjections of Latin and Greek, aphoristic wisdoms and quasi-liturgical repetitions. But it was written to be sung not read, and in the theatre worked with astonishing clarity and good sense, a model libretto with barely a word in excess and most of it audible, especially when it most mattered.

The work, labelled 'dramatic tableaux' by the creators, is set at the turn of the second millennium and looks back to that meeting between Christ and his disciples, as it was then and as it might be if a second chance were permitted. A chorus figure named 'Ghost', sung by the soprano Susan Bickley who negotiated a long and challenging vocal line with formidable ease, provides a commentary. Acting as an ever-present representation of the Holy Spirit and an intermediary between human and divine, she invites the disciples to supper 'once again - over bread and wine'.

One by one they gather, appearing as if in slow motion though a brightly-lit tunnel in the centre of the stage. Each is sharply delineated in music and speech, 'ordinary salt-of-the-earth men caught up in something extraordinary', as Birtwistle has put it. James 'the Great' and James 'the Less', here called Little James, are paired vocally as countertenors, giving a striking timbre to the men's voices, otherwise split between tenors and baritones/basses.

A question mark hangs over whether or not Judas, too, has been invited. They hope he hasn't. Suddenly, unnoticed, he arrives, adding 'Amen' to their singing of (a variant on) the Lord's Prayer. He carries a bolt of red cloth, the only noticeable colour in Alison Chitty's severely handsome, open-box design, otherwise dominated by shades of indigo and grey. Judas's arrival shocks, presaging the arrival of Christ, also unnoticed and dressed in white, in the mirroring style of a medieval mystery play. He atones for the disciples' sins, washing their feet one by one, reciting a litany of Man's crimes over the past 2,000 years.

All are generic - the unmournable wars and killing fields, discrimination of man against man - except when it comes to Judas. At that point, Jesus turns to face the audience and sings 'The Holocaust shattered my heart'.

To hear that line without flinching would be impossible, especially in Berlin, with its daily preoccupation with the new Liebeskind Jewish Museum and the prominent Holocaust memorial next to the Brandenberg Gate in preparation. Yet this literalness was in danger of endorsing the narrow focus of our times which judges, or would seem to judge, this as mankind's sole atrocity. It certainly struck an awkward note, though the moment passed without undue emphasis. After the supper, with all its intimations of betrayal, the work ends with Christ's voice asking out of the darkness 'Whom do you seek?' A cock crows and the curtain falls. In the end is also the beginning.

This enthralling work, which runs without interval for two hours, has three main sections: Ghost's opening narration, the reunion of the disciples and their pagan-like dance, and the supper with Christ. Intercutting these sections, but not demarcating them, are three Visions. Like the Passing Clouds in Birtwistle's 1984 opera The Mask of Orpheus, they add another layer to the narrative (or anti-narrative, as it might better be called). In Martin Duncan's clear, unobtrusive staging, these Visions are enacted by a dumb-show on high at the back of the stage, based on precisely replicated images by Zurbaran. The Crucifixion, the Stations of the Cross and the Betrayal - in reverse order of events as we think of them - are played out, while a scintillating cascade of pre-recorded voices, electronic and live sounds play round the auditorium.

The orchestral writing, skilfully handled by the Staatsoper orchestra under Daniel Barenboim, is sparse, with only 33 players in the pit. Much of it is antiphonal, featuring pairings of woodwind in the style of Bach's Passions (with which the entire work has many resonances). With no violins and an emphasis on low woodwind - alto flutes, cor anglais, bass clarinets and double bassoon - Birtwistle has created a powerfully melancholic soundworld, at once richly lyrical and hieratic.

Throughout, either the vocal line or an obbligato instrument seems to forge through the piece like a stratum, over and above which instruments rush and buzz in flurries of agitated semiquavers like energised iron filings round a magnet. Creating yet another layer, the Chorus Mysticus - nine amplified female voices - and a pre-recorded chorus sing their own, Palestrina-like plainchant, but here the intervals are squeezed and dissonant. Stravinsky's Oedipus Rex is ever a distant echo.

The British cast was outstanding, led by Thomas Randle and William Dazeley as Judas and Christ. The work, commissioned by Glyndebourne with the Staatsoper Berlin and the Royal Festival Hall, has further performances in Berlin between now and June. The British premiere (given by Glyndebourne Touring Opera) takes place on 21 October. The cheers and applause lasted 15 minutes. Book now.

A question mark hangs over whether or not Judas, too, has been invited. They hope he hasn't. Suddenly, unnoticed, he arrives, adding 'Amen' to their singing of (a variant on) the Lord's Prayer. He carries a bolt of red cloth, the only noticeable colour in Alison Chitty's severely handsome, open-box design, otherwise dominated by shades of indigo and grey. Judas's arrival shocks, presaging the arrival of Christ, also unnoticed and dressed in white, in the mirroring style of a medieval mystery play. He atones for the disciples' sins, washing their feet one by one, reciting a litany of Man's crimes over the past 2,000 years. All are generic - the unmournable wars and killing fields, discrimination of man against man - except when it comes to Judas. At that point, Jesus turns to face the audience and sings 'The Holocaust shattered my heart'. To hear that line without flinching would be impossible, especially in Berlin, with its daily preoccupation with the new Liebeskind Jewish Museum and the prominent Holocaust memorial next to the Brandenberg Gate in preparation. Yet this literalness was in danger of endorsing the narrow focus of our times which judges, or would seem to judge, this as mankind's sole atrocity. It certainly struck an awkward note, though the moment passed without undue emphasis. After the supper, with all its intimations of betrayal, the work ends with Christ's voice asking out of the darkness 'Whom do you seek?' A cock crows and the curtain falls. In the end is also the beginning. This enthralling work, which runs without interval for two hours, has three main sections: Ghost's opening narration, the reunion of the disciples and their pagan-like dance, and the supper with Christ. Intercutting these sections, but not demarcating them, are three Visions. Like the Passing Clouds in Birtwistle's 1984 opera The Mask of Orpheus, they add another layer to the narrative (or anti-narrative, as it might better be called). In Martin Duncan's clear, unobtrusive staging, these Visions are enacted by a dumb-show on high at the back of the stage, based on precisely replicated images by Zurbaran. The Crucifixion, the Stations of the Cross and the Betrayal - in reverse order of events as we think of them - are played out, while a scintillating cascade of pre-recorded voices, electronic and live sounds play round the auditorium. The orchestral writing, skilfully handled by the Staatsoper orchestra under Daniel Barenboim, is sparse, with only 33 players in the pit. Much of it is antiphonal, featuring pairings of woodwind in the style of Bach's Passions (with which the entire work has many resonances). With no violins and an emphasis on low woodwind - alto flutes, cor anglais, bass clarinets and double bassoon - Birtwistle has created a powerfully melancholic soundworld, at once richly lyrical and hieratic. Throughout, either the vocal line or an obbligato instrument seems to forge through the piece like a stratum, over and above which instruments rush and buzz in flurries of agitated semiquavers like energised iron filings round a magnet. Creating yet another layer, the Chorus Mysticus - nine amplified female voices - and a pre-recorded chorus sing their own, Palestrina-like plainchant, but here the intervals are squeezed and dissonant. Stravinsky's Oedipus Rex is ever a distant echo. The British cast was outstanding, led by Thomas Randle and William Dazeley as Judas and Christ. The work, commissioned by Glyndebourne with the Staatsoper Berlin and the Royal Festival Hall, has further performances in Berlin between now and June. The British premiere (given by Glyndebourne Touring Opera) takes place on 21 October. The cheers and applause lasted 15 minutes. Book now.

fields.headline: Move over, Shania
fields.standfirst: In America, Faith Hill is country music's biggest star. But are model looks and slick ballads enough to succeed in Britain?
fields.trailText: In America, Faith Hill is country music's biggest star. But are model looks and slick ballads enough to succeed in Britain?
fields.body:
She's not famous here yet, but give her six months and Faith Hill could be the new Shania Twain - and not only in the sense that she looks more like a supermodel than a country singer. Twain's Come On Over - the UK's biggest selling album of 1999 - has redefined the perception of country music in Britain, and Hill, already a superstar in her native US, is poised to follow in Shania's rhinestone bootsteps.

Only in country would a crossover artist be considered radical. In this respect and no other, Faith Hill is one rad chick. Her fourth album, the lush and super-slick Breathe, entered the US Billboard Top 100 chart in the number one slot, breaking Shania's record for the biggest-selling debut-week album by a country star.

Faith and I are enjoying tea together in a top-floor suite at Park Lane's Four Seasons hotel. Tall, svelte and decked out in a country chic ensemble of tight, white, tasselled leathers and what looks like Dorothy's ruby shoes, she is undeniably drop-dead gorgeous and I tell her so. 'Thank you,' she smiles sweetly.

Hill readily agrees that her fortunate looks mixed with a seemingly good-natured disposition and down-home charm haven't exactly hurt her career. In the country glam sweepstakes she's at the front of the cattle call. Already she has graced the covers of American Vogue, Glamour and Redbook, and is the face of a recent Cover Girl make-up ad campaign. 'They wanted a career woman who has a family and they chose me,' she says glowingly.

In contrast to the Dixie Chicks or Mindy McCready, gleefully singing songs about killing their man, Faith Hill does not court controversy. She seems very sweet, faultlessly polite. But sometimes the gracious Southern belle persona can be a bit overwhelming, and in interviews she tends towards yawn-inducing blandness.

Is she really like this or is she acting? If so, she sure is good at it. Perhaps a movie career beckons? 'Oh, I've been offered a few scripts but nothing that's stood out.' What kind of movie could see yourself in, Faith? 'Oh, gosh, something like Steel Magnolias or Erin Brockovich. Something with a strong woman character.'

Born in the small town of Star, Mississippi, 32 years ago, Hill moved to Nashville at 19 after years of singing locally in churches, fairs - wherever. She grew up listening to gospel, rhythm and blues and country crooners like Tammy Wynette. 'You can probably hear a bit of Tammy in my voice.'

In her soft Southern burr she explains: 'It was four or five years before I was discovered by Warner Brothers. During that time I was, I guess, networking. Just figuring out how the town worked.' To make ends meet, she took a job in the merchandising division of country legend Reba McEntire's empire. 'I was responsible for filling orders for her fan club.'

In 1989 she auditioned for a place in Reba's touring band. She didn't get the gig. This turned out to be a lucky break in disguise: a few years later Reba lost most of that group in a plane crash over San Diego.

Hill's 1994 debut Take Me As I Am was followed by two more multi-platinum-selling albums. The country-pop single 'This Kiss' reached number 13 in the UK at the end of 1998. She's married to fellow country star Tim McGraw, who lends his vocal sensitivities to their duet 'Let's Make Love', and they have two young daughters, Gracie and Maggie. The couple, who fell for each other in 1996 on the auspiciously named Spontaneous Combustion tour, have made a vow not to spend more than three days apart. When touring, the whole family travel on an elegant monstrosity of a bus 'designed' by Faith with the children in mind. 'I wanted something child-safe, lots of clean lines - not much clutter,' she laughs.

We talk about her recent performance at this year's Academy Awards and the VH1 Divas Live 2000 event with Diana Ross, Mariah Carey and Donna Summer. How does she think the British will take to the country-tinged single 'Breathe'? 'They'll hear it's not Patsy Cline, it's not Loretta Lynn, but hopefully it's something that they'll dig. That it's beautiful, simple... sensual.'

A languid lullaby to intimacy, it starts softly then builds to the mother of all power-ballad choruses, climaxing in an alluring falsetto warble: 'Caught up in the touch/ The slow and steady rush/ Baby isn't that the way that love's supposed to be/ I can feel you breathe_' It's already a Nashpop crossover classic. Faith confesses she is often moved to tears when per forming it. I ask who she has in mind when she sings it? 'My husband, of course,' she giggles. Of course.

Unlike Loretta, Tammy and even Shania, she hasn't struggled from that dirt-poor, traditionally tragic background we've come to expect from our country queens. She's a glamour girl whose favoured designers are, in no particular order: 'Gucci, Prada, Richard Tyler, Versace, Ralph Lauren...' She fingers the tassels on her white leather jeans and laughs. 'But I'm still a country girl at heart.'

 Breathe is released on 15 May on WEA

fields.headline: Frederick the great?
fields.standfirst: Ashton's Dante Sonata has been revived after 50 years
fields.trailText: Dante Sonata
fields.body:
Dante Sonata Birmingham Hippodrome

The start of a new century has stirred debate about the nature and nurture of British ballet, as artistic directors come and go. Northern Ballet Theatre has just parted company with its new Italian director, Stefano Giannetti, Scottish Ballet frets over its national identity and the appointment of Australian Ross Stretton as Anthony Dowell's successor raises the question of whether the Royal Ballet has a sacred duty to preserve a uniquely English heritage.

The temptation for any director taking over a company must be to acquire works by famous or fashionable choreographers under-represented in the repertoire. As a result, big ballet companies increasingly resemble each other. The Royal Ballet tries to cover all bases by veering between international aspirations and revivals of its signature works. Its sister company in Birmingham has been more consistent in building up its own catalogue of British ballets, first under the direction of Peter Wright, then of David Bintley.

Bintley has contributed his creations on English themes - Arthur, Edward II, Far from the Madding Crowd - while reviving 'out-of-print' works by the company's founder-choreographers, Ninette de Valois and Frederick Ashton. The latest addition, in a well-chosen Ashton triple bill, is Dante Sonata, unseen for 50 years. Ashton started work on it in 1939. After its January 1940 premiere at Sadler's Wells, the doom-laden ballet was toured throughout the war.

However, Dante Sonata seemed out of kilter with the times and was dropped from the repertoire. All that remained for later generations were photographs of its barefoot cast against the etched white lines of Sophie Fedorovitch's backdrop.

Fortunately, Jean Bedells, then an impressionable young dancer, has retained her prodigious memory and prompted others to supply any missing bits. BRB's revival may not be exact in every detail, but the mood of the period would be impossible to recapture. We can only look at the work as an example of turbulent Ashton, expressing torments of anxiety and frustration that were widely shared.

Ashton was careful to be non-specific about his combatants. He divided them into the Children of Light, in white draperies, and the Children of Darkness, with black, snake-like coils around their bodies. The cast are clear relations of de Valois's biblical characters in her 1931 Job, with Satan the model for Ashton's leader of the forces of darkness. Job is a hieratic ballet, marked by still poses and carefully composed groupings.

Dante Sonata's frenzy is closer to Isadora Duncan's pliant plastique: the flying feet and curving arms are reminiscent of the Isadora waltzes that Ashton recreated for Lynn Seymour.

The baddies get the most dramatic steps, with the exception of a white-clad Cassandra figure bewailing her way through the angelic hosts. Whipping her hair and pounding her fists, she expresses the despair that her pure-in-heart colleagues dare not confess. Margot Fonteyn's soulful role as the leader of the Children of Light went to Monica Zamora, huge, dark eyes longing in hope. Her male counterpart has a Spartacus role, confronting evil only to be crucified for his defiance. Both groups, light and dark, end up in cruciform tableaux side by side: no one triumphs in this anguished account of a world where innocence cannot prevail against evil.

Although the subject matter is timeless, Ashton's treatment is not: the intricacy of the groupings, the lavishness of the upper-body movements and the overwrought emotions prevent the ballet from being monumental, out of its wartime context. Dante Sonata is an important part of English ballet history but it is not a classic.

fields.headline: Stockwatch
fields.trailText: Glaxo Wellcome | Hammerson | Tempus Group
fields.body:
Astra logical
Stronger -than-expected results from soon-to-be-joined SmithKline Beecham and Glaxo Wellcome got the markets on the drugs again last week. Everybody's favourite blue-chip sector in pre-history looks like pepping up again - Glaxo returned to double-digit sales growth in the first quarter and SB reported a 10 per cent profits surge for the same period.

Astra Zeneca also gained 73p to reach 2847p, but there may be a little more medicine in the chest for investors. Patents on its Losec gastrointestinal treatment - for acid suppression and heartburn - look like expiring in October 2001, although they could last for longer than this.

The market will see similarities between this and Glaxo's experience with Zantac. But the company is confident that Nexium, its new gastrointestinal product, will outperform generic competition after the Losec patent expiry, keeping it ahead in the digestion market.

Astra is expected to launch the product in Europe this year and in America - where the company has a big sales force - early next year. Analysts point to worldwide sales of $US3.5 billion (£2.2bn) by 2003 - blockbuster territory.

Salomon Smith Barney has set a target price of 3000p. It's risky, but there may still be value there.

Land fit for heroes
Hostile bid talk in the maligned property sector just won't go away. Stories circulating this week suggest that Hammerson, Britain's fourth- largest landlord, is being targeted by a German fund.

This story may well be a case of 'Easter bunny' but there are plenty of nervous executives anxiously anticipating unwelcome predators.

And they don't come much more nervous than at Land Securities, where Liberty International, the property and financial services group, has snatched a 3.4 per cent stake in Britain's only Footsie 100 property company.

LandSec has been desperately concentrating on its larger assets and is also buying back its own shares to shore up its defences in case a bid materialises. Trading at a 35 per cent discount to net asset value, it is regarded as slow and conservative. But its £7bn portfolio includes some of the country's premier shopping centres, and office developments in some of London's most expensive locations.

Analysts now believe that shares in LandSec, which last Thursday closed at 748.5p, have bottomed out.

Less than two years ago, Land nudged over the 1150p mark. While no one is suggesting that its shares may hit those heights, a buy now could see reasonable long-term growth.

Tempus flies
Tempus Group, the media buying business, has suffered of late from the end of the romance with TMTs - Technology Media and Telecoms - and seen its share price fall off a small cliff. Still priced at over twice its market valuation a year ago, the company has suffered from losing clients via its CIA subsidiary.

However, it has also shown, through its new online divisions, some promising growth. The historically difficult UK subsidiary, CIA UK, is perceived to be doing better under the guiding hand of experienced adman David Wheldon. It is also encouraging that Tempus has decided not to rush into spinning off Outrider as a sort of dot.com hybrid.

It is particularly encouraging that new business of £391 million makes Tempus, comparatively, the top performer in the marketing services sector. Broker West LB Panmure is tipping the stock as a 'buy' with a target price of 613p.

If the company can maintain growth rates and hit its margin targets, this does not look overly ambitious. A lot rests with the management's ability to maintain turnaround momentum, but so far the omens look reasonably good. Buy.

fields.headline: Don't vote for a philistine
fields.standfirst: By ignoring the arts, London's mayoral hopefuls are snubbing the city
fields.trailText: By ignoring the arts, London's mayoral hopefuls are snubbing the city
fields.body:
If you were wanting to clone artistic geniuses, you could find no richer environment for them to grow up in than London. Your little cyber-Mozart, replicant Keats or Miles Davis clone would flourish in such a cosmopolitan capital city.

They would find new cultural traditions forming in front of their eyes from the clashing and sparking of rival old ones. They would be faced by an arts audience more adventurous than any other in the world.

Provided that they had a private income, a business sponsor or a wealthy patron and had been cybermorphed into a comfortable, white, middle-class family. Because, increasingly, that's what you need to make your creative way in Europe's cultural capital.

Oh, did I hear a mayoral candidate speaking dynamically about investment in London as a cultural capital? Yes, but that was Jeffrey Archer in 1998. The current candidates avoid the subject like the plague. Even 'Cultural Ken' is reduced to iso lated promises about St Patrick's Day celebrations and grants to attend London Zoo. It's absurd. The arts in London are at the heart of its success. The creative industries sparkle with investment opportunities and offer tools for social regeneration. Why is it that the piping-hot bloodstream of our culture has become such a cold political potato?

One evening last year, I went to the Houses of Parliament to find out. I was to address a collection of befuddled MPs and lords on the subject of the arts in London. I planned to tell them that one third of Britain's artists lived in London; that artists, like penguins, thrive in groups and that London was sitting on an emperor colony if only it would invest in it.

I would plead that any business entrepreneur overseeing Britain's creative industry would die for an R&D lab such as London's fringe - and would have investors queuing to buy it. I wanted them to think about how art works as a lens through which a fractured or changing culture can explore its identity.

It stuck in my craw that none of Chris Smith's wad of lottery cash for the arts had been prioritised for London's needs. No one had raised a voice to say that it was potentially the richest cultural city in the world and that an artistically vibrant London was good for the nation.

But I was wasting my time. Of the 74 London MPs, only three turned up. The audience was made up of civil servants and peers, earnest smiles on their faces and expiry dates inked on their flanks. Capitalising on bad press about the cost of the Royal Opera House, pressure groups of regional MPs have made a powerful case for taking arts funding to the countryside. The people who should have been making the case for prioritising funding in London probably didn't even bother to show up.

That's why we need a mayor for London, said hopeful deputy Trevor Phillips, attending the meeting in his capacity as chair of the London Arts Board. But what have we heard about the arts in the mayoral campaign? Nothing. So, Steve, Frank, Sue and Ken, wake up. Sing the praises of London as the cultural capital of Europe and don't fall into all the traps that make politicians terrified to talk about art.

Don't talk about the Opera House. Soon, it will be a thriving business. Do boast about London's status as a world centre for culture (205 theatres, 104 cinemas, 1,500 theatre companies, 2.5 million regular art-watchers).

Do talk about London as the gateway to the nation (76 per cent of visitors are here for the art) and argue that if culture in London is humming, properly invested arts in the regions will hum better themselves.

Do argue that the arts cannot be truly representative until people from every part of London's culture can afford to join in. Don't compare attendance figures for theatre and football (theatre wins hands down, incidentally). Theatre is far less exciting than football at the moment and it doesn't take a great cultural commentator to point that out.

Do emphasise the financial scale of cultural activity in London (more than 7 per cent of GDP). Don't prevent artists from working while they are on benefit. Do talk about London's unrivalled community of young artists as an asset for cultural research and development. The business community will understand.

Do use the language of social inclusion to explain why we should invest in community arts activities. Do celebrate the innovation of London's artists. Businesses understand that too. Don't think that talking to Damon Albarn constitutes supporting the arts. According to the form book, between now and 4 May, the arts will slide off the political agenda as sleekly as Torvill and Dean.

Don't let it happen, you mayors-to-be. Open your political throats and feel the roar of culture. Just for once. I don't want to have to tell little Keats to give up on poetry and become a spin doctor.

fields.bodyText: If you were wanting to clone artistic geniuses, you could find no richer environment for them to grow up in than London. Your little cyber-Mozart, replicant Keats or Miles Davis clone would flourish in such a cosmopolitan capital city. They would find new cultural traditions forming in front of their eyes from the clashing and sparking of rival old ones. They would be faced by an arts audience more adventurous than any other in the world. Provided that they had a private income, a business sponsor or a wealthy patron and had been cybermorphed into a comfortable, white, middle-class family. Because, increasingly, that's what you need to make your creative way in Europe's cultural capital. Oh, did I hear a mayoral candidate speaking dynamically about investment in London as a cultural capital? Yes, but that was Jeffrey Archer in 1998. The current candidates avoid the subject like the plague. Even 'Cultural Ken' is reduced to iso lated promises about St Patrick's Day celebrations and grants to attend London Zoo. It's absurd. The arts in London are at the heart of its success. The creative industries sparkle with investment opportunities and offer tools for social regeneration. Why is it that the piping-hot bloodstream of our culture has become such a cold political potato? One evening last year, I went to the Houses of Parliament to find out. I was to address a collection of befuddled MPs and lords on the subject of the arts in London. I planned to tell them that one third of Britain's artists lived in London; that artists, like penguins, thrive in groups and that London was sitting on an emperor colony if only it would invest in it. I would plead that any business entrepreneur overseeing Britain's creative industry would die for an R&D lab such as London's fringe - and would have investors queuing to buy it. I wanted them to think about how art works as a lens through which a fractured or changing culture can explore its identity. It stuck in my craw that none of Chris Smith's wad of lottery cash for the arts had been prioritised for London's needs. No one had raised a voice to say that it was potentially the richest cultural city in the world and that an artistically vibrant London was good for the nation. But I was wasting my time. Of the 74 London MPs, only three turned up. The audience was made up of civil servants and peers, earnest smiles on their faces and expiry dates inked on their flanks. Capitalising on bad press about the cost of the Royal Opera House, pressure groups of regional MPs have made a powerful case for taking arts funding to the countryside. The people who should have been making the case for prioritising funding in London probably didn't even bother to show up. That's why we need a mayor for London, said hopeful deputy Trevor Phillips, attending the meeting in his capacity as chair of the London Arts Board. fields.headline: Samba enchanted evening...
fields.standfirst: Virgínia Rodrigues Barbican, London EC2
fields.trailText: Virgínia Rodrigues
fields.body:
Last Wednesday, the Barbican was filled to capacity for the third London appearance of the extraordinary young Brazilian contralto Virgínia Rodrigues. Hers was the sonorous voice that almost stole the show last November at the Royal Albert Hall, when more than 5,000 people witnessed the greatest line-up of Brazilian performers ever, anywhere in the world. For me, it was like dying and going to heaven. I lived in Brazil in the mid-Sixties, saw the young Chico Buarque, Caetano Veloso, his sister Maria Bethnia and his friend Gilberto Gil performing live in So Paulo, and was hooked. Years later, in my new life, I came to publish Chico's two novels and we became good friends. The remarkable thing is that these kings and queens of samba, all now in their fifties, are still at the top of their game. But on Wednesday we were watching the new generation emerging.

In her earlier appearances, Rodrigues had stunned audiences with the resonance and power of her voice - one critic was moved to compare it to 'African honey spilling out of a golden comb. You can taste it' - but she herself had come across as a passive vessel: contained, restrained and overwhelmingly melancholy. Last week, another Virgínia shone through. She sailed majestically on to the stage resplendent in a golden coat, beaming like the sun coming up in the Bay of All the Saints. Her opening notes pealed out as if they were being flung from a mountain top.

Rodrigues was born 33 years ago in Salvador Da Bahia, the home of Carnival. She grew up in a poor family and started singing as a four-year-old, picking up church music from her maternal grandparents. She left school at 12, and began working as a manicurist. Later, she appeared in a small role with Olodum, the renowned street theatre company of Bahia, where Rodrigues was overheard by the great singer-composer Veloso. He was moved to tears and then to action. He took Virgínia under his wing and two years ago produced her stunning first CD, Sol Negro. Concert appearances in New York, Berlin and London followed, and this year, another acclaimed album, Nós .

The Barbican show was wonderfully varied, featuring traditional sambas, elements of jazz, blues and Gregorian chants. The six versatile musicians who accompanied her on a dazzling array of instruments were an integral part of the performance. Towards the end they gradually left the stage, until Rodrigues was alone, singing a cappella: a cascade of swooping notes that rose then plummeted with death-defying audacity and total control. She was obviously enjoying herself: she samba-ed, she shook, she sashayed, hands wafting like butterflies around her. The audience gave back grateful ovations.

In the greenroom afterwards, golden coat discarded, her feet thrust into floral flip-flops, Virgínia has sunk into a chair and is drinking a Coke with relish. 'I sing what I like. My influences are from everywhere. From the church, from Candomblé [the African religion prevalent in Bahia], from my black ancestors, from the radio, from the world.' Despite a major American tour last month, she is clearly eager for further concerts in Belgium, France, Spain, Portugal, Germany and Italy. She then goes on tour in Brazil. 'I am black. I am poor. I am a woman.' Coming from her, these apparent drawbacks must be seen as advantages. The message is clear. And it can only bring joy and hope wherever her voice is heard.
