fields.headline: Wall Street trash
fields.standfirst: American Psycho is a long book, but a mercifully brief movie
fields.trailText: American Psycho | The Story of Us | Kevin and Perry Go Large | Night Train | Earth | Sex: The Annabel Chong Story
fields.body:
American Psycho (101 mins, 18) Directed by Mary Harron; starring Christian Bale, Willem Dafoe, Reese Witherspoon

The Story of Us (96 mins, 15) Directed by Rob Reiner; starring Bruce Willis, Michelle Pfeiffer

Kevin and Perry Go Large (82 mins, 15) Directed by Ed Bye; starring Harry Enfield, Kathy Burke, Rhys Ifans

Night Train (92 mins, nc) Directed by John Lynch; starring John Hurt, Brenda Blethyn

Earth (106 mins, 15) Directed by Deepa Mehta; starring Aamir Khan, Nandita Das, Rahul Khanna

Sex: The Annabel Chong Story (87 mins, 18) Directed by Gough Lewis

Back in 1991, Bret Easton Ellis's novel American Psycho shocked readers with its cool account of Patrick Bateman, the fashion-conscious Wall Street broker who works on 'mergers and acquisitions' by day and 'murders and executions' by night. Mary Harron's movie version, co-scripted by feminist Guinevere Turner, isn't likely to shock anyone, partly because their mercifully brief adaptation of the book is a comic turn, and partly because the serial killer has become one of the cinema's stock characters this past decade.

Bateman was clearly named to echo America's most famous movie psycho, Norman Bates, but the characters he most resembles are those more recent sociopathic figures fleeing from or attracted to the upper middle-class high life played by Edward Norton in Fight Club, Jude Law and Matt Damon in The Talented Mr Ripley, and Kevin Spacey in American Beauty. This very knowing picture, lit to give the New York scene a hard, metallic surface, is set in the Eighties, the 'me decade' that was supposedly more self-seeking than the 'caring Nineties'. Bateman is a man without any sense of identity who tends his body as if it were a sports car, tuning the engine with exercise, treating the surface with unguents. He's the ultimate other-directed man, caring only about acquisition, status and consumption. This narcissist is so empty that he seeks to externalise his inner turbulence by sadistic, homicidal acts. Or does he? Maybe the violence is all in the mind.

American Psycho is a shallow movie, as two-dimensional as its hero, though in a performance that is convincingly American, eerily disturbing and edgily comic, Christian Bale brings Bateman to life. This is, however, pulp fiction printed on glossy magazine paper, it's Driller Killer in a Cerrutti suit - Bateman's first victim, like that of the nutty murderer in Abel Ferrara's video nasty, is a wino sheltering in an alleyway.

Presumably intended to be an informal sequel to his When Harry Met Sally, Rob Reiner's The Story of Us is a self-regarding piece in which a TV comedy writer (Bruce Willis) and a crossword puzzle designer (Michelle Pfeiffer) review their tired 13-year marriage while their son and daughter are away at summer camp. There are the usual restaurant dinners in which the hero discusses women and sex with two male chums and the heroine discusses men and sex with two female chums. But the talk is banal, the insights into marriage about as profound as (though less memorable than) 'You got to give a little, take a little, let your poor heart break a little'. His jokes aren't very good, her crosswords are deadly dull, and given the choice, I'd rather have gone to camp with the kids than stayed home with Michelle and Bruce.

Expanded from TV sketches, the disastrous Kevin and Perry Go Large stars Harry Enfield and Kathy Burke as moronic London teenagers trying to lose their virginity and become DJs while holidaying in Ibiza. The succession of crude, unfunny jokes about masturbating, vomiting, defecating, erections and exploding zits makes you realise how hard and skilfully the Farrelly Brothers work on their scripts. If I had not already seen the forthcoming Janice Beard: 45 WPM, I might have chanced my arm and called this the worst Rhys Ifans film this year, rather than the worst Ifans film up to now.

From Ireland and India come two honourable little failures. Night Train, the directorial debut of actor John Lynch, is a chamber drama about the chaste middle-aged love affair between a fugitive underworld bookkeeper (John Hurt) and his landlady's repressed spinster daughter (Brenda Blethyn) in a Dublin suburb of suffocating respectability. The central image provided by Hurt's hobby - a miniature Orient Express on a model landscape of his own design - is attractive, and both bruised performances ring true.

The Canadian-based Deepa Mehta returned to her native India to make Earth, in which the tragically troubled days before and after Partition in 1947 are seen through the puzzled eyes of an eight-year-old Parsee girl. It's moving, deeply felt, yet oddly listless. As the child's nanny, a young Hindu woman in love with a Muslim, Nandita Das is staggeringly beautiful.

Gough Lewis's Sex: The Annabel Chong Story is an intriguing, inevitably voyeuristic but unprurient documentary. Its subject, Grace Quek, a Singapore-born middle-class convent girl, worked her way through the University of Southern California (honours in anthropology) by appearing in porn movies under the nom de guerre Annabel Chong. She rather took to the life, thinking she was exploring her sexuality rather than being exploited, and became notorious in 1995 by having sex with 251 men in 10 hours, billed as 'The World's Biggest Gang Bang'. This got her invited by the Cambridge Union Society to take part in its presidential debate, but she has been replaced by Jasmine St Claire, who managed to service 300 men in one session. Grace is less well-adjusted than she initially appears and the fact that she was a multiple rape victim while an art student in London may have affected her. One's heart goes out to this vulnerable woman and one would like to spray something lethal under the stone from beneath which most of the American men in this picture crawled.

fields.headline: My fellow Un-Americans
fields.standfirst: Tim Robbins promotes the overthrow of capitalism with help from Orson Welles and a Mexican revolutionary
fields.trailText: Cradle Will Rock
fields.body:
Cradle Will Rock (135 mins, 15) Directed by Tim Robbins; starring Hank Azaria, John Cusack, Emily Watson, John Turturro

Orson Welles began creating his own legend as a teenage genius and since his death it has been further burnished by biographers and filmmakers. He appeared as a tutelary figure in Tim Burton's Ed Wood . There has been a TV movie built around his notorious 1938 radio version of War of the Worlds that persuaded thousands of listeners that America was being invaded by Martians, and a few months ago there was another TV film about the scandals attendant on his first Hollywood film, Citizen Kane , in 1941.

Now with the exhilarating Cradle Will Rock, Tim Robbins tells what the credits call 'A [Mostly] True Story' about the sensational production of Marc Blitzstein's Brechtian agitprop musical, The Cradle Will Rock , in 1937 by the federally subsidised theatre company called Project 891 that Welles and John Houseman ran in New York. It's for people who wince at the implications of the phrase 'he's history'.

The film is a sort of dialectical mosaic that attempts to do for the 1930s what E.L. Doctorow's Ragtime did for the decade before the First World War. To achieve this, Robbins brings together three key events of the decade. The first is the commissioning in 1932 by enlightened plutocrat Nelson Rockefeller (John Cusack) of a vast mural for the Rockefeller Center by the revolutionary Mexican artist Diego Rivera (Ruben Blades). In early 1934, before being unveiled, the work known as Man at the Crossroads Looking with Hope and High Vision to the Choosing of a New and Better Future was ground to dust because of its inflammatory radical character, though Rivera later re-created it in Mexico City.

The second event is the appearance in December 1938 of Hallie Flanagan (Cherry Jones), the formidable head of the Federal Theatre, before the newly formed House Committee on Un-American Activities (Huac), a philistine organisation. This hearing, in which Flanagan ran rings around her Red-hunting interrogators, helped bring about the end of federal funding for the arts that had been launched as part of President Roosevelt's New Deal in 1934.

Robbins has moved the Rivera affair ahead in time by three years, and the Huac hearings back by 18 months so that they exactly coincide with the extraordinary first performance of The Cradle Will Rock at a rundown Broadway theatre, the Venice. Project 891's own theatre had been suddenly closed and sealed by security guards following a federal economy drive aimed at radical artists. Because the actors' and musicians' unions refused to sanction a performance elsewhere, Houseman and Welles - in the ultimate realisation of the show-must-go-on ethos - mounted it as a one-man show with the composer Marc Blitzstein (Hank Azaria) at the piano. Members of the cast, wearing rehearsal clothes, gradually joined in from their seats in the audience following the courageous example of the inexperienced young actress Olive Stanton, a figure so amazing and so affectingly played by Emily Watson that one might suppose that Robbins invented her. He did not.

Robbins works on as vast a canvas as Rivera's tendentious political mural, and with a comparably sharp, visual shorthand, caricaturing and glorifying in a similarly provocative manner. Rockefeller, Hearst and their oligarchic circle, buying up Old Masters, encouraging Nazis and fascists as a bulwark against communism, scheming to prevent a second American Revolution, are mocked.

Hallie Flanagan, the sane non-communist with a vision of creating a genuine national theatre, is the heroine of the piece, along with Olive Stanton and an anti-fascist Italian-American actor played by John Turturro. Somewhere in between, the haughty Houseman (Cary Elwes) product of an English public school, and the histrionic Welles (Angus MacFadyen), in search of glory, are treated with a gentle humour.

Over dinner at a fashionable restaurant after rehearsing a gritty musical about the overthrow of capitalism, the pair bicker like a married couple. Blitzstein's mentor, Bertolt Brecht, has a walk-on part, appearing in the composer's imagination to criticise and advise, and there is a touching, presumably fictitious character, an alcoholic vaudeville ventriloquist played brilliantly by Bill Murray, whose dummy takes over from him, making left-wing jokes and singing the 'Internationale'. The Huac politicians are given the rope of their official transcript with which to hang themselves.

Cradle Will Rock closes with an image of the tame, unchallenging, neon-lit Times Square of today. It opens with a wonderful sequence announcing both a new dawn and a backstage story set against the background of a turbulent era.

First seen stretched out behind a cinema screen, the homeless, unemployed Olive Stanton is literally awoken from sleep and figuratively awakened to politics. As she dresses, a newsreel carries items about the Italian invasion of Abyssinia, the Nazis' exhibition of Decadent Art in Germany, Roosevelt opening a dam as part of the Tennessee Valley Authority, a fashion parade in Florida. Going out into the world, she washes her face at a fire hydrant as the camera pans up to the apartment where Blitzstein is struggling with his opera.

The movie continues with a similar fluidity, cutting between its different narrative strands, introducing a vast array of people, vividly recreating a point in American life as the Depression is moving into the pre-war era. It's a time of hope and despair and the movie's final sequence cuts between a mock funeral, a theatrical celebration, and a party of capitalists in fancy dress discussing how to hang on to power.

In an entertaining, if at times simplified manner (Robbins makes too light of communism), the picture examines the relationship between art and society. It dramatises the tug creative people feel between their need to adopt adversarial positions and the wish to be part of the community; and it confronts the perennial problem of pipers having to give account to those who pay for the tunes.

Blitzstein's mentor, Bertolt Brecht, has a walk-on part, appearing in the composer's imagination to criticise and advise, and there is a touching, presumably fictitious character, an alcoholic vaudeville ventriloquist played brilliantly by Bill Murray, whose dummy takes over from him, making left-wing jokes and singing the 'Internationale'. The Huac politicians are given the rope of their official transcript with which to hang themselves. Cradle Will Rock closes with an image of the tame, unchallenging, neon-lit Times Square of today. It opens with a wonderful sequence announcing both a new dawn and a backstage story set against the background of a turbulent era. First seen stretched out behind a cinema screen, the homeless, unemployed Olive Stanton is literally awoken from sleep and figuratively awakened to politics. As she dresses, a newsreel carries items about the Italian invasion of Abyssinia, the Nazis' exhibition of Decadent Art in Germany, Roosevelt opening a dam as part of the Tennessee Valley Authority, a fashion parade in Florida. Going out into the world, she washes her face at a fire hydrant as the camera pans up to the apartment where Blitzstein is struggling with his opera. The movie continues with a similar fluidity, cutting between its different narrative strands, introducing a vast array of people, vividly recreating a point in American life as the Depression is moving into the pre-war era. It's a time of hope and despair and the movie's final sequence cuts between a mock funeral, a theatrical celebration, and a party of capitalists in fancy dress discussing how to hang on to power. In an entertaining, if at times simplified manner (Robbins makes too light of communism), the picture examines the relationship between art and society. It dramatises the tug creative people feel between their need to adopt adversarial positions and the wish to be part of the community; and it confronts the perennial problem of pipers having to give account to those who pay for the tunes.

fields.headline: Make mine a double
fields.standfirst: Passion is well spent at the Donmar in a balletic Peter Nichols revival, while a beguiling Falstaff gives Henry IV some swagger
fields.trailText: Passion Play | Henry IV, Part One | Snogging Ken | The Threesome
fields.body:
Passion Play,Donmar, London WC2

Henry IV, Part One, Swan, Stratford

Snogging Ken, Almeida London N1

The Threesome, Lyric Hammersmith, London W6

Passion Play is a blazing diagram of a drama. Michael Grandage has already staked a claim to be one of Britain's most illuminating directors with his As You Like It and The Jew of Malta. At the Donmar, he makes you feel that you are looking at the X-ray of a marriage.

Peter Nichols's play, first staged in 1981, begins as an apparently predictable adultery-in-the-middle-classes story, with a 50-year-old married couple showing a younger woman how snug they are. You're pretty certain that a different intimacy will be established, and, sure enough, husband and young woman launch into an affair.

What changes the play into something surprising, and penetrating, is a theatrical device. As the schism in the marriage becomes apparent to husband and wife, so each of them splits into two: each is played by two actors. A debate becomes a dance of death.

Bland James (adroit James Laurenson), returning from a clandestine encounter, is coached by a worldly version of himself (an impish Martin Jarvis). Eleanor (beautifully poised Cherie Lunghi), remains composed when tipped off about her James's affair, but sprouts another self in Cheryl Campbell (wonderfully quizzical and crumpled), who explodes and prepares for fisticuffs.

To watch these selves and second selves in different combinations is like watching someone plait hair: you never can tell the separateness of a strand. At times, Laurenson cradles Jarvis; at others, Jarvis and Campbell are impassively overlooked by Lunghi and Laurenson. In one brilliantly balletic scene, husband and wife and their dark shadows prepare to make love on a sofa; when the doorbell goes, four heads spring up in alarm.

There are cracks in this play. The troublesome young woman (only one of her) is badly underwritten. The title, which refers to human love and to Christ's death, bestows unearned magnificence on the couple's pain - one of them is restoring a painting of the Crucifixion, the other is singing an 'Agnus Dei' while her partner makes love. But there's no gainsaying the grip of the piece, swelled by Bach's music and enhanced by Christopher Oram's design: as the light fades on the blocks of the back wall, the central struts glow like a cross.

The RSC's history cycle is wheeling from one kind of strength to another. Under Stephen Pimlott's direction, Richard II was biting and modern. Now Michael Attenborough has directed a swirling, emotional, vibrant Henry IV set in a fourteenth-century twilight.

Es Devlin's cinder-grey design has only one splash of colour, that of a golden robe draped on the throne. In a stroke, the glister and the grit of the play are registered and the Swan is made into an arena fit both for battle and for melting exchanges.

The fights and rough-house scenes are exciting: Adam Levy is a fizzing Hotspur and William Houston, though too often wearing an inappropriate smile, is an arresting, calculating Hal; as Bardolph, Arthur Cox has perfect pitch. But it is the tender episodes - the sad sequence of leave-takings, between husbands and wives and fathers and sons - that are outstanding. These would have been even more striking had not David Troughton turned the king into a creature of bombast and a choppy verse-speaker.

The beguiling thing about Desmond Barrit's performance as Falstaff is his sense of complete relaxation. His body seems to be built on an entirely different scale from those around him. Melancholy murmurs escape him like the creaking of his big bones. He may adopt an actorly swagger to utter his biggest lies, but his most gorgeous phrases roll from him naturally, as if he were sweating adjectives.

Tariq Ali, Howard Brenton and Andy de la Tour have slipped their new satirical sketch about the election for London mayor on to the sleek set designed for the Pinter double-bill at the Almeida. Snogging Ken is a promising title for a skit, suggesting a sexual declension in the candidates - working down from 'Shagger' Norris. Some of its points are on the button: one character observes that while Londoners have a fondness for Livingstone's GLC, they can't remember much about what it did - it's all a blur of fireworks and fares.

None of Snogging Ken is subversive - it's the chat of Londoners put on stage. There's some point in that, but the authors provide a manifesto declaring that 'if more than a few London critics ever like our work, we will be duty bound to ask ourselves where we went wrong'. What would they feel about the woman next to me who remarked to her companion: 'Nothing wrong about having your prejudices confirmed'?

At the Lyric Hammersmith, Neil Bartlett as translator and Gordon Anderson as director are attempting to justify the ways of French farce by staging The Threesome by nineteenth-century playwright Eugène Labiche, author of The Italian Straw Hat . This tale of a skilfully concealed liaison in which the duped party ends up double-duped, is steeped in heavy Victorian decorum and accoutrements - a moose head, a summerhouse - while the action moves with the speed of a guillotine.

What should be an extended panic attack is here more like a series of indigestion disorders. The production doesn't sizzle, but it purrs. As a barmy Alsatian (with a beetle in his lederhosen), Paul Bradley seesaws between silliness and solemnity. And Deborah Findlay can suggest a week of pleasure and disdain with one lift of her upper lip.

fields.headline: What the Sensationalists did next
fields.standfirst: Charles Saatchi dusts down some old favourites and Jay Jopling offers the good, bad and risible at White Cube 2
fields.trailText: Ant Noises | Out There
fields.body:
Ant Noises The Saatchi Gallery, London NW8 until 20 August

Out There White Cube 2 , London N1 until 1 July

The greatest concentration of contemporary British art anywhere in the world is to be found in 50,000 square metres of an east London warehouse. Momart is where private collections are put out to pasture, where works that are too big, too precious, too fragile or simply supernumerary to their owners' homes are discreetly tended by expert staff.

This is where the totems of Sensation go when they are not on global tour - the waxworks, the mannequins, the ageing shark. It is also home to many of the other works in Charles Saatchi's collection, such as the items in Ant Noises now receiving a few months in the sun after three, four or even five years of air-conditioned darkness.

Normally, that wouldn't seem like much of an absence - some art languishes for centuries in museum stacks - and normally one wouldn't mention it. But the publicity for Ant Noises (an anagram of Sensation, as you know) makes a virtue of the new, the fresh, the recent: visit the Saatchi Gallery to find out what the Sensationalists did next.

What they did next is available for all to see, of course, in every second British art show. Not since abstract expressionism has any group of artists been quite so overexposed. Of the six represented here, only Damien Hirst has been off-stage for more than a moment since Sensation in 1997 and he has still kept snug tenure in the media headlines. The purchase of Hirst's outsize Humbrol toy is at once the emblem and theme of this show, which seems nothing other than what Saatchi bought next.

Credit where it's due: Norman Emms made a grand job of the anatomical toy he designed for Humbrol, the partially flayed man with his one lidded eye and his other exposed and goggling eyeball. Hirst has not made a grander job by enlarging it from 10 plastic inches to 20 feet of costly bronze.

All the fascinations of the original, its intricacy, its medical and metaphysical revelations of the skull beneath the skin, are lost in Hirst's inert, bombastic icon. It may not be a toy - the removable organs have been amalgamated into a solid whole - but it's not a sculpture, either. Hymn is a reductio ad absurdum of another man's model and a hugely disappointing work for such an exceptional artist.

To see scale used to spectacular effect look no further than Ron Mueck's hyperreal figures, one of which, the piteously half-sized Dead Dad, was the show-stealer at Sensation. Saatchi has released five more from Momart, including Mueck's portrait of his own furiously glowering face - three feet of towering frown from ridged brow to bristling chin - and his small, depressive angel, cut down by middle age, the burdens of office implicit in his heavily-feathered wings.

These figures don't just look astoundingly real to the last follicle and furrow; they have a presence that amounts to character and spirit. Even the two giant babies, stranded in their nappies on the floor, have identities to match their size. One is devastatingly alert, demandingly vital, while the other is inconsolable, beyond sleep or tears. Crouch down beside them and you have the essence of Mueck's art: even at point-blank range, where the illu sion could waver, his sculptures pulse with sheer force of personality.

If you haven't seen them before, then Ant Noises ought to be the ideal place to start. But it isn't ideal for the simple reason that Mueck's figures are better chanced upon in crowded rooms than ostentatiously positioned in splendid isolation, one per acre of pristine white space.

It isn't true that the Saatchi Gallery gives all art a lift. Rachel Whiteread's resin casts of the spaces beneath a hundred chairs, for example, may glow a little more with this skylighting but they still look exactly as they did in Sensation, like a classroom of seats kept in arbitrary detention.

Ant Noises itself feels somewhat arbitrary, hastily assembled, even proleptic, as if slotted in after the recent lapses of Neurotic Realism and Eurovision to remind us just what a pioneering patron of BritArt Charles Saatchi has been. Alternatively, you might regard it as philanthropy, another chance for the (paying) public to see privately-owned British art. Personally, I wouldn't mind if this particular quartet of Chris Ofili paintings had stayed in the warehouse and I'm not sure that the minuscule advances Jenny Saville has made in five years of painting fleshy broads are actually worth the outing. But that is the tax on overexposure; the briefly new can swiftly seem like the same old same old.

Anyone eager to see the very latest from some of these artists should go to Out There at White Cube 2, Jay Jopling's new gallery in up-and-coming Hoxton in east London. Only twice the size of the original midget gallery in Mayfair, the new emporium is a tight fit, the brand names crammed into the kind of space Saatchi gives his Savilles. This makes for sharp juxtapositions - Antony Gormley's iron Titan bursts from the wall above Mark Quinn's lead man, crushed to a shadow of his former self on the floor. But it also means that you can never get away from Gilbert and George.

Everything has its price: Hirst's skeleton on its glass crucifix, ping-pong eyeballs levitating on air-jets, is a mordant joke at a quarter of a million. The Chapman brothers' scale model of a dystopian McDonald's, overgrown and deserted, is £58,000. Tracey Emin's discomfort blanket, stitched with the desperate details of a school trip to Austria, costs a fraction less.

Some of the star cast, Hume and Quinn for example, have flourished in the brief interval since 1997. Some are just as bad as they ever were - Marcus Harvey still hasn't got an idea or brushmark to call his own. Others have out-parodied themselves. Gavin Turk's waxwork portrait of himself as the corpse of Che Guevara, in Tussaud panstick and shop-dummy wig, is destined straight for Momart without passing Go.

fields.headline: End of the special relationship
fields.standfirst: The Beatles did it in the Sixties, Culture Club in the Eighties. But don't hold your breath for a third British Invasion. America doesn't need us any more
fields.trailText: The Beatles did it in the Sixties, Culture Club in the Eighties. But don't hold your breath for a third British Invasion. America doesn't need us any more
fields.body:
Amid all the self-congratulatory hubbub over the British successes at the Oscars, few people stopped to reflect that Sam Mendes hadn't made a film called British Beauty, that his stellar debut was a study of dysfunctional American suburbia set thousands of miles from the director's beloved Donmar Warehouse. More recently, the movie version of Nick Hornby's Britbloke novel High Fidelity was relocated from London to Chicago without a murmur of complaint, not even from Hornby himself.

Brits such as Mendes and Hornby may still have that certain 'I don't know what' for Americans, but Britain is no longer perceived across the water as the epicentre of cool, only as the trustafarian tourist trap of Notting Hill. And nowhere is this more evident than in music, an arena in which Brits have traditionally set the pace for the rest of the world. 'It's true that other countries, America in particular, did look to us for guidance, particularly where alternative music was concerned,' remarked senior pop citizen Sting in the Times last weekend. 'Now they make their own. The world has changed.'

The world has certainly changed since the Beatles first stepped off the plane at Idlewild Airport in 1963, an epochal moment which consolidated the 'special relationship' Britain had always enjoyed with the US. 'America needed someone to fall in love with after Kennedy died and there the Beatles were,' says LA rock béte noire Kim Fowley, notorious former manager of the Runaways. America also needed someone to shake it out of its post-Eisenhower slumber. Perhaps this was why the arrival of the Beatles was seen as an 'invasion', a term suggesting the ambiguity Americans felt about the way British bands (the Stones, the Who et al) took black American R&B, refashioned it as delinquent white angst, and fed it back to the would-be punks of America's suburban garages.

The Beatles not only came, saw, and conquered, introducing the US to cheeky-chappie charm and wit at a time when most American boys were dorks with ducktails, but they transformed 'pop' into a credible art form, setting off wave after wave of musical change.

From late Sixties heavy metal to early Eighties synth pop, Brits were at the cutting edge of pop's evolution. Since the 'second British invasion' of Boy George and Sting, however, the 'special relationship' between the two countries has counted for a lot less than it did in the days of Swinging London. Gone for good is the era when skinny Brits could saunter along Sunset Boulevard and take their pick of blonde goddesses on the strength of their monosyllabic Anglo-Saxon grunting. The mid-Nineties Britpop explosion of Blur and Oasis was the last chance to convince America it still needed us - and it failed.

'There's a particular kind of British classic rock that doesn't really translate at this point,' says Ann Powers, music critic for the New York Times. 'Part of that has to do with America's fascination with hip hop. Hip hop, unlike blues in the Sixties, hasn't been taken up by British artists and made more interesting the way the Stones and Eric Clapton did with blues. Hip hop and R&B are really flavouring mainstream American pop, so what British pop is about is just not interesting to mainstream audiences.'

For the vast majority of American teens and twentysomethings, talk of British invasions has become a non-issue. To them, the Beatles are as remote and mummified as Elvis Presley. Pockets of Anglophilia survive, but Americans have slowly been waking up to their own national treasures, from Woody Guthrie and Hank Williams to Captain Beefheart and Tom Waits. Unimpressed by the surly grandchildren of the Beatles and the Who, they have gone back to what Greil Marcus calls 'the old, weird America' of Harry Smith's seminal Anthology of American Music. In the words of Beck, whose playful melange of blues, folk, funk and hip hop owes little to British influence: 'The boggy wasteland of the American spirit is more fluorescent than ever.'

'There used to be this fascination with European bohemian life,' says Powers, whose newly-published Weird Like Us: My Bohemian America (Simon Schuster $23) examines the way 'alternative' culture has seeped into the US mainstream. 'But it's just not what kids are looking to now. It's as though there's been enough of an American tradition, especially in terms of the bohemian slacker culture of the Eighties and Nineties, which is very focused on American popular culture and looks to that for inspiration.'

Significantly, the most critically lauded albums of the past decade, both in America and here, have been by hybridising artists such as Beck, by hip hop and R&B acts such as the Fugees and TLC, and by such practitioners of refracted Americana as Lambchop and Mercury Rev. The 1999 Album of the Year in NME wasn't by Blur or even Death in Vegas but by oddball Oklahomans, the Flaming Lips. (I don't count Radiohead, whose music transcends the whole issue of Britrock anyway.) True, Britain's electronic underground has had an impact in America, kick-starting the overhyped and ultimately ephemeral 'electronica' vogue of 1997, but dance music culture is too amorphous and pan-European to make any difference to the way Americans perceive our culture. You're more likely to hear Underworld or the Chemical Brothers on a TV ad than you are to hear them on the radio.

'Americans want to be shocked by British bands,' says Laurence Bell of Domino Records, British home to Smog, Palace and other US mavericks. 'When the Beatles went over there, it was like, "What is this? Who are these guys?" Now there's no real intelligence or exoticism. Obviously, we're setting the pace in electronic music, but Americans stopped caring about Britrock years ago. They see these bands come in on waves of hype who can't even play their instruments and they're just not interested.'

Several reasons could be given for the perplexing reversal of fortune. One is that Britain never produced a Kurt Cobain or, for that matter, an adequate response to grunge (unless you count Bush). Another is that Americans are less and less concerned with what's going on outside their huge country, with its internal diversity and plurality. This we know from the relegation of stories about Zimbabwe to the middle or back pages to make way for the minutiae of the Elian Gonzalez case.

'In a negative sense, I would say America's become more provincial,' says Ann Powers. 'Even though capitalism has become global, our own focus has become myopic.' Still another is the tired theory of Yanks not getting our amazingly subtle 'irony' (when did Britain last produce a TV show as witheringly ironic as The Simpsons?). More troubling, at least to some, is the possibility that we have ourselves become so Americanised that our cultural products no longer bear the true stamp of our national character.

A more convincing analysis might be that America has taken what it needs from British pop - style, irreverence, artistic daring - and simply moved on. In a country of 280 million, where Spanish is about to become the dominant language, 'Cool Britannia' has become just another ice-cream flavour. London is calling but America ain't home.

'It would seem that America has assimilated what it's needed to take out of British pop culture in the past 40 years, and there really isn't that much that Britain has to offer right now,' says Nic Harcourt, Birmingham-born host of KCRW's influential Morning Becomes Eclectic show in Los Angeles. 'I wouldn't say that no British bands are ever going to break through again - Travis look like they might do it - but America at this point is the great global experiment. It may still be very white in the middle, but in the cities there's now such a tapestry of cultures. Nothing really stands out so much anymore, and certainly not Britrock.'

Between Da Brat and Shania Twain, Ricky Martin and Rage Against the Machine, Americans appear to have everything they need, with every genre neatly tailored to its appropriate demographic. Between the Listerine teenpop of 'N Sync and the testosterone jock metal of Limp Bizkit, American radio offers few holes for square pegs such as Supergrass, P.J. Harvey or Massive Attack. Or even for Robbie Williams. These days, we can't even compete with America's boy bands.

In the new virtual global village, with the world at our electronic fingertips, the very concept of Britishness looks ever more anachronistic. Maybe it's time we stopped looking to America for its approval.

 Barney Hoskyns's recent books include Glam! Bowie, Bolan and the Glitter Rock Revolution and The Mullet: Hairstyle of the Gods (co-author)
fields.bodyText: Amid all the self-congratulatory hubbub over the British successes at the Oscars, few people stopped to reflect that Sam Mendes hadn't made a film called British Beauty, that his stellar debut was a study of dysfunctional American suburbia set thousands of miles from the director's beloved Donmar Warehouse. More recently, the movie version of Nick Hornby's Britbloke novel High Fidelity was relocated from London to Chicago without a murmur of complaint, not even from Hornby himself. Brits such as Mendes and Hornby may still have that certain 'I don't know what' for Americans, but Britain is no longer perceived across the water as the epicentre of cool, only as the trustafarian tourist trap of Notting Hill. And nowhere is this more evident than in music, an arena in which Brits have traditionally set the pace for the rest of the world. 'It's true that other countries, America in particular, did look to us for guidance, particularly where alternative music was concerned,' remarked senior pop citizen Sting in the Times last weekend. 'Now they make their own. The world has changed.' The world has certainly changed since the Beatles first stepped off the plane at Idlewild Airport in 1963, an epochal moment which consolidated the 'special relationship' Britain had always enjoyed with the US. 'America needed someone to fall in love with after Kennedy died and there the Beatles were,' says LA rock béte noire Kim Fowley, notorious former manager of the Runaways. America also needed someone to shake it out of its post-Eisenhower slumber. Perhaps this was why the arrival of the Beatles was seen as an 'invasion', a term suggesting the ambiguity Americans felt about the way British bands (the Stones, the Who et al) took black American R&B, refashioned it as delinquent white angst, and fed it back to the would-be punks of America's suburban garages. The Beatles not only came, saw, and conquered, introducing the US to cheeky-chappie charm and wit at a time when most American boys were dorks with ducktails, but they transformed 'pop' into a credible art form, setting off wave after wave of musical change. From late Sixties heavy metal to early Eighties synth pop, Brits were at the cutting edge of pop's evolution. Since the 'second British invasion' of Boy George and Sting, however, the 'special relationship' between the two countries has counted for a lot less than it did in the days of Swinging London. Gone for good is the era when skinny Brits could saunter along Sunset Boulevard and take their pick of blonde goddesses on the strength of their monosyllabic Anglo-Saxon grunting. The mid-Nineties Britpop explosion of Blur and Oasis was the last chance to convince America it still needed us - and it failed. 'There's a particular kind of British classic rock that doesn't really translate at this point,' says Ann Powers, music critic for the New York Times. 'Part of that has to do with America's fascination with hip hop. Hip hop, unlike blues in the Sixties, hasn't been taken up by British artists and made more interesting the way the Stones and Eric Clapton did with blues. Hip hop and R&B are really flavouring mainstream American pop, so what British pop is about is just not interesting to mainstream audiences.' For the vast majority of American teens and twentysomethings, talk of British invasions has become a non-issue. To them, the Beatles are as remote and mummified as Elvis Presley. Pockets of Anglophilia survive, but Americans have slowly been waking up to their own national treasures, from Woody Guthrie and Hank Williams to Captain Beefheart and Tom Waits. Unimpressed by the surly grandchildren of the Beatles and the Who, they have gone back to what Greil Marcus calls 'the old, weird America' of Harry Smith's seminal Anthology of American Music. In the words of Beck, whose playful melange of blues, folk, funk and hip hop owes little to British influence: 'The boggy wasteland of the American spirit is more fluorescent than ever.' 'There used to be this fascination with European bohemian life,' says Powers, whose newly-published Weird Like Us: My Bohemian America (Simon Schuster $23) examines the way 'alternative' culture has seeped into the US mainstream. 'But it's just not what kids are looking to now. It's as though there's been enough of an American tradition, especially in terms of the bohemian slacker culture of the Eighties and Nineties, which is very focused on American popular culture and looks to that for inspiration.' Significantly, the most critically lauded albums of the past decade, both in America and here, have been by hybridising artists such as Beck, by hip hop and R&B acts such as the Fugees and TLC, and by such practitioners of refracted Americana as Lambchop and Mercury Rev. The 1999 Album of the Year in NME wasn't by Blur or even Death in Vegas but by oddball Oklahomans, the Flaming Lips. (I don't count Radiohead, whose music transcends the whole issue of Britrock anyway.) True, Britain's electronic underground has had an impact in America, kick-starting the overhyped and ultimately ephemeral 'electronica' vogue of 1997, but dance music culture is too amorphous and pan-European to make any difference to the way Americans perceive our culture. You're more likely to hear Underworld or the Chemical Brothers on a TV ad than you are to hear them on the radio. 'Americans want to be shocked by British bands,' says Laurence Bell of Domino Records, British home to Smog, Palace and other US mavericks. 'When the Beatles went over there, it was like, "What is this? Who are these guys?" Now there's no real intelligence or exoticism. Obviously, we're setting the pace in electronic music, but Americans stopped caring about Britrock years ago. They see these bands come in on waves of hype who can't even play their instruments and they're just not interested.' Several reasons could be given for the perplexing reversal of fortune. One is that Britain never produced a Kurt Cobain or, for that matter, an adequate response to grunge (unless you count Bush). Another is that Americans are less and less concerned with what's going on outside their huge country, with its internal diversity and plurality. This we know from the relegation of stories about Zimbabwe to the middle or back pages to make way for the minutiae of the Elian Gonzalez case. 'In a negative sense, I would say America's become more provincial,' says Ann Powers. 'Even though capitalism has become global, our own focus has become myopic.' Still another is the tired theory of Yanks not getting our amazingly subtle 'irony' (when did Britain last produce a TV show as witheringly ironic as The Simpsons?). More troubling, at least to some, is the possibility that we have ourselves become so Americanised that our cultural products no longer bear the true stamp of our national character. A more convincing analysis might be that America has taken what it needs from British pop - style, irreverence, artistic daring - and simply moved on. webTitle: Why am I under the hammer?

fields.headline: Why am I under the hammer?
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.trailText: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.body:
I sold a picture in a local auction. It had a reserve price of £800 but went for £7,000. The auctioneers' terms say they will insure sale items for 1 per cent of the reserve price, so I assumed it would cost £8. But I was charged £70 plus VAT and told it was 'usual practice' to base the fee on the sale price achieved.

If the picture had been destroyed prior to the sale, I assume I would have received £800 less 1 per cent. When the hammer came down, I was no longer the owner. Can you explain an insurance charge for which I could receive no benefit?

AP, Weymouth

YOU can only insure something for a value agreed at the outset. If the contract you signed said the charge is based on the reserve figure, that is what it is, and auctioneers cannot change the rules at whim.

You should also complain if they are adding 17.5 per cent VAT; it should be insurance premium tax at 5 per cent. In any case, 1 per cent for around three weeks' insurance is expensive. You do not have to buy the auctioneers' policy; indeed your house contents policy might have covered it.

Mis-sold pension: Poorer sister

WITH my brothers and sisters, I took out a Prudential pension in 1984 for our sister, who has spent her entire adult life looking after our elderly parents. I recently realised that, as she did not have a job, she did not qualify for a pension, and raised it with the Pru.

The Pru offered to return the amount paid into the policy plus interest and, when I complained, increased the offer to £13,854, calculating interest at 11.5 per cent. But I feel the least they can offer is a sum that will enable her to buy anannuity as shown in their projections.

PP, Leominster

IT IS entirely the Pru's fault that you believed you could buy your sister a pension which, the statement shows, would give her about £1,400 a year from September 2004. The company readily admits that its salesman, who no longer works there, mis-sold the policy, but it only has to refund the premiums and add interest as though you had saved in a deposit account.

However, the Pru should not make a profit out of its error and, when I asked, admitted that the fund is now worth £13,924 after charges. It has therefore rounded the payment to £14,000. Part is a refund of your premiums; if you paid net of tax, you will have to return the tax. The interest is subject to income tax but your sister, as a non-taxpayer, can reclaim it.

The £14,000 is not enough to buy the annuity in the Pru forecasts but that figure includes another four years' contributions and is based on your sister being 60. You can complain to the PIA Ombudsman but the Pru feels it has paid out in line with earlier Ombudsman decisions.

Sharedealing: No cooling-off

ON 4 April, at 1.30 pm, I telephoned M&G to purchase a stocks and shares mini-Isa ahead of the 5 April deadline. I bought the Global Technology Fund but, as it was after noon, was told the deal would be done the next day. Shortly after, I heard that the US technology stock market was in free fall. I phoned M&G again to change to a general fund, but was told that, because the arrangement had been done over the telephone, this was irrevocable. Had I posted my application, I would have had two weeks to change my mind.

SC, Nottingham

YOU have a two-week cooling off period only if you buy from a company salesman or through a financial adviser. You cannot cancel if you have a discretionary advice agreement with your adviser or you buy direct, as you did. Immediately you put the phone down, M&G (as Isa-manager) orders the units from M&G (as fund manager) and you were committed even though the deal was done on the next day's price.

If you had been able to cancel, you would still have lost money because you get back the price on the day you cancel and not the day you buy.

Retirement: A better offer

I AM a hospital doctor. I am retiring in May, seven months before I reach 65; my wife is 54. I have a good occupational pension, and a free-standing AVC with Allied Dunbar, which is now worth £50,500. I am told that the joint-life annuity will be £3,020 a year, which I find ridiculous. Moreover, in the event of my death, the insurance company will swallow up the capital.

How can I get the best income from my AVC, bearing in mind that I had coronary artery bypass nine years ago and now show early signs of heart failure?

DS, Bridge of Weir

YOU should certainly get quotations from other insurers through a financial adviser. A few companies sell impaired-life annuities, which give a larger pension to people unlikely to survive the average timespan. They are more attractive to people with minor impairment because you receive the better income for longer.

You should also look at investment-linked, particularly with-profits, annuities where your income is not guaranteed but neither are you locked in to the low rates currently being paid. Only Scottish Widows and Sun Life sell impaired-life investment-linked annuities; eight others sell non-impaired with-profits annuities: Scottish Mutual, Norwich Union, Pru, CGU, Standard Life, Scottish Widows, Equitable and Legal & General.

Write to Margaret Dibben, Money Writes, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER and include a telephone number. Do not enclose SAEs or original documents. Letters are selected for publication and we cannot give personal replies. The newspaper accepts no legal responsibility for advice .

Writeback: Giving til it Hertz

MM of Bray, County Wicklow, had a remarkably similar experience to JH of London, whose Visa card was debited by Hertz for car rental even though she had paid in advance: 'My father prepaid for a hired car in Australia when we visited, but my husband had to show his credit card when we took the car. When we returned home, we found that my husband had been charged for the hire of the car, so we notified Hertz.

'They were difficult about it, though they had obviously been paid twice over. It took several months, and personal visits to their offices by my father in Oz, before they refunded the money. Plainly, this was entirely to their advantage: a not inconsiderable sum reposed illegitimately in their account during the whole lengthy process.'

fields.headline: Uninsured loss recovery
fields.trailText: What is uninsured loss recovery?
fields.body:
Q What is uninsured loss recovery?

A It is a form of legal expenses insurance that helps you recover money you have paid out following a car accident that was not your fault and which is not covered by your own motor policy. This can be compensation for personal injury, the excess on your policy, cost of car hire, taxis, public transport, phone calls, damage to your clothes.

Q How does it work?

A Your comprehensive policy indemnifies you for repairs to your car, which your insurer gets back from the guilty side, but will not pay for out-of-pocket expenses. When you are the innocent victim of an accident, the guilty driver's insurer will pay these but not without at least checking and possibly fighting. Uninsured loss recovery provides someone to argue your case for you, but you must keep evidence of any money you spend.

Q Why doesn't my own insurer pay?

A The excess is an amount you agreed to pay to reduce your premiums. However clear-cut the circumstances, your insurer treats you as guilty until proved innocent and immediately reduces your no-claims discount, probably by 20 per cent. If you need to renew your policy before the claim is finalised, you have to pay higher premiums. Once your innocence is accepted, your insurer refunds the overpayment.

Q Does uninsured loss recovery come automatically with motor insurance?

A No, but you can buy it through your insurer or from a broker. It is usually called legal expenses insurance.

Q How much does it cost?

A It depends on the ceiling for legal costs (£50,000 or more) and varies between £13 and £20 a year.

Q Do I have to get permission before hiring a car?

A Some insurers provide you with a replacement car while yours is off the road. If not, check: your insurer is unlikely to give firm assurance that your costs will be refunded. Any hired car must be reasonably priced: even if your Rolls-Royce is damaged, the other side could argue against your need to hire another Roller.

Q Can I get my money back if I don't have uninsured loss recovery?

A You're entitled to compensation if you weren't to blame for the accident, but will have to negotiate it yourself.

Q Can I be confident of getting my money back?

A If you are a little to blame for the accident, you will not get all your expenses. You may get nothing if the other driver is uninsured. The other side will pay only for losses that can be attributed to its policyholder's actions. If you spend weeks disputing the write-off value your insurer offers for your car, the other side will not refund costs during that period. If you eventually negotiate a better price, you can claim these costs from your own insurer.

webTitle: Who wants to be a scrubber?

fields.headline: Who wants to be a scrubber?
fields.standfirst: Doing their own housework the way their grandmothers did is all the rage for career women in the US. But will the New Domesticity take off this side of the Atlantic?
fields.trailText: Doing their own housework the way their grandmothers did is all the rage for career women in the US. But will the New Domesticity take off this side of the Atlantic?
fields.body:
In the dying hours of the late Late Review, Tony Parsons declared that there was no sight more erotic than Annette Bening vacuuming furiously in her slip in American Beauty . It doesn't matter that the scene is heavily ironic - far from being a compliant housewife, Bening is a shrewish estate agent desperately primping one of her properties - Parsons's response suggests that for many men there's always been something singularly satisfying about a sexy woman getting down to some hard domestic graft.

Far stranger is the growing band of woman who declare themselves, if not exactly turned on, then certainly deeply pleasured by the idea of keeping house. More specifically, keeping house with as much bother as possible. Creating a place where you can turn dinner guests loose without worrying that they'll stumble across evidence of your threat to public health is nice, but that isn't the point. The new domestics actually enjoy the process of creating order out of chaos, and to prove it they do it with as much inconvenience to themselves as possible. Time-saving strategies - a Dyson, three sorts of Mr Muscle, a twice-weekly Croatian - are, they say, spoiling the fun. Expending elbow grease is a crucial part of the pleasure.

'There's nothing more soothing than coming home after a hard day's work and doing a basket full of ironing,' confirms Jane Sampson, 42, a property consultant. 'And the nastier the day, the more I want to do housework. When I was going through my divorce I had kitchen cupboards that would have gladdened any drill sergeant's heart.' When pushed, Sampson admits that there's a dark psychological side to all this: 'Yes, I know it's all about making order out of some spectacularly nasty chaos, but who cares? It works for me.'

The high priestess of born-again domestics such as Sampson is Cheryl Mendelson, the American academic who recently published up a storm with her unlikely bestseller, Home Comforts: The Art and Science of Keeping Home (Scribner $35). The book has nothing to do with nostalgic top-dressing, and you won't find a lavender bag or distressed Tuscan tile in sight. Instead, what Mendelson advocates is the kind of back-breaking routine she learnt from her Appalachian farmhouse grannies in the Fifties. Thus Mendelson seriously suggests that you do your washing on Monday, odd jobs on Tuesday, and so on even if, like her, you live in Manhattan. The book is nearly 900 pages and consists of nitty gritty chapters with titles like 'Aprons, Rags and Mops'. There's a right way to roll up socks, apparently, and an essential way to wash your hands (Mendelson says to get them really clean you should be able to hum right through 'Yankee Doodle'. Obviously we need to substitute here, so watch out in the office lav for people who insist on muttering the words to 'Maybe It's Because I'm a Londoner' - they're the clean ones).

Mendelson says that her book is a way of honouring women's work, that rich tradition of domestic knowledge, labour and mystery which has so often seemed invisible to historians. In this she follows the example of Mrs Beeton, whose aim in publishing The Book of Household Management in 1861 was to give middle-class women a sense of pride in their domestic skills and achievements. Beeton compared the mistress of the house to an army general, and briefed her readers with the facts, figures and strategies which would enable them to run their household with military precision.

This talked-up moral urgency made perfect compensatory sense in a world where middle-class women were barred from any kind of labour outside the home. But Cheryl Mendelson, who is often called the new Mrs Beeton, has no need to convince anyone of her usefulness. With a law degree from Harvard, a PhD in philosophy and a teaching job at Columbia, she has hardly been twiddling her thumbs. But here's the thing: Mendelson claims that all those years when she was working 60-hour weeks and coming home to an empty fridge and unsorted socks made her miserable. It wasn't until her second marriage in 1990 that she felt strong enough to admit that what she really wanted to do was keep house in as fiddly and time-consuming way as possible.

The fact that Home Comforts has sold around 200,000 copies in a few months suggests that it is much more than a gimmicky, counter-intuitive statement which pleases the press for a day, but soon passes. In any case, Mendelson is not the first writer to suggest recently that spiritual peace is to be found by dusting properly under your bed. Sarah Ban Breathnach is a domestic historian turned self-help guru whose two-million selling Simple Abundance: A Daybook of Comfort & Joy (Bantam £12.99) maintains that making your own jam is a moral act, and a deeply satisfying one at that. In America there are 'Simple Abundance' support groups where teachers, doctors and lawyers get together to rap about the pleasures of a really good polish.

Tania Carpenter, 35, understands what they're talking about. 'For me housework has always been a creative act. It's about contributing my labour and my know-how in order to make a calm, nurturing space for my family.' Friends think that Carpenter, who works 12-hour days in marketing for a blue-chip company, is crazy. 'They ask me why I don't hire a cleaner like everyone else. But they're missing the point. I don't see housework as some chore to be got through as quickly as possible, or palmed off on someone else. It's more than my hobby, it's a kind of therapy. If I didn't do it I'd be a less fulfilled person.'

Carpenter isn't the only British woman yearning to return to a time when housework was difficult, dirty and even dangerous. One Sunday supplement recently ran a piece telling you where to buy Brasso. Another magazine did a feature on proper yellow dusters and loose-weave cotton cloths (neither of which work as nicely as a synthetic, sky-blue J-cloth). Posh shops and high-street retailers alike are full of great hunks of white laundry soap which look like you should be scrubbing your clothes down by the river's edge, instead of using a Hotpoint. They also do scented waters in which to rinse your bed linen (if you have a polyester-mix duvet cover then you're missing the point completely).

But particularly odd is the way that Cheryl Mendelson chooses to present her own experience in the introduction to the book. She characterises her love of hard domestic slog as a 'secret passion' which she has previously felt too ashamed to share. Writing Home Comforts, she says, has been a way of outing herself as the queen of clean. This suggests that, first, Mendelson has some pretty strange friends if she honestly thought they might dump her when they discovered that her immaculate apartment was all her own work. But second, and more serious, is her implication that this 'secret' self is also her true one. The way Mendelson frames it, her PhD, the job at Columbia, the Harvard law degree are nothing more than a dutiful nod towards inauthentic social norms. Housework, by contrast, brings her 'the increasingly rare freedom to engage in unalienated, honourable work'. The idea that tidying up after other people for little thanks and no money is less alienating than being paid plenty for your quick legal brain seems odd. Also worrying is the fashionable Darwinian implication that no matter how much you tinker with social formations (giving a girl a good education), biological imperatives will prevail. And, in Mendelson's case, those imperatives will always show themselves in knowing the right way to fold a sheet.

The fact is that fantasising about a time when a girl's best friend was her mangle only makes sense if you reserve the right to use a tumbler dryer when you're pressed for time. Opting for Sunlight soap (you can still get it if you know where to look) is fun only if you've consciously rejected the idea of using Persil tablets, at least for today. A dingy cotton cloth is bearable when you know you can always go over the surface again with a disposable, disinfected household wipe. The woman in Channel 4's documentary The 1900 House didn't have the choice, and so was famously reduced to tears. Hot water which comes and goes as it pleases, dust which sulks in corners and towelling sanitary towels which scratch and smell - these are just a few of the things which the new domestics forget to tell you about housekeeping the old-fashioned way.

The fantasy of the new domesticity is beguiling because it suggests a time when it was possible to spend your time doing one thing well. A time when it really was feasible to dedicate Mondays to washing, Tuesdays to odd jobs and know that the plan would hold because you weren't trying to run a career on the side. Skidding home from work to meet the childminder's deadline before organising some sort of meal for everyone is hardly conducive to making sure that the tops of your books are properly vacuumed (Mendelson, page 612). The new domesticity implies too that you have someone to support you financially while you fold and smooth and pat. In reality, of course, it would not be fun, as all those numb, raging women who talked to Betty Friedan for The Feminine Mystique would tell you. But, still, a girl can dream of Monday wash day.

Far stranger is the growing band of woman who declare themselves, if not exactly turned on, then certainly deeply pleasured by the idea of keeping house. More specifically, keeping house with as much bother as possible. Creating a place where you can turn dinner guests loose without worrying that they'll stumble across evidence of your threat to public health is nice, but that isn't the point. The new domestics actually enjoy the process of creating order out of chaos, and to prove it they do it with as much inconvenience to themselves as possible. Time-saving strategies - a Dyson, three sorts of Mr Muscle, a twice-weekly Croatian - are, they say, spoiling the fun. Expending elbow grease is a crucial part of the pleasure. 'There's nothing more soothing than coming home after a hard day's work and doing a basket full of ironing,' confirms Jane Sampson, 42, a property consultant. 'And the nastier the day, the more I want to do housework. When I was going through my divorce I had kitchen cupboards that would have gladdened any drill sergeant's heart.' When pushed, Sampson admits that there's a dark psychological side to all this: 'Yes, I know it's all about making order out of some spectacularly nasty chaos, but who cares? It works for me.' Instead, what Mendelson advocates is the kind of back-breaking routine she learnt from her Appalachian farmhouse grannies in the Fifties. Thus Mendelson seriously suggests that you do your washing on Monday, odd jobs on Tuesday, and so on even if, like her, you live in Manhattan. webTitle: Dry rot, or something more sinister?

fields.headline: Dry rot, or something more sinister?
fields.standfirst: Few people want to move in and find an earlier owner still with them in spirit. Anne Caborn on how not to be spooked by your new home
fields.trailText: You've been in your new house for just a few days when you notice the stairs creaking at night, and a ghostly chill every time you enter the sitting room. Can you blame your surveyor?
fields.body:
You've been in your new house for just a few days when you notice the stairs creaking at night, and a ghostly chill every time you enter the sitting room. Can you blame your surveyor?

A good survey is an invaluable tool when buying a home. It may root out dry rot, residual damp and a need for repointing. It can save you a costly mistake - or at least help you argue the price down.

But you can, and perhaps should, explore further than the physical condition of the property. This could range from a Feng Shui pre-purchase appraisal, to calling in a local spiritualist. If all this sounds a little out of this world for bricks and mortar, bear in mind that only last year a couple went to court in a countersuit over the outstanding balance of the purchase price, claiming their house was haunted.

The judge found against the couple. But in an increasingly litigious age, surveyors, solicitors, vendors and purchasers would be wrong to dismiss bumps in the night or bad Feng Shui out of hand. A few years ago, chartered surveyor Martin Cotsen, based in Cardiff, was taken to task by one purchaser for not mentioning that a house was haunted. Whether you believe in ghosts or not, a 'haunted' property could command a lower resale value.

'If I had to do a survey on that house again, I don't think I would put anything in my report,' he said. ' But I would have a word with the solicitor and suggest that one of the questions to ask the vendors is whether the house is haunted.'

But Yarmouth chartered building surveyor David Bullen also points out that one buyer's ghost is another's money-spinner. He has carried out three surveys of properties said to be haunted. In two of the cases the buyers pulled out. In the third, a pub, the buyer went ahead: he thought a ghostly resident would boost trade. 'I felt I should pass the information on,' says Bullen. 'There are those who would not buy a haunted house.'

The Spiritualists' National Union says its members are more likely to be called in when a presence in the prop erty manifests itself. Said a spokesman: 'A typical thing that can happen is when an elderly person dies in their sleep, and doesn't know they are dead.

'A new person moves in, moves things around and ignores them - so they get a bit upset.

'Somebody coming to view a property won't necessarily upset them; it's usually after they move in. You need someone to come in, point out that they are dead and tell them that they should be moving on.'

While relatively few people would think of calling in a spiritualist when buying a home, an increasing number are interested in Feng Shui. Simon Brown, whose latest book is Practical Feng Shui Solutions (Cassell), has many house hunters among his clients.

Feng Shui involves assessing and manipulating Chi, or energy. Obstruction to the Chi, perhaps caused by the design of a house, can - according to practitioners - affect people's lives, jobs, and relationships as well as their physical, mental and financial wellbeing.

In some cases, Brown's clients would reject a property if the energy within it wasn't right. 'It does depend on the climate of the property market. A few years ago, when there was a lot more choice, people would pick two or three houses and I would say which was the best for them.'

These days Simon is more likely to look for ways of improving the energy flow around the house, by positioning things like furniture and plants, or perhaps some remodelling.

He also advises prospective purchasers to find out a little about previous occupants - and not just the last owners. 'Preferably find out about the owners before that. Has there been a history of relationship break-down, or bankruptcy in the property?'

The British Society of Dowsers occasionally receives requests from property purchasers. Dowsers can divine cavities, tunnels and archaeological remains, as well as water and the energy lines that apparently crisscross the earth. According to the society's executive secretary Deirdre Rust, this energy can be positive, neutral or negative. 'You can get bad lines if the line you're dealing with crosses polluted water, or comes into contact with power lines.'

Such negative energy running through a house can cause geopathic stress, and in turn ill health. Dowsers can not only discern such bad lines but also correct them using a variety of objects, including gem stones and copper coils.

Diana and Nick Reeves use the broad principles of Feng Shui in their home and also in the properties they have bought and renovated for rental income. Brown has viewed properties for them. When their daughter bought a home in Glasgow, they provided Brown with drawings of the property so he could offer an opinion.

'We lived in the Far East for many years, Diana says, 'and were aware of Feng Shui, but we didn't apply it in England until six or seven years ago when we moved here permanently. I don't tend to mention it because it's very trendy at the moment, and to me it's more than a trend.'

When a property has been renovated, Diana will leave tenants a portfolio explaining how the Chi in the property works and why plants should be left in certain positions. They may choose to follow this. With houses in shared occupancy, she may paint the communal areas yellow, an earth colour.

'I don't go overboard about it,' she says, 'but we've had students in a shared house saying they've been there two years and never had an argument. I think people see it as a bit of a giggle to begin with, but if things are going well, or not so well, they tend to look at it in more detail.

'We have really good tenants, and things do go well, but that could also be because we look after the properties.'

webTitle: Breaking up is hard - and what do you do with the money?

fields.headline: Breaking up is hard - and what do you do with the money?
fields.standfirst: Julian needs help to invest cash from a joint home, he tells Helen Pridham
fields.trailText: Julian English and his girlfriend are parting amicably. They are about to complete the sale of their jointly owned property and divide the proceeds, releasing a considerable sum.
fields.body:
JULIAN ENGLISH

AGE: 33

LIVES IN: Teddington, west London

OCCUPATION: Sales manager for a promotional travel company

EARNS: £30,000 plus bonuses

MORTGAGE: About to take one out for £100,000

DEBTS: Credit card bill of £3,500

INVESTMENTS: None

PENSION: Personal pension with Friends Provident

AIMS: To find out the best way to use equity released from sale of a previous property

Julian English and his girlfriend are parting amicably. They are about to complete the sale of their jointly owned property and divide the proceeds, releasing a considerable sum.

He is wondering about the most effective way of investing his share of the money. 'The housing market has worked well for me,' he says. I have never had this amount of cash.'

He realises he will need to put most of it towards a new home, though he expects to take out a new mortgage for £100,000. He would like to use some for riskier, potentially more profitable, investments.

After the sale of his current home, he plans to stay with friends for a short time while he spends between three and six months looking for the right property. He hopes to keep the cost down by picking up a bargain at an auction, and is already on the lookout.

'I would like a place I can refurbish - somewhere run-down, or even a commercial property which I could convert to residential.'

His last mortgage was with Bristol & West, but is considering approaching a lender such as the Ecology Building Society, which specialises in loans for re-cycling derelict property.

He wants a house with at least two bedrooms so he can let a room to get extra income, and he needs space to work from home four days a week.

Julian intends to use part of the equity in the house he is selling to pay off his £3,500 credit card bills; he will invest the rest. He is wondering whether setting up a savings plan and starting his own shares portfolio would be a good idea.

He is unsure about two endowment policies for a total of £98,000. One was taken out with J Rothschild in 1996, and the other with Scottish Amicable in 1998 as he moved up the housing ladder. Now he does not know whether he should 'transfer them to my new property, continue with them for savings purposes, or get rid of them'.

He also has a personal pension with Friends Provident, taken out in 1997. He started off contributing £150 a month, but after his credit card debts mounted he cut this to £50. He hopes to increase this again soon, and says he does not want to let his card borrowings rise to their previous level again.

Julian adds that he is determined to live within his means in future.

Adviser 1: Charles Levett-Scrivner

Julian's objectives and attitudes appear to put him in the 'high-risk, high-reward' category, but he may be over-ambitious.

Borrowing £100,000 with his basic salary of £30,000 plus bonus - more than three times that basic pay - may be too much. He should arrange his mortgage at a fixed rate, say over between three and five years, to lower risk and protect himself from any future interest rate rises.

His budget for buying and doing up a new house seems to me to be too small. He should be aware than the London property market has risen very strongly in recent years, and could suffer a setback.

By borrowing so much, he could lose his home if he lost his job, because he would be unable to pay the interest on the mortgage, though this risk could be covered by an unemploy ment insurance arranged at the same time as the mortgage.

Julian, as a higher-risk investor, should keep his endowments. He needs to investigate whether the policies are underwritten on his life alone, or jointly with his ex-girlfriend. If they have been arranged with his ex-partner, she needs to be removed as a life assured, which could lead to a small saving.

He should think about equity investment only once the property expenditure has been completed, he has found his lodger and has built an emergency fund of at least three months' expenses.

He should check whether the stakeholder pension scheme, which starts in 2001, has lower costs than his existing one.

Charles Levett-Scrivener works for financial adviser Towry Law.

Adviser 2: Sharon Linnard

Julian's investment strategy will depend on the home he buys and the cost of renovating it.

Initially, he should clear his credit card bills - an expensive form of borrowing - and then invest his equity in the short term in a high-interest instant access postal, telephone or Internet account, which can pay interest of more than 6.5 per cent.

Once he finds a house and all the costs associated with its purchase and development have been identified, other investments can be considered. But there may be little left.

He should go to a broker to seek the best mortgage deal, and make sure the lender he chooses is happy for him to let a room.

If he does let, he should be able to use the 'rent a room' scheme, which will enable him to generate rental income of up to £4,250 a year tax free. Should the income be more than this, it may be worth having it treated as normal rental income, which means he could deduct expenses, such as some mortgage interest.

Endowments may not be fashionable now, but as Julian already has these and will have paid a lot of the initial charges, it will probably be sensible to use them as the vehicle to repay the new mortgage.

Once he knows his new outgoings, there may be money to invest aggressively in the stock market. Julian should balance this with a cash fund, and some longer-term saving in pensions and perhaps equity Isas. The bonuses he expects should give scope for significant tax-efficient saving.

Sharon Linnard works for chartered accountant KPMG.

Advice is for guidance only.

Do you want to appear in Wealthcheck? Write, including daytime and evening telephone numbers, a brief list of circumstances and any investments, to: Wealthcheck, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, or e-mail cash@observer.co.uk You must be prepared to be interviewed and photographed.

His budget for buying and doing up a new house seems to me to be too small. He should be aware than the London property market has risen very strongly in recent years, and could suffer a setback. By borrowing so much, he could lose his home if he lost his job, because he would be unable to pay the interest on the mortgage, though this risk could be covered by an unemploy ment insurance arranged at the same time as the mortgage. Julian, as a higher-risk investor, should keep his endowments. He needs to investigate whether the policies are underwritten on his life alone, or jointly with his ex-girlfriend. If they have been arranged with his ex-partner, she needs to be removed as a life assured, which could lead to a small saving. He should think about equity investment only once the property expenditure has been completed, he has found his lodger and has built an emergency fund of at least three months' expenses. He should check whether the stakeholder pension scheme, which starts in 2001, has lower costs than his existing one. Charles Levett-Scrivener works for financial adviser Towry Law. Adviser 2: Sharon Linnard Julian's investment strategy will depend on the home he buys and the cost of renovating it. Initially, he should clear his credit card bills - an expensive form of borrowing - and then invest his equity in the short term in a high-interest instant access postal, telephone or Internet account, which can pay interest of more than 6.5 per cent. Once he finds a house and all the costs associated with its purchase and development have been identified, other investments can be considered. But there may be little left. He should go to a broker to seek the best mortgage deal, and make sure the lender he chooses is happy for him to let a room. If he does let, he should be able to use the 'rent a room' scheme, which will enable him to generate rental income of up to £4,250 a year tax free. Should the income be more than this, it may be worth having it treated as normal rental income, which means he could deduct expenses, such as some mortgage interest. Endowments may not be fashionable now, but as Julian already has these and will have paid a lot of the initial charges, it will probably be sensible to use them as the vehicle to repay the new mortgage. Once he knows his new outgoings, there may be money to invest aggressively in the stock market. Julian should balance this with a cash fund, and some longer-term saving in pensions and perhaps equity Isas. The bonuses he expects should give scope for significant tax-efficient saving. Sharon Linnard works for chartered accountant KPMG. Advice is for guidance only. Do you want to appear in Wealthcheck?
