webTitle: We can still win this mean game of cards

fields.headline: We can still win this mean game of cards
fields.trailText: Consumers clearly do not want to pay for getting out cash. Although there have been many setbacks for their cause in recent weeks - the closure of bank branches and the decision by Barclays and other banks to levy charges at cash machines - there are also positive signs.
fields.body:
Consumers clearly do not want to pay for getting out cash. Although there have been many setbacks for their cause in recent weeks - the closure of bank branches and the decision by Barclays and other banks to levy charges at cash machines - there are also positive signs.

Tesco, for instance, is taking up the consumer cudgels. The chain of 500 supermarkets plans to double the maximum cashback (at no charge, of course) at the checkout, from £50 to £100.

It would prefer to do this with the co-operation of the banks which run the money transmission systems. And it has started discussions with Switch and Visa Debit, hoping for a response this week. Tesco argues that the £50 limit is long overdue for a rise: it has not been changed in 12 years.

Switch - unlikely to give a formal response until after its next board meeting at the end of May - argues that consumer demand is insufficient, since the average cashback is £23. These arguments are likely to be rehearsed in public over the next few weeks.

Another long-term development could be the growth of electronic money transmission. Mondex, launched with poor public response five years ago, is a £19 smartcard you can charge up with cash over the phone. Although few retailers accept it, the growth of Internet 'micro-payment' buying could change that over the next few years. As more Internet companies start selling low-cost items over the web, Mondex hopes it will be used as the payment mechanism, rather than credit or debit cards.

The debate over paying for cash has a long way to run.

Maria Scott is on holiday

webTitle: Yet more tales of virtual difficulty...

fields.headline: Yet more tales of virtual difficulty...
fields.standfirst: Maria Scott finds more readers fed up (mostly) with Internet banks
fields.trailText: Maria Scott finds more readers fed up (mostly) with Internet banks
fields.body:
Douglas Robertson, of Reading, has, like others we reported last week, had difficulties gaining access to the Co-op's Smile Internet bank account.

'Last October, my wife and I decided to change our banking arrangements. As we both work full-time, reaching a bank during opening hours was becoming increasingly difficult, and reaching a bank counter even more difficult because of the long queues.

'Towards the end of October, my wife applied to open Smile current and savings accounts. A few days later I spent more than £2,000 buying the new Apple iMac computer setup that I had been promising myself for months.'

Mrs Robertson's application was at first rejected, even though she already had an account with the Co-op and a good credit balance.

'It was impossible to speak to a human being over the phone to sort out the erroneous rejection. Apparently the preferred means of communication at that time was email.

'My wife wrote to Smile, whereupon they immediately opened two accounts for her and apologised for the rejection.'

So far, so irritating. But having opened the accounts Mrs Robertson found she could not access them from home.

'Eventually, Smile admitted that they couldn't support access from Apple Mac hardware yet, but hoped to do so in two months,which would be January. They then put the "no Apple Macs yet" information on their web-site. Before my wife applied to open her accounts I had studied Smile's website, but found no mention of problems using Apple Mac equipment.'

Mr Robertson contacted Smile again in January, and this time was told to come back in March. In March, he was told the system would be compatible with Macs by May.

'At this point my wife opened a savings account with Nationwide building society. The new account was opened without problems - whenever we phone we get through first time, and we are now using these accounts successfully over the Internet.'

The Co-op says there has indeed been a problem for Mac users, although it appears to affect the newer version of the iMac, rather than the original. 'We really are wanting to solve it,' said a spokesman.

FOR Loretta Searle of York, the interest rate on her Smile cash Isa was a delight. But, she says: 'It appears that I cannot print out details of my account until after a number of transactions have been completed. As I have invested the maximum £3,000, I cannot pay any more in and I hope I shall not have to take any out. In this case, I have no proof of my account apart from the account number and, in the event of a systems failure, have no tangible evidence of what I have paid in.'

The Co-op says Loretta should be able to download a statement without problems. 'Our techie people will talk her through it,' they promised.

NOT ALL readers' experiences of hi-tech banking have been negative. Don Curtis of Brighton uses an online service from HSBC . This is operated by direct connection, rather than through the Internet. Although the registration process was 'horrendous', once this was completed it was 'an absolute joy to use'.

The Internet account at Nationwide is slower than HSBC's to use but, says Don, this is understandable since it is a true Internet bank linked from its website.

'Thus its security is more elaborate and more than one password check is involved. The plus side is that it can be accessed from any computer wherever you are. Dial-up systems like the HSBC's are accessible only from your home number.'

He adds that Nationwide's service has also improved since it was launched, and offers a wide range of services.

 If you have a story to tell, write to the Personal Finance Editor, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER.

webTitle: Find the home you've been praying for...

fields.headline: Find the home you've been praying for...
fields.standfirst: A revamped church can make a distinctive dwelling.  Graham Norwood looks at reaching to the converted
fields.trailText: As fewer people go to church regularly, conversions of a more materialist kind are on the increase: turning the buildings into homes.
fields.body:
As fewer people go to church regularly, conversions of a more materialist kind are on the increase: turning the buildings into homes.

Around 70 UK churches are sold off every year, and there is no shortage of long-standing conversions on our streets - 10,000 were put on the market by the Church of England and the Catholic and Methodist authorities during the last century.

City churches are often large and suitable for conversion into flats. Upmarket customers are attracted by the distinctiveness of the accommodation, the large rooms, the period windows and city centre locations.

Rural churches are smaller, and frequently become unique and charming family homes, often acting as village centrepieces.

Some ecclesiastical buildings are sold for more exotic purposes - Nottingham's Central Methodist Mission became a nightclub - but whatever the ultimate use, developers do not always leap at the chance to convert a church.

The saga of Middlesbrough's old Catholic cathedral shows why. 'It's in an area of extreme urban deprivation, about 500 yards from the city centre. We've had plans for social housing, executive housing, an art gallery and commercial use - all of them failed to take off,' says Father Derek Turnham, the parish priest.

'We've had a series of city centre redevelopments since the Second World War: each one reduced the significance of the cathedral's location because of a shift in the commercial element of the centre or roadbuilding, which has cut car parking spaces.'

In 1986 a new Catholic cathedral was built in a residential part of the town, but plans to sell or demolish the old one were complicated by its status as a Grade II-listed building.

'The conservationists wouldn't have it - and we've been fighting them ever since,' says Turnham.

There is inevitably a conflict between conservation groups and developers or one-off buyers who want to convert a church, says Jonathan Hewlett, head of the Sloane Street office of the property consultancy FPD Savills. 'Someone wanting to convert or live in a former church is likely to be a little flamboyant, wanting something quirky, and keen to exploit the space and the light.

'They are people who like originality and they're going to want to put in floors or make changes which inevitably remove it from what it used to be,' he says.

'There is almost bound to be some conflict with English Heritage and other groups.'

Each denomination has a different procedure for selling off property, but most devolve the decision to local members, who must be satisfied that the reduced attendance justifies the disposal.

'Each diocese is autonomous,' says the Reverend Kieran Conry, director of the Catholic media office. 'All the disposals we've had in recent years have been because of population shifts, and in particular the move away from city centres.

'We have cathedrals in Liverpool, Middlesbrough and Clifton in Bristol which are now being disposed of, despite a growth in the number of dioceses we have overall,' he adds.

Church authorities will sometimes try to find alternative religious uses, even involving other denominations. Organisations such as the Church of England insist that disposal decisions be based on ensuring the best alternative use for a building - not on extracting the maximum market value.

If the property includes a graveyard, there will probably be a deconsecration procedure and consultation with relatives of those buried there. There could even be agreement for people to retain access to some of the land to tend graves.

Despite the low number of converted churches and the potential expense of conversion, they do not always cost the earth.

Boltby Chapel, on the North Yorkshire moors near Thirsk, retains early twentieth-century original features such as arches, exposed beams and stone walls. It has four bedrooms, two bathrooms and even a small service lift reaching all three floors. It is on the market through Strutt and Parker (01423 561274) for just £275,000 - the price of a London two-bedroom flat.

In Cheshire there is Tabernacle Cottage, a seventeenth century church converted in the Eighties into a three-bedroom, two-bathroom house with gardens, a terrace and a pond, on sale, also through Strutt and Parker, for £289,000 (01244 320747).

The most spectacular churches reach the other extreme of the market. Harrods Estates is selling the First Church of Christ the Scientist near its Knightsbridge store in London.

The building is vast - its first-floor auditorium is big enough for 1,300 worshippers. But it has been empty for five years and is now on the market for a cool £6 million, complete with planning permission for conversion into a luxurious eight- bedroom home, with swimming pool and gym, library, accommodation for domestic staff and underground parking for six cars.

'While it's been empty there have been talks with English Heritage and planning authorities to make sure the proposed conversion has their support,' said FPD Savills' Hewlett (020 7730 0822).

'The planners say any conversion must be residential, because of the housing around it, and this was about the easiest kind of high-quality house we could achieve with the support of conservation groups,' says Hewlett.

At that price in a premium location, it is not surprising that developers snap up redundant churches. Most individuals have to settle for buying the completed conversion.

But if you are determined to have the ultimate do-it-yourself job, ask local church organisations whether any building is being considered for disposal, and befriend your local planners and conservation groups.

fields.headline: Cashpoints
fields.trailText:
We're living long - and prospering

Legal & General is cutting its term life assurance premiums 'by up to 6 per cent' - to reflect 'mortality statistics that indicate that the average life expectancy has increased'. The monthly premium for a 45-year-old female non-smoker on a sum assured of £50,000 is being cut from £11.80 to £11.20.
fields.body:
We're living long - and prospering
Legal & General is cutting its term life assurance premiums 'by up to 6 per cent' - to reflect 'mortality statistics that indicate that the average life expectancy has increased'. The monthly premium for a 45-year-old female non-smoker on a sum assured of £50,000 is being cut from £11.80 to £11.20.

The reason: 'A 35-year-old insured woman now has a life expectancy of 88 years and one month; compared with 84 years and seven months in 1980. The average 35-year-old insured male now has a life expectancy of 85 years and one month; compared with 80 years and one month in 1980.'

Trip below par?

More people are now going on golfing holidays to Spain, Portugal and the US, according to direct insurer, Club Direct. This is why they are promoting their own specialist package that covers golfing equipment, accidental damage, and cancelled green fees as well as providing the standard travel terms. A week's cover in Europe costs £27.90. Tel: 0800 074 4556.

Returning office

Unit trust investors wanting help with the investments part of their tax return can get a free leaflet, 'Unit Trusts and Tax - Completing your return. What you need to tell the taxman 1999/2000'. It is available from the Association of Unit Trusts on 020 8207 1361.

Young shoulders
MONEY is the biggest cause of anxiety among young people, according to research commissioned by Alliance & Leicester. About two-thirds of 16 to 24-year-olds worry about money and not having enough of it to go out. The older you are the less likely you are to be worried by money, according to the research. One in three 25 to 34-year-olds worries about money, compared with one in five of 35 to 44-year-olds.

...and old heads

Close to retirement? Financial adviser Chartwell is offering two free booklets, a 'Guide to Annuities' and a 'Retirement Options Guide'. Telephone 01225 321710, or write to Freepost BS9409, Bath, BA1 2BF. The guides are also available on www.chartwell-investment.co.uk. The annuities guide explains the workings of conventional, with-profit and unit-linked annuities, commenting on nine different products. The options guide is for people who want to take maximum control of their funds through phased annuities and income drawdown.

Tax ticks

Lloyds TSB has rushed out its Tax Guide 2000/ 2001 a month after the Budget. It sells in bookshops for £7.99, but publisher Profile Books is offering it at £6.99, including p&p. Telephone 020-8324 5530 or email bookshop@bvcd.prestel.co.uk.

The 336-page book includes the Budget changes, chapters on basic issues such as filling in your tax return and '75 ways to save tax'.

Car cares

About 30,000 drivers are expected to have breakdown problems this Easter, according to the RAC. The top five problems for motorists taking their cars abroad are electronics faults, a blown head gasket, seized engines, accidents and a blown radiator.

The typical cost for repairing the starter motor in a family saloon car is £800 in continental Europe. A blown head gasket costs £500, a seized engine £1,500.

Not surprisingly, the RAC is trying to encourage drivers to take out breakdown cover. Details from 08000 726 999 or on www.rac.co.uk/travel.

fields.headline: Squaring the charity circle
fields.standfirst: Give good causes the cold shoulder - and more cash.  Andrew Bibby explains how
fields.trailText: Stand by for an increase in the mail you receive from charities. Since the start of the tax year on 6 April, even the smallest donations to charity are now potentially eligible for tax relief under the Gift Aid rules
fields.body:
Stand by for an increase in the mail you receive from charities. Since the start of the tax year on 6 April, even the smallest donations to charity are now potentially eligible for tax relief under the Gift Aid rules. Britain's charities, which expect the new rules to benefit them collectively by £1 billion over the next two years, are all set to promote the opportunities the Government has provided.

The tax changes are good news, but the junk mail may be less appreciated, even by people who want to give to good causes: charities use direct marketing techniques because they are cost-effective, but not everyone welcomes another heart-tugging letter in the post.

There are ways to avoid the guilt, however. A small group of friends in Kew, south-west London, have devised an innovative way to organise their charitable giving. Since January last year they have been meeting informally once a month to decide collectively which charities they want to support.

'We enjoy ourselves, it's very easy to do, and we get away from feeling guilty about the begging letters,' says Judy Weleminsky, who came up with the idea. 'I didn't want to just bin the appeals and not give to charity, though I suspected that was what many other people of potential goodwill were doing.'

Meetings of the Kew Giving Circle, as the group is now called, rotate among the houses, with the host usually responsible not only for providing coffee and cakes, but also for nominating the charity of the month. Normally £50 or £100 is jointly given each month: just over £1,000 was donated in the group's first year. Charities supported include the Red Cross, Crisis at Christmas, the Jubilee 2000 anti-debt campaign, the Kosovo appeal, the Rainbow Fund for South Africa and - at the suggestion of children of one of the group's members - Childline.

The group currently consists of six individuals and two couples, almost all of whom are parents of children at the same local primary school.

'I think the idea of a giving circle works as a local initiative. We all live within walking distance, and we normally meet at about nine o'clock, when the kids are in bed,' says Weleminsky, a former chief executive in the voluntary sector and now a freelance consultant. 'It's fun and it seems to work. We all learn a bit from each other.'

There are ground rules: members undertake not to nominate charities in which they have a direct personal interest, which rules out, among other things, the school PTA. The aim is to give to a mix of local, national and international charities. The members agree to support each other's choice of charity, unless strong objections are raised. The group is also clear that it is not its role to engage in fundraising.

The practical arrangements have been kept simple. The giving circle has taken advantage of the Charity Cheque account scheme, run by Charities Aid Foundation (CAF), with members making their own donations privately into a joint CAF account. 'Some people put in £10 a month, some £50 a quarter, some have put in a £300 lump sum,' Weleminsky says. At the end of each meeting, a cheque drawn on the CAF account is sent off to the chosen charity.

webTitle: Crisis? It pays to keep your head

fields.headline: Crisis? It pays to keep your head
fields.trailText: The value of shares can go down as well as up. Surely the regulators who came up with that warning did not expect that markets would do both, several times the same day.
fields.body:
The value of shares can go down as well as up. Surely the regulators who came up with that warning did not expect that markets would do both, several times the same day. Share prices have rarely been more volatile, alternately soaring and plunging on sudden changes in sentiment. But the professionals' advice is unanimous: do not panic.

It is far better, they say, to remain fully invested than to buy and sell on market movements. Transaction costs will erode any profits you may make from jumping in and out of the market. Much more importantly, even the experts do not claim to be able to spot the peaks and the troughs: amateur investors risk being expensively wrong.

Fidelity Investments, the fund manager, says that if you had invested in the stock market at the end of 1987 and held on to the shares until the end of last year, you would have made an average of 16.2 per cent a year. But if you had missed the best 40 days, the return would have fallen to 6.7 per cent, before dealing costs.

'Investors widely predicted that the remarkable [US] bull run of the Nineties would end at the start of 1994, 1995, 1996, 1997 and 1998. These predictions were wrong every time,' says Fidelity. 'Whether the market's rise was justified by the economic fundamentals, or valuations were pushed well beyond what would normally be regarded as reasonable, is immaterial.

'Even the experts cannot call the market accurately and consistently.'

Fidelity is undoubtedly right that investment in shares should be for the long term, but that does not necessarily mean that long-term investors will make money. For most periods in the past 100 years, shares have been the best-performing investments, particularly if dividends were reinvested. But those who bought just before the big stock market crashes of the Twenties, the Thirties and the Seventies, for example, would have had to wait a long time before they started showing a profit, after taking account of inflation. Anyone who put in £100 at the end of 1968, for example, would have had to wait until the end of 1993 before making money in real terms.

That was not the only period of lengthy declines: an investor at the end of 1937 would still have been nursing losses, in real terms, 20 years later. Timing your entry into the market is as crucial as timing your exit.

These statistics reflect the market as a whole, but investors buy shares, not markets. Choosing the right ones is crucial. The market may have been rising almost constantly since 1980, but some companies have gone bust - remember Polly Peck - and others have done very badly, such as Hanson and Somerfield. Anyone invested in firms like these would have done far worse than the market average.

fields.headline: Media diary
fields.trailText: Not ON | Girls on top
fields.body:
Balls, my liege
ONdigital's airing of the compelling Barcelona v Chelsea match on Tuesday failed to reach at least one subscriber - bouncy Tony Ball, chief executive of BSkyB.

He rushed home to catch the game on the competitor's digital service to find that he could only get 90 minutes of kakalaka in the form of Lazio v Valencia. Mr Ball allegedly called the service centre to get the glitch sorted, only to find the switchboards jammed.

Uh-oh. It was a bittersweet evening in the Ball household, because while as a 10 per cent shareholder in Chelsea, Sky now faces the possibility that their team is going to win f*** all - this will also be the case with Leeds United, in which Sky also has a stake. (A curse story in waiting?)

But on the other hand Mr Ball can derive some satisfaction from his shocking service at the hands of a competitor - unless, of course, OnDigital specifically targeted his house for a 'prank'.

OnDigital, when contacted about the predicament, said it was 'devastated' that Mr Ball hadn't been able to see the match but added: 'The difficulty seems to have been extremely localised.'

Cox up
The Telegraph, anxious to keep up its triple babe masthead count, rushed Friends star Courteney Cox Arquette on to its front page sells. Curiously though, it a) failed to note the actress's married status and b) spelt her first name wrong - with only one 'e'.

Change at top
Guardian Newspapers Ltd, owner of The Observer and its sister paper the Guardian, has appointed Carolyn McCall as its new managing director. McCall takes over from outgoing managing director Caroline Marland in November, in what must be a rare case of one woman succeeding another at the top of a newspaper company. Perhaps it will catch on.

fields.headline: Boom town
fields.standfirst: From Heathrow's T5 to Sir Norman Foster's 'glass fencing mask', London is in the grip of the biggest building frenzy it's seen in 50 years. Deyan Sudjic reports on the changing face of the 21st-century city
fields.trailText: From Heathrow's T5 to Sir Norman Foster's 'glass fencing mask', London is in the grip of the biggest building frenzy it's seen in 50 years. Deyan Sudjic reports on the changing face of the 21st-century city
fields.body:
It is a decade since Richard Rogers first started work on a project that will one day dwarf even his millennium Dome.

A quarter of a mile long, with a flow of more than 20 million people spilling under its rollercoaster glass-and-steel roof each year, and a price tag nudging £2 billion, Heathrow's fifth terminal is the biggest single architectural project London has ever seen.

But if London is getting ready to build big, it still hasn't worked out how to build fast. There is an entire office block on the Bath Road with 300 people in it devoted entirely to Terminal 5, but there is nothing more to show for their efforts than a tidied-up sewage farm on which the airport will one day stand, and pantechnicon-loads of documents for a public inquiry more convoluted than a Norse saga. By contrast, that same 10 years have been time enough for Rogers's old partner, Norman Foster, to win the competition to design Hong Kong's no less impressive new airport, Chep Lap Kok, build it, and see it open for business.

In the process, a derelict dump on the edge of one of central London's least appetising inner city streets - an area as big as Soho - will have been made safe for footloose Euro business at a cost of another £2 billion. The man in the Hugo Boss suit will be able to fly into Terminal 5, board the Heathrow Express and be in one of the gleaming office towers in the Paddington Basin to meet the marketing team from Barcelona and the account handlers from Stuttgart - from plane door to front door in half an hour.

And to make it easier still, Paddington station is planing to turn itself inside out. Rather than put its main entrance on its south side, under the rebuilt Great Western Hotel, Paddington's public face will be moved east, so that it will look directly over the canal basin, and be linked to the new offices by a pair of spidery bridges.

Put together, these developments represent nothing less than the root and branch re-engineering of a huge swathe of London. They will turn land values upside down, create thousands of new jobs, and give London a city gate in Terminal 5 that has a good chance of fighting off cut-throat competition from its rivals in Paris, Frankfurt and Amsterdam.

London is in the grip of a frenzied rebuilding the like of which it has not experienced in 50 years. Later this year we will see the completion of the last of the big Lottery projects. The millennium bridge, the first completely new crossing of the Thames for a century, the great court at the British Museum, the Welcome Wing at the Science Museum, and the Tate Modern will all join the Royal Opera House and the Dome on the roll call of London's millennial trophies.

But the biggest is yet to come. A group of developers, with the invincible sense of self-confidence that comes from having known only good times for a decade, are responsible for a wave of brashly assertive and conspicuous landmarks. Everywhere you look, there are earth-moving machines, forests of tower cranes and scaffolding.

Take the seat of the Greater London Authority, the glass fencing mask designed by Norman Foster, just across the river from the Tower of London. It is a privately funded scheme, even though it has a public-sector body as its sole tenant. It will be the first step in the redevelopment of the area into a new office district. In the City of London itself, Swiss Re, the re-insurance giant, is planning to build itself another unmistakable landmark, also designed by Norman Foster. It is his first British skyscraper, rising 41 floors above the site of the old Baltic Exchange.

And there are half a dozen other private projects which will have the same impact: the new Wembley Stadium, for example, the Kings Cross railway lands, the reconstruction of White City, the Millennium village at Greenwich, the attempts to breathe life into the capital's forgotten north-east around Newham. Big private developments, transforming whole slices of London with landmark structures.

The jaundiced would see the new London as a simple re-run of the speculative boom of the 1960s, though the brute concrete has given way to steel and glass, and the much-derided commercial architects have been supplanted by Rogers, Foster and Terry Farrell, as well as Nicholas Grimshaw and Michael Hopkins. The big names are building big. But the generation that will one day follow them, the David Chipperfields, the Zaha Hadids, the Will Alsops and others, are almost nowhere to be seen. The problem is that like generals who constantly fight the battles of the next war with the weapons and tactics of the last, architects have found themselves building the projects that never quite made it last time around. The London of 2007 would have looked pretty extraordinary if only it had been finished in 1987, when a lot of the ideas that are shaping it first took root. As it is, there will be a sense of déjô vu.

It's as if the development of London was a game of musical chairs. Year after year, the music plays and nothing happens as the contestants warily circle the furniture. Then suddenly, every 20 years or so, the music finally stops and the contestants fight it out for a seat and the chance to build whatever it was they first thought of when the music started. There is it seems, simply no time to do anything else.

fields.headline: Life support
fields.standfirst: Rape, drugs and violent crimes barrister Deborah Morris specialises in the sharp end of London life. Key to her defence is the input of trainee barrister Jonthan Goodman. We follow them through a typical day in court
fields.trailText: Rape, drugs and violent crimes barrister Deborah Morris specialises in the sharp end of London life. Key to her defence is the input of trainee barrister Jonthan Goodman. We follow them through a typical day in court
fields.body:
Deborah Morris
We are in Wood Green Crown Court, defending in what amounts to a neighbours dispute. It is serious because our client, who is one of a family of Greeks living in north London, stands to lose not only his liberty but his home if he is found guilty.

It's a complicated case and the whole family is charged on 15 counts ranging from threats to kill through to putting people in fear of violence and criminal damage. The accusations come from the next-door neighbours, originally an East End family. This is not in any way a racial trial, but is one of those tragedies in which no one will be the winner. The case has already been in court for four and a half weeks.

Jonathan Goodman, who acts as my 'noting' junior in this case and is consequently being paid a fee for it, is one of the most gifted pupils I have worked with. Like me, he came late to the law, having worked in commerce in the Midlands. He's 44 now, but was a lay magistrate for five years before deciding to study law at Luton University where he won a first class LLB (Hons) in two years, so he knows what he's doing. This is a complicated trial with a number of accusations and video evidence, and I need his help.

I am deputy head of chambers at Number One Grays Inn Square, where Jonathan has been a pupil since last October. His pupilage will last 12 months of which he has already spent six as a student taking no active part in court proceedings. Now, he is able to appear in court in his own right.

Work during the trial is intense and we are in each other's company for five days every week. As luck would have it, we are happy in each other's company; in fact, he's taking me out to dinner tonight. He is specialising in crime and criminal fraud, which means that his knowledge and experience is already of great help.

I am meticulous about preparation and, in the course of a trial, Jonathan will do much of the legal research for me. If, for instance, it is a complicated and difficult fraud, he will work on the chronology of the witness statements and give me an outline, in a simplified form, of who said what and when. When I am cross-examining a witness and Jonathan feels that I have forgotten to make a point, he will make a note and pass it across.

I love my job, but I came to the law late. I am 45-years-old and was called to the Bar when I was 34, after starting my career as a model, then as a teacher in a comprehensive and finally as an accountant. Virtually all my Bar work is as a defence advocate, but I only work in the London Crown Courts, such as Snaresbrook, Wood Green, Middlesex Crown Court, The Old Bailey and Southwark, because I have two small children and I feel that they have a right to see their mother in the evening.

One of the problems facing all barristers is the difficulties of juggling their time. Trials tend to run on for all sorts of reasons; a juror can be taken ill, or a defendant can fail to turn up. The jury has just retired in this case so, although they have 15 counts to consider, we expect to finish by the beginning of next week at the latest. In fact, I have a rape case starting at Middlesex Crown Court on Monday and I also have a 'Pleas and Directions' at Snaresbrook on the same day. This is when the judge will hear pleas, agree witnesses, fix the date of a trial and any preliminary issues of law will be raised. I have briefed Jonathan to handle this for me and am more than happy for him to do it. I know him well enough to be happy with delegating this sort of work to him.

Jonathan Goodman
I am now more than half way through my pupilage and this is one of the first criminal trials at which I have been able to take an active part. There are three defendants in the case and the consequence has been that I have had to carry out a great deal of research and preparation for the defence team. If counsel is not sufficiently prepared, it comes across in court and is always obvious to the jury. In this trial, for example, Deborah has asked me to prepare the discrepancy charts which we need as a means of throwing up any contradictions there may be between witness statements.

I have also put together a chronological exhibit list, so when the defence asks for the jury to be shown an exhibit, it can be dealt with immediately and efficiently.

Deborah specialises in rape, sex cases, serious drugs, fraud and violent crimes, and I suppose you could say she is at the sharp end of the criminal Bar. I have now attended 10 full trials with her, and I am learning what you can never learn at law school, which is the unpredictable and rough and tumble nature of what goes on in a Crown Court, the unpredictability of witnesses and the perverse attitudes of juries.

This trial has also given me a chance to see how personally difficult the proceedings have been for our client and how important it is for the defence to look after those they represent. Deborah is a fearless advocate and fights for her clients. In this case, there have been tremendous feelings of tension and fear amongst our clients who stand to lose their home and their liberty if the verdict goes against them. It brings it home to me how important it is to do all you can to win the case for your client. You learn very little about passion and the will to win in law school.

I am at the beginning of my career as a lawyer. I decided that I wanted to become a barrister about five years ago, and I suppose I am about two thirds of the way there. When I come to the end of my pupilage, I have to apply for a tenancy in chambers. If that is not forthcoming, then you could say I have wasted three years of my life, because there is little chance of me achieving my ambition. However, Deborah has been an inspirational person to work with and I feel fairly confident about the future.

This trial is a tragedy for the defendants and the family which has accused them. Neither side can win, really. It has gone far beyond that. They have fallen out so badly, they will never be able to come to terms with their hatred of one another.

The jury has now returned after six hours considering all 15 counts and have found for the defence on every single count. This means that our clients and the rest of their family are released without a stain on their characters. I have to say, it feels great.

If, for instance, it is a complicated and difficult fraud, he will work on the chronology of the witness statements and give me an outline, in a simplified form, of who said what and when. When I am cross-examining a witness and Jonathan feels that I have forgotten to make a point, he will make a note and pass it across. I love my job, but I came to the law late. I am 45-years-old and was called to the Bar when I was 34, after starting my career as a model, then as a teacher in a comprehensive and finally as an accountant. Virtually all my Bar work is as a defence advocate, but I only work in the London Crown Courts, such as Snaresbrook, Wood Green, Middlesex Crown Court, The Old Bailey and Southwark, because I have two small children and I feel that they have a right to see their mother in the evening. One of the problems facing all barristers is the difficulties of juggling their time. Trials tend to run on for all sorts of reasons; a juror can be taken ill, or a defendant can fail to turn up. The jury has just retired in this case so, although they have 15 counts to consider, we expect to finish by the beginning of next week at the latest. In fact, I have a rape case starting at Middlesex Crown Court on Monday and I also have a 'Pleas and Directions' at Snaresbrook on the same day. This is when the judge will hear pleas, agree witnesses, fix the date of a trial and any preliminary issues of law will be raised. I have briefed Jonathan to handle this for me and am more than happy for him to do it. I know him well enough to be happy with delegating this sort of work to him. Jonathan Goodman I am now more than half way through my pupilage and this is one of the first criminal trials at which I have been able to take an active part. There are three defendants in the case and the consequence has been that I have had to carry out a great deal of research and preparation for the defence team. If counsel is not sufficiently prepared, it comes across in court and is always obvious to the jury. In this trial, for example, Deborah has asked me to prepare the discrepancy charts which we need as a means of throwing up any contradictions there may be between witness statements. I have also put together a chronological exhibit list, so when the defence asks for the jury to be shown an exhibit, it can be dealt with immediately and efficiently. Deborah specialises in rape, sex cases, serious drugs, fraud and violent crimes, and I suppose you could say she is at the sharp end of the criminal Bar. I have now attended 10 full trials with her, and I am learning what you can never learn at law school, which is the unpredictable and rough and tumble nature of what goes on in a Crown Court, the unpredictability of witnesses and the perverse attitudes of juries. This trial has also given me a chance to see how personally difficult the proceedings have been for our client and how important it is for the defence to look after those they represent. Deborah is a fearless advocate and fights for her clients. In this case, there have been tremendous feelings of tension and fear amongst our clients who stand to lose their home and their liberty if the verdict goes against them. It brings it home to me how important it is to do all you can to win the case for your client. You learn very little about passion and the will to win in law school. I am at the beginning of my career as a lawyer. I decided that I wanted to become a barrister about five years ago, and I suppose I am about two thirds of the way there. When I come to the end of my pupilage, I have to apply for a tenancy in chambers. If that is not forthcoming, then you could say I have wasted three years of my life, because there is little chance of me achieving my ambition. However, Deborah has been an inspirational person to work with and I feel fairly confident about the future. This trial is a tragedy for the defendants and the family which has accused them. Neither side can win, really. It has gone far beyond that. They have fallen out so badly, they will never be able to come to terms with their hatred of one another. The jury has now returned after six hours considering all 15 counts and have found for the defence on every single count. This means that our clients and the rest of their family are released without a stain on their characters. I have to say, it feels great.

fields.headline: North of the border clashes
fields.standfirst: Fierce new competition sees the  Scotsman at daggers drawn.  Stuart Millar  reports
fields.trailText: Fierce new competition sees the Scotsman at daggers drawn. Stuart Millar reports
fields.body:
In the salubrious Holyrood district of Edinburgh, a storm is breaking. Not over the ugly building site which is all that is visible of the expensive Scottish parliament fiasco, but across the road in the plush new offices of the Scotsman newspaper.

Just weeks before a vital and long-awaited relaunch, the traditional champion of liberalism north of the border is in turmoil. The paper was rocked to its foundations last week with the shock announcement that its new editor, Tim Luckhurst, is taking long-term sick leave - suffering from high blood pressure and severe stress.

No wonder. In the two months since the departure of Luckhurst's predecessor, Alan Ruddock, the paper has been engaged in near-permanent bloodletting. The deputy editor has gone, the night editor has gone, and the news editor has gone, as have the features editor and much of the business and reporting staff. Then on Friday associate editor Dean Nelson resigned, only three months after joining the paper from the Observer.

And there may be more bad news around the corner. Well-informed sources are suggesting that Luckhurst will not be returning to his new job. 'You have to ask whether it's worth your health, and the answer is: it's not,' remarked one insider.

One effect of the current fallout has been to reignite criticism of Andrew Neil, the combative publisher of the Scotsman and its sister paper Scotland on Sunday. More fundamentally, the strife in Holyrood comes just as the Scottish newspaper market is going ballistic.

Since Neil was put in to oversee the Scotsman by the Barclay brothers in 1996, sales have continued to bump disappointingly around the 80,000 mark, and there have been constant tales of him interfering in the editorial direction - of furious phone calls from London berating executives.

'People get overexcited about Andrew Neil's politics,' a former senior executive told The Observer . 'But it's his incompetence as a manager that's the problem. He doesn't know how to deal with people; he doesn't know how to build a strategy to make a paper successful. In my opinion, he is a one-trick pony. Nothing he has touched since he left the Sunday Times has worked. The more you change people around - the more flux there is - the less chance you have of success.'

Ruddock left in February after he and his publisher had clashed over the direction of the paper. Ruddock envisaged it becoming a national newspaper for Scotland. Neil, however, is determined that it should become an international broadsheet which just happens to be based north of the border.

That is where the much-heralded relaunch comes in. Backed by a multi-million pound promotion, the expanded Scotsman will have beefed-up news and features coverage plus a Guardian G2- style tabloid - imaginatively titled S2. Luckhurst, Ruddock's deputy, was made acting editor, to see through the changes.

But the big surprise was the appointment of Rebecca Hardy as joint deputy editor in charge of S2. Until she got the call from Neil, she had been senior feature writer at the Daily Mail, and had little editing experience. Now she is running the Scotsman . 'Don't underestimate Rebecca,' said one well-placed supporter. 'She'll be in there to prove her self, and I wouldn't be surprised if she had her eye on the editor's job.'

Gathering staff together last week, she announced her intention to make the paper 'great again'. Neither Neil nor Hardy was available for comment last week, but a spokesman for the Scotsman's London PR agency denied rumours that Luckhurst would not be returning to work. He added: 'There have been a number of departures. The Scotsman is undergoing a radical replanning. Changes in personnel are inevitable because the paper is moving forward, developing its journalism and improving its coverage for readers.'

The Scotsman has not been helped by the fact that its troubles come just as the Scottish newspaper market is set to become even more competitive with the launch by Swedish group Bonnier of the first new daily for over a century. Focusing on business and politics, its editor will be John Penman, a former executive at the Scotsman and the Daily Record. The arrival of the new paper has had a painful effect on the Scotsman . Perhaps the biggest blow before last week's developments was the resignation of widely admired deputy editor Richard Neville, who left to join his old colleague Penman. Almost the entire business desk and the core of the reporting team have followed him.

Neville insists the decision to move was a positive one. 'I never thought in my career that there would ever be another daily paper launched in Scotland. But the timing is right, and it was a really simple decision to make.'

Neville says the new paper will be a supplementary read, offering upmarket business readers deeper coverage to complement what is already on offer. But few executives in Edinburgh doubt that it will further damage the struggling Scotsman .

That is not Neil's only headache. Scotland on Sunday is locked in a fierce and vitriolic battle with the Glasgow-based Sunday Herald, launched 14 months ago by the Scottish Media Group, owner of the Herald newspaper and Scottish and Grampian television stations. Its official sales hover around 50,000 compared with the 110,000 regularly achieved by its Edinburgh rival, but under the direction of Andrew Jaspan, former editor of Scotland on Sunday and The Observer, it has mounted a no-holds-barred campaign to pinch readers which culminated last weekend in a 10p price offer. SoS, in a move which smacked of panic, immediately did likewise.

Early unofficial figures say sales went up to 135,000, while the Sunday Herald's almost doubled to 95,000 copies.

'A lot of our readers who would previously not have been tempted to buy the Sunday Herald will have given it a go when they saw they could get our paper for 10p,' said Kevin McKenna, SoS deputy editor. 'We think that somebody will soon pull the plug on the Sunday Herald . If you look at its news pages, you can see that there is no advertising, no commercial activity at all.'

But Jaspan remains defiant. 'Once people start looking at the paper, they enjoy it. We just have to get them to try it. SoS are getting very upset about this, but it is 12 years old, and we are just trying to get up to speed. We will resort to anything we can.'

The turmoil looks set to continue.

fields.headline: @large
fields.trailText: Silicon fens | Terminal abuse
fields.body:
Suffolk punch
Cambridge's reputation as the UK home for cutting-edge technology is having some interesting spin-offs. In a move that smacks of bandwagon-jumping, nearby Ipswich will this week announce the creation of a 'hi-tech corridor' linking the town to the home of Silicon Fen. As such, Ipswich will subsequently be marketed as a 'hi-tech cluster within the corridor', a move which the town hopes will 'create thousands of jobs'. Inspired. We look forward to the imminent creation of the Govan-Cambridge corridor, not to mention the Toxteth/Cambridge cluster, as other towns get in on the act.

Lambeth squawk

'Lamberth declares war on cyber-squatters' screams the press release. And boy does the London borough mean to take a tough line against squatters' guides on the Internet. In future, the council's bulletin boards and guides will be carrying 'Keep out of Lambeth' messages. Problem solved.

Virgin calling
'Ten things you could buy with £1.3 billion' is the headline for a nice piece of advertorial in last week's Mirror promoting Virgin's mobile phone network.

Apparently, Virgin claims that if everyone on a mobile in the UK switched to its network, the total saved would be £1.3 billion - enough to buy more than 10 teams worth of Emile Heskeys or 3.25 billion Cadbury's cream eggs.

Or, given Virgin's recent credit crunch, the sum would be enough to pay off the debts Branson's Our Price and megastore chains had clocked up with the record companies several times over. Strangely, the latter option was not mentioned in the piece, despite the fact that it ran to four pages.

Silver-tongued?
A report in the net magazine found that 'silver surfers' - Internet users aged 65 and over - are the group most likely to swear at their computers. Half of those people aged 65 and over admitted to having directed expletives at their terminals. Apparently, one in 10 Londoners has actually hit their machines, the survey found.

fields.headline: BNFL's nuclear fallout
fields.standfirst: Safety and privatisation just don't add up in this case of mismanagement, reports  Oliver Morgan
fields.trailText: Safety and privatisation just don't add up in this case of mismanagement, reports Oliver Morgan
fields.body:
The rest of the world may be four months into the new millennium. But last Tuesday the calendars at British Nuclear Fuels' central London offices read 01/01/00.

Hugh Collum and Norman Askew, chairman and chief executive of the nuclear reprocessor, generator and decommissioner, spent all day in BNFL's Buckingham Gate boardroom trying to persuade the world that this was the nuclear year zero.

They have to succeed. In the past three months BNFL has suffered some of the most ferocious criticism ever heaped on a British commercial organisation. Regulators, government, MPs, environmentalists, even customers, have poured scorn on its safety, management, environmental record and accounting practices.

Three reports by the Nuclear Installations Inspectorate, the industry watchdog, into operations at BNFL's Sellafield plant in Cumbria were published in February. They could scarcely have been more damning.

One, written after a two-week inspection of Sellafield last September, found 'a lack of a high-quality safety management systems across the site' and 'insufficient resources to implement even the existing safety management system'.

During that inspection a major scandal broke at Sellafield. Staff at a demonstration facility for production of an experimental mixed plutonium and uranium fuel (MOX) were exposed as falsifying data. The NII began a second investigation.

Its report damned Sellafield a second time. 'In a plant with the proper safety culture, the events discussed in this report could not have happened,' it said.

But the NII was not alone. The Environment Agency pitched in. Its criticisms were not focused simply on Sellafield; they included its fuel manufacturing plant at Springfields as well as some of its ageing Magnox power stations.

As if all this were not enough, the politicians had their penn'orth too. Martin O'Neill, chairman of the influential commons Trade and Industry Select Committee, criticised BNFL's accounts for being at best unclear. It also said the company treated the Government and the public with 'disdain'.

Collum must have wondered what had hit him. His City background saw him appointed last autumn to steer the company through the planned public-private partnership (PPP) - effectively a part privatisation.

No sooner had he arrived than the organisation began disintegrating around him. In the wake of the NII reports, the Government put off the PPP. Collum started fighting back days after those reports. He replaced BNFL's chief executive John Taylor with Askew, a respected utility boss.

Askew says that when he arrived he could not work out how Sellafield operated. 'I am used to organisations where there is very clear accountability,' he said. 'I didn't find that. There were people running parts of it with different safety systems in different parts of the site. I just said: why isn't one person running it?'

On Tuesday, Collum and Askew presented a plan aimed at overhauling safety and management. A freeze on job cuts was announced. Four clear business groups were set out: fuel manufacturing; electricity generation at Magnox power stations; spent fuel management including reprocessing; and decommissioning.

There was a clear-out of all non-executive directors, along with half the executive board, including finance director Ross Chiese and safety director David Coulston.

Askew says the plan has to be implemented within 18 months if the company is to survive. He is confident.

But at its core is a tension that may well undermine that confidence. On the one hand, Collum and Askew have to prove that BNFL is safe. On the other, they have to bring the PPP back on track by the end of 2002. They maintain the two are not mutually exclusive. Collum says: 'The disciplines of the PPP were making people understand that some of the changes had got to happen.'

But there are bound to be controversies. For example, the NII criticised BNFL for being 'underresourced' and pointed to stretched manpower.

Askew says that although employment levels will be frozen now for safety reasons, jobs will go at privatisation: 'When you take a business from the public sector to the private, you can do it with fewer people.'

So the question is, can safety and commercialisation be reconciled? Many believe they cannot.

Again, concerns focus on Sellafield's reprocessing oper ations. Reprocessing involves taking spent uranium fuel and breaking it down into reprocessed uranium, plutonium and nuclear waste. In theory, the uranium can be reused in reactors, or mixed with the plutonium in MOX fuel. Its commercial viability has never been clear. Neither has it been safe - the Sellafield site has been linked with safety scares ever since it was opened in 1953 (see right).

BNFL has been playing down the role of reprocessing in its business model for some time. Askew says it currently represents between 20 and 25 per cent of group revenue - and that could fall as other parts of the business, such as decommissioning, grow. Collum said recently that the company may abandon reprocessing in future. But if it wants to be privatised within 18 months it cannot abandon reprocessing now. In short, the desire to privatise BNFL could prolong the problem which lies at its heart.

Professor William Walker, author of a book on BNFL and 'political entrapment', says: 'They are not addressing the policy problem - why is it reprocessing at all? Reprocessing is not a precondition for privatisation; it is a hindrance.'

The crucial element at the centre of all decision-making is one of the most hazardous substances known to man - plutonium. Plutonium is created when uranium is burnt in a reactor. In the Forties, its use, and its value, was primarily military. Britain's civil reprocessing programme - and BNFL itself - was a spin-off. Nevertheless, a complex case for civil reprocessing was developed in the Fifties and Sixties.

Sellafield began reprocessing fuel from the 11 first-generation Magnox power stations at a plant built in the Sixties called B205. A £2.85 billion second-generation plant called Thorp, which became operational from 1994, followed. Whether reprocessing is commercial has been contentious ever since. The most basic problem was that the price of uranium crashed from $45 dollars a pound in 1978 to $10 a pound in 1999. In addition, nuclear weapons programmes slowed, creating the prospect of dangerous and worthless plutonium stockpiles. A commercial value for the deadly substance had to be found to sustain the reprocessing industry.

The answer was a generation of plutonium-burning 'fast-breeder reactors' (FBRs) to generate electricity. These were designed in the Seventies and Eighties in Britain, the US, France, Russia and Japan. They were a failure.

Gordon MacKerron, a nuclear economist at Sussex University, says: 'The only justification for FBRs was the uranium price remaining high to justify high building costs compared with conventional reactors.'

The next suggested solution to the plutonium problem was as MOX fuel for use in conventional reactors. BNFL has built several MOX plants at Sellafield: the latest cost £300 million.

MOX today faces similar threats. Fresh uranium fuel is now much cheaper. Last year a House of Lords Science and Technology Committee report recommended that non-military plutonium be considered as waste. The Government is considering its response.

The stakes are high -the Government response will effectively decide whether the economic case for reprocessing is maintained.

MacKerron argues that neither reprocessing nor MOX manufacture can form part of the company's commercial future, and should be abandoned.

Potential customers have contracted for only 6.7 per cent of the MOX plant capacity - well below the break-even point.

On top of this comes the falsification scandal, which has undermined confidence among vital customers and threatened future sales.

The future of MOX impacts on Thorp, which is generating hazardous separated plutonium all the time. If MOX fails, the justification for plutonium separation at Thorp is weakened.

Thorp's difficulty is that there is no real market for its products - only experimental amounts of its output have been used. Its case rests on contracts for reprocessing, which have given the plant a £12bn order book.

Many of these contracts were agreed in the Seventies and Eighties with UK and foreign utilities. Most were 'cost plus', allowing BNFL to make a margin however much the work cost. More importantly, two-thirds of the £2.85bn cost of building Thorp was financed from upfront payments from these contracts.

Thorp is currently fully booked. When it was commissioned, BNFL estimated profits averaging £50m a year until 2004. But the 2004-2114 period looks dicey - only half of capacity is filled, and many of these deals are with British Energy in the form of options to reprocess or store spent fuel. BE has said recently said it is moving against reprocessing in favour of storage.

In addition, says MacKerron, utilities in Germany and Japan have realised that storage is a lot cheaper.

As well as reprocessing issues, the ageing Magnox stations are contributing greatly to BNFL's problems. Magnox contributed a £34m loss in the three months of 1998 for which it was included in the group. Indeed, MacKerron believes BNFL makes money only from managing massive funds it has inherited from historical sources. He points out that the company made a £62m loss last year on 'continuing operations'.

Part of these funds are upfront Thorp payments. But they also include £2.6bn raised through a nuclear levy paid by the public on their fuel bills in the Eighties and Nineties - intended for Magnox decommissioning.

In addition, £3.7bn of future decommissioning costs will come from a special 'Secretary of State's Undertaking' - effectively an IOU from the Government spanning 108 years from 2008, when facilities will be decommissioned.

BNFL is already claiming part of this in its accounts - it included a £249m credit in its figures last year, although it did not receive a penny from the Treasury. Collum emphasises that this is legitimate accounting practice.

Calculating the costs of dismantling nuclear plants over coming decades is hideously complex, but it is vital to the commercial future because anyone buying in will have to evaluate the risks. The Magnox stations brought with them huge liabilities which contribute some £8bn of the calculated £13bn total.

BNFL claims it has covered 89 per cent of these. It has, for example, a £3.9bn Nuclear Liabilities Investment Portfolio (NLIP), and the Government's £3.7bn IOU. But the NLIP's status after a privatisation would be unclear. And whether the Government's IOU is paid will depend on the goodwill of at least 21 different governments over the 108-year decommissioning period.

MacKerron is concerned about the ability of a company that is essentially lossmaking to fund liabilities which are difficult to quantify, over a period which is hard to conceive. This problem will only increase if BNFL is privatised.

For William Walker, this is fundamental. The story of reprocessing at BNFL is one of 'political entrapment', where military/commercial decisions taken in the years after the war set in train events which have forced governments to press on with the programme despite evidence indicating it was neither economic nor safe.

As time has passed, the tensions between the company and the institutions which surround it have simply grown - culminating in the Sellafield debacle.

Walker believes the affair could provide a chance for a real fresh start. But the Government's insistence on the PPP and statements of strong support for reprocessing from the Prime Minster in parliament gives him cause to doubt.

'Why is it that Tony Blair, the arch moderniser, wishes to perpetuate the failed policies of the past?' he asks.

In fact Blair has long been strongly committed to Sellafield. On a visit there in 1989 he underlined 'the absolute commitment of the Labour Party to Sellafield, and to reassure the workforce that jobs here are entirely safe.'

Blair could simply be uncharacteristically stuck in his ways over BNFL. Or he could be the latest victim of entrapment. But if reprocessing and the PPP go ahead, the evidence is that he will be passing on the problems of today to his successor.

And then this year's nuclear crisis may be only the beginning...

Unlimited liability dates from way back
Sellafield, formerly known as Windscale, has a history of problems dating back to its creation in the 1940s. The plant was originally operated by the UK Atomic Energy Authority (UKAEA) but was handed over to BNFL when the company was formed in 1971 to take on the civil aspects of Britain's nuclear programme. Its safety record is not unblemished.

1957: Fire at Sellafield, then still called Windscale, sends contamination across England, Wales and Europe.
1973: Thirty-five workers are contaminated by a steam explosion at the plant.
1976: Leak of radioactive water from storage silo.
1981: Leak of radioactive iodine.
1983: Beaches for 25 miles around Sellafield were cleared on government orders after radioactive water was released into the sea.
1986: Eleven workers contaminated when plutonium nitrate leaked into the air at one Sellafield facility.
1990: High levels of leukaemia found in children living close to Sellafield linked to the fact their fathers all worked at the plant.

But the problems at Sellafield became even more severe last year...
August 1999: Falsification of MOX fuel quality control data discovered at Sellafield.
October 1999: Five workers sacked over the scandal - one later reinstated.

And continued this year...
January 2000: Japanese utility Kansai Electric refuses BNFL's MOX fuel.
18 February: Nuclear Installations Inspectorate publishes three damning reports into BNFL, criticising safety and management culture.
8 March: BNFL stopped from shipping MOX fuel to Germany.
10 March: Archie Robertson, the Environment Agency director of operations, writes to BNFL, expressing concern about BNFL's environmental record.

18 April: BNFL responds to NII reports with a safety and management shake-up.
fields.bodyText: The rest of the world may be four months into the new millennium. But last Tuesday the calendars at British Nuclear Fuels' central London offices read 01/01/00. Hugh Collum and Norman Askew, chairman and chief executive of the nuclear reprocessor, generator and decommissioner, spent all day in BNFL's Buckingham Gate boardroom trying to persuade the world that this was the nuclear year zero. They have to succeed. In the past three months BNFL has suffered some of the most ferocious criticism ever heaped on a British commercial organisation. Regulators, government, MPs, environmentalists, even customers, have poured scorn on its safety, management, environmental record and accounting practices. Three reports by the Nuclear Installations Inspectorate, the industry watchdog, into operations at BNFL's Sellafield plant in Cumbria were published in February. They could scarcely have been more damning. One, written after a two-week inspection of Sellafield last September, found 'a lack of a high-quality safety management systems across the site' and 'insufficient resources to implement even the existing safety management system'. During that inspection a major scandal broke at Sellafield. Staff at a demonstration facility for production of an experimental mixed plutonium and uranium fuel (MOX) were exposed as falsifying data. The NII began a second investigation. Its report damned Sellafield a second time. 'In a plant with the proper safety culture, the events discussed in this report could not have happened,' it said. But the NII was not alone. The Environment Agency pitched in. Its criticisms were not focused simply on Sellafield; they included its fuel manufacturing plant at Springfields as well as some of its ageing Magnox power stations. As if all this were not enough, the politicians had their penn'orth too. Martin O'Neill, chairman of the influential commons Trade and Industry Select Committee, criticised BNFL's accounts for being at best unclear. It also said the company treated the Government and the public with 'disdain'. Collum must have wondered what had hit him. His City background saw him appointed last autumn to steer the company through the planned public-private partnership (PPP) - effectively a part privatisation. No sooner had he arrived than the organisation began disintegrating around him. In the wake of the NII reports, the Government put off the PPP. Collum started fighting back days after those reports. He replaced BNFL's chief executive John Taylor with Askew, a respected utility boss. Askew says that when he arrived he could not work out how Sellafield operated. 'I am used to organisations where there is very clear accountability,' he said. 'I didn't find that. There were people running parts of it with different safety systems in different parts of the site. I just said: why isn't one person running it?' On Tuesday, Collum and Askew presented a plan aimed at overhauling safety and management. A freeze on job cuts was announced. Four clear business groups were set out: fuel manufacturing; electricity generation at Magnox power stations; spent fuel management including reprocessing; and decommissioning. There was a clear-out of all non-executive directors, along with half the executive board, including finance director Ross Chiese and safety director David Coulston. Askew says the plan has to be implemented within 18 months if the company is to survive. He is confident. But at its core is a tension that may well undermine that confidence. On the one hand, Collum and Askew have to prove that BNFL is safe. On the other, they have to bring the PPP back on track by the end of 2002. They maintain the two are not mutually exclusive. Collum says: 'The disciplines of the PPP were making people understand that some of the changes had got to happen.' But there are bound to be controversies. For example, the NII criticised BNFL for being 'underresourced' and pointed to stretched manpower. Askew says that although employment levels will be frozen now for safety reasons, jobs will go at privatisation: 'When you take a business from the public sector to the private, you can do it with fewer people.' So the question is, can safety and commercialisation be reconciled? Many believe they cannot. Again, concerns focus on Sellafield's reprocessing oper ations. Reprocessing involves taking spent uranium fuel and breaking it down into reprocessed uranium, plutonium and nuclear waste. In theory, the uranium can be reused in reactors, or mixed with the plutonium in MOX fuel. Its commercial viability has never been clear. Neither has it been safe - the Sellafield site has been linked with safety scares ever since it was opened in 1953 (see right). BNFL has been playing down the role of reprocessing in its business model for some time. Askew says it currently represents between 20 and 25 per cent of group revenue - and that could fall as other parts of the business, such as decommissioning, grow. Collum said recently that the company may abandon reprocessing in future. But if it wants to be privatised within 18 months it cannot abandon reprocessing now. In short, the desire to privatise BNFL could prolong the problem which lies at its heart. Professor William Walker, author of a book on BNFL and 'political entrapment', says: 'They are not addressing the policy problem - why is it reprocessing at all? Reprocessing is not a precondition for privatisation; it is a hindrance.' The crucial element at the centre of all decision-making is one of the most hazardous substances known to man - plutonium. Plutonium is created when uranium is burnt in a reactor. In the Forties, its use, and its value, was primarily military. Britain's civil reprocessing programme - and BNFL itself - was a spin-off. Nevertheless, a complex case for civil reprocessing was developed in the Fifties and Sixties. Sellafield began reprocessing fuel from the 11 first-generation Magnox power stations at a plant built in the Sixties called B205. A £2.85 billion second-generation plant called Thorp, which became operational from 1994, followed. Whether reprocessing is commercial has been contentious ever since. The most basic problem was that the price of uranium crashed from $45 dollars a pound in 1978 to $10 a pound in 1999. In addition, nuclear weapons programmes slowed, creating the prospect of dangerous and worthless plutonium stockpiles. A commercial value for the deadly substance had to be found to sustain the reprocessing industry. The answer was a generation of plutonium-burning 'fast-breeder reactors' (FBRs) to generate electricity. These were designed in the Seventies and Eighties in Britain, the US, France, Russia and Japan. They were a failure. Gordon MacKerron, a nuclear economist at Sussex University, says: 'The only justification for FBRs was the uranium price remaining high to justify high building costs compared with conventional reactors.' The next suggested solution to the plutonium problem was as MOX fuel for use in conventional reactors. BNFL has built several MOX plants at Sellafield: the latest cost £300 million. MOX today faces similar threats. Fresh uranium fuel is now much cheaper. Last year a House of Lords Science and Technology Committee report recommended that non-military plutonium be considered as waste. The Government is considering its response. The stakes are high -the Government response will effectively decide whether the economic case for reprocessing is maintained. MacKerron argues that neither reprocessing nor MOX manufacture can form part of the company's commercial future, and should be abandoned. Potential customers have contracted for only 6.7 per cent of the MOX plant capacity - well below the break-even point. On top of this comes the falsification scandal, which has undermined confidence among vital customers and threatened future sales. The future of MOX impacts on Thorp, which is generating hazardous separated plutonium all the time. If MOX fails, the justification for plutonium separation at Thorp is weakened. Thorp's difficulty is that there is no real market for its products - only experimental amounts of its output have been used. Its case rests on contracts for reprocessing, which have given the plant a £12bn order book. Many of these contracts were agreed in the Seventies and Eighties with UK and foreign utilities. Most were 'cost plus', allowing BNFL to make a margin however much the work cost. More importantly, two-thirds of the £2.85bn cost of building Thorp was financed from upfront payments from these contracts. Thorp is currently fully booked. When it was commissioned, BNFL estimated profits averaging £50m a year until 2004. But the 2004-2114 period looks dicey - only half of capacity is filled, and many of these deals are with British Energy in the form of options to reprocess or store spent fuel. BE has said recently said it is moving against reprocessing in favour of storage. In addition, says MacKerron, utilities in Germany and Japan have realised that storage is a lot cheaper. As well as reprocessing issues, the ageing Magnox stations are contributing greatly to BNFL's problems. Magnox contributed a £34m loss in the three months of 1998 for which it was included in the group. Indeed, MacKerron believes BNFL makes money only from managing massive funds it has inherited from historical sources. He points out that the company made a £62m loss last year on 'continuing operations'. Part of these funds are upfront Thorp payments. But they also include £2.6bn raised through a nuclear levy paid by the public on their fuel bills in the Eighties and Nineties - intended for Magnox decommissioning. In addition, £3.7bn of future decommissioning costs will come from a special 'Secretary of State's Undertaking' - effectively an IOU from the Government spanning 108 years from 2008, when facilities will be decommissioned. BNFL is already claiming part of this in its accounts - it included a £249m credit in its figures last year, although it did not receive a penny from the Treasury. Collum emphasises that this is legitimate accounting practice. Calculating the costs of dismantling nuclear plants over coming decades is hideously complex, but it is vital to the commercial future because anyone buying in will have to evaluate the risks. The Magnox stations brought with them huge liabilities which contribute some £8bn of the calculated £13bn total. BNFL claims it has covered 89 per cent of these. It has, for example, a £3.9bn Nuclear Liabilities Investment Portfolio (NLIP), and the Government's £3.7bn IOU. But the NLIP's status after a privatisation would be unclear. And whether the Government's IOU is paid will depend on the goodwill of at least 21 different governments over the 108-year decommissioning period. MacKerron is concerned about the ability of a company that is essentially lossmaking to fund liabilities which are difficult to quantify, over a period which is hard to conceive. This problem will only increase if BNFL is privatised. For William Walker, this is fundamental. The story of reprocessing at BNFL is one of 'political entrapment', where military/commercial decisions taken in the years after the war set in train events which have forced governments to press on with the programme despite evidence indicating it was neither economic nor safe. As time has passed, the tensions between the company and the institutions which surround it have simply grown - culminating in the Sellafield debacle. Walker believes the affair could provide a chance for a real fresh start. But the Government's insistence on the PPP and statements of strong support for reprocessing from the Prime Minster in parliament gives him cause to doubt. 'Why is it that Tony Blair, the arch moderniser, wishes to perpetuate the failed policies of the past?' he asks. In fact Blair has long been strongly committed to Sellafield. On a visit there in 1989 he underlined 'the absolute commitment of the Labour Party to Sellafield, and to reassure the workforce that jobs here are entirely safe.' Blair could simply be uncharacteristically stuck in his ways over BNFL. Or he could be the latest victim of entrapment. But if reprocessing and the PPP go ahead, the evidence is that he will be passing on the problems of today to his successor. And then this year's nuclear crisis may be only the beginning... Unlimited liability dates from way back Sellafield, formerly known as Windscale, has a history of problems dating back to its creation in the 1940s. The plant was originally operated by the UK Atomic Energy Authority (UKAEA) but was handed over to BNFL when the company was formed in 1971 to take on the civil aspects of Britain's nuclear programme. Its safety record is not unblemished. 1957: Fire at Sellafield, then still called Windscale, sends contamination across England, Wales and Europe. 1973: Thirty-five workers are contaminated by a steam explosion at the plant. 1976: Leak of radioactive water from storage silo. 1981: Leak of radioactive iodine. 1983: Beaches for 25 miles around Sellafield were cleared on government orders after radioactive water was released into the sea. 1986: Eleven workers contaminated when plutonium nitrate leaked into the air at one Sellafield facility. 1990: High levels of leukaemia found in children living close to Sellafield linked to the fact their fathers all worked at the plant. But the problems at Sellafield became even more severe last year... August 1999: Falsification of MOX fuel quality control data discovered at Sellafield. October 1999: Five workers sacked over the scandal - one later reinstated. And continued this year...
