webTitle: How can I tame my son's rage?

fields.headline: How can I tame my son's rage?
fields.trailText: My son is prone to serious temper tantrums. How can a parent help an angry child?
fields.body:
Ever since he was little my son has been prone to serious temper tantrums. He is now nine years old and has been getting into fights at school. He also fights with me at home - cursing and hitting - but cannot say what it is that triggers his rages. His father and I do not live together but he has a violent temper too. The anger is so bad it is spoiling our lives. How can a parent help an angry child?

J.M. of South London

Temper tantrums are a common phenomenon in young children but the term, implying as it does self-limiting juvenility, is not appropriate for a boy of nine. These outbursts usually appear at the age of two, gradually fade out at four, and occur because the child's motivation and desires outstrip his motor capacity and co-ordination; they are therefore an expression of frustration. Your observation about his father is relevant because this behaviour pattern is almost certainly inherited. It is logical to try to understand the cause so that you can modify the problem. Triggers which spark off your son's rages are probably irrelevant; the defect lies within his psychological make-up, and is therefore difficult to reach and influence.

Aggression is a vital inherited characteristic in an intensely competitive world. It is expected that everyone will have a measure of pugnaciousness in his/her constitution, but most people cope by compartmentalising or sublimating. Not surprisingly many men who have reached highly influential positions have a history, like your son, of a short fuse and a red-hot temper going back to childhood.

Accept that your son has a personality problem which will never be eradicated, but which he can learn to control and even to channel into creative conduits. Professional help is unavailable for this type of disorder, but your input will certainly be influential and perhaps his father's even more so. You need to engage the boy in frank and serious analysis of his turbulence when he is calm. He should come face to face with the potential destructiveness of his nature, of its unacceptability, particularly of the hurt and misery he causes you.

If at all possible you should take a video of him in one of these furies, then make him watch. Never let him achieve any reward from his violence, getting his own way or escaping from obligations, and manipulating adults. But praise him when he does control himself. Talk with his school teachers and find out what his strengths are and maximise his chance to engage in these.

Next week's dilemma is from L.B. of Eastbourne

My only son left his wife of eight years for another woman who he will soon marry. I had always been close to my daughter-in-law. I don't know what I would have done without her support when my husband died a few years ago. I was deeply upset over my son's behaviour and initially refused to meet his new partner. However as my relationship with him was suffering I agreed to meet her. I now see both of them regularly. I talked to my daughter-in-law and she assured me that she understood my position, but she has changed towards me. Although I still see my young grandson often I only get to see his mother briefly and we are not so close. She is now planning to move 200 miles away. I'm afraid of losing contact with them both. What can I do to heal the rift?

fields.headline: Hailing the new cab
fields.standfirst: The Fairway, the much-loved London black cab, has been overtaken by the new TX1. CD player, vanity mirrors, reading lights and windows that actually stay open make it a transport of delight.
fields.trailText: The Fairway, the much-loved London black cab, has been overtaken by the new TX1. CD player, vanity mirrors, reading lights and windows that actually stay open make it a transport of delight.
fields.body:
Leave on left, Green Lanes. That was my first instruction, but it wasn't that easy as I was heading in the wrong direction. So, filled with the joys of Finsbury Park traffic, and thrilled with my vehicle's legendary 25ft turning circle, I did a U-turn into oncoming traffic. You would have, too, if you'd been there, behind the wheel of a TX1, the newest London cab, a motor for a profession of motormouths. I was a King of the Road for the day. I was a member of the brotherhood. Other taxis let me through at junctions, cabbies smiled back and a little old lady in a Fiesta cut me right up, I can tell you. Right across the front of me, no kidding, knew just what she was doing, too, only pretended she wasn't looking - Fiesta drivers, eh?

Like a real would-be cabbie, I was starting at the very beginning, the very place where ordinary men and women turn into Knowledge Boys and Girls. As Arthur's knights began their quest for the Grail by mounting their steeds in the grounds of Camelot, so taxi drivers all start out on the quest for the 'badge' at the otherwise obscure north London junction where Green Lanes crosses Seven Sisters Road.

It's the kick-off point for the first route in the 'blue book', the collection of 'runs' a London cabbie must memorise to get a licence - see Jack Rosenthal's The Knowledge for the full horrors of this trial. Known as 'Manor House to Gibson Square', this first run slices through the three miles or so of inner London you can't easily cross by bus or tube. Cutting across the fault lines of the modern city, it starts by a littery park and finishes in a literary Georgian square.

Bear right into Petherton Road. That was the next instruction given to me by a cabbie of my acquaintance. By name, residence and idiosyncracy of enthusiasms, he's typical of the fraternity - Barry from Loughton, Essex, specialist subjects Pilates and reflexology. 'Love it. Absolutely love it,' said Barry of his new TX1. He bought it last autumn and can't find a thing bad to say about it - just don't get him started on the jerk who chucked up on its carpet.

Right St Paul's Road. The TX1, which has been around since 1997, is the latest in an almost apostolic succession of dedicated London taxis, made by London Taxis International, whose only competitor is the slightly larger, more angular and less popular MetroCab. Before the TX1 was the Fairway, a development of the 1958-vintage FX4 - this was the classic black cab shape, with its big bonnet and box-like passenger compartment. Before that was the FX3 - the one with no front left door, as used in Carry On Cabbie . Mann & Overton, the company which leant me the vehicle, goes back even further than that. Its dealt exclusively in cabs since 1889 and its north London showroom shifts 2,000 new and secondhand taxis a year.

Everywhere else in the taxi world, anything vehicular goes. London's Public Carriage Office has none of that. Its demands have never been less than stringent and comprehensive. The latest requirements focus on public transport's two major current health and safety issues - emissions and the Disability Discrimination Act (DDA). So the TX1 retains some of its predecessors' beloved profile, but is a little taller and has doors that are 44 per cent wider. Both changes were to accommodate wheelchairs, but are a boon for all of us.

Comply Highbury Corner. Swinging on to the roundabout, the TX1 handles far more like a family saloon than you'd expect. The steering is clean, though still a little firm to those of us who don't drive old trucks for a living. The diesel engine delivers the power smoothly. The automatic gearbox does just what it's meant to. The power brakes do what they're meant to, though you do have to step on them in good time - 2 tonnes takes some stopping. And the cupholder by your left shoulder doesn't slop the drink around - though it's as inconvenient a location as you could imagine. 'Not up to car comfort and build yet,' said Nick Tim Hughes of Mann & Overton.

Leave by Upper Street. 'Comfortable,' said my fare - well, my wife actually. If I'd plied for hire, I'd have had a library - shelves, date stamps and all - thrown at me. Older London cabs were even less pleasant for the passengers than they were for the drivers. They rattled, they shook, they juddered at the lights, they had heating systems which seemed to have only two settings - blowtorch and 'Open, the window, guv'. Even then, the window would slither closed all by itself. Now the passenger has two vanity mirrors, two reading lights and a heater which actually does what it's told.

Right Barnsbury Street. Like a lot of drivers, Barry no longer has a second car. When he and his best girl Trudy step out, it's in his top-of-the-range cab, complete with CD player. Still, she knew what she was getting - they met when he picked her up as a 'fare' in the City.

Left Milner Square. It's true that a TX1 would make an excellent town runaround - Stephen Fry has one, it seems, and so does the Lord Mayor of London. The driving position is high, with clear views all round, except immediately behind - though it's noisier and rattlier in the cab than in the passenger compartment. The tight turning circle means it is almost laughably manoeuvrable - more like being on the dodgems than the road. And its 2 tonnes and steel chassis are fantastic insurance in crashes.

Leave by Milner Place. But there's no boot room. It's all taken up by the spare tyre and wheelchair access ramps - mandatory on all London taxis since 1 January, which is why many older cabs are heading to the secondhand market and provincial cities. The TX1 is getting about a bit, too. Of the 7,000 on the road, just 4,000 are in London. Its wheelchair accessibility could well make it an international success.

Gibson Square Facing. Right, boss that'll be £28,990. Plus £560 for the Maldives Blue finish - metallic paint never comes cheap. Another £40 for the headrest, and £549 for the Alpine radio and CD package. Call it £30,000. Have I got change for a £20? You must be joking.

webTitle: Mandy to roll away the business stone

fields.headline: Mandy to roll away the business stone
fields.trailText: Easter Sunday is a good time to reflect on resurrections, which brings me back to the subject of Peter Mandelson. Mr M has, one imagines, a number of things in common with Our Lord, including a respect for well-made furniture, and an insight into what it's like to be crucified, albeit in a less physical manner.
fields.body:
Easter Sunday is a good time to reflect on resurrections, which brings me back to the subject of Peter Mandelson. Mr M has, one imagines, a number of things in common with Our Lord, including a respect for well-made furniture, and an insight into what it's like to be crucified, albeit in a less physical manner.

But this Thursday past we learnt something shocking from page one of the Sun - a tabloid newspaper. Not that George Best enjoyed a shandy occasionally, but that Mandelson could be on the move from his post in Northern Ireland as quickly as July, should the peace process fail to restart. Apparently Mandy would then take on the mantle of Cabinet enforcer and election campaign mastermind. This is something of a blow as it spoils what, in racing terms, is known as a 'banker' - that Mandelson will be finding his way back to the DTI in short order.

Not back to his desk, of course, because when incumbent he decided it was better not to have one - a mannerism also adopted by his successor Stephen Byers, who will therefore have nothing to clear should he be required to move somewhere else. (Education perhaps?)

Byers would appear to have weathered the Rover storm, but there is a more serious problem looming which Tony Blair feels an urgent need to address - the peeling away of the business community from the New Labour cause.

Mandelson's speech on the strong pound, also delivered last week to coincide with the story he gave to - sorry, the story originated by - the Sun , spoke more of an interest in returning to his old DTI stamping ground than of a desire to enforce probity and unity within the cabinet.

Blair's anxiety over business is now reaching a more fevered pitch. According to those close to No. 10, since the Financial Times - a trade paper dealing with matters of business - ran a story claiming business leaders have fallen out of love with New Labour, the leadership has become increasingly nervous.

Byers' torrid time with Rover; the clamour against a strong pound; the 'dividend mixing' tax loophole closing with the Budget; and the general griping about the increasing burden of tax and bureaucracy... The business community has spotted an opportunity to do what it does best: whinging expediently in the hope of forcing concessions.

In this situation Tony needs a hero to bail him out. Gordon Brown is not the man. His macro-management of the economy has left him no time to help with knottier issues such as failing car manufacturers. Mandelson would be the perfect buffer between Downing Street's flimsy grasp of business and the fat cat fraternity.

The fact that Mandelson loved the DTI and the DTI loved him is well documented. Nowhere else would a steely faced Machiavellian who loves cold cash have fitted in so well. As the Rover episode has shown, the human touch is of no use when dealing with the duplicitous, or the merely economical with the vérité.

It may be embarrassing for him to return there before issues relating to Transtec have been cleared up, although his old mucker and building society manager Geoffrey Robinson seems exonerated of any wrongdoing in this arena.

Cabinet sources would pass off the disgruntlement with the Government as nothing more than a marketing exercise on the part of the FT to recapture its heartland of middle managers. (I kid you not: this is the kind of convoluted spin they need to resort to.) But it speaks more of profound unease within organisations such as the Institute of Directors and, more importantly, the Confederation of British Industries, where director-general Digby Jones is less inclined to be kind to the Government.

And when good businesses such as Nissan start to complain about the pain, the risk of leaking votes and funding increases sharply.

If Mandelson is not back in the DTI by the next election it will not be for the want of both Tony and Peter thinking about the possibility very hard indeed.

fields.headline: Final frontier
fields.standfirst: Rundown Georgian architecture, soaring house prices, a trendy art gallery, and all just minutes away from the City - could Deptford be the new Hoxton?
fields.trailText: Rundown Georgian architecture, soaring house prices, a trendy art gallery, and all just minutes away from the City - could Deptford be the new Hoxton?
fields.body:
Let's be honest, Deptford does not have a good reputation. Most Londoners don't really know where it is: a suburb in deepest south London, somewhere they've heard of but never wanted - or dared - to go. A place, perhaps, where gangsters hang out and football hooligans meet in dingy pubs. Not an up-and-coming area with a burgeoning art scene, just a short ride from the West End. And surely not the new Hoxton?

The approach to Deptford from New Cross tube station is predictably bleak: a large power station on the right, sprawling industrial estates on the left, a clutch of high-rise tower blocks stark against the grey sky. Everything has a rundown, uncared-for look. If Deptford feels a little left out, it has good reason. Greenwich next door has received huge amounts of public money and seen property prices rise in the past year by 30 per cent: compared with its prodigious neighbour and its Dome, Deptford is a mere pimple.

Despite this, Deptford is on the rise. The new DLR link at Deptford Bridge and the Jubilee Line extension at Canada Water, only two stops away from New Cross, together with a BR station just three stops from Charing Cross, have brought it within 15 minutes of the City, the West End and Canary Wharf. One-bedroom flats, selling last year for £45,000, are now going for £65,000. Victorian three-bedroom homes, priced two years ago at £120,000 are now £170,000.

Deptford has a certain gritty chic, an edge that sets it apart from the more expensive suburbs further out. This is frontier country: don't expect to find Marks & Spencer here, but if you want a couple of pigs' snouts or a tailor-made suit for under £500, you're in luck. It has one of the last undiscovered pockets of housing along the Thames, with the bonus of close proximity to the green spaces of Greenwich and Blackheath.

Artists have been living quietly there for years, taking advantage of low rents in large empty factory and dockside buildings. Steven Pippin, short-listed last year for the Turner Prize, has a studio in Blackheath Road. More obvious signs of the area's artistic reputation can be found along the high street where there's Hales Gallery, one of the most exciting small galleries in London. Its smart café has become a magnet for local artists and musicians. Opened in 1992 by Paul Hedge and his business partner Paul Maslin, the gallery was converted from a derelict property that belonged to the church behind. Now it has a stable of artists including Jonathan Callan, Andrew Bick and Tomoko Takahashi, the star of last year's Neurotic Realism show at the Saatchi Gallery.

The Museum of Installation, an artist-led organisation is nearby and, five minutes walk away in Creekside, there is the 40 studios and gallery of the Art in Perpetuity Trust (APT), which is closely involved with the fledgling Deptford X annual contemporary art fes-tival. 'It's starting to change here already,' says Barny Drabble, gallery co-ordinator at APT. 'Things are really picking up.'

Round the corner is the site of the new Laban Centre, a leading contemporary dance school, whose Creekside development has been designed by Herzog and de Meuron, the architects responsible for the Tate Modern at Bankside. Michael Craig-Martin, professor of fine art at nearby Goldsmiths College, is artist-consultant on the new project, advising on the planned colourful exterior decoration of the building.

Evidence of Deptford's new desirability can be found on quiet Albury Street, where Georgian terraced houses have wooden shutters and cherubs above the doors. Halfway down the street, you get a glimpse of stunning St Paul's Church, designed by Thomas Archer and described by Pevsner as 'one of the most moving 18th-century churches in London: large, sombre and virile'.

Local residents are proud of their historic roots. Built around the mouth of the Ravensbourne, Deptford was the birthplace of the Royal Navy. Behind the hotch-potch of modern facades along the high street are visible signs of the past. At Deptford Action Group for the Elderly, a charity shop, I am shown up the oak-panelled staircase to an upstairs room with its original wooden sinks and ancient boiler, still intact from its days as a turn-of-the-century tea house.

As for decent cafés and restaurants, Deptford has a long way to go. A Fairview development currently under way at the mouth of Deptford Creek will eventually link 650 shiny new Thameside homes with the cinemas, bars and restaurants of an even bigger complex at Greenwich by way of a footbridge. But for now there's a handful of reasonable pubs, including the Dog and Bell and the Paradise Bar. It's not exactly buzzing with bars like Hoxton but, as Barny Drabble points out, 'the name of Hoxton has become more important than what goes on there. It's full of tourists looking for Jarvis Cocker.'

Maybe that's where Deptford differs - despite the rising excitement, it remains unpretentious and in no hurry for a makeover. 'I do feel we are on the cusp of a very serious, fundamental change in Deptford,' says Paul Maslin, 'it's just a question of how long that's going to take.'

 Hales Gallery, 70 Deptford High Street, London SE8 (020 8694 1194), is currently showing work by Neville Gabie, Monday to Saturday 10am-5pm. Constructions, a group show, starts on 3 May at APT, 6 Creekside, London SE8 (020 8694 8344), 12 noon-6pm daily

fields.headline: Sold to the slyest bidder
fields.standfirst: Game theory is being tested out in telecom and TV rights auctions as bidders try to beat the system, says  Faisal Islam
fields.trailText: Game theory is being tested out in telecom and TV rights auctions as bidders try to beat the system, says Faisal Islam
fields.body:
Sotherby's must be casting envious eyes over two lots currently up for auction. Neither lot number one, licences for third-generation mobile phone services, nor lot number two, the rights to televise Premiership football, could be described as antique, fine art, or rock star memorabilia.

The commissions from these multi-billion pound deals could, however, warrant the two lots a place under the hammer at the New Bond Street auction house.

But auctions like these, rather than lining the pockets of traditional auction houses, are providing work for an army of mathematical economists and game theorists.

Auction theory, as this complex amalgam of microeconomics is known, has a wide application. It is relevant to the £22 billion battle for control of mobile phones. BSkyB's bid to take control of Manchester United was blocked, in part, because of the insights of auction theory. Sales of gold and electricity, and the increasing use of the Internet for procurement of business supplies, have also brought the theory back to the fore.

Essentially auctions are an efficient method of distributing a scarce resource: by collecting all the possible bidders, an auction should get the maximum price from the most eager bidder. In a commercial auction, bids indicate the amount of profit each bidder expects to make.

So, although much is said about the £22bn mobile phone auction amounting to a tax on technology, access to this portion of the airwaves offers a licence to print money. Auction theory says it would be 'economically inefficient' to hand these licences - or, more specifically, these tranches of the electromagnetic spectrum - over to selected companies for a low price in a beauty contest.

'Well-run auctions assign rights to the bidders who are willing to pay most - not the party with the most political influence,' says Professor Paul Milgrom of Stanford University. He designed the mechanism used by the Federal Communications Commission for the first 'spectrum auction' in America in 1994. The auction of next-generation mobile phone licences in Britain is a modified version of those auctions.

The essentials remain the same regardless of the auction: bids are the lowest a firm believes will secure the lot. A bidder has to make a careful analysis of what the other bidders may do, which in turn will be dependent to some degree on what they think he may bid. This is the realm of game theory.

It has identified two main problems with the auction process. When all the bidders for a licence can only secure the same profits, any victor in an auction faces the 'winner's curse'. The winner is likely to be the bidder most optimistic about potential profits. In many circumstances it will have paid over the odds and is really a loser. At worst this can lead to bankruptcy.

In an ascending bid auction this problem is lessened. Throughout the auction, bidders reveal more and more information about how they value a contract or licence, and learn from each other's reactions. Game theorists employed by telecoms companies will have played out this high-stakes poker game already. Using advanced computer models they will have worked through every possible permutation of response from each bidder.

However, these auctions leave the door open to a second problem - collusion between bidders.

Professor Paul Klemperer of Oxford University, the economic theorist behind the current next-generation mobile auctions, says auctions in Germany last year offering extra capacity for conventional mobile phones illustrate this point.

Mannesmann bid a low price for half the licences and an even lower price for the other half. Though no discussions had taken place, the structure of their bid meant the other bidder, T-mobil, only needed to raise the bid on half the licences slightly. The result was that after two rounds of bidding each of the bidders had half the licences for the same low price.

A 'second-price' auction in New Zealand in 1990 (see box) enabled one bidder to pick up the rights to a tranche of the mobile phone spectrum for just NZ$6.

In America there have been instances of bidders using the final four numbers of their multi-million dollar bids to signal to each other which telephone code area they want to buy.

In a separate case, the US Justice Department was brought in to investigate possible collusion in a 1997 auction expected to raise almost $2bn that raised less than $14 million.

The use of these auctions has clearly not been an unmitigated success. 'It's a case of horses for courses,' says Klemperer. 'There are many different methods of auctioning and which is best is sensitive to the specific details of the market.'

But his theories have also been applied to other, seemingly unrelated areas. In Britain a report by the Competition Commission recommending that BSkyB's takeover of Man Utd should be blocked was rooted in Klem perer's analysis of 'toehold effects' in bidding situations.

Put simply, if BSkyB bought Man Utd, any TV rights deal would offer the same potential profit to both companies. Imagine that BSkyB owned United and was bidding against Ondigital for Premiership rights. If Ondigital were to win, 7 per cent of its bid would go to BSkyB. Thus, whether it wins the rights or not, BSkyB has an incentive to push up the bidding that much more aggressively. This exaggerates the winner's curse for OnDigital; in effect, it has to back off the bidding more than BSkyB.

The 'toehold' affects both sides of the bidding equation, setting off a vicious circle for OnDigital and a virtuous circle for BSkyB. Ondigital, knowing that BSkyB can bid more aggressively, will scale back its bidding. BSkyB will always win the rights in an auction like this.

While BSkyB was not able to take over Man Utd, it has taken strategic 9.9 per cent stakes in four Premiership clubs. It still has a toehold, but this time one shared across several different clubs rather than concentrated on one.

The last negotiation for Premiership rights had a gaping flaw. Awarding BSkyB the right to match any rival offer may have been seen as a clever way to top any final bid for rights, but Klemperer says: 'Giving a bidder the right to match is not a costless exchange, since there is no reason to bid the price up in the first instance.' So knowing that it could always match any offer, BSkyB never pushed up the bid price.

Even the forthcoming Pre miership auction seems questionable, given the insights of auction theory. The parties have been invited to lodge a sealed bid before 10 May, after which there will be an auction of the rights by July. Given that the first sealed bid appears not to be binding, it is difficult to see why potential bidders would want to give too much information away before the serious business begins.

Auction theory also shows up glaring inconsistencies in government policy.

Toehold effects, identified as a primary reason for blocking BSkyB's bid for Man Utd in the Competition Commission's report, have not been ended. BSkyB, and to a smaller extent other broadcasters, continue to collect small stakes in Premier League clubs.

Similarly, why in a climate of converging technologies are auctions designed to extract the maximum fees from bidders for mobile phone operators, when television operators need only have their licences rubber-stamped by the ITC for comparatively pitiful sums of money?

As consumers begin to get used to auctions through Internet sites such as QXL and eBay, analysis of auction behaviour will become an increasingly fertile area for research.

And given that, the Premier League might consider employing a leading game theorist to design an auction before they are going, going, gone.

Under the hammer

1. Types of auction

Ascending price (English) auction

Example: mobile phone licences. Bidders offer sequentially higher prices until there is one left. Such auctions can lead to collusion.

Descending price (Dutch) auction Example: tulip, tobacco. Prices start high and descend until a buyer is found.

Sealed-bid auction

Example: tenders for government contracts and, to some degree, TV rights for Premiership football. Each bidder makes one bid, without knowing the others.

Second-price auctions

Example: New Zealand's spectrum auction in 1990. The licence is awarded to the highest bidder but for the second highest price, so avoiding 'winner's curse'.

2. Problems with auctions

Winner's curse

In a sealed bid auction, the winner is the optimistic bidder who most overvalues the 'prize'. Ascending price auctions get round this problem by gradually revealing information from the whole marketplace about the value of the auction.

The theory assumes 'common value' - that the value of whatever is bid for is approximately the same to each bidder.

Collusion

This can happen when two or more bidders make illegal arrangements not to bid up the auction price. But tacit collusion - where bidders signal their intentions or make 'offers' to other bidders through the bid itself which can also depress prices - is not illegal.

So knowing that it could always match any offer, BSkyB never pushed up the bid price. Even the forthcoming Pre miership auction seems questionable, given the insights of auction theory. The parties have been invited to lodge a sealed bid before 10 May, after which there will be an auction of the rights by July. Given that the first sealed bid appears not to be binding, it is difficult to see why potential bidders would want to give too much information away before the serious business begins. Auction theory also shows up glaring inconsistencies in government policy. Toehold effects, identified as a primary reason for blocking BSkyB's bid for Man Utd in the Competition Commission's report, have not been ended. BSkyB, and to a smaller extent other broadcasters, continue to collect small stakes in Premier League clubs. Similarly, why in a climate of converging technologies are auctions designed to extract the maximum fees from bidders for mobile phone operators, when television operators need only have their licences rubber-stamped by the ITC for comparatively pitiful sums of money? As consumers begin to get used to auctions through Internet sites such as QXL and eBay, analysis of auction behaviour will become an increasingly fertile area for research. And given that, the Premier League might consider employing a leading game theorist to design an auction before they are going, going, gone. Under the hammer 1. Types of auction Ascending price (English) auction Example: mobile phone licences. Bidders offer sequentially higher prices until there is one left. Such auctions can lead to collusion. Descending price (Dutch) auction Example: tulip, tobacco. Prices start high and descend until a buyer is found. Sealed-bid auction Example: tenders for government contracts and, to some degree, TV rights for Premiership football. Each bidder makes one bid, without knowing the others. Second-price auctions Example: New Zealand's spectrum auction in 1990. The licence is awarded to the highest bidder but for the second highest price, so avoiding 'winner's curse'. 2. Problems with auctions Winner's curse In a sealed bid auction, the winner is the optimistic bidder who most overvalues the 'prize'. Ascending price auctions get round this problem by gradually revealing information from the whole marketplace about the value of the auction. The theory assumes 'common value' - that the value of whatever is bid for is approximately the same to each bidder. Collusion This can happen when two or more bidders make illegal arrangements not to bid up the auction price. But tacit collusion - where bidders signal their intentions or make 'offers' to other bidders through the bid itself which can also depress prices - is not illegal.

fields.headline: Hard pills to swallow
fields.standfirst: A supplement may not always be the cure-all you hope,  professional advice from a dietician ensures you do no harm
fields.trailText: A supplement may not always be the cure-all you hope,  professional advice from a dietician ensures you do no harm
fields.body:
Last week I noticed an unexpected increase in the number of my patients wanting to know whether they should be taking a zinc supplement. I can only assume they had all read an article suggesting that popping a zinc pill would act as a cure-all.

If you are ever swayed by such articles, I'd like to offer you a few words of warning. Many readers don't realise that some articles written by nutritional therapists are either directly or indirectly commissioned by companies which manufacture supplements and who clearly have a vested interest in promoting sales. Some journalists, furthermore, find it quite difficult either to gain access to unbiased research or to consult independent nutritional consultants and practitioners. On top of this, far too many therapists are either not sufficiently qualified to make a sound clinical judgment or have been offered a financial incentive to sell certain supplements. Because many therapists are paid a share of the profits of such sales, journalists and patients who consult them may be given subjective, rather than objective, advice.

The incorrect prescribing of supplements was recently highlighted by Which Health (published by the Consumers Association). It was highly critical of food therapists, concluding that, as a body, they had a 'haphazard and inconsistent approach'. The report cited the experiences of undercover researchers who reported symptoms of irritable-bowel syndrome (IBS) to 14 nutritional therapists. The report's findings included the following criticisms:

 Five of the therapists made no reference to the researchers' GPs, and only three recommended that the researchers should consult their doctors.

 The dietary advice given by most of the therapists was general healthy-eating advice rather than information about how to combat the reported symptoms of IBS.

 Some dietary advice that was given was simply wrong, for example, recommending carrot juice as a good source of calcium.

 Products were recommended or sold at 12 of the consultations. These included vitamin and mineral supplements, digestive enzymes, linseed oil, blue-green algae, lecithin granules, psyllium husks, herb and vitamin mixtures and probiotic supplements. Yet according to an expert consulted by Which Health , 'only two of these (probiotic and psyllium husks) were considered as possibly beneficial'.

 One of the most dubious products sold (for £16.95) was a bottle of aerobic oxygen, which, according to a Which Health expert, would provide no more oxygen than a glass of water.

In summary, Which Health 's research shows the nutritional therapists consulted were not only giving poor advice, but that many were also not referring people with potentially serious problems to their GPs.

These findings do not surprise me. You may recall that last year I explained the difference between dieticians and nutritionists, a distinction that I think is worth repeating. Dieticians must hold a dietetic degree or diploma (having previously received a degree in a related subject) and must also work within the medical profession - they cannot see people without a medical referral. In addition, dieticians are regulated by both the British Dietetic Association and the Council for Professions Supplementary to Medicine. Nutritionists, nutritional therapists, food therapists or diet therapists - or whatever they style themselves - are not currently regulated by any legal body, with the result that anyone can set up in practice.

While I, along with the Consumers Association, do recognise some organisations, such as the Society for the Promotion of Nutritional Therapy, the British Association of Nutritional Therapists (BANT) and the Institute of Optimum Nutrition (ION) - none of these are regulated by law, which means that we cannot rely on their standards of care. Indeed, Which Health found that 'the performance of the BANT nutritional therapists wasn't any better than that of the other therapists'. For its part, BANT says that by choosing a BANT-registered therapist you have the assurance that the therapist is insured and that you furthermore have the benefit of a body to complain to should you be unhappy with your treatment.

The best way in which to safeguard your health - and your wallet - is to contact the British Dietetic Association (0121 616 4900) and ask for its list of state-registered dieticians (SRDs). In order to qualify for the SRD accreditation, dieticians must work within the medical profession and cannot give you specific advice until you have officially registered with them as a patient. (This professional stipulation explains why I cannot answer a reader's individual health or therapeutic queries. Unless you are registered with my practice as a patient, I can only give general advice.) Although it may sound pedantic, this rule serves to protect you. For the majority of people, food can be a marvellous healer, but incorrectly prescribed, food can also cause devastating damage. To give just one example, if your dietician doesn't know that you are taking the antidepressant drug monoamine oxidase inhibitor (MAOI) and recommends you eat more cheese, the consequent interaction between the drug and the cheese could be fatal. This is why it is vital you are referred to a dietician by your GP. Remember, too, that dieticians are barred from selling nutritional supplements, although they can recommend a particular supplement and dosage.

Unfortunately, many doctors won't offer to refer you to a dietician because they don't believe that diet can play a role in helping you to overcome your particular condition (which may be why some people consult nutritionists who don't require a referral from a GP). Quite understandably, many medical practitioners whom I have questioned don't have confidence in the dietetic or nutritional professions because they feel they cannot rely on the qualifications of nutritionists and don't fully understand the distinction between dieticians and nutritionists. Yet I firmly believe doctors should be in favour of referring people to dieticians. After all, changing someone's diet can improve their health without the need to resort to expensive medication and treatments.

Finally, back to zinc; one of the most popular supplements being prescribed at the moment. This element performs many important functions within the body, including maintaining a healthy immune system. A deficiency of zinc may result in a loss of appetite, the slow healing of wounds, skin complaints and sexual problems ranging from a low libido through a low-sperm count to sterility. It is vital that you don't take more than 15 to 20mg of zinc a day, however, because excess zinc can cause your body to become more susceptible to bacterial infections (which may explain why some people develop chest infections after they have taken a zinc supplement to get over a cold). In order to ensure their zinc levels remain balanced, I prefer to encourage my patients to eat more zinc-rich foods, from which the body will absorb only what it needs and no more. Such foods include shellfish and canned sardines, turkey, duck, goose and lean meats like beef, lamb and, pork, as well as liver and kidneys. Parmesan and other hard, or crumbly, cheeses, including Cheddar, also contain high levels of zinc, as do eggs, wholegrain bread, brown rice and pulses, nuts and seeds (also in peanut butter and tahini), dried apricots, fresh peas and, finally, passion fruit. You should ideally include one of these rich sources of zinc in your daily diet, perhaps in the form of a sandwich made with wholemeal bread, Cheddar cheese and tomato chutney, or one of my own favourite childhood snacks, tinned sardines on warm toast. If you don't like or eat many of these foods, consult a dietician for advice on alternative options.

webTitle: Sterile gesture won't tame soaring sterling

fields.headline: Sterile gesture won't tame soaring sterling
fields.standfirst: On these pages Gerald Holtham argued for government action to lower the exchange rate. Now an MPC member demands  the right of reply
fields.trailText: On these pages Gerald Holtham argued for government action to lower the exchange rate. Now an MPC member demands the right of reply
fields.body:
The plight of manufacturing has focused attention on sterling's persistent strength. The MPC (Monetary Policy Committee) recognises the problem, but argues there is little it can do. It is mandated to pursue the Government's inflation target. Only if this target is met can other objectives be pursued.

This leaves little scope for reining in the pound, as the short-term interest rate the MPC uses as its instrument cannot be used to achieve both inflation and exchange rate goals.

Gerry Holtham (Observer , 9 April) and Robin Marris (Times , 11 April) claim that additional policy tools are available. They assert that by changing the currency composition and maturity structure of the Government's debt, the exchange rate can be tamed without increasing inflation. They call for the authorities to lower the pound by buying euro-denominated securities and undoing any effect on the money supply by selling sterling-denominated securities.

The idea is not new; it is called sterilised intervention. Most of the foreign exchange intervention since the mid-Seventies - including the failed defence of the pound in autumn 1992 - has taken this form. Does it work? In theory, perhaps; in practice, no. Sterilised intervention is an empty gesture.

The usual justification is that if sterling and euro bonds have different risk characteristics, investors care how their portfolios are allo cated between them. And if the supply of euro bonds falls relative to the supply of sterling bonds, the euro must strengthen to restore the desired portfolio balance. Any effect on UK inflation can be offset with changes in short-term UK interest rates.

However, if selling sterling securities and purchasing euro securities were to have an effect on the exchange rate, the Government would alter its future budget constraints. Thus the Government would have to change its fiscal policy, now or later. Anticipating this may cause investors to modify their desired portfolios. The magnitude and direction of the net effect on the exchange rate are not obvious.

In practice, things are clearer than in theory. A vast body of empirical work and decades of experience have led to near-consensus among economists. Sterilised intervention is ineffective, except possibly in the very short run.

Holtham's wrinkle on this proposal is for the Government to issue long-term sterling debt and buy euro bonds. The UK yield curve slopes down, and long-term sterling yields have recently fallen below long-term euro yields. Holtham, ignoring the possibility of a future strengthening of sterling, argues that selling long-term sterling debt and buying euro bonds has the further benefit of reducing government debt service costs. However, managing a hedge fund is risky.

Substituting long-term sterling debt for short-term sterling debt makes sense if the sterling debt market is segmented. The Minimum Fund ing Requirement (MFR) requires pension funds to use the yield on long gilts as the benchmark in deciding whether pension liabilities are adequately funded. It does not require pension funds to hold these assets, but fund managers have chosen to do so.

As the Government has issued little long-maturity debt in recent years, long rates are artificially low. Thus, the Government can have a free lunch if it issues long-term rather than short-term sterling debt.

We are sceptical. If regulations such as the MFR cause market failure, the spread between long and short rates may depend upon relative supplies of long and short bonds. But why are other potential suppliers of very low-risk long-term sterling bonds - the World Bank, other governments or central banks, or even high-grade private institutions - not taking advantage? Even if the story is correct, it is only an argument for changing the the sterling debt's maturity structure, not its currency composition.

The scale of operation Holtham envisages - possibly tens of billions of pounds - could not be conducted by the Bank of England with its own, limited, resources. It would have to be done by the Treasury, or by the Bank as agent for the Government. If there is market segmentation, long sterling issues on the scale envisaged would soon raise long-term sterling rates, and further operations would no longer be profitable.

Recognising that there is little theoretical or empirical support for sterilised intervention, with or without a maturity twist, its supporters often argue that it is a useful signal of future intentions. This is perplexing: why use an ineffective instrument to signal the future behaviour of the MPC's one effective tool - the short-term interest rate? It would be irresponsible for the MPC to act as if it had multiple instruments when it has only one. If token, symbolic gestures were effective, the MPC may as well paint itself blue and run round the City naked. Either way, the empty gesture would only undermine its reputation.

 Willem Buiter, Professor of International Macroeconomics at Cambridge and member of the Monetary Policy Committee, co-wrote this article with Professor Anne C. Sibert of Birkbeck College

fields.headline: It's that woman again...
fields.standfirst: Not everyone would see public disgrace and humiliation as a career opportunity. But then not everyone is Christine Hamilton, bouncing back with her own chat show - and interviewing the likes of Jonathan Aitken
fields.trailText: Not everyone would see public disgrace and humiliation as a career opportunity. But then not everyone is Christine Hamilton, bouncing back with her own chat show - and interviewing the likes of Jonathan Aitken
fields.body:
Ruined at Christmas, new career by Easter - truly the rewards of corruption in this country are quite magnificent. Neil Hamilton lost his libel case against Mohamed al-Fayed on 21 December, and for a moment it seemed the Hamiltons were finally crushed, as they talked about bankruptcy and having to sell their house in Cheshire. But forget all that - the house is still theirs, the threat of bankruptcy has receded, they are even planning to appeal against the libel verdict. And now Christine has her own television show - happy days are here again.

I suppose you get used to surviving disgrace when you've done it as often as the Hamiltons - first, when the Guardian exposed the cash for questions scandal in l994; second, when the electors of Tatton rejected him; third, when the Downey Report found 'compelling evidence' that he had accepted cash from Fayed; fourth when he lost his case - Liar-v-Liar as the Sun dubbed it - against Fayed.

Christine says there were times in this saga when she was temporarily embarrassed: 'But that's all absolutely a thing of the past now. It was difficult straight after the verdict, because you don't know what people are thinking. But now Neil is perfectly happy out and about - he got mobbed by the girls in Safeway the other day. People come up and say good luck, and it is heartwarming. I mean we don't fool ourselves. I'm well aware that millions of people think we're horrendous and corrupt, but you can't think about that.'

Not thinking about it is one of her coping mechanisms: 'I just blot out the bad bits of the whole of my life, because it's easier if you do.' Hence her relentless jolly hockey sticks bravado, which is somehow admirable and repellent at the same time. She is Mrs Thatcher writ small: if she does have any moments of self-doubt she never admits them. I met her alone at their flat - Neil was off at their accountants - and kept offering her the deluded-wife escape option, but she flatly refused to take it: 'If Neil's a liar, I'm a liar; if Neil's corrupt, I'm corrupt.'

So be it. Anyway, she's bounced back. I imagine she always bounces back. Within a fortnight of the Fayed verdict, she'd received not one but two television offers. They came to her, she says. 'I haven't sort of hawked myself around.' But luckily it was just what she had always wanted. The first offer was for an obscure cable channel called Simply Money; the second was for the digital channel BBC Choice for which she is making The Christine Hamilton Show, no less. Her present series runs for six programmes, but if it's a success the BBC has the option on another twelve.

She describes her show as 'conversations with people who have been through stormy waters and survived' - so I thought at first it was a sailing programme but it turns out not. Her roster of interviewees includes Jonathan Aitken, James Hewitt, Kara Noble (another cad, who sold pictures of topless Sophie Rhys-Jones to the tabloids and has now moved to America), a trio of disgraced former MPs (Harvey Proctor, Piers Merchant and David Ashby), a couple of footballers (Paul Merson and John Fashanu), then Michael Cole (Fayed's former PR) and Anil Bhoyrul the ex Mirror City Slicker. The only name missing is Jeffrey Archer - she claims not to know whether he was asked.

Rather oddly, Tony Slattery is in there too after a 'four-year battle with depression'. I suppose the common theme is that they all - except perhaps Slattery - will want to have a good whinge about the wicked press, and who better to do it to than Christine Hamilton? No danger of her being 'judgmental' or, as far as I can gather, asking any awkward questions at all.

'I don't go in under the ribs, I just couldn't do that to somebody. I've been skewered and stitched up so many times and it's not in my nature to do it.'

Really? I thought she prided herself on being a battleaxe. She did after all write a book called British Battleaxes, which included herself, but she says that was misleading.

'I hate confrontation and conflict. I really don't enjoy it. I like to get on with people. I can't bear the thought - well, I say I can't bear it, I don't think about it - that there are millions of people out there who think I'm absolutely ghastly because of the press I've had.' So forget battleaxe, think caring sharing on the sofa with all these survivors of stormy waters. How was dear old Jonathan? Still wielding his trusty sword of truth, with God in his Rolex? 'He was in very good humour. It's amazing the way he's come through everything. He was very amusing about life in prison. He got on terribly well with people and he said it's an extraordinary experience to suddenly be thrown together with people who you probably wouldn't have met otherwise.'

I dare say. Of course, disgrace brings all sorts of new friends - Christine Hamilton, for instance, barely knew Aitken before his downfall, but she wrote to him in prison and asked him to dinner when he came out. 'So he's a new friend. And obviously we've both suffered from the Guardian, so I suppose that was a bond - friendship in adversity.'

Meanwhile, Neil is busy clearing up after their libel action and has been astonishingly successful so far. When the case ended just before Christmas, he was left owing all Fayed's legal costs as well as his own (three-quarters of a million pounds) and supposedly facing bankruptcy and the inevitable sale of their house in Cheshire.

But that's all changed, according to Christine: 'We've now had all these developments about the police investigating the allegations that Fayed paid £10,000 for documents stolen from our lawyers' dustbins. And the police are now investigating. Whether they actually do anything is another matter, because they seem to be rather slow-moving. But on the strength of that we went back to court and got the cost order against Neil suspended, and stopped Fayed making Neil bankrupt. And we've now applied formally to have the costs order lifted completely.'

Moreover, she says, they are now planning to appeal against the libel verdict. But how can they, when they still owe their lawyers three quarters of a million? 'We've got very patient lawyers, who believe in us.' But why go on? Even if they could overturn the Fayed verdict, they're never going to lose the stigma of the Downey Report. For a moment, Christine loses her bravado and looks defeated: 'I know. Why go on?' But then she braces herself: 'Well, because - if it was your reputation, if you'd been castigated as a liar and corrupt, what would you do? We're not obsessed about it, we're getting on with our lives. And we've hopefully got lots of our life left and it's something that would eat away at us.'

But Christine, you still can't alter the basic facts, I tell her - at the very least, you took a socking great freebie from Fayed. 'It wasn't a socking great freebie - it was no more or less than a very large number of other people did. I mean now an MP doesn't take a lump of sugar without declaring it, but in the Eighties the climate was completely different, it was not regarded as wrong to accept hospitality. Go to Wimbledon any day and it was packed with MPs. Go to Ascot, Covent Garden - packed with MPs. All we ask is to be judged by the standards of the time. It wasn't as if we came back from the Ritz and said Gosh, no one must know about this. We were full of it, we were so excited about it.'

Perhaps this was the Hamiltons' fatal flaw - everyone was doing it but they were too damn full of it; they were rubbing other people's noses in it. But of course the libel case unveiled convincing evidence that Neil Hamilton took cash as well as hospitality. And just the other day the Sunday People published yet another allegation, when a beer importer called Andrew Ronnan claimed Hamilton took bribes from brewers while he was at the DTI. 'Oh, that's absolute nonsense on stilts,' says Christine. So will they be suing? 'No, the People's not worth suing really. I mean the idea that Neil had £200,000 over the table, or under the table, from the brewers! Honestly, it's just tabloid muck-raking.'

But it's yet another little diversion to keep Neil busy. He doesn't seem to have bounced back with quite the same élan as her. So what's he up to now?

'Oh he's up to all sorts of things. First, there's the ongoing legal bit - that obviously occupies some of his time. And he is writing a novel - we're both writing novels - but it's very difficult for him to find the concentration. He's actually involved in a business thing at the moment, he's teamed up with an inventor - which is not something he's ever done before - so hopefully that will work. What he'll eventually do, I don't know.'

Why can't he go back to being a tax barrister? 'But what firm of chambers is going to take him on? You can't go back. Anyway, he's 51, you can't start to rebuild a career that you haven't touched for 20 years. Neil is pretty unemployable.'

But meanwhile, he's been very helpful while she's been doing her television series: 'He's taken his duties as a house husband very seriously, and he now goes off to the supermarket and he's an incredibly economical shopper. Anyway, as far as she's concerned, it's all turned out rather well. 'I mean I feel 100 per cent liberated being out of politics - I can't tell you - I really do feel Wey hey! Almost - almost - thank you Mr Fayed. It's great to have a change at the age of 50 and be able to start a completely new life. And Neil doesn't sit here thinking, "Gosh, I wish I was Chancellor of the Exchequer." We're having a very exciting time now, and we're enjoying it. I know some people think we should be sitting in sackcloth and ashes but life has to go on.'

Neil Hamilton lost his libel case against Mohamed al-Fayed on 21 December, and for a moment it seemed the Hamiltons were finally crushed, as they talked about bankruptcy and having to sell their house in Cheshire. But forget all that - the house is still theirs, the threat of bankruptcy has receded, they are even planning to appeal against the libel verdict. And now Christine has her own television show - happy days are here again. I suppose you get used to surviving disgrace when you've done it as often as the Hamiltons - first, when the Guardian exposed the cash for questions scandal in l994; second, when the electors of Tatton rejected him; third, when the Downey Report found 'compelling evidence' that he had accepted cash from Fayed; fourth when he lost his case - Liar-v-Liar as the Sun dubbed it - against Fayed. Christine says there were times in this saga when she was temporarily embarrassed: 'But that's all absolutely a thing of the past now. Not thinking about it is one of her coping mechanisms: 'I just blot out the bad bits of the whole of my life, because it's easier if you do.' Hence her relentless jolly hockey sticks bravado, which is somehow admirable and repellent at the same time. She is Mrs Thatcher writ small: if she does have any moments of self-doubt she never admits them. I met her alone at their flat - Neil was off at their accountants - and kept offering her the deluded-wife escape option, but she flatly refused to take it: 'If Neil's a liar, I'm a liar; if Neil's corrupt, I'm corrupt.' So be it. Anyway, she's bounced back. I imagine she always bounces back. Within a fortnight of the Fayed verdict, she'd received not one but two television offers. They came to her, she says. 'I haven't sort of hawked myself around.' But luckily it was just what she had always wanted. The first offer was for an obscure cable channel called Simply Money; the second was for the digital channel BBC Choice for which she is making The Christine Hamilton Show, no less. Her present series runs for six programmes, but if it's a success the BBC has the option on another twelve. She describes her show as 'conversations with people who have been through stormy waters and survived' - so I thought at first it was a sailing programme but it turns out not. I suppose the common theme is that they all - except perhaps Slattery - will want to have a good whinge about the wicked press, and who better to do it to than Christine Hamilton? fields.headline: Health report: Hands on healing
fields.standfirst: Teaching mothers to massage their babies could be more effective than drugs or counselling in the treatment of postnatal depression. Nick Jarrett reports
fields.trailText: Teaching mothers to massage their babies could be more effective than drugs or counselling in the treatment of postnatal depression. Nick Jarrett reports
fields.body:
Every year 700,000 women in the UK give birth. In the weeks that follow a new baby's arrival, at least half of all mothers are hit by the 'baby blues'. These are characterised by feelings of sadness and a tendency to cry easily. For most mothers these feelings are short-lived, passing within a few days. But a significant number of women are not so lucky. They fall beyond the blues, becoming clinically depressed.

Postnatal depression affects 10 per cent of mothers. Symptoms are the same as those of depressive episodes not related to pregnancy and birth. They include irritability, anxiety, listlessness, poor concentration and even hopelessness. These negative emotions are bound to take their toll on the mother-baby relationship.

Dr Vivette Glover, head of a research team at Queen Charlotte's and Chelsea Hospital in west London, has been investigating postnatal depression for the past 10 years. 'Mothers with postnatal depression often fail to relate to their children in the normal way,' she says.

By carefully examining video recordings of mothers with their infants, many researchers have been able to characterise typical mother-baby interactions. 'A healthy mother will react to her child - if the baby smiles the mother will smile back, if it makes an 'aah' sound the mother will respond with a similar noise,' says Dr Glover. 'Depressed mothers, on the other hand, tend to be silent and look away, alternatively they may try too hard and be over-intrusive, causing the baby to become distressed.'

While postnatal depression responds rapidly to treatment, it is now clear that the condition has consequences which, for the infant, may be much more long-term. Children whose mothers suffer postnatal depression are at an increased risk of developing cognitive and behavioural problems in later years. At age four they are less cognitively able than their peers. This may have serious consequences for their subsequent academic development.

During the infant's first few months of life it is particularly sensitive to human contact. Patterns of behavioural activity between parent and child become established and, thereafter, are extremely difficult to break. Many developmental problems may have their roots in a strained mother-child relationship set up in the first months of life.

The long-term effects associated with postnatal depression make its prompt diagnosis and treatment all the more vital. Antidepressant medication, such as Prozac, has been shown to relieve the condition. Similarly, counselling sessions help. However, many mothers are reluctant to admit that they are suffering from a mental health problem in the first place. Those who do seek help may have reservations about taking medication - particularly if they are breast-feeding.

To make matters worse, it seems that even if the depression is successfully treated, poor mother-baby interactions do not necessarily normalise. In fact, until now, no simple form of therapy had been shown to be capable of targeting this aspect of postnatal depression.

In a recent study, Dr Glover and her team attempted to break the cycle of behaviour between depressed women and their infants by teaching mothers to massage their babies. They reasoned that this would encourage positive and mutually rewarding interactions. Once a week, for five weeks, a group of depressed mothers and their infants attended massage classes. Their progress was compared to that made by a group of similarly depressed mothers who did not learn massage. The results were remarkable.

Women in the first group benefited from substantially greater depression relief than those in the second. More impressively, the interactions between these mothers and their infants normalised. 'The massage classes taught the mothers to communicate with their babies,' says Dr Glover.

Cherry Bond, the infant-massage instructor, explains that these classes teach much more than just massage strokes. 'They provide an opportunity for parents to get to know their children through time and touch. Parents provide help and ideas for each other, discussing behaviours like sleep, crying, and body language. By learning to interpret their baby's body language,' she continues, 'mothers can adjust their reactions appropriately. This increases periods of quiet alertness, avoiding over-stimulation and distress as well as under-stimulation and boredom. Successfully comforting her baby is bound to make a mother feel good - this can only help depression.'

The massage classes at Queen Charlotte's and Chelsea Hospital in London have been running for some time. They are open to all mothers of babies born there. That they exist at all is exceptional. That the first five sessions are provided free of charge demonstrates the success they have achieved. Few trusts are willing to finance classes of this sort. However, Dr Glover's work has shown that as well as being enjoyable the classes are of medical value.

Parents interested in baby massage should be warned, however, that some infant massage classes offer little more than instruction in basic massage strokes. The instructors at Queen Charlotte's and Chelsea Hospital are trained by the International Association of Infant Massage (IAIM). 'We are taught to watch and to respect parents,' says Cherry Bond. 'We do not tell parents what to do, we teach through facilitation.' The end result is a class that teaches communication rather than simply massage. 'If enough people insist that they want these classes, more hospitals will eventually follow Queen Charlotte's and Chelsea Hospital's example,' says Bond. For now though, interested parents should contact the IAIM to find the location of their nearest group.

For women suffering postnatal depression, infant-massage classes offer a supportive environment in which they can overcome many of their difficulties. If the classes were offered as an integral part of post-birth care, the poor mother-baby interactions that develop through postnatal depression might never take hold.

 The UK chapter of the International Association for Infant Massage can be contacted on 020 8591 1399, or at www.iaim.org.uk

webTitle: Energis set to make name in mobile phone market

fields.headline: Energis set to make name in mobile phone market
fields.trailText: Energis, the telecommunications firm that specialises in building state-of-the-art data networks, is poised to enter the mobile phone market, holding talks with several operators about taking capacity on their networks which it would then resell under the Energis brand.
fields.body:
Energis, the telecommunications firm that specialises in building state-of-the-art data networks, is poised to enter the mobile phone market, holding talks with several operators about taking capacity on their networks which it would then resell under the Energis brand. Energis is believed to be in discussions with One 2 One, which already allows its network to be rebranded by Carphone Warehouse and Virgin.

Energis is keen to move into the mobile phone sector as a precursor to securing partnerships with those companies that win the current auction battle for so-called 3G licences. These will allow mobile phone networks to offer wireless Internet and data services to customers - a service Energis sees as crucial if it is to attract the business sector to its network.

Some analysts had predicted that Energis would seek to acquire a 3G licence itself, but the company, which owns the Planet Online Internet service provider, opted to strike deals with licence holders instead. The company is talking to a number of mobile phone operators about offering its network as a carrier for their 3G services, which will be rolled out from 2002 onwards.

Energis's mobile phone services will initially be aimed at business customers.

The company's move into the mobile sector, details of which will be unveiled with the company's full-year re sults next month, marks the latest stage in Energis's business strategy. Formed in 1993, it floated in 1997 and is now trying to build a pan-European data-carrying network. The company, currently valued at more than £9 billion, has clients including Boots, the BBC and Freeserve.

As part of its strategy of offering broadband data networks to corporate clients, Energis will bid for a clutch of regional radio spectrum licences up for grabs later this year. The licences enable holders to offer 'fixed wireless' solutions. This will allow telecoms firms to connect their broadband networks to companies' telephone exchanges using radio signals rather than cable.

fields.headline: Is Rudy finally losing it?
fields.standfirst: His common touch has deserted him, as have key staff and maybe even his wife. In the battle for a Senate seat, the Mayor of New York's worst enemy is not his opponent, Hillary Clinton - it's himself
fields.trailText: His common touch has deserted him, as have key staff and maybe even his wife. In the battle for a Senate seat, the Mayor of New York's worst enemy is not his opponent, Hillary Clinton - it's himself
fields.body:
Rudy Giuliani picks at ham and eggs, sipping furtively from a cup of coffee. John McCain, his self-described 'soul mate' and campaign support act, pours cream and sugar into his. McCain doesn't actually touch the cup but the point here is not to drink coffee, rather, to leave a tip at the Landmark diner in Roslyn, Long Island.

Rudy reaches into the right back pocket of his trousers, pulls out a generous $20 bill and slaps it down on the Formica-topped table. Just to show that he is not a carpetbagging alien like that Clinton woman, who had breezed out of a breakfast joint in Manhattan a few days previously leaving no tip at all for the wretched waitress. Just to show that Hurricane Rudy is a man of the people. 'Rudy without the Rude' as they are now trying to sell him. Which is absurd, because without the rude, it isn't Rudy.

Giuliani and his star support act look good together - two men who are scratchier, more stubborn and principled than the Republican party machine they serve. Eggs eaten and tip deposited, they board the bus to continue along what will be the most electrifying US campaign trail in decades, the nastiest, most jagged clash of cheese-grater egos within living political memory - His Honour the Mayor versus the First Lady in the contest for a seat in the Senate.

For a year, Giuliani has led Hillary Clinton in the polls, which is itself not remarkable for a man rightly credited with having led New York's urban renaissance; it should be no contest, a walkover. But now Clinton is stealing a march. Last week, for the first time, Giuliani's aides were not brushing off the polls as whimsy and fad, mainly because the reason for Clinton's apparent acceleration ahead of her rival is nothing to do with her - it reflects something mysterious and ambivalent between the most popular Mayor New York has ever had and his citizenry.

This man making his weaselish way through the crowds on Long Island has remained as enigmatic as he is ubiquitous. Giuliani looks prickly and embattled these days; the comparison with Richard Nixon is irresistible. He has lost weight, he looks gaunt and menacing. His facial muscles work hard, indicating distress as well as unrelenting energy. There seem to be two Rudy Giulianis fighting this election: one, the dragon-slaying District Attorney who was elected mayor and set out to make New York a greater place; the other, a man propelled by deeper, more personal and complicated - perhaps even darker - motives.

It has been a bittersweet couple of weeks for Giuliani. After the jolt in the opinion polls came the political equivalent of a midwinter holiday in the sun - opening day at Yankee Stadium, which is home turf for the Mayor. He wore his 'NY' cap and jumped in the air like a schoolboy along with tens of thousands of other people who adore him second only to the Bronx Bombers themselves.

But behind this happy break, yet another rupture has opened up at Giuliani's fortress of City Hall, where both the politics and the psychodrama of his administration are played out. Just as he is embarking on an embrace of every voter in New York State, Giuliani has become more and more reclusive, his cabal of confidants and allies ever-shrinking into a tight circle of almost Bolshevik intensity. And last week, that circle shrunk yet again, by one.

The city's comptroller - or top civil servant - Alan Hevesi had never been part of the inner, inner sanctum. He was a Democrat, for a start, but leader of that crucial constituency of 'Giuliani Democrats'.
