But memory is fickle, short and unforgiving, especially in the case of New York and Rudy Giuliani. When he won the mayoral election of 1993, New York had been written off as ungoverned and apparently ungovernable. The murder rate was at a record high; there was a sense that the rule of law had collapsed. The public sector under Mayor David Dinkins was a lurching, corrupt miasma of Byzantine patronage operating like a Mafia statelet and spending public money as though there were no tomorrow. The economy was in ruins.

Giuliani and his then police commissioner William Bratton took an axe first to crime, and to the roots of policy on crime. The received wisdom was that crime would be solved through political means: gun control, welfare spending, education spending, public housing and other estimable policies accompanied by 'community policing'. Against this approach, Giuliani tried what he called the 'broken windows' method, also known as 'zero tolerance': the idea that allowing one broken window to go unmended encourages vandals to break more. Translated, it meant that the authorities would stop small problems turning into big ones by targeting them head-on, specifically the drug rings and the guns that empowered them.

The results are well-known. The murder rate plunged by roughly 100 people a month. Had it remained at the level it was in the last year of the Dinkins administration, 1,328 New Yorkers would now be dead who are not. By 1998, New York recorded fewer murders than Chicago, a city one-third its size. The area that saw the sharpest drop in the crime rate was the black area of Harlem, where violent crime fell by 61 per cent between 1994 and 1998. Giuliani had overturned three decades of thinking about how to enforce the law in America and the ghetto was the first place to breathe the oxygen of relative safety.

At the spearhead of this attack was a new police division called the street crimes unit, which operated from precinct to precinct. It is remarkable how much damage 362 cops can inflict on a city of 7.5 million people. In the two years up until its apocalyptic and disastrous moment - the killing of an unarmed West African called Amadou Diallo - the unit made 9,500 arrests, mostly for illegal firearms, in 45,000 stops, a hit-rate of 20 per cent. Looked at another way: 0.3 per cent of the NYPD was confiscating 40 per cent of the guns.

Crime was not the only notch on Giuliani's staff. In 1993, New York was losing 7,000 jobs a month, a total of 330,000 during the Dinkins administration. Last year, however, the city's economy grew faster than that of the nation for the first time in a decade. Private-sector jobs expanded at an all-time record pace. Nowhere was the new affluence more visible than in Harlem, undergoing what was called a 'second renaissance'.

The man elected to rule the metropolis came from a family that epitomises the epic of New York City. He was the grandson of poor Italian immigrants and only child to parents who considered his birth to be a divine miracle in answer to their prayers. His childhood was wrapped in a deep Catholicism, especially by his father. As in many Catholic homes, John F. Kennedy was the household icon alongside the Messiah. The young boy was diligent, hard working and almost as ambitious for himself as his mother Helen was. There was corporal punishment at home, and at Bishop Loughlin High in Brooklyn, run by the Christian Brothers. It was the best for miles around - each parish in Queens, Brooklyn and Long Island could send only its two brightest pupils.

The Brothers were also a guiding hand behind Manhattan College in the Bronx, to which Giuliani proceeded, majoring in political science and philosophy. He considered the priesthood, but his fondness for women was an obvious obstacle to such a plan. Instead, he went to NYU to read law. An excavation of his writing in the university law review makes interesting reading: he supported the Senate candidacy of the man then decried by the New York Times as a 'carpetbagger', Robert F. Kennedy. He despised Barry Goldwater. Giuliani's views were broadly liberal; the Republican congressman for Long Island, Peter King, even recalls the student Giuliani being sympathetic towards the race rioters in Watts and Chicago.

But Giuliani was a Republican and moral crusader, and his destiny was to be a prosecutor pointing the righteous finger of accusation. In the month in 1968 that his hero Bobby Kennedy was assassinated, Giuliani began his clerkship and soon dazzled in court with cross-examination as sharp as a scalpel blade. The young prosecutor found a political mentor called Harold Tyler in the Ford administration, but the advent of Jimmy Carter to the White House sent him back into private practice, and a partnership in the Manhattan law firm, Patterson's, until the call came to serve under the Reagan administration in 1981. During that time, he would work by day and party by night. One of the firm's young hopefuls, Renee Szybala recalls chancing upon the prodigy Giuliani one night on a dance floor. 'I was flabbergasted,' she says. 'It was not the usual place to meet partners.'

Even now, he likes a dance, loves the attention of women and enjoys a show - he was an opera-lover even as a child - especially when he is the star. There was a party last year for a carefully picked selection from the City Hall politburo at which Rudy surprised the company by turning up in drag. The wig was auburn, the dress a cling-fit. Then there was the night he met and even flirted with Hillary Clinton.

This was only last month, at a banquet at the Midtown Hilton. When Hillary entered, Rudy seized her hand and greeted her like a prom queen. 'I hear you're the star of the show,' said Hillary with a coquettish smile. 'We'll see,' replied the Mayor. A few minutes later, Rudy reappeared, the tux exchanged for a John Travolta-style pressed white suit. The Bee Gees struck up and Rudy shook his stuff to 'Night Fever', leading a blonde in a backless number and heels to kill with.

When violence shattered the funeral of Patrick Dorismond in Brooklyn's Little Haiti two weeks ago, it was not only Giuliani's insensitive handling of the dead man's petty criminal record that detonated emotions on the street. The collective memory of Haiti's wretched diaspora recalls well that a young Turk in the Justice Department called Giuliani once represented the US government in its refusal of political asylum to thousands of desperate boat people in flight from the Tonton Macoute. And that he made a visit to their country, met its dictator, Baby Doc, and concluded that 'political repression, at least in general, does not exist'.

In 1983, Giuliani moved back to New York, to become District Attorney. It was a curious career move: by then, aged only 38, he was the most senior federal prosecutor in the land. But it was the city state not the nation state that interested Giuliani, and he declared unrelenting war on the column of power that governed that city state in parallel to his own: Cosa Nostra. In a series of investigations and court cases before which Martin Scorsese's movies pale, Giuliani began branding his imprint on New York life. He broke the Mafia's back. He broke the Colombo crime syndicate, he broke mobster, Anthony 'Fat Tony' Salerno, he broke and recruited Sammy 'the Bull' Gravano, thereby laying the ground for the conviction of John Gotti. He also broke into trickery on Wall Street, and made inroads into political corruption. It became quickly clear that New York was never going to recover from this man.

This was the man the city - Democratic to the core - rejected once in the mayoral election of 1989 but could not resist again in the mayhem of 1993. His re-election four years later was a foregone conclusion and a landslide. 'Giuliani looked infallible,' said one former adviser, 'and he felt it too. Only problem is that he wasn't and isn't, and he was and is the only person not to realise that.'

How could the man at the apex of such a revolution possibly trail in the polls behind the out-of-town wife of an adulterous, impeached President? The story of the fall, like the story of the rise, has crime and street violence as its driving narrative.

Ironically, the Mayor had created a good-time mood in New York and he was out of step with that mood. The prosecutor could not stop, and the offences were soon out of proportion to his zeal. Under the aegis of the 'broken windows' policy, Giuliani's crusade expanded from gun-toting drug-dealers to such folk as jaywalkers, hot-dog vendors and zig-zagging cab drivers. The crusade against crime became a crusade against immorality, as porn shops, strip clubs and the Sensation art show came under the Giuliani hammer.

The nadir in Giuliani's search for undesirables came last Christmas, when the Mayor declared a cruel war on the homeless. He instructed the police to drive them off the streets and into shelters, where they would have to register for work or face jail. Of course the policy failed, but by then the damage had been done by another Giuliani reform: fatally, he had trebled the size of the street crimes unit. If 138 cops could do all that damage, imagine what 380 could do. But there were not enough veteran officers to go round - only the wild bunch, anxious to do it all. That would be Giuliani's costliest mistake.

There was also, meanwhile, a problem of political deportment and the Mayor's outsized personality. Conversations with people who work under and with Giuliani at City Hall all converge on descriptions of how he rules city state New York like a Machiavellian prince holed up in a fortress. And within that fortress is an inner citadel, the Mayor's office. Like any megalomaniac autocrat, Giuliani trusts few if any of his staff and rules from an inner sanctum. 'He centralised everything,' says one aide.'The Mayor knows everything,' Giuliani said recently in unconvincing self-mockery, 'he finds out everything.'

When black politicians complain that Giuliani treats them badly, they are right. But Rudy treats all politicians badly. He was never a man in search of advice. 'He is a man of talent, self-confidence and ruthless energy,' said one official still on Giuliani's staff, 'but each of those assets has a flip side. On the other side of the confidence is disdain for others; on the other side of the energy, there's a blind spot'.

At the core of the inner sanctum was Giuliani's connection to the outside world, his 'communications director' Chrystine Lategano. She was his shadow, his closest aide. The overt intimacy between the two was brazen and audacious: after spending all day huddled up together in the office, they would adjourn to Cooper's Classic Cigar bar in midtown to continue the never-ending conversation about how to run New York. Donna Hanover - aka Mrs Giuliani - meanwhile kept her maiden name in deed as well as word, hardly ever appearing at official functions and now reported to be living apart from her husband. She even refused to say whether she had voted for him.

But even those who worked closely under Giuliani could never prove what happened behind closed doors, and few even want to hypothesise the untold tale of a love affair. 'It is presumed, but not known,' says one former aide. 'It was in the glint of an eye, but no more.' In May last year, Lategano mysteriously quit. The parting was apparently amicable and widely assumed to be a way of fending off the pincer movement of rumour on the one hand and advancing foes on the other. What is astonishing, however, is the contrast between the silent awe at the possibility of Giuliani's affair with Lategano, and the voracious appetite for every detail of the extramarital sex life of Hillary Clinton's husband.

When the pool of confidants is a small one, desertion - let alone a brain drain - is a serious matter. One by one, some of the most talented people in City Hall trickled away, cut out of the loop - the artisans of government, the craftsmen and women of civic life.

In Lategano's place, Giuliani chose another controversial confidant in Bruce Teitelbaum. Operating as hatchet man, like Giuliani's military wing, Teitelbaum was a faithful pen-pusher in the mayoral campaigns suddenly elevated to become the second most powerful man in the city. And yet Teitelbaum casts his own shadows: he was questioned by the Brooklyn District Attorney this year for connections to an Hassidic Jewish construction consortium associated with the collapse of a building in which two workers were killed. Teitelbaum was said to have fostered special treatment for the company at City Hall in order to maintain good relations with the crucial Jewish community that is said to hold the electoral balance of power in New York.

By the start of last year, something was waiting to go wrong for Giuliani. Finally, it happened in the Bronx in February 1999. Four officers from the street crimes unit shot Amadou Diallo, an unarmed, deeply religious, innocent West African street vendor.

Giuliani's response to Diallo's death was politically tone-deaf. Which was strange, since his outraged reaction to another police abomination - the torture of a Haitian in policy custody - had been exemplary and prompted the American Civil Liberties Union to call the revolting episode 'Giuliani's finest hour'. Now, he made a series of costly errors. 'Fatally, he presumed he had the family on his side and he did not,' recalls one aide. He said he would 'reserve judgment' on the shooting; he defended the record of the street crimes unit. In the month that followed, his popularity fell by 20 points.

Giuliani's enemies were many, but none was more eager to advance against the Mayor than the Rev Al Sharpton, self-appointed leader of the black community. Sharpton needed a break after making a fool of himself in backing a hoax - a woman who said she had been assaulted by the Ku Klux Klan, but had made it up. Now, Sharpton's moment had come and he seized it with relish.

From then on, he capitalised on injury to a black community that had benefited most from Giuliani's war on crime, but which now felt itself to be ruled by an army of occupation called the NYPD. The killing of Dorismond last month not only deepened that sentiment but widened it too, calling into the question the mayoralty and character of Giuliani and the price extracted by 'zero tolerance'. Giuliani's reaction to the Dorismond death was so bizarre that even William Bratton, co-architect of zero tolerance, said: 'Like the rest of the New York, I'm appalled. People are beginning to question this guy's judgment.'

The late Erik Erikson, Pulitzer Prize-winning psychoanalyst, wrote that great political leaders must be protean to a degree and adopt a range of guises. Thomas Jefferson was Erikson's exemplary specimen and how he would have admired the President named after him, William Jefferson Clinton. And how he would have despaired at Giuliani. 'He strikes me as someone who feels he can shape reality to suit his own interests rather than adjust to it,' said Dr Richard Ulman, a Manhattan psychologist who studies political figures.

In this hex, Giuliani becomes his own worst enemy. Because he habitually chooses hubris over contrition, the political complexities of his candidacy get blurred over. He has, actually, taken a moderate stand in many areas of social policy on which he would be required to vote in the Senate and is a downright heretic on such matters as welfare, abortion and gay rights. Only recently has Giuliani had to play at being a partisan Republican, but this he has done with a gusto which may come to haunt him.

He has hired the Svengali of direct mailing, Richard Viguerie, to send fusillades of propaganda into the mailboxes of New York. Viguerie is an ideologist of the hard Right, who first practised the art of mass-mailing in the 1960s for the man whom the law student Giuliani passionately loathed, Barry Goldwater. The beneficiaries of his expertise since then have included George Wallace, Oliver North, Jesse Helms and the Rev Sun Il Moon. Giuliani has also accepted free campaign advertising from another right-wing maverick, Howard Ruff, a Utah Mormon with 18 grandchildren who is buying TV time and Netspace to become Hillary Clinton's latest rabid antagonist. 'It's easier to kill a baby snake than a 12-foot king cobra,' ranted Ruff. 'We need to stop this woman.'

In this artificially polarised climate, not only do Giuliani's achievements get overlooked, but also the facts about the now accursed NYPD. The reality is that along with crime, police violence in New York is also down to an all-time record low, the force never more disciplined. Fatalities per capita as a result of police guns are way below those of, say, Washington DC, which has a black Mayor. Indeed, the race card too fails to convince, insofar as Giuliani's achievements in New York are rivalled - and probably exceeded - only by those of his opposite number in New Orleans. There, Mayor Marc Morial has deployed an iron fist to punch down crime and murder rates and presided over an extraordinary economic boom. Morial is black; he was a civil rights activist. They even call him the 'black Giuliani' down on the bayou - and that's a compliment.

Deep down, New Yorkers know all this when they size up Hillary Clinton's bromide smile against Giuliani's grimace and that is why only a fool or a pollster would dismiss Giuliani at this stage. Either because of or despite the fact that he is the most remarkable politician in America, Giuliani doesn't take much notice of polls - but then nor do most New Yorkers. Even the fact that Giuliani has the political subtlety of a juggernaut without brakes can play to his advantage in this city.

A friend of mine - America's leading writer on what propels the intelligent criminal mind - speaks for most of New York when she says: 'I am angry with Giuliani and grateful to him at the same time. Anyone who is honest in this town is torn about Rudy. And knows that we're all in the shitpan when he leaves us. He behaves horribly, but New York behaves horribly. He's our guy, he's an asshole, but he's our asshole'.

Rudy reaches into the right back pocket of his trousers, pulls out a generous $20 bill and slaps it down on the Formica-topped table. Just to show that he is not a carpetbagging alien like that Clinton woman, who had breezed out of a breakfast joint in Manhattan a few days previously leaving no tip at all for the wretched waitress. Just to show that Hurricane Rudy is a man of the people. 'Rudy without the Rude' as they are now trying to sell him. Which is absurd, because without the rude, it isn't Rudy. Giuliani and his star support act look good together - two men who are scratchier, more stubborn and principled than the Republican party machine they serve. Eggs eaten and tip deposited, they board the bus to continue along what will be the most electrifying US campaign trail in decades, the nastiest, most jagged clash of cheese-grater egos within living political memory - His Honour the Mayor versus the First Lady in the contest for a seat in the Senate. 'He centralised everything,' says one aide.'The Mayor knows everything,' Giuliani said recently in unconvincing self-mockery, 'he finds out everything.' When black politicians complain that Giuliani treats them badly, they are right. But Rudy treats all politicians badly. He was never a man in search of advice. 'He is a man of talent, self-confidence and ruthless energy,' said one official still on Giuliani's staff, 'but each of those assets has a flip side. On the other side of the confidence is disdain for others; on the other side of the energy, there's a blind spot'. At the core of the inner sanctum was Giuliani's connection to the outside world, his 'communications director' Chrystine Lategano. She was his shadow, his closest aide. The overt intimacy between the two was brazen and audacious: after spending all day huddled up together in the office, they would adjourn to Cooper's Classic Cigar bar in midtown to continue the never-ending conversation about how to run New York. Donna Hanover - aka Mrs Giuliani - meanwhile kept her maiden name in deed as well as word, hardly ever appearing at official functions and now reported to be living apart from her husband. She even refused to say whether she had voted for him. But even those who worked closely under Giuliani could never prove what happened behind closed doors, and few even want to hypothesise the untold tale of a love affair. 'It is presumed, but not known,' says one former aide. 'It was in the glint of an eye, but no more.' In May last year, Lategano mysteriously quit. The parting was apparently amicable and widely assumed to be a way of fending off the pincer movement of rumour on the one hand and advancing foes on the other. What is astonishing, however, is the contrast between the silent awe at the possibility of Giuliani's affair with Lategano, and the voracious appetite for every detail of the extramarital sex life of Hillary Clinton's husband. When the pool of confidants is a small one, desertion - let alone a brain drain - is a serious matter. One by one, some of the most talented people in City Hall trickled away, cut out of the loop - the artisans of government, the craftsmen and women of civic life. In Lategano's place, Giuliani chose another controversial confidant in Bruce Teitelbaum. Operating as hatchet man, like Giuliani's military wing, Teitelbaum was a faithful pen-pusher in the mayoral campaigns suddenly elevated to become the second most powerful man in the city. And yet Teitelbaum casts his own shadows: he was questioned by the Brooklyn District Attorney this year for connections to an Hassidic Jewish construction consortium associated with the collapse of a building in which two workers were killed. Teitelbaum was said to have fostered special treatment for the company at City Hall in order to maintain good relations with the crucial Jewish community that is said to hold the electoral balance of power in New York. By the start of last year, something was waiting to go wrong for Giuliani. Finally, it happened in the Bronx in February 1999. Four officers from the street crimes unit shot Amadou Diallo, an unarmed, deeply religious, innocent West African street vendor. Giuliani's response to Diallo's death was politically tone-deaf. Which was strange, since his outraged reaction to another police abomination - the torture of a Haitian in policy custody - had been exemplary and prompted the American Civil Liberties Union to call the revolting episode 'Giuliani's finest hour'. Now, he made a series of costly errors. 'Fatally, he presumed he had the family on his side and he did not,' recalls one aide. He said he would 'reserve judgment' on the shooting; he defended the record of the street crimes unit. In the month that followed, his popularity fell by 20 points. Giuliani's enemies were many, but none was more eager to advance against the Mayor than the Rev Al Sharpton, self-appointed leader of the black community. Sharpton needed a break after making a fool of himself in backing a hoax - a woman who said she had been assaulted by the Ku Klux Klan, but had made it up. Now, Sharpton's moment had come and he seized it with relish. From then on, he capitalised on injury to a black community that had benefited most from Giuliani's war on crime, but which now felt itself to be ruled by an army of occupation called the NYPD. The killing of Dorismond last month not only deepened that sentiment but widened it too, calling into the question the mayoralty and character of Giuliani and the price extracted by 'zero tolerance'. Giuliani's reaction to the Dorismond death was so bizarre that even William Bratton, co-architect of zero tolerance, said: 'Like the rest of the New York, I'm appalled. People are beginning to question this guy's judgment.' The late Erik Erikson, Pulitzer Prize-winning psychoanalyst, wrote that great political leaders must be protean to a degree and adopt a range of guises. Thomas Jefferson was Erikson's exemplary specimen and how he would have admired the President named after him, William Jefferson Clinton. And how he would have despaired at Giuliani. 'He strikes me as someone who feels he can shape reality to suit his own interests rather than adjust to it,' said Dr Richard Ulman, a Manhattan psychologist who studies political figures. In this hex, Giuliani becomes his own worst enemy. Because he habitually chooses hubris over contrition, the political complexities of his candidacy get blurred over. He has, actually, taken a moderate stand in many areas of social policy on which he would be required to vote in the Senate and is a downright heretic on such matters as welfare, abortion and gay rights. Only recently has Giuliani had to play at being a partisan Republican, but this he has done with a gusto which may come to haunt him. He has hired the Svengali of direct mailing, Richard Viguerie, to send fusillades of propaganda into the mailboxes of New York. Viguerie is an ideologist of the hard Right, who first practised the art of mass-mailing in the 1960s for the man whom the law student Giuliani passionately loathed, Barry Goldwater. The beneficiaries of his expertise since then have included George Wallace, Oliver North, Jesse Helms and the Rev Sun Il Moon. Giuliani has also accepted free campaign advertising from another right-wing maverick, Howard Ruff, a Utah Mormon with 18 grandchildren who is buying TV time and Netspace to become Hillary Clinton's latest rabid antagonist. 'It's easier to kill a baby snake than a 12-foot king cobra,' ranted Ruff. 'We need to stop this woman.' In this artificially polarised climate, not only do Giuliani's achievements get overlooked, but also the facts about the now accursed NYPD. The reality is that along with crime, police violence in New York is also down to an all-time record low, the force never more disciplined. Fatalities per capita as a result of police guns are way below those of, say, Washington DC, which has a black Mayor. Indeed, the race card too fails to convince, insofar as Giuliani's achievements in New York are rivalled - and probably exceeded - only by those of his opposite number in New Orleans. There, Mayor Marc Morial has deployed an iron fist to punch down crime and murder rates and presided over an extraordinary economic boom. Morial is black; he was a civil rights activist. They even call him the 'black Giuliani' down on the bayou - and that's a compliment. Deep down, New Yorkers know all this when they size up Hillary Clinton's bromide smile against Giuliani's grimace and that is why only a fool or a pollster would dismiss Giuliani at this stage. Either because of or despite the fact that he is the most remarkable politician in America, Giuliani doesn't take much notice of polls - but then nor do most New Yorkers. Even the fact that Giuliani has the political subtlety of a juggernaut without brakes can play to his advantage in this city. A friend of mine - America's leading writer on what propels the intelligent criminal mind - speaks for most of New York when she says: 'I am angry with Giuliani and grateful to him at the same time. Anyone who is honest in this town is torn about Rudy. And knows that we're all in the shitpan when he leaves us. He behaves horribly, but New York behaves horribly. He's our guy, he's an asshole, but he's our asshole'.

webTitle: God's on our side. So's the union

fields.headline: God's on our side. So's the union
fields.trailText: It's an invitation that could make the more traditional parson choke on the Paschal lamb. The white-collar MSF union is launching a campaign to boost its membership among the dog-collar wearing fraternity. It is aiming to recruit 2,000 members of the Christian brotherhood to the ranks of Manufacturing, Science and Finance this year, more than doubling the 1,700 clergymen and women it already represents.
fields.body:
It's an invitation that could make the more traditional parson choke on the Paschal lamb. The white-collar MSF union is launching a campaign to boost its membership among the dog-collar wearing fraternity. It is aiming to recruit 2,000 members of the Christian brotherhood to the ranks of Manufacturing, Science and Finance this year, more than doubling the 1,700 clergymen and women it already represents.

The drive will be launched at the Millennium Dome during the Trades Union Congress day on 1 May. A nationwide poster campaign backed with information leaflets is planned. But its invitation goes out to a wider spiritual audience than those who are celebrating the culmination of Holy Week today. MSF spokesman Chris Ball said the union was open to all religions.

'We are very ecumenically minded. Our core membership is obviously Anglican, but we have Roman Catholics, Greek Orthodox, Methodist, Episcopalian... people from all denominations. I've even bumped into a Buddhist.'

Ball said clergy were threatened with growing job insecurity as traditional benefices - where vicars were endowed a job and accommodation - fall away, leaving them with low pay and no guarantees of future employment. He said the union would be able to counsel and represent any parsons who were facing insecurity as well as all those individuals who found the Church to be an unsympathetic or discriminating employer. In one case a Methodist minister was facing disciplinary action and possible dismissal when the Church discovered he was in a single-sex relationship.

The union came to his rescue and safeguarded his job.

He added that the clergy section had been going since 1994 but felt there was a great opportunity to recruit many more of the 16,000 clergymen of all religions in the UK.

fields.headline: The Max factor
fields.standfirst: Our celebration of the capital starts with a Lynn Barber profile of the most influential man in the mayoral election:  Evening Standard editor Max Hastings. A huge responsibility for a shooting, fishing countryman who loathes city life
fields.trailText: Our celebration of the capital starts with a Lynn Barber profile of the most influential man in the mayoral election: Evening Standard editor Max Hastings. A huge responsibility for a shooting, fishing countryman who loathes city life
fields.body:
One could hardly imagine a more improbable editor for a London newspaper than Max Hastings. His hobbies are shooting and fishing. He commutes from a farmhouse in Berkshire with a proper gun room, and dreams of the salmon rivers of Scotland. He has never willingly spent a weekend in London, except to attend the Countryside March. He doesn't quite wear green wellies to work but his office car is a chauffeur-driven Range Rover. He is six foot five, with a voice pitched to carry across grousemoors. Moreover, he is going deaf from all the shooting, so his bark is getting steadily louder. And yet he also blushes like a schoolgirl. Some of 'the troops' - which is how he refers to his staff - find him terrifying; others find him tactless but kind.

He is often referred to as General Hastings (or Hitler Hastings, by Private Eye) - even journalists assume that he has some military background. Actually he doesn't - he toyed with the idea of joining the paras after school and went on a training exercise but acquitted himself so badly that he quietly dropped that ambition. But he made his name as a journalist in the Falklands War. He was the first reporter into Port Stanley where he 'liberated' the Upland Goose pub single-handed. He believes that he owes his whole subsequent career to that one improbable stunt in an improbable war. The other journalists hated him - Michael Nicholson of ITN said that 'He was considered an insufferably pompous, bumptious egoist, which, of course, he was and remains' - but he came back a star. Conrad Black appointed him editor of the Telegraph in 1986, and he turned the moribund, near-bankrupt newspaper into a sleek commercial success. But he was always at odds with Black over politics - Hastings is a left-of-centre One Nation Tory who says he now has no party to vote for - and in 1996 he thankfully moved to the Evening Standard. To his Tory toff friends, it must have seemed a terrible comedown, going from a stately broadsheet much read in the corridors of power, to a scruffy tabloid much read on the Tube, but he admits that money was an incentive - £400,000 pa instead of £185,000 - and he was in the middle of a very expensive divorce.

So now this man with no stake in London and no very obvious affection for it, runs London's monopoly newspaper (circulation 470,000) with all the power to make or break any candidate in the Mayoral election. It is more power than any editor should have - it is positively indecent. Hastings admits to some unease: 'I don't normally lie awake at nights worrying terribly that something we've done in the newspaper might have terrible effects on the nation because, actually, one of the good things about life is that newspapers have rather less effect than people think. But I do worry about the Mayor because the Evening Standard campaigned for a Mayor for London, and if it's all going to be a disaster, then yes, I will be blushing a bit.'

He was blushing furiously at the beginning when Jeffrey Archer was chosen as the Tory candidate. Hastings has always loathed and distrusted Archer and pulled out every possible stop to expose him, sending reporters to investigate the Anglia shares deal, and getting Paul Foot to refresh our memories of his Canadian shoplifting contretemps. But Archer survived the massed guns of the Evening Standard, and was only finally brought down by the sudden exposure of his fake libel alibi. Hastings admits, 'We were as jawdropped as anybody else. At one level I was so relieved. Peter Kellner, our very good political commentator, was always saying, "Relax, Max, there's no way Archer can win." But I used to literally lie awake nights thinking, "How will I feel if, having been so keen on a Mayor for London, we end up with a complete shyster and I will have helped to bring that about?" I had all sorts of people, quite intelligent, thoughtful people, coming up to me and saying, "Why do you keep up this vendetta against poor old Jeffrey? He's not a bad fellow really." I was shocked. Yet even now, people still seem willing to eat with him, hobnob with him - it's incredible.'

Those same friends, of course, tell him that it will be all his fault if 'that Livingstone' gets in. All his fishing pals, all his shooting cronies, all his chums in the Beefsteak, Brooks's, Pratt's must be snorting through their snifters at the prospect of Red Ken. And then, of course, there's Number 10 constantly complaining about anything it sees as a pro-Livingstone story in the Standard. But Max Hastings has proved steady under fire. As soon as Dobbo was chosen as Labour candidate, the Standard published a poll showing the strength of Livingstone's support, which drew a hail of faxes from Downing Street saying, 'Is Ken Livingstone writing your headlines for you now?' Hastings found it irritating rather than alarming. 'One of the things I love about getting older is that 10 years ago that sort of thing would have rattled me, but nowadays it doesn't bother me a bit.'

He has said all along that the Standard will not come out for any candidate until election day. Officially, he remains a sceptic on Livingstone who he first met in 1981, 'I disagree with everything he stands for but he's always good company and he has that quality of mischievous defiance which is always irresistible. Even now, whenever I see him, I tend to grin because it's hard not to like him.'

And anyway, he says, 'It would have been a very dull contest without Ken Livingstone. But there's no doubt that the consequences for the Blair government if Livingstone wins are extremely serious. In fact, I think they're a lot more serious for Blair than they are for Londoners.' Livingstone as Mayor can't do too much damage to London (because the Mayor's powers are very limited) but he can provide years of Blair-baiting fun for the Evening Standard. I would be amazed if the paper eventually came out for anyone else.

Typically, at the last election, Hastings advised Standard readers to vote Labour, while declaring that he himself would vote Tory because he couldn't support a party that wanted to ban fox-hunting. This rather glaringly illustrated the gulf between him and his readers. But he now seems keen to minimise that gulf, or at least play down his disdain for the City. There is an old and much-loved story that Simon Jenkins, a former editor of the Evening Standard, once insisted on driving Hastings round London on a Sunday to demonstrate that it was still populated at the weekend. Hastings says of course it's not true - but then chortles 'I would have my toenails extracted with redhot pincers rather than spend a Sunday in London. But that doesn't alter the fact that one spent all one's formative years here. I know my way around London inside out and back to front.'

Really? So has he been to Hoxton? He thinks so, once, 'about 15 years ago'. The other night his daughter, down from university, demanded that he show her London's celebrity hangouts, so he dutifully dug out his Groucho Club and Met Bar membership cards, unused before, and ventured warily into London's nightlife. But if there were any celebs to be spotted he didn't spot them and he was safely back in bed by midnight. Anyway, he says, he's not going to pretend to be au courant with the clubbing scene - 'I'm not Janet Street-Porter!' - but he goes to the theatre, he goes to restaurants. And he has been on the Tube, last autumn in the rush hour. How did he find it? 'Rather like spending four hours at the Dome, which was probably my worst experience this year. It was horrific. But at least they can't say that one hasn't had a good look.'

He says that one thing he shares with Ken Livingstone is that he had a 'London childhood'. I don't imagine Livingstone would see much similarity - Hastings grew up in Rutland Gate, going for walks with his nanny round Kensington Gardens and having food delivered from Harrods. He claims that when he first got a flat, he didn't know you could obtain food any other way, and would place his grocery order with Harrods and wait for the green van (though I think he is winding me up a bit here). He certainly is when he says that one of the major inconveniences of recent years is that he cannot now buy 'so much as a collarstud' from Harrods, since Mohamed Al Fayed became its owner. 'I think Fayed is a bad man. I find it incredible that people cheerfully wander in and out of Harrods buying things and don't appear to care that he is running it.'

Hastings is quite strict, even puritanical, about such matters. He wrote a blistering article last November about 'The Friends of Jeffrey Archer'. Hastings believes if someone's a rogue you've got to shun him. He says it sometimes causes awkward moments in his social life, not so much over Archer, as over Jonathan Aitken. 'I always thought Aitken was a bad man, but to this day quite a few friends of mine, people I like and respect, think that he's a fundamentally decent man who's been hard done by. I disagree violently. It's not that one wants anything further awful to happen to him, but I think it is a bit tough if any of us are expected to sit at the same dinner table with him.'

He means this literally. A few years ago, he walked out of a country house party - before the shooting! - because his host made an anti-Semitic remark. (Hastings has always been passionately pro-Jewish, long before he married his present wife, Penny, who is Jewish. He often says the world should be run by women and Jews.) Hastings was embarrassed that I knew about the incident and added, 'One is sometimes amazed at how anti-Semitic a chunk of English life still is. Do you find that?' Well yes - but it's precisely the chunk Hastings is normally so enraptured by, the great backwoods landowners with their sporting estates and antediluvian ideas. I'm amazed that he 's amazed to find them making anti-Semitic remarks - it seems to betray an odd naivety. 'Fair point. But I suppose, I've always lived my life in a way between traditional English countryside and the media, and I love both worlds - but, of course, what you end up being is slightly distrusted by both. And in the end you have to say journalists are the most fun - it's such a privilege living and working with clever people, isn't it? I mean I've spent quite long stretches of my life living deep in the country and in the end it does drive you mad because nobody reads at all.'

But, of course, he says that to me, a journalist - maybe to his shooting friends he says the opposite. This is the great problem for Hastings-watchers: is he at heart a journalist playing at being a country gentleman, or a country gentleman playing at being a journalist? He was certainly born to be a journalist - his father was Macdonald Hastings, intrepid war correspondent and Special Investigator for Eagle comic; his mother, Anne Scott-James, was a very distinguished columnist. He says he always idolised his father, and was frightened of his mother. 'The irony - which I didn't understand when I was younger but I do now - was that whatever intelligence I have, that has enabled me to bluff my way through journalism all these years, I owe to my mother. My father was a great romantic. His grasp on reality was always rather slender. My mother always used to say he was verging on barking. He had delusions and a grossly exaggerated respect for the landed classes which undoubtedly did influence me when I was younger.'

His father went off on mad adventures for Eagle, crossing the Kalahari desert and being cast away on a desert island (he almost died). He was a great hero to schoolboys, which meant that Hastings as a boy 'was teased all the time that the son of the Eagle Special Investigator was a notable coward on the football field.' He describes his schooldays, at Charterhouse, as 'hellish' and adds 'I hope I'm not in the least bitter, but on the other hand, nothing cheers me up more than to kick an Old Carthusian when he's down. It's amazing, the letters I get from people saying, 'Dear Max, don't you remember me from the dear old school? How would you like to come and open my restaurant?' And you say 'Of course I remember you from the dear old school. Last time we met you were holding me against the study fire!'

He only 'found himself' when he became a reporter on the Evening Standard and discovered he could write. But in those days he was still eaten up with envy for aristocratic landowners - 'When I was 24, I would have killed to own a castle.' He spent a quarter of his salary every year on renting a shooting lodge in Scotland, so that he could play the laird for a couple of weeks. 'It was a complete fantasy. I mean I loved it but it was completely barking. But I think by the time one was about 40, one had got all this out of one's system. And nowadays, I would say, cross my heart, I'm not jealous of anybody and am aware of how lucky I am - I'm grateful to be blissfully happy.'

Much of his happiness comes from his second marriage to Penny Levinson. He first met her when they were both 17 - he was a researcher for the BBC in his gap year before Oxford and she was working in the library. 'I took her out for a while and she recalls with vivid dismay fighting off my beastly advances.' But she went on to marry Michael Grade and he married Patricia Edmondson, a keen fox-hunter, and had three children. When his marriage ended after 20 years, he spent a brief period as a bachelor but didn't exactly make hay: 'I think I once took out a girl quite a bit younger than me, but after dinner she said "Shall we go dancing?" and I looked at her in horror, and said "You must be mad. It's 25 past 10 and I go to bed at half past." And I realised then that there was actually no way that one was up for this.'

He married Penny quietly in a register office last year with Robert Harris and his wife as witnesses.

The Hastings live in a farmhouse near Hungerford, Berkshire, and spend all their weekends gardening. He says that his adventuring, swashbuckling days are behind him - 'One grew up believing that the most important thing in the whole world was to have adventures. But I always had this struggle between being keen on adventures and then being fairly cowardly. I mean if someone had said "Shoulder to shoulder, Carruthers" to me, I'd probably have been running before they'd finished the sentence. I did live hard when I was younger, but now I want to be fantastically comfortable.'

He hopes to stay at the Evening Standard at least until the next general election but by then he'll be 55 and eligible to retire: 'I do feel that I've been sort of bluffing my way through editing all these years, and I do want to have another life as a writer.' He will write military histories, which he is good at: he has just published an excellent memoir of his war-reporting years called Going to the Wars. He is resigned to not getting a knighthood. When he became editor of the Daily Telegraph, he says, a knighthood almost went with the job, and 'I cannot tell a lie - I really liked the idea very much indeed. But then one of Thatcher's henchmen said to me, "You do realise, Max, that if you want your knighthood you'll have to be a lot more helpful to the government," and I was genuinely rather naively shocked. Then, when John Major became prime minister, one was sort of vaguely wondering, but damn me, then one of his chaps said "Well, of course, Max if you want a knighthood..." And I did actually then cross a great thing where I thought: I would love to be given a gong for being a good journalist, but editors don't get gongs for being good journalists, they get them for being helpful to the government of the day, and that is not what we're here for.'

But there's no doubt that the consequences for the Blair government if Livingstone wins are extremely serious. In fact, I think they're a lot more serious for Blair than they are for Londoners.' Livingstone as Mayor can't do too much damage to London (because the Mayor's powers are very limited) but he can provide years of Blair-baiting fun for the Evening Standard. I would be amazed if the paper eventually came out for anyone else. Typically, at the last election, Hastings advised Standard readers to vote Labour, while declaring that he himself would vote Tory because he couldn't support a party that wanted to ban fox-hunting. This rather glaringly illustrated the gulf between him and his readers. But he now seems keen to minimise that gulf, or at least play down his disdain for the City. There is an old and much-loved story that Simon Jenkins, a former editor of the Evening Standard, once insisted on driving Hastings round London on a Sunday to demonstrate that it was still populated at the weekend. Hastings says of course it's not true - but then chortles 'I would have my toenails extracted with redhot pincers rather than spend a Sunday in London. But that doesn't alter the fact that one spent all one's formative years here. I know my way around London inside out and back to front.' Really? So has he been to Hoxton? He thinks so, once, 'about 15 years ago'. The other night his daughter, down from university, demanded that he show her London's celebrity hangouts, so he dutifully dug out his Groucho Club and Met Bar membership cards, unused before, and ventured warily into London's nightlife. But if there were any celebs to be spotted he didn't spot them and he was safely back in bed by midnight. Anyway, he says, he's not going to pretend to be au courant with the clubbing scene - 'I'm not Janet Street-Porter!' - but he goes to the theatre, he goes to restaurants. And he has been on the Tube, last autumn in the rush hour. How did he find it? 'Rather like spending four hours at the Dome, which was probably my worst experience this year. It was horrific. But at least they can't say that one hasn't had a good look.' He says that one thing he shares with Ken Livingstone is that he had a 'London childhood'. I don't imagine Livingstone would see much similarity - Hastings grew up in Rutland Gate, going for walks with his nanny round Kensington Gardens and having food delivered from Harrods. He claims that when he first got a flat, he didn't know you could obtain food any other way, and would place his grocery order with Harrods and wait for the green van (though I think he is winding me up a bit here). He certainly is when he says that one of the major inconveniences of recent years is that he cannot now buy 'so much as a collarstud' from Harrods, since Mohamed Al Fayed became its owner. 'I think Fayed is a bad man. I find it incredible that people cheerfully wander in and out of Harrods buying things and don't appear to care that he is running it.' Hastings is quite strict, even puritanical, about such matters. He wrote a blistering article last November about 'The Friends of Jeffrey Archer'. Hastings believes if someone's a rogue you've got to shun him. He says it sometimes causes awkward moments in his social life, not so much over Archer, as over Jonathan Aitken. 'I always thought Aitken was a bad man, but to this day quite a few friends of mine, people I like and respect, think that he's a fundamentally decent man who's been hard done by. I disagree violently. It's not that one wants anything further awful to happen to him, but I think it is a bit tough if any of us are expected to sit at the same dinner table with him.' He means this literally. A few years ago, he walked out of a country house party - before the shooting! - because his host made an anti-Semitic remark. (Hastings has always been passionately pro-Jewish, long before he married his present wife, Penny, who is Jewish. He often says the world should be run by women and Jews.) Hastings was embarrassed that I knew about the incident and added, 'One is sometimes amazed at how anti-Semitic a chunk of English life still is. Do you find that?' Well yes - but it's precisely the chunk Hastings is normally so enraptured by, the great backwoods landowners with their sporting estates and antediluvian ideas. I'm amazed that he 's amazed to find them making anti-Semitic remarks - it seems to betray an odd naivety. 'Fair point. But I suppose, I've always lived my life in a way between traditional English countryside and the media, and I love both worlds - but, of course, what you end up being is slightly distrusted by both. And in the end you have to say journalists are the most fun - it's such a privilege living and working with clever people, isn't it? I mean I've spent quite long stretches of my life living deep in the country and in the end it does drive you mad because nobody reads at all.' But, of course, he says that to me, a journalist - maybe to his shooting friends he says the opposite. This is the great problem for Hastings-watchers: is he at heart a journalist playing at being a country gentleman, or a country gentleman playing at being a journalist? He was certainly born to be a journalist - his father was Macdonald Hastings, intrepid war correspondent and Special Investigator for Eagle comic; his mother, Anne Scott-James, was a very distinguished columnist. He says he always idolised his father, and was frightened of his mother. 'The irony - which I didn't understand when I was younger but I do now - was that whatever intelligence I have, that has enabled me to bluff my way through journalism all these years, I owe to my mother. My father was a great romantic. His grasp on reality was always rather slender. My mother always used to say he was verging on barking. He had delusions and a grossly exaggerated respect for the landed classes which undoubtedly did influence me when I was younger.' His father went off on mad adventures for Eagle, crossing the Kalahari desert and being cast away on a desert island (he almost died). He was a great hero to schoolboys, which meant that Hastings as a boy 'was teased all the time that the son of the Eagle Special Investigator was a notable coward on the football field.' He describes his schooldays, at Charterhouse, as 'hellish' and adds 'I hope I'm not in the least bitter, but on the other hand, nothing cheers me up more than to kick an Old Carthusian when he's down. It's amazing, the letters I get from people saying, 'Dear Max, don't you remember me from the dear old school? How would you like to come and open my restaurant?' And you say 'Of course I remember you from the dear old school. Last time we met you were holding me against the study fire!' He only 'found himself' when he became a reporter on the Evening Standard and discovered he could write. But in those days he was still eaten up with envy for aristocratic landowners - 'When I was 24, I would have killed to own a castle.' He spent a quarter of his salary every year on renting a shooting lodge in Scotland, so that he could play the laird for a couple of weeks. 'It was a complete fantasy. I mean I loved it but it was completely barking. But I think by the time one was about 40, one had got all this out of one's system. And nowadays, I would say, cross my heart, I'm not jealous of anybody and am aware of how lucky I am - I'm grateful to be blissfully happy.' Much of his happiness comes from his second marriage to Penny Levinson. He first met her when they were both 17 - he was a researcher for the BBC in his gap year before Oxford and she was working in the library. 'I took her out for a while and she recalls with vivid dismay fighting off my beastly advances.' But she went on to marry Michael Grade and he married Patricia Edmondson, a keen fox-hunter, and had three children. When his marriage ended after 20 years, he spent a brief period as a bachelor but didn't exactly make hay: 'I think I once took out a girl quite a bit younger than me, but after dinner she said "Shall we go dancing?" and I looked at her in horror, and said "You must be mad. It's 25 past 10 and I go to bed at half past." And I realised then that there was actually no way that one was up for this.' He married Penny quietly in a register office last year with Robert Harris and his wife as witnesses. The Hastings live in a farmhouse near Hungerford, Berkshire, and spend all their weekends gardening. He says that his adventuring, swashbuckling days are behind him - 'One grew up believing that the most important thing in the whole world was to have adventures. But I always had this struggle between being keen on adventures and then being fairly cowardly. I mean if someone had said "Shoulder to shoulder, Carruthers" to me, I'd probably have been running before they'd finished the sentence. I did live hard when I was younger, but now I want to be fantastically comfortable.' He hopes to stay at the Evening Standard at least until the next general election but by then he'll be 55 and eligible to retire: 'I do feel that I've been sort of bluffing my way through editing all these years, and I do want to have another life as a writer.' He will write military histories, which he is good at: he has just published an excellent memoir of his war-reporting years called Going to the Wars. He is resigned to not getting a knighthood. When he became editor of the Daily Telegraph, he says, a knighthood almost went with the job, and 'I cannot tell a lie - I really liked the idea very much indeed. But then one of Thatcher's henchmen said to me, "You do realise, Max, that if you want your knighthood you'll have to be a lot more helpful to the government," and I was genuinely rather naively shocked. Then, when John Major became prime minister, one was sort of vaguely wondering, but damn me, then one of his chaps said "Well, of course, Max if you want a knighthood..." And I did actually then cross a great thing where I thought: I would love to be given a gong for being a good journalist, but editors don't get gongs for being good journalists, they get them for being helpful to the government of the day, and that is not what we're here for.'

fields.headline: Londoners
fields.standfirst: Bangladeshis in Brick Lane, Africans in Harlesden, Cypriots in Green Lanes... and every one a Londoner. Trevor Philips salutes the ethnic diversity of the capital
fields.trailText: Bangladeshis in Brick Lane, Africans in Harlesden, Cypriots in Green Lanes... and every one a Londoner. Trevor Philips salutes the ethnic diversity of the capital
fields.body:
Madonna, Kevin Spacey, Kathleen Turner... these days you can hardly move in London without bumping into Hollywood. The fashionable cosmopolitanism of today's capital has brought the stars flocking to Malibu-by-the-Thames, as the Notting Hill-Chelsea strip is bound to become known. The buzz of street markets with yam and plantain on the stall, the sound of drum'n'bass from the oversized car speakers at the traffic lights, and the smell of coriander wafting from the neighbour's kitchen have become part of the signature of this new London. But diversity wasn't always such a big draw.

In the 12th century, the monk Richard of Devizes spelled out a bloodcurdling warning to travellers heading for London. 'Each race brings its own vices and its own customs to the city,' he wrote. 'Jesters, smooth-skinned lads, Moors, flatterers, pretty boys, effeminates, pederasts, singing and dancing girls, quacks, belly-dancers, sorceresses, extortionists, night-wanderers, magicians, mimes, beggars, buffoons - all this tribe fill all the houses... Therefore if you do not want to dwell with evil-doers, do not live in London.'

Today the very reasons that so repelled the old friar are exactly the reasons that draw more than 14 million visitors from abroad each year. The excitement, the diversity, the edge of danger in a great capital city are special. No matter how many episodes of The Bill you watch from the armchair of your country seat, the energy, the hum of London's streets cannot be replicated. It is the sound of a hundred cultures softly clashing, sometimes melding, occasionally grating uncomfortably. Today more than 50 distinct ethnic communities thrive in London; a visitor from virtually anywhere will find a familiar smile.

This is a different London to the one into which I was born. My parents came from a small village on the Atlantic coast. The capital of Guyana used to be a beautiful garden city, with canals laid out by 17th-century Dutch settlers, flowering bushes, and a climate with only two variations: warm and dry, and warm and wet. It was a kind of tropical paradise. But there's a problem with paradise. It can be boring and tetchy. In a country the size of England and Wales, a population of less than 1 million should have enough room for everyone. My parents came here partly to escape the oppressiveness of small-town life. They certainly didn't travel thousands of miles for an improved lifestyle. In the grey London of the 50s, there was little comfort to be had - two rooms and six children is an uncomfortable way to learn long division.

But like most, they found adventure in the big city. And in turn they gave it colour, music, noise and fun. The ethnic mix in London has transformed some traditional institutions. Superstores and out-of-town shopping have destroyed many of London's high streets and markets. Where they survive, they do so because new communities have recreated them in their own images. Bangladeshis in Brick Lane, Gujuratis in Wembley, the Chinese in Gerrard Street, Caribbeans in Brixton, Africans in Harlesden, and the Cypriots in Green Lanes have revived Sunday shopping as a recreational activity. The discreet harvest festivals and genteel hymns of the postwar Church of England have been transformed into the riot of sound and colour wrought by Hindus, Moslems, Pentecostalists and Sikhs.

But there is another, more subtle quality that London has shown through two millennia that other great metropolises do not share. It is the fact that anyone can become a Londoner. We can, within a single generation, throw off the shackles of the past without losing the link to our heritage.

Think of George Michael, or Frank Bruno. Each is the son of immigrants, yet each is unmistakably a Londoner. And unlike the other great cosmopolitan metropolis of New York, Londoners do not hang on to their past heritage. That doesn't mean there are no racial problems or conflict. But in London, the friction is less neighbour against neighbour, and more minorities against the system. You could sit for a week with any black or Asian family and not reach the end of the list of injustices perpetrated by the police, schools, churches, local councils, banks or any other authority figure.

But things have changed from the days when Caribbean immigrants were warned by their landladies to leave home early and return late so the neighbours did not see them. Surveys show that the number of 'white' Londoners who object to having black or Asian neighbours has fallen steadily for decades; intermarriage is on a scale that would make Americans' eyes pop.

London is not a melting pot. The loss of identity is not an option for young Londoners - my children's generation have no doubts about their heritage and they won't give it up easily. But that does not mean a retreat to the ghetto. Young Londoners have found ways of sharing their heritage with their friends that my generation never managed. One colleague told me a few years ago that he had to change his frame of reference when walking behind a group of teenagers: so mixed were their styles, ways of walking and talking, he had to get in front of them to discover who was white and who black.

London is on the verge of doing what every great world city has tried for in vain for three millennia - to welcome all comers and embrace them with ease and comfort. That is, after all, the ideal of the city, the brilliant crossroads where all talents meet. In a century when most of humankind will need to find a new path to urban life, London is showing the way.

webTitle: How much sex are you having?

fields.headline: How much sex are you having?
fields.standfirst: Not a lot, says Jane Phillimore
fields.trailText: Not a lot, says Jane Phillimore
fields.body:
There's a new sex joke doing the rounds. A woman's so worried about the lack of sex with her hardworking husband that she asks an agony aunt for help. 'Seduce him,' came the age-old advice. 'When he comes home from work, shrug off your fur and whisper, "Super sex" in his ear.' So, the next day, when her bonus-rich yet orgasmically challenged man arrives home, she throws open her Prada wolfskin and drawls, 'Super sex' in a Dietrich growl. He takes one look, brightens noticeably, then replies, 'I'm too tired for the sex, but I'll take the soup.'

Funny, yes, but also very, very true. Let's not be sexist here - husbands and wives both arrive home too knackered for sex. As a matter of interest, when did you last make the beast with two backs? If it's in the past week, congratulations. The rest of you might like to ponder how the puritan work ethic came to take over your lives.

Our current sexual preoccupation is not how often or who with, but when. When will we ever have the time, energy or inclination for sex? One 1999 study found that 40 per cent of women suffer chronic loss of libido due to the stress of their jobs, another that a third of men are reporting sexual problems, including loss of desire. For men, this is a whole new area of distress: in the late 60s, Masters and Johnson didn't even think it worthy of categorisation.

Our attitude is partly misguided snobbery. In the unnaughty noughties, we think that sex has become a function for which only the unambitious or unfocused can guarantee a regular window. When does Martha Lane Fox have time for anything as mundane as a bit of bonking? The virtual office is no respecter of recreational activities. International deals are being done 24/7, and if you don't want to miss out, you join in. Sex drive has taken a back seat to the hard drive.

Until recently, only the very highly paid - City brokers, corporate lawyers and the like - have been TEFS (Too Exhausted For Sex). But now the rest of us are, too. The big question is why. Why do we paltry wage slaves collude in a work, work, work culture whose only result - apart from 20 per cent lower productivity than any other country in Europe - is bad sex and bad lives?

The answer is simple: 21st-century sex has become synonymous with anxiety, and work is our only legitimate escape. For single women, spending hours at the office means you have no resources left to worry about your crap sex life. There's no time to think about why you're not conforming to the spooky, instantly up-for-it sexual arousal typified by Demi Moore circa 1994.

For men, work is a holiday from performance worries. Every bird they meet is 'sexually literate'. Egged on by how-to articles in women's glossies, she thinks she has a goddess-given right to sexual satisfaction. So she's forever measuring up whether his penis/oral technique/G-spot arousal/multiple orgasm rate is big/fast/effective enough. And it's usually not.

For those in long-term relationships, work has become the only (respectable) refuge from the anxiety created by sexual boredom. And sexual boredom, as we all know, is less acceptable than herpes. 'Nobody dares admit to being sexually bored, because it makes them question their own performance or their love for their partner,' says Aneta Joiner, a PhD student at London's Southbank University who's researching the subject.

Of course, sexual boredom is nothing new. But the way we think about it is. We believe that our sexual desire has to be focused intensely on one person: our partner. Although it's unrealistic to expect mind-blowing desire to well up for this person the statutory three times a week, we still do. Furthermore, we think that being sexually bored with our partner means we don't love them, which of course means we should leave. 'We're working too hard for sex' has become our safety valve, not just a justification for our deprived lives but also a palatable way to avoid divorce.

All the sex therapists I spoke to agreed that, if you want to do it, you'll find the time (just look at Tony Blair). And if you don't? 'It's a serious signal,' says psychotherapist Professor Petruska Clarkson. Sexual boredom has been related to depression, hopelessness, anxiety, loneliness, hostility and impulsiveness, and correlated to drug use, eating disorders, job dissatisfaction and having unprotected sex. Whereas good sex has multiple benefits. As well as being, as Clarkson puts it, 'a mutual artwork - a way to be creative in a world that can be hostile and exhausting,' it keeps people healthier longer, builds love, trust and communication, keeps marriages together and provides a good, healthy, sensual atmosphere for children to grow up in.

Since nobody has yet come up with a blueprint for a relationship which would alleviate sexual boredom (affairs don't work - we tend to marry them), we need practical coping strategies. First, we must ditch our unrealistic ideas about romance and the ever-ready flame of sexual desire. 'Spontaneous sex is a fallacy,' insists Clarkson. Rampant sexual excitement doesn't just rise up on the sofa after Match of the Day, you know. It takes time and planning, the kind of attention you would have given it in the early days of romance.

Secondly, we must chill out. 'Being sexually bored with someone doesn't mean you don't love them,' says Aneta Joiner. In her work with gay and straight couples, she's found that those who don't get bored tend to have high life satisfaction but also, more importantly, they fantasise regularly about other people. They also have an arsenal of erotic strategies, including: the communication of erotic ideas, the use of pornographic material and sex toys, masturbation, romantic intimacy, infidelity and flirting with others.

So that Prada wolfskin might come in handy after all. And if you can't get home any earlier, there's no excuse for not fantasising while at work. It's a long way from the puritan work ethic, but it may save your marriage. And at least you're getting paid for it.
