It's a long way from the puritan work ethic, but it may save your marriage. And at least you're getting paid for it.

fields.headline: My London
fields.standfirst: In a city of more than seven million people, there are more than seven million stories. Here are just 10
fields.trailText: In a city of more than seven million people, there are more than seven million stories. Here are just 10
fields.body:
The bus driver

Denzil 'Scotty' Scott was recruited in Barbados by London Transport in 1962, when he was 20. He began driving a Routemaster bus in 1970, and is still driving a Routemaster today

 I decided to give it a go because a lot of my mates that I used to hang around with joined the scheme. The first route I did was the 41. At that time, it used to go down to the Victoria and Albert Docks from Archway. Now it only goes from Tottenham Hale to Archway. That was a nice route to go on. It had some really friendly people, like the dockers. Things were more friendly then: around Christmas time, you used to get so many little gifts and people would always be singing on the bus. I don't know what people are eating now, but everyone seems to want to fight. You can't talk to anyone on the bus nowadays - they just stare at you. My favourite route is the 41, because I have been doing it for so many years. When my family comes over from Barbados, the first place they ask about is Madam Tussaud's. But I take them to see St Paul's and the Tower of London. I love London. I live in Tottenham, just up the road from this garage, and this is my favourite area. I have looked at other garages like Peckham, Catford, Woolwich, and I didn't like them. I have always been here and everyone knows me. Why go somewhere where you're not known?

The eco-activist

Simon Gould, decorator and Free Tibet campaigner, lives in Chalk Farm and has meditated outside the Chinese Embassy every Wednesday evening for the past 10 years

 I totally got rid of the Tube from my life when I was bringing up my son, J. I have gone everywhere by bike ever since. The London you see by bike is a totally different London. By bike you can decide to go to the Natural History Museum and just spend 20 minutes in it, because the journey is part of the enjoyment. We used to go three times a week, when it was free.

Since 1994, I've turned up at more than 50 Critical Masses and two Reclaim the Streets demonstrations. I just want an improvement in London, it doesn't matter what the ideology is, really. Not any more.

I spend more time at the Chinese Embassy, in Portland Place near Regent's Park, than anywhere else. Since 1989, I have been there 400, 500 times, so I suppose it is a bit like my local pub. I admit that it is actually a social gathering.

I hate the pollarded trees in London. I find it very unpleasant to cycle down a street and see branches that appear like supplicants' arms, chopped off and mutilated as if in the very act of asking for our assistance. It is just done for the traffic.

Traffic does rule London. I have even been arrested for standing still in the road. That was about six months before Jiang Zemin's visit, on a march where the police had said suddenly that nobody was allowed to stand still as they passed the Chinese Embassy. So it was 'obstruction of the highway, method used: stood still'.

I don't have a love affair with London, but the Tibet vigil is the most important thing I do, and it does define my London. I seem to be fated to be here, and I embrace that.

The socialite

Lady Victoria Hervey, model, aristocrat and now shopkeeper, runs Belgravia boutique Akademi with partner Jayne Blight

 The shop was originally going to be on Chelsea Green, behind Fulham Road, but we didn't think that road was going to be fashionable enough. We decided on Motcomb Street because Jimmy Choo is here and it is a bit more exclusive.

I love New York, but I wouldn't want to live there. Paris is too arrogant and Milan is too much of an industrial place. London is more like a village. If New York is a loft apartment, then London is a cottage.

I grew up in the south of France and moved to London when I was about 12, but it is only in the last four years that I have felt more at home here.

Usually I just go out between King's Road, Fulham Road and Brompton Road. Momo's is one of my favourite places, and Woody's in Notting Hill. It is always full of my sort of people: photographers and models. We do a lot of business in Clerkenwell because many of the designers have showrooms down there, but it seems like miles away.

Places I hate: Leicester Square. Brixton. Daphne's. I have been to a lot of places I hate, I've even been on castings in E17 before: that is the furthest I've trekked. Never again.

The policeman

Chief Inspector Chris Bradford was born in Greenwich and joined the Metropolitan Police 27 years ago, when he was 19. He currently works in the Vice Unit, based in Charing Cross Road

 I have moved around London, but I always come back to the centre. There is a draw about the West End. I still like the bright lights. It's the adrenaline and the challenges. If anything happens in London, it's always front-page news. At the Downing Street mortar bombing, I was the Incident Officer because I happened to be there at the time. I can look back on that and know I was a part of it.

The vice department brings together the licensing unit for clubs, and the vice units. We look at organised prostitution, the trafficking of women, violence, coercion, juvenile crime. We might tackle street prostitutes one week and kerb-crawlers the next, so we are seen to be fair.

I am not a very emotional person. I was relatively unemotional when I came into the service and I have only compounded it now. You come across quite horrific offences and for me, personally, it is water off a duck's back. You've got to deal with it and I am very fortunate in that I have never been affected.

But I don't think London is good place to bring up children. Definitely not: I'm encouraging mine to go. Why? Because I'm jaundiced. I go to Leicester Square at 2am and although I don't feel personally threatened, it is a threatening environment. You can see the different gangs of thieves operating.

One example of our relationship with the community is Operation Malachite, which concentrates on brothels and prostitution. These girls are our community and they are entitled to just as much protection as anyone. We make a point of going round to what we call walk-up flats, for instance in Berwick Street, and speaking to the girls. Quite naturally they attract strange individuals. They get to know our faces and they begin to tell us all sorts of things, for instance if anyone is asking for strange perversions and that information goes into our database. We police the community, but it's not about kicking doors in.

The PR

Joanne Asquith, 33, runs her own fashion PR company, CPR, and lives in Primrose Hill with her two children

 I haven't always lived in London. My parents are from London, and they moved out into Kent, where I was born. I ran away to London for a couple of days when I was 16, and I moved back to London as soon as my parents let me, which was when I was 17. I have worked in fashion since leaving school and my first job was in this dynamic young fashion company in Covent Garden. London was all glamour and excitement and sex and, drugs and rock'n'roll. Bright lights, big city, fast living.

That's all I was interested in when I was at 17. Now, I can't stand any of that: for me, it's about earning enough money to look after my children and have decent holidays and nice houses.

London is really hard work. You have to do the legwork and the networking. London can be shallow and fickle, and you've got to be competitive.

There's a part of me that thinks London looks amazing. When I come over Waterloo Bridge, London looks quite majestic. Obviously, I don't think it's majestic in Peckham, but I love the opulence around Chelsea and Mayfair. I am always proud to say I live in London.

I hate Notting Hill. Portobello Road is a dump, and for some reason people think it's cool and trendy. Soho is awful, although in the 80s it was glamourous. It has become seedy and sleazy and there are no nice shops, except Agent Provocateur. The restaurants are all crap. It's just another con.

I never used to like west London much, but Knightsbridge is lovely, and Kensington and Chelsea. It is civilised and quiet. Kensington Place, off Kensington Church Street, has beautiful shops. The quaint streets don't go anywhere but just have beautiful houses covered in wisteria. It's a little jewel. You can meander through Regent's Park, with its wonderful flower gardens. I love all the parks in London. And I used to spend a lot of time on the river when I was a child - we'd chug up and down the Thames every weekend on our boat.

I have a million ideas a day, and I motor ahead - I wouldn't get inspired if I wasn't in London. There are brilliant opportunities. And I haven't exhausted my supply of ideas and energy yet.

The refugee

Dr Arumugam Visagaratnam, a Tamil refugee, lives in south London. He is 75

 I came to London in 1993. I had to flee from Sri Lanka to save my life and my family got scattered. I have eight children and they fled to France, Canada and Britain long before I left. We went to my daughter's house in Wimbledon. I don't remember my first impressions - I was not in the mood to think about my environment or anything else. My wife had left Sri Lanka before me, so I did not know her whereabouts. I was worried, but then I found out she had arrived, and when I saw her I forgot everything. My family did not let me leave my daughter's house for about 10 days, I was like a man under house-arrest.

I have a lot of friends and I am the vice-president of the South London Tamil Welfare Group and through that association we do a lot of things: we have a social group for the elderly and a women's front and we do a lot of cultural work. Every fortnight, we have a get together and there is a coffee morning on Mondays. From time to time, we go on pleasure trips to temples. Recently we went to the Millennium Dome. I did not appreciate it very much: you can enjoy that type of thing only up to a certain age.

It is not always easy in London, but we hear that there are also problems with racism in other European countries. Once my wife and I were walking along the street and there was a group of young people. As they passed one boy spat on my wife so I got annoyed. But what can we do? There are good and bad people everywhere.

The truth is that we are waiting for the first opportunity to leave this country. I have peace of mind in London, but I want to see Sri Lanka again before I die.

The nightworker

Arthur Zielinski has been a Noise Abatement Officer for Westminster Council for eight years. His night shift is from 10pm to 7am

 In the past 25 years, the night scene has changed substantially. I know Westminster extremely well, every street, although not quite every brick. It has a nice cosmopolitan feel: you get everybody from dukes to dustmen.

I have lived in Sydenham, south London, for most of my life and I suppose I am that rare breed, a secret admirer of south London. The place is deeply unfashionable and you can't get a cab home, but that is part of the excitement.

People seem to change at night. Many people feel freer. Alcohol and other chemicals also have a peripheral role. Some of the most objectionable and verbally abusive people, on a regular basis, are educated middle-class people. If they are usually quite powerful, they may feel humiliated.

I like being called out to Old Compton Street, because it is always lively. It is a convergence for a lot of cultures. There is the Italian thing, the gay thing, the Chinese thing, the club thing, the showbiz thing. Purely on a people-watching basis it is an interesting place. Millbank, for instance, is dead.

Also, at four in the morning after it has been raining heavily and there is a breeze blowing in from the countryside, you actually smell the countryside. And the air is fresh.

The drug dealer

Maurice lives and works in London

 I was brought up in east London and I bought my first kilo of hash when I was 17. I sold hash for about 10 years and then, through the lifestyle I was in, I started taking coke and heroin. So I started selling coke and heroin. Once I started smoking and injecting coke, the clientele completely changed. Then, of course, I changed. But I looked on it as a business to supplement my habit. It became a necessity. The lifestyle led you back on to the streets, which is where I first started, smoking dope. I just progressed to selling heroin in blocks of flats.

Until you got aggravation or trouble, or arrested by the police, you would work a particular area. There were times when I was serving heroin where one minute I'd be serving in a block of flats in Walford, the next minute I'd be serving in Deptford, and then three months later in Muswell Hill and Kentish Town. You'd sell wherever you were living.

I'd always be on guard. I moved to Portobello Road and served drugs there for five years. Before that, I'd been OK. But when I went into that lifestyle, I saw a side of Notting Hill I'd never experienced before. I'd always thought of it as being quite trendy - lots of nice bars, the market. But there is a completely different side to the relaxed, bohemian Notting Hill. When you go into the drug cultures in those areas, people are not smoking dope, they're not going out and drinking champagne. They are smoking crack every day, taking heroin, taking different sleeping pills. It is a really dark place to be.

I'd done quite well, I had two business, and, all of a sudden, I was on the street hustling, looking for someone to buy crack at three, four, five in the morning and meeting people in cars. They say all types of people live in Notting Hill, and they do. You sleep during the day, you live by night.

Fear is what I feel most about London. I've seen what a lovely city London is and the freedom that we have, but it instils a lot of fear into you to see the other side: the night owls and crack houses.

I love London, but there is a big focus on materialism, status and money. There is a lot of pressure to earn money, and you need to earn a lot of money to live in London.

I loved living in Notting Hill for a time. But once I started selling drugs and got into its drug culture, I despised the area. If you offered me a free flat, now, to live off Portobello Road, I'd say no. I have too many bad memories: I saw the dark side. I became a prisoner of Notting Hill. I have no problems with Battersea, or Kensington, or Chelsea, but as I go further west and further east I have bad associations with Hoxton, with Bethnal Green, Hackney, all through selling drugs.

I see myself continuing to live in London, but not through choice. I have no real ties here, and not much loyalty to London. But I have lived here all my life. It's like a marriage, like a love-hate relationship.

The head teacher

Linette Seath, headmistress, taught at Stockwell Primary School for 26 years and retired last week. She lives in Streatham

 When I first started at the school, in 1972, the children were predominantly Afro-Caribbean, with a few from Nigeria and some from Ghana. Over the years, we got more and more from different countries, even to the extent of having one child whose mother is from Finland. We have got some South American children, but we don't have many refugees from Kosovo at the moment. People from the Sudan, Somalia and Eritrea came over when the famine and war first started. I think Brixton has always welcomed people from other nations who are having difficulties, and over the years the population has changed quite a bit.

There is quite a community here and there are some long-established families. We get children coming back whose parents went to the school. It is friendly and very supportive and that is one of the reasons I have stayed here. Most of the time, it has been happy. You get occasional glitches: people do come in and let off steam, but it is usually about social things like housing, not the school. At least they know that they can come and ask for advice, especially if they don't speak English well.

As I retire, we shall probably move out of London, and I shall really miss the mix of people that there are here. But Brixton is perhaps a place for young people. It has changed a lot recently - housing in some parts of Brixton is really expensive now. A lot of my teachers are finding it very difficult to afford housing.

The largest social change in the area, over the years, has been drugs. The estate across the road used to be an intimidating place to visit. You can still see people openly doing deals. The Jamaican population has always smoked ganja, but it is the syringes that are far more worrying.

The chef

Margot Henderson, moved to London from New Zealand, in 1985. She runs The French House restaurant in Soho and lives in Covent Garden with her husband Fergus and three children

 I came to London for love. Perhaps that is an unusual reason to travel halfway around the world, but I also wanted to see Big Ben. I love London. I love the size of it, the massive scale, and all the foreigners. Thank God for the foreigners! Where would London be without them?

London is exciting for parents: you don't get suburban neuroses and your friends pop round more frequently. It's very sociable in Covent Garden - walk out in the streets and you know people. Soho is similar: people go to Bar Italia, the little shops, Berwick Street market. I like the mix of so many different people constantly coming and going, tourists and working people. It's a mess - a good, happy mess.

Soho, Fitzrovia, they're just like villages squished together. London is expensive: property's expensive, fun's expensive, alcohol's expensive, everything's expensive. Sometimes I feel it is a huge struggle, and I am just fighting against everything. But in the end, we have made our lives here. I have had so much fun: I've done well, enjoyed my restaurant, enjoyed cooking here. Even though I think London can feel a bit snooty and alienating sometimes, it is really quite a friendly place, and you've just got to go for it.

She lives in Streatham  When I first started at the school, in 1972, the children were predominantly Afro-Caribbean, with a few from Nigeria and some from Ghana. Over the years, we got more and more from different countries, even to the extent of having one child whose mother is from Finland. We have got some South American children, but we don't have many refugees from Kosovo at the moment. People from the Sudan, Somalia and Eritrea came over when the famine and war first started. I think Brixton has always welcomed people from other nations who are having difficulties, and over the years the population has changed quite a bit. There is quite a community here and there are some long-established families. We get children coming back whose parents went to the school. It is friendly and very supportive and that is one of the reasons I have stayed here. Most of the time, it has been happy. You get occasional glitches: people do come in and let off steam, but it is usually about social things like housing, not the school. At least they know that they can come and ask for advice, especially if they don't speak English well. As I retire, we shall probably move out of London, and I shall really miss the mix of people that there are here. But Brixton is perhaps a place for young people. It has changed a lot recently - housing in some parts of Brixton is really expensive now. A lot of my teachers are finding it very difficult to afford housing. The largest social change in the area, over the years, has been drugs. The estate across the road used to be an intimidating place to visit. You can still see people openly doing deals. The Jamaican population has always smoked ganja, but it is the syringes that are far more worrying. The chef Margot Henderson, moved to London from New Zealand, in 1985. She runs The French House restaurant in Soho and lives in Covent Garden with her husband Fergus and three children  I came to London for love. Perhaps that is an unusual reason to travel halfway around the world, but I also wanted to see Big Ben. I love London. I love the size of it, the massive scale, and all the foreigners. Thank God for the foreigners! Where would London be without them? London is exciting for parents: you don't get suburban neuroses and your friends pop round more frequently. It's very sociable in Covent Garden - walk out in the streets and you know people. Soho is similar: people go to Bar Italia, the little shops, Berwick Street market. I like the mix of so many different people constantly coming and going, tourists and working people. It's a mess - a good, happy mess. Soho, Fitzrovia, they're just like villages squished together. London is expensive: property's expensive, fun's expensive, alcohol's expensive, everything's expensive. Sometimes I feel it is a huge struggle, and I am just fighting against everything. But in the end, we have made our lives here. I have had so much fun: I've done well, enjoyed my restaurant, enjoyed cooking here. Even though I think London can feel a bit snooty and alienating sometimes, it is really quite a friendly place, and you've just got to go for it.

fields.headline: The perfect... thriller
fields.trailText: Let me introduce you to Turner. He's a cop on the edge. His boss hates him and his wife hasn't spoken to him in a civil tone since he began an intense relationship with a certain Jack Daniel's. He is investigating a baffling murder/heist/disappearance. Unfortunately, he seems unlikely to solve it since his life is heading towards a tragedy of Rikki Lake proportions. He lives in New York or another city where it often rains.
fields.body:
Let me introduce you to Turner. He's a cop on the edge. His boss hates him and his wife hasn't spoken to him in a civil tone since he began an intense relationship with a certain Jack Daniel's. He is investigating a baffling murder/heist/disappearance. Unfortunately, he seems unlikely to solve it since his life is heading towards a tragedy of Rikki Lake proportions. He lives in New York or another city where it often rains.

Stop me if this sounds familiar. And yet there is something marvellous about a top-notch, formulaic thriller, if you get it right. Of course there are crime movies told from the point of view of robbers, gangsters, serial killers and other undesirable antiheroes, but there is a pleasing symmetry in the cop-versus-bad-guy scenario. Even though our man Turner isn't exactly a candidate for sainthood.

That's why you need the right actor to play him. He's a bit of a rebel with a shady past and an uncertain future. He only smiles in the presence of a bartender and only then with wry detachment. Hugh Grant need not apply. In fact, all the obvious choices are either dead - Bogart, McQueen, Mitchum - or too old to chase punks through the subway; sorry Nicholson, Eastwood and De Niro. Harvey Keitel would be fine but he can't be trusted to keep his trousers on. Russell Crowe was excellent as the tortured officer in LA Confidential. He'll do.

Then there's the long-suffering wife. Her scenes will mainly consist of venting self-righteous rage at her errant husband and hanging around their surprisingly upmarket apartment in a designer negligee. In the last half-hour she will reveal a devastating secret which throws our increasingly resourceful hero off-kilter. Meryl Streep's agent isn't likely to call, but Salma Hayek's may. And the main villain? He must be British. There should also be a femme fatale. She needs an icy demeanour and hair colour that contrasts with the protagonist's wife.

The plot will be an intriguing mix of corruption, sleaze and miscellaneous human detritus, taking increasingly beguiling twists. Hint: no one can be trusted. But the plot turns can't be too jaw-droppingly unexpected. There is a fine line between silly (Basic Instinct) and sublime (Chinatown).

Finally, you need to hire a director. That's often the most difficult decision, but since all the right elements are in place this soon-to-be classic will virtually direct itself. So, sit back, relax and put a call in to Michael Winner.

webTitle: Phil Hogan  joins the chain gang

fields.headline: Phil Hogan  joins the chain gang
fields.body:
With summer almost upon us, apart from the bit where it gets warm enough not to have to wear your coat in bed, my wife has got it into her head that the eldest ought to have a bike, even though he has shown zero interest in owning one, preferring now to bombard us over successive birthdays and Christmases with requests for his own semi-automatic firearm, horse, poisonous reptile, tattoo and mobile phone before accepting the weary counsel of his parents and settling for whatever must-have Japanese fad-merchandising trash is currently flooding the globe. On the other hand, I admit he is currently leading his gang of chums and brothers in a series of conservation initiatives, which typically involve wading across the swamp in his school uniform to rescue endangered pondlife with a view to nurturing it to the point of death in his centrally heated bedroom, or taking my bike off to the woods to build a log cabin, which of course is news to me until five days later, when I discover that he has left it upside down in a ditch near the farmer's field, exact grid reference unknown. 'Well, the chain came off,' he says, which passes for an apology in the faraway galaxy of So-What? where he spends his free time.

'Aaaah every boy should have a bike,' says my wife, who thinks we live in the lazy hazy dozy days of the 50s and that the little scamps are out tracking gypsy caravans or tackling sheep rustlers or recovering stolen diamonds with nothing more required to sustain a boy for the day than a hunk of bread and cheese and water from a crystal stream, while mum's at home in the kitchen kneading dough and father's in his study designing aircraft carriers and smoking a pipe.

'Come to think of it, I think there's a bike auction at St Joseph's today,' she says, her head in the local paper. 'Yes, viewing at 10 o'clock'

How very coincidental. I traipse outside to find the boy busy selling frogspawn to his younger brothers.

'How would you like a bike?' I say.

His eyes light up. 'Can I have my ear pierced instead?'

'No.'

We drive up to the school to see what they've got. He moves disinterestedly among the upturned rusty pedals until we identify two of the shiniest models with the most outlandish designs, highest number of gears, gaudiest paint jobs, optimally ridiculous chrome suspensions. He's off across the football pitch on one of them trying to do wheelies. 'We can only go up to £50,' I shout after him. He comes back breathless, eyes full of desire. 'Maybe you should look at some of the others,' I say. 'How about this one?'

He pulls a face. 'Nah no shock-absorbers.'

'What about the yellow Peugeot - it's got those funny handlebars you like.'

'Nah.'

Right. Lots 96 and 100. I jot the numbers down, explaining that if the bidding goes too high we'll have missed just about everything else that's any good. He's not listening. 'Mmm' he says, wandering off to the car boot sale in the playground to buy a telephone answering machine and two candlesticks. At last we're ready and they've got a proper country auctioneer up there in tweed tie and brogues, tapping the microphone, and suddenly they're off. A toddler's trike is hoisted on to the picnic table and goes for a quid, followed by a ladies' shopper with a flat tyre, then one of those folding jobs that you might ride if you don't mind being laughed at, a boy's racer, his'n'hers mountain bikes. 'Seventy-five, 77, 80, 82 if you like' the auctioneer is rattling on as if there's a last orders on speech. The boy is looking anxious. 'Sixty quid for that?' he whispers. At last we're on. But the first one he wants whizzes past us at £96, the second goes for over a hundred. 'Never mind,' I say. 'Maybe' But there are only five more lots to go and the auctioneer is telling us that the hot dog stand is selling everything for 30p, so the boy lopes off forlornly to join the stampede, but he's still in the queue when the yellow Peugeot comes up. 'Start at 10? Five?' says the man. 'Four' No one moves. I stick my hand up. 'You sir, four pounds, four, four five, anyone?' No one. 'Four pounds!' he says.

Suddenly the boy is rushing back, whooping at his good fortune snatched from the jaws of not getting anything. He loves it. Perfect for tracking gypsies.

'Did you have to spend a lot, Dad?'

I wink. 'Let me worry about that,' I say, putting my fatherly arm round him as he wheels it away.

Times like this a chap needs a pipe

 bicycle clips to phil.hogan@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Long live the King
fields.standfirst: Elvis is resurrected (again) next week. This time in a biographical ballet that aims to bring dance to a wider audience
fields.trailText: Elvis is resurrected (again) next week. This time in a biographical ballet that aims to bring dance to a wider audience
fields.body:
Opening next week at Sadler's Wells, The King has been described as both a 'rock ballet' and 'dansical' - but don't let that put you off. It's a production by the Danish company The Peter Schaufuss Ballet. Schaufuss had been a world-renowned dancer and choreographer as well as artistic director of the English National Ballet, Berlin Ballet and the Royal Danish Ballet, before he formed his own award-winning company in 1997.

His stated mission is to persuade a wider audience - 'beyond ballotmanes' as he puts it - of the joys of dance, and apparently he's having no small success: at its premiere The King received a standing ovation that went on for 20 minutes. A bit of a wag, Schaufuss says he picked on Elvis because he wanted to do a piece about our era, our cultural time, and 'all the Spice Girls songs sound the same'. He ended up listening to all 460 of Elvis Aaron Presley's recordings before deciding on 21 songs to make up the soundtrack for his piece, which covers the King's life and centres on the nature of fame, and 'how it poisons and destroys you'.

Back on more familiar territory, Schaufuss's next piece will be the life story of Hans Christian Andersen.

 The King runs from Thursday 27 April to Saturday 6 May at Sadler's Wells, Rosebery Avenue, London EC1 (020 7863 8000).

fields.headline: Fast forward
fields.standfirst: This week: Elliot Smith
fields.trailText: This week: Elliot Smith
fields.body:
Who's he? The next big thing, if we are to believe the critics. His new album, Figure 8, released last week on Steven Spielberg's Dreamworks label, has had the English music press ripping off their Kangol anoraks in excitement. 'The most deviously sweet, deliciously clever album' cooed one. A recent sell-out gig at London's ULU had another exclaiming that 'you could almost smell the devotion in the air'.

So why haven't I heard of him? Because you don't move in the sort of 'muso' circles where as soon as somebody appears on the cover of NME their credibility is lost. For years, Smith's name has been bandied about by people 'in the know' in a reverent, almost evangelical way. Much like Macy Gray, his reputation has spread by word of mouth. But this is not the work of marketing strategists. Smith, who hails from Portland, Oregon, has been touring continuously as a solo artist since 1994. He once released four albums in three months and has built up quite a cult following on the American and British 'alternative' scene. Every two years or so, he resurfaces in the music press, is applauded for his 'claw-hammer picking technique' and hailed as a songwriting genius; but, unlike Macy, he has yet to achieve real superstardom.

I won't have seen him on Top of the Pops, then? I'm afraid not. His only taste of such celebrity was when his song Miss Misery (part of the Good Will Hunting soundtrack) was nominated for an Oscar in 1998. Described as 'the strangest billing since Jimi Hendrix opened for the Monkees', Smith appeared at the ceremony, opening for that grand dame of commercial durge, Celine Dion.

What type of music does he play? He seems to be difficult to categorise. The comparisons have been endless - from Nick Drake and Kurt Cobain to Simon and Garfunkel and the Beach Boys. One critic described his music as 'bringing self-evident truths bobbing to the surface, then letting them sink again with a shimmering splash of realisation.'

So he's a miserable git? He's not called 'Portland's favourite grouch' for nothing.

fields.headline: 'Best United side ever'
fields.trailText: Sir Alex Ferguson rates his new champions the best Manchester United team ever, and the bookmakers appear to agree.
fields.body:
Sir Alex Ferguson rates his new champions the best Manchester United team ever, and the bookmakers appear to agree.

As Ferguson's side coasted to their sixth Premiership title in eight years at Southampton yesterday, Ladbrokes installed them as shortest-ever priced favourites to lift next year's title - the absurd odds of 4-6 on amounting to telling the rest of the league not to bother.

'That's ridiculous,' Ferguson said, but he was only joking. United have just spent £16.5m on Dutch striker Ruud van Nistelrooy to join a forward line which has already set a domestic scoring record. Ferguson described van Nistelrooy as 'for the future'. 'The reason for signing him at this stage is because we couldn't see anyone else in the world emerging,' Ferguson explained.

Assuming van Nistelrooy fits in, this young United team can only get better. Ferguson believes there is still room for improvement in terms of maturity and tactical ability, but has no qualms about suggesting the achievements of the Best, Law and Charlton side and even the Busby Babes have been eclipsed.

'No one knows how good that side might have become, that's one of life's tragedies, but what we have achieved with this squad in the last two years has been phenomenal,' he said. 'This is a special unit, a marvellous team, and it's a pleasure to be managing them. They did not sit back on last year's treble, the team have gone on to prove themselves and that's why I say they are the best ever. I'm 58 and more mellow than I used to be, but I could be even more sedate and it wouldn't matter, because all the players have the hunger. They are real winners, the team is full of players with inner drive, and I'm fortunate to have people like that.'

fields.headline: Spurs punish dull Dons
fields.trailText: Wimbledon are very lucky; lucky yesterday that they lost by only two goals when it could have been 10, and lucky that the Premiership has been so limp that none of the bottom three has been able to put any real pressure on them. In another year, Wimbledon would surely have been relegated. Seven defeats in a row and still the gap between them and Sheffield Wednesday is five points.
fields.byline: Ian Ridley at White Hart Lane
fields.body:
Wimbledon are very lucky; lucky yesterday that they lost by only two goals when it could have been 10, and lucky that the Premiership has been so limp that none of the bottom three has been able to put any real pressure on them. In another year, Wimbledon would surely have been relegated. Seven defeats in a row and still the gap between them and Sheffield Wednesday is five points.

You understand now why no one at Tottenham seemed too concerned by their own recent bad run - four defeats in five games before a midweek win at Leicester and they always knew they had Wimbledon to come at home. This week, unlike last against Aston Villa, they never looked likely to surrender a two-goal lead.

Wimbledon also have five points in hand over Bradford City, whom they visit next Sunday, but even defeat there would not condemn them. In fact, it is hard to see either of their rivals at the bottom making up the deficit. Wimbledon could well beat the previous lowest number of points - 38 - needed to stay in the Premiership.

'Maybe three or four more will be enough. The situation is not dark,' insisted the Wimbledon manager Egil Olsen, who admitted he was relieved to reach the sanctuary of the dressing room and hear that Wednesday had lost. 'We tried but not hard enough,' he added. 'I have seen more spirit in previous matches. I hoped for more energy and hard work.'

Olsen grew understandably prickly, however, when pressed on the subject of the loss of the old 'Crazy Gang' spirit - only in England were people so obsessed with workrate, he said - and cited the appalling second half of last season, before he arrived. Rightly he pointed to more technical deficiencies. The team had had trouble in adapting to his zonal marking defence, he admitted, and had conceded too many goals through giving the ball away and from set plays.

The way their heads dropped after Carl Cort missed the game's first chance - and the way they conceded from Spurs' first chance - summed up their current deficiencies. Steffen Iversen was unmarked in heading on Ian Walker's long free-kick and Chris Armstrong nipped past a stationary Kenny Cunningham to steer home a volley.

The second goal, Iversen picking out Darren Ander ton's unaccompanied run with a through-ball that Anderton guided home neatly off a post, should have been the prelude to a sackful.

David Ginola, in another of his sublime moments, chipped on to the roof of the net, Armstrong's touch home from the Frenchman's low cross was ruled offside, the striker also forcing Neil Sullivan into a good save and then heading just over, and Anderton was also inches wide with a cross- shot. Even when presented with a chance when Walker dropped a cross at Jason Euell's feet, Wimbledon could not take advantage. White Hart Lane has never liked the Dons but there was little about this insipid bunch to get worked up about.

The situation is not dark,' insisted the Wimbledon manager Egil Olsen, who admitted he was relieved to reach the sanctuary of the dressing room and hear that Wednesday had lost. 'We tried but not hard enough,' he added. 'I have seen more spirit in previous matches. I hoped for more energy and hard work.' Olsen grew understandably prickly, however, when pressed on the subject of the loss of the old 'Crazy Gang' spirit - only in England were people so obsessed with workrate, he said - and cited the appalling second half of last season, before he arrived. Rightly he pointed to more technical deficiencies. The team had had trouble in adapting to his zonal marking defence, he admitted, and had conceded too many goals through giving the ball away and from set plays. The way their heads dropped after Carl Cort missed the game's first chance - and the way they conceded from Spurs' first chance - summed up their current deficiencies. Steffen Iversen was unmarked in heading on Ian Walker's long free-kick and Chris Armstrong nipped past a stationary Kenny Cunningham to steer home a volley. The second goal, Iversen picking out Darren Ander ton's unaccompanied run with a through-ball that Anderton guided home neatly off a post, should have been the prelude to a sackful. David Ginola, in another of his sublime moments, chipped on to the roof of the net, Armstrong's touch home from the Frenchman's low cross was ruled offside, the striker also forcing Neil Sullivan into a good save and then heading just over, and Anderton was also inches wide with a cross- shot. Even when presented with a chance when Walker dropped a cross at Jason Euell's feet, Wimbledon could not take advantage. White Hart Lane has never liked the Dons but there was little about this insipid bunch to get worked up about.

fields.headline: Late Phillips strikes shatter Wednesday
fields.trailText: Just when it seemed that Sheffield Wednesday had scaled another rung of the ladder to safety, Kevin Phillips came snaking along to shoot their hopes to pieces. The master marksman scored twice in the last five minutes to nip Wednesday's revival in the bud and keep alive Sunderland's chances of a Uefa Cup place.
fields.body:
Just when it seemed that Sheffield Wednesday had scaled another rung of the ladder to safety, Kevin Phillips came snaking along to shoot their hopes to pieces. The master marksman scored twice in the last five minutes to nip Wednesday's revival in the bud and keep alive Sunderland's chances of a Uefa Cup place.

It was a cruel finish for a team resuscitated by successive victories over Wimbledon and Chelsea and by the collective failings of those other sides in trouble. There was nothing wrong with their application and appetite for the task in hand. Yet the truth is that Wednesday had only themselves to blame.

They had enough possession, applied sufficient pressure and created more than enough chances to have won with something to spare.

What they didn't have was a striker of anything like the calibre of Phillips, who now has 29 for the season. As a result, Thomas Sorensen was equal to everything thrown at him, and it was his excellent goalkeeping, more than anything, which eventually frustrated Wednesday to the point that the tight grip applied previously to Phillips loosened sufficiently for him to make all the telling difference.

A yard of space on the edge of the penalty box enabled him to manoeuvre into position for a left-foot shot driven into the top corner. The second could not have been in sharper contrast, tapped in from three yards from Alex Rae's low cross. Yet it underlined the potency of Phillips from all ranges and he could even have completed a hat trick in the time remaining.

'It was an opportunity missed for us,' admitted Wednesday's acting manager Peter Shreeves. 'We lacked that cutting edge when we were on top and along came Phillips to show what it is all about. His first goal was right out of the top drawer. I've told the players not to get too disheartened. We are in the same position we were before the game. There are still 12 points to play for, so we have to lick our wounds and come back fighting. I remain optimistic.'

Peter Reid, the Sunderland manager said: 'Scoring 29 premiership goals tells you everything about Phillips and why he is worth his weight in gold. He will get the headlines, but I thought Sorensen was terrific as well. He kept us in it because our passing for most of the game was useless.'

Sorensen's one-handed save low down from Niclas Alexandersson was probably his best of the afternoon, with a block on Gilles de Bilde, who had escaped the attentions of Jody Craddock, not far behind. But the goalkeeper should really not have had a chance when a far post cross from Andy Hinchcliffe found the captain, Peter Atherton, who blazed his effort into the crowd.

Equally significant was the way in which the busy Alan Quinn swung carelessly at Wim Jonk's low centre and pulled his shot wide. Had any of those efforts gone in, Wednesday would now be contemplating one of the great escapes. Instead, for the moment, they are merely still whistling in the wind.

fields.headline: Macca playing the goat
fields.trailText: Steve McManaman thinks Kevin Keegan might have given up on him after failing to feature in England's last four matches, and with memories still fresh of a fairly dismal personal failure in Poland last year, he could be right.
fields.body:
Steve McManaman thinks Kevin Keegan might have given up on him after failing to feature in England's last four matches, and with memories still fresh of a fairly dismal personal failure in Poland last year, he could be right.

Keegan did say he hoped McManaman would rediscover his old form and put himself back in the international spotlight at Real Madrid, however, and the former Liverpool player has certainly managed to do that in the two legs of the Champions League quarter-final against Manchester United.

Over the two games, McManaman was arguably Real's most impressive player. When he used to operate in a free role for Liverpool opposing teams would often put a man on him, reasoning that to shut him down was to effectively shut down the whole side. It is not quite so simple with the wealth of attacking options open to Real Madrid, but even so United were surprisingly slow to counter McManaman in both legs.

They failed to pick him up at all in the first half at the Bernabeu, allowing him to drop deep to collect the ball and provide a link between defence and attack. McManaman has always been a good distributor as well as a dribbler, but when United got a little tighter on him in the second half he willingly took them on, and - had his old weakness as a finisher not let him down - he could easily have consigned them to first leg defeat.

It was his performance at Old Trafford which re-asserted his England claims though. Effortlessly finding space and using it well, either holding the ball or releasing colleagues with well-timed passes, McManaman looked just the sort of player Keegan's somewhat shapeless England sides have been crying out for.

So should Keegan call him up? Emphatically yes. And will he play like that for England? Of course not. Or rather, to be fair to McManaman, he will try to do what he does best but England will completely fail to play like Real Madrid. When McManaman receives the ball for England he is usually in a tight spot rather than in space, and when he looks up he will normally see Alan Shearer and Co running head down towards the penalty area in anticipation of a cross.

England's game is not about fluidity and movement any more, under Keegan they play in straight lines. McManaman is at his best when exploiting space, holding the ball and waiting for supporting runs, which is why he is enjoying himself more at Real than at any time since his early days at Liverpool or his all too brief flowering for England under Terry Venables.

'I'm happy with my form and the club are doing fantastically well,' McManaman said after the Old Trafford victory. 'I would love to be in the England squad, but if I am successful with Real I will be happy regardless of whether I go to Euro 2000 or not.' McManaman surely ought to go to the finals, for the simple reason that regular internationals like David Beckham and Paul Scholes could hardly get near him on Wednesday night and Darren Anderton is not in the same league, but he knows from experience that England have no role he can easily slot into apart from that of scapegoat.

He is not the answer to the left-wing problem, for instance, whatever Ryan Giggs might think. If England want someone to replicate on the left what Beckham does on the right they would be better sticking with Jason Wilcox. It is hardly the best use of available resources, but if Keegan sticks McManaman out on the left in the vague hope he will play as well there as he does for Real it will be an even worse squandering of talent.

McManaman has made his point and answered most of his English critics over the past couple of weeks, he does not need to spend the summer going over old ground. That's Shearer's job. There may be room for McManaman in a free role once Euro 2000 is over and Shearer has retired, but don't hold your breath.

fields.headline: Charlton celebrations
fields.trailText: Charlton were at last able to start celebrating when they clinched promotion as a result of Ipswich's surprise stumble at QPR.
fields.body:
Charlton were at last able to start celebrating when they clinched promotion as a result of Ipswich's surprise stumble at QPR.

Having failed to do it on their own in their last three matches, Charlton might well be tempted to reserve three bottles of their champagne for Gavin Peacock, Sam Koejoe and Chris Kiwomya - the QPR scorers in their 3-1 victory.

Kiwomya, who scored QPR's third - after Ipswich had made it 2-1 - is a former Ipswich player. As QPR's manager, Gerry Francis, said: 'He is always fired up for this one. I think on Monday we will tell him we are playing Ipswich again.'

As for the other teams challenging for automatic promotion, Manchester City strengthened their position with a 2-0 win over Tranmere - which put them four points clear of Ipswich - but Barnsley's hopes were effectively ended by a 2-0 defeat at Wolves.

City's breakthrough was provided by Sean Goater's 28th goal of the season after only 10 minutes. It stemmed from a long City clearance, which the Tranmere defence expected their teenage goalkeeper, Joe Murphy, to clear. But the Irish youth international hesitated on the edge of his area, waiting for the ball to reach him, and Goater was able to nick the ball from his fingertips and apply the finishing touch from an acute angle.

Even Tranmere's manager, John Aldridge, was moved to applaud Goater's opportunism. Once a striker himself, he said: 'It is what I would have done.'

Few would now bet against City finishing in the top two, but their manager, Joe Royle - inevitably - preferred to adopt a cautious stance. 'This club has a history of putting its foot in it,' he explained. In that respect, he seemed particularly con cerned about tomorrow's match at Portsmouth. 'Their manager has an ulterior motive for beating us,' Royle said, pointing out that Pulis was in charge of the Gillingham team beaten in last season's Second Division play-off. 'I expect our game at Portsmouth to be very tough.'

The man who did most of the damage to Barnsley's automatic promotion hopes was Ade Akinbiyi, who scored both goals in Wolves' win. Barnsley's manager, Dave Bassett, said: 'We are not conceding anything but let's have a sense of realism. I don't live in fantasy land. We had an opportunity to win automatic promotion, but it looks like we have not grasped it.'

Wolves' success has given them an excellent chance of getting into the play-off zone, at their expense of Huddersfield. The latter were another team at the top who struggled to cope with the pressure of their position, going down 3-0 at home to Bolton.

Bo Hansen scored Bolton's first two goals, and their manager, Sam Allardyce, said: 'That makes it five goals in three games for Hansen, but it is not just his goalscoring which impresses me. He has upped his work rate 25-30 per cent, and that is one of the reasons he stays in the team. Both the goals were great finishes.'

The big surprise at the other end was Swindon's 1-0 win over Fulham. The best individual performance, though, came from Crewe's Mark Rivers, who scored twice in the 3-2 win against Stockport. Crewe's manager, Dario Gradi, said: 'He was the one who was taking the game to Stockport. It didn't look as if anyone else was going to threaten their goal. Mark should have had a hat-trick.'

Bristol Rovers moved into third place in the Second Division promotion race with a 2-0 win over Bristol City. Few Nationwide League forwards have the finishing skills of Jason Roberts and Mark Walters and, as one might have expected, they scored the decisive goals.

fields.headline: Saddlers climb clear
fields.trailText: Walsall showed the greater skill and desire in the big Division One West Midlands relegation derby, coming from behind to climb out of the bottom three at the expense of a hugely disappointing West Bromwich Albion.
fields.body:
Walsall showed the greater skill and desire in the big Division One West Midlands relegation derby, coming from behind to climb out of the bottom three at the expense of a hugely disappointing West Bromwich Albion.

Walsall fell behind to an early Sean Flynn strike, but two second-half goals from Andy Rammell and on-loan Tom Bennett completed a deserved comeback in a game the Saddlers dominated from start to finish.

With three games to go, including trips to promotion-chasing Birmingham and Ipswich, however, Walsall manager Ray Graydon was at pains to point out afterwards that, although vital, this result merely gives his side a fighting chance.

'If we had lost today, we knew we would have faced an uphill fight,' he said. 'We've still got a chance, but that's all we've got. There are still nine points to play for. If we don't carry on performing in the next three games, we'll go down. But we've got a good record in local derbies - we've won four and drawn one so far this season. I'm hoping that run continues against Birmingham. Today, we played very well. We deserved the points, but we've got to keep it up.'

That Walsall are still even within sight of safety after their promotion last year is a minor miracle. Defender Tony Barras, who cost £20,000, is the only player in the squad who commanded a fee, and he wasn't even in the team yesterday. The rest of the players include either free transfers (two icelanders, an Argentinian, a Dutchman, a Hungarian, a Spaniard, a Greek and a Yugoslavian who fled to Sweden during the Balkan war) or loan players. The average wage of their players is thought to be around the £40,000 mark - a year.

Albion, on the other hand, are badly under-achieving. Former Blackpool, Stockport and Stoke manager Gary Megson has failed to arrest their poor form since taking over in mid-March, picking up just seven points from 21. More alarmingly, they have lost the lead in four out of their last five games.

'Too many of our players were not in the game, and you don't win matches if players do not play well,' he said. 'They put us under a lot of pressure and we just couldn't handle it.'

Albion were badly missing the presence of leading scorer Lee Hughes, who broke his leg a fortnight ago. Flynn's goal aside, they created only one other clear-cut chance, when Fabian De Freitas broke clear at the end of the first half.

Their goal came early when Bob Taylor tussled with Adrian Viveash near the goal line. Viveash claimed he was fouled but nothing was given, Taylor crossed the ball back into Flynn's path on the edge of the box, and he fired a shot low to keeper Carl Emberson's right.

Walsall should have been level by half-time, the best of several chances falling to Bennett, a curling 20-yard effort which was tipped acrobatically around the post by West Brom keeper Brian Jensen.

Both Walsall goals came from corners by Pedro Matias, a former Real Madrid trainee. Bennett was first to a loose ball on the edge of the box and his shot was deflected into the net by Andy Rammell for the equaliser, before Bennett himself headed the winner from ten yards late on, with no defender in sight.

fields.headline: Millwall are Cooked
fields.trailText: The annual Manchester United coronation that passes for a Premiership title contest these days may have concluded earlier than normal, but a few miles into the Lancashire heartland calculators, valium and a steady finger on the Teletext button are still the order of the day.
fields.body:
The annual Manchester United coronation that passes for a Premiership title contest these days may have concluded earlier than normal, but a few miles into the Lancashire heartland calculators, valium and a steady finger on the Teletext button are still the order of the day.

Burnley, Preston and Wigan have helped make this Second Division promotion race an absorbing one, even allowing for North End having all but secured first place, with the sort of plot twists and turns that our top division used to provide.

Burnley's considerate attempt to squander a 4-0 lead against Millwall, third placed before kick-off, not only enhanced the general tension at the top but was also a considerable aid to Wigan and increased the chances of all three neighbours meeting next season in Division One.

After scoring their fourth goal seven minutes into the second half, it should have been a routine outing for Burnley, who even felt confident enough to throw on part-time striker and full-time talk show host Ian Wright with 20 minutes left.

But, with a nice sense of the dramatic, Burnley conspired to make life unnecessarily uncomfortable for themselves after Neil Harris opened Millwall's account with a tidy close-range finish from a cross by substitute Lucas Neill on the hour.

Harris was on the mark again after 78 minutes, outpacing the defence after collecting Ifill's through-ball and beating Crichton from 15 yards. When Tim Cahill scrambled the ball in, after a point blank save and goal-line clearance, in the 88th minute, and the fourth official declared there were four minutes of injury-time to play, any outcome seemed plausible.

'Sweating? Not at all,' said Burnley manager Stan Ternent. 'What the **** do you think? It may have been great for the fans but it was crazy from my point of view.

'The main thing is we got the three points, but at this stage of the season people become anxious. I don't know who deserved to win and who didn't, it was that sort of game. And I'm not sure I want to be associated with all these "entertainers". It's no good for my heart whatsoever.'

It had all seemed so untaxing for the Clarets as they took just seven minutes to ease pre-match anxieties. webTitle: It's your title again, Sir Alex

fields.headline: It's your title again, Sir Alex
fields.trailText: Manchester United collected their sixth Premiership title in eight seasons with a minimum of fuss and an early flurry of goals, putting their Champions League disappointment behind them and Southampton's mini-revival under Glenn Hoddle firmly into perspective.
fields.body:
Manchester United collected their sixth Premiership title in eight seasons with a minimum of fuss and an early flurry of goals, putting their Champions League disappointment behind them and Southampton's mini-revival under Glenn Hoddle firmly into perspective.

Perhaps United were relieved to be playing relegation candidates after Real Madrid, although the Saints are now safe following Sheffield Wednesday's defeat. Or perhaps they were just anxious to end what little suspense was left in a title race which was effectively decided weeks ago.

Either way they needed only seven minutes to score and no more than a third of the game to leave Southampton wishing they were playing some other opponents, some other Saturday. With half an hour on the clock United were leading 3-0, and Southampton had seen Dean Richards clear a David Beckham free-kick off the line and Neil Moss touch an Ole Gunnar Solskjaer shot on to the crossbar.

Southampton doggedly stuck to their plan of crowding a midfield that was being cut to pieces by raking passes from Beckham and runs by Ryan Giggs as if transfixed by United's brilliance. The new champions could certainly have made the victory even more emphatic but were probably worried about attracting the attention of the League Against Cruel Sports.

'There was never going to be a hangover from Wednesday,' Sir Alex Ferguson said. 'This team reacted to losing 5-0 to Chelsea and 3-0 to Newcastle by waking up and doing the business. Wednesday was a terrible night for us but losing is part of the game. It's how you recover that counts. I'm lucky to have a collection of players who mirror my own hunger, but the drive comes from within themselves. This is a team full of players with inner drive.'

Ferguson singled out David Beckham as among the most driven of his players, and there was a certain predictability about the way he put United in front. Hoddle knows all about Beckham's range and ability at set pieces, so we must assume Francis Benali did not heed the warnings when he crashed into Andy Cole 20 yards out. Once referee Neale Barry marched the defensive wall back the full distance, the whole ground knew what was about to happen but Neil Moss was still powerless to prevent Beckham's free-kick curling into his top left corner.

Eight minutes later Giggs's elegant flick opened up a tract of undefended left wing for Phil Neville to run into, and the full-back galloped into the area to unleash a low drive across the face of goal which the hapless Benali had little option but to turn past his goalkeeper.

Then Solskjaer produced a stunning snap shot from a Giggs pass which Moss kept out with the aid of his woodwork, Richards retrieved another goal-bound Beckham effort after Tahar had handled within shooting range, and United still managed to extend their lead after 28 minutes. Beckham's crossfield pass picked out Solskjaer in the area, and the Norwegian's control and deadly left foot did the rest, a low shot beating Moss to his left.

Ferguson values control in his strikers, judging from his scathing remarks about Dwight Yorke and Andy Cole's lack of it in Madrid, but Solskjaer, selected here instead of the former, is neatness and economy personified. The assumption seems to be that the perennial substitute will be leaving Old Trafford in the wake of £16.5m Ruud van Nistelrooy's arrival, but this may be a misreading of the situation.

United would not pay that sort of money for a reserve, and if the Dutch striker plays it is likely to be at the expense of a more regular member of the side. And any manager would think twice before selling Solskjaer, a wonderful player and model professional with a sensational left foot. At 27, seven years younger than Teddy Sheringham, Solskjaer has time to feature more prominently in United's attack, and the club should be wary about letting him feature in anyone else's.

Solskjaer was substituted in a tame second half, which only briefly flickered to life when a couple of Southamp ton players declared open season on Beckham. Marian Pahars started it with a foul which earned him a booking on the stroke of the interval. Chris Marsden continued it with a heavy challenge early in the second half which brought instant retribution and a caution for Roy Keane, then Kevin Davies saw yellow for a hack at Beckham which had United players screaming for protection.

Fit again after what Hoddle described as 'his flu situation', Pahars pulled a goal back for Southampton six minutes from the end with a crisp finish after a run down the right. By that time Southampton had sent a few more attacking players on and a United defence featuring Ronny Johnsen for the first time this season was almost sleepwalking through the game, but the overall outcome was never in doubt, a familiar enough scenario.

United's season might have come to a somewhat abrupt conclusion with Wednesday's Champions League exit and the title now tied up a month before the FA Cup final, though it has been an extraordinary league campaign and one which could see several more records set. They have now scored 87 goals in 34 games, surpassing Newcastle's Premiership record of 82 set over a 42-game season, and at this rate must have a chance of becoming the first Premier League side to reach a century.

Their current lead over Liverpool is 13 points, which if maintained would equal Everton's record set in 1985, again in a 42-game season. Depending on how their rivals fare United could conceivably stretch their lead.

Just don't mention the FA Cup. 'We have played more games this season than Liverpool and Arsenal,' said a Ferguson clearly annoyed at suggestions United have made things easy for themselves. 'We have played 56 games already.' There are still four left, and as there was no Premiership trophy for United to parade round the Dell, they will just have to do all that at home to Chelsea tomorrow. Nice that their supporters still have something to look forward to.

fields.headline: Elliott tames Villa again
fields.trailText: Aston Villa do not like playing Leicester - after all, they haven't beaten them for 13 years. They were the better side for long stretches of yesterday's encounter, but still Martin O'Neill's side battled back twice to avoid defeat.
fields.body:
Aston Villa do not like playing Leicester - after all, they haven't beaten them for 13 years. They were the better side for long stretches of yesterday's encounter, but still Martin O'Neill's side battled back twice to avoid defeat.

'If Leicester played against everyone like they do against us then they would win the Premiership,' said a disgruntled John Gregory after the game. 'I don't know why he says that,' countered O'Neill, 'because our record is very good against a lot of teams.' Good, but not that good.

The only great moment of controversy came in injury time, when Robbie Savage was clattered over by Villa's substitute Lee Hendrie, who was booked. Leicester reacted with fury, and soon 12 players were arguing at the touchline, with Leicester's assistant manager John Robertson joining in for good measure. O'Neill was still furious at the post-match press conference; Gregory was more philosophical. 'These things happen,' he said. 'There is nothing to worry about.'

Indeed, just about the only thing Gregory did have to worry about was Leicester's talismanic captain Matt Elliott, who scored one goal and claimed an assist for the other.

Elliott started at centre-back, leaving the diminutive partnership of Tony Cottee and Muzzy Izzet up front. It didn't go well, and Leicester rarely threatened before they fell behind.

The only surprise was that it took the home side so long to score. They tested Tim Flowers several times before, just past the half-hour, Dublin back-heeled the ball neatly into the path of Alan Thompson, who drilled home his second goal in three starts.

O'Neill swiftly reorganised, moving Elliott up front with Izzet moving back. The move paid almost immediate dividends, Gareth Barry failing to clear a right-wing cross which duly fell to Elliott's feet for an emphatic finish.

Villa regrouped at half-time and started the second period much as they had the first. This time it took them only three minutes to score, Merson's late run timed perfectly to meet Steve Watson's deep cross from the right. But while they threatened to extend their lead further , they were again caught out as Elliott nodded Izzet's cross into the path of Neil Lennon, who scored. As Villa pushed for the winner Elliott returned to the defence to keep Leicester's 13-year-old record intact, until next season at least.

fields.headline: Chelsea not equal to task
fields.trailText: Chelsea once dared to dream that their match at Manchester United tomorrow would be the Premiership title decider. Now they will merely be making up the numbers at the annual Old Trafford championship party with only blanks to fire come the high-noon showdown.
fields.body:
Chelsea once dared to dream that their match at Manchester United tomorrow would be the Premiership title decider. Now they will merely be making up the numbers at the annual Old Trafford championship party with only blanks to fire come the high-noon showdown.

Safe to say that the Chelsea supporters who left in droves before the end of this match were not preparing for an early start up the M1. Most of those who stayed booed their fallen idols in reaction to the final whistle. Chelsea had better be up for the FA Cup or a season which promised so much fun will end in tears.

After taking an early lead they could have buried this game by half-time, but were ultimately fortunate not to lose. Once again Chelsea failed to go for the jugular of a weakened opponent and are left with only an outside chance of gaining an all- important top-three finish to qualify for the Champions League.

Manager Gianluca Vialli rightly praised his players for taking the club so near to what could have been their greatest ever season. He was just as strong in defending his management of the campaign. Was he troubled by the booing? 'No, I wasn't,' he responded. 'I make decisions without taking note of what the supporters think. I am the manager and I know sometimes not everyone agrees, but that does not really matter because I make my decisions for the best of the team.'

Vialli, gracious in his praise of United's latest title success, was also man enough to concede that Chelsea had not shown the required clinical approach against teams they had been expected to beat.

Their task now is to win their remaining games against United, Liverpool, Arsenal and Derby. Any hopes? Vialli says yes, but no would be the most popular answer judging on yesterday's performance.

Vialli's immediate priority was to tend to the bruised egos of his players. As so often this season, he tried to make that job easier by introducing six new, and therefore untainted, players to his staffing line-up. He explained: 'I always select my best team, keeping in mind a few things the supporters and journalists don't know.'

Italian winger Gabriele Ambrosetti made the most of a rare starting chance, whipping in a series of venomous crosses which left the Middlesbrough defence scrambling.

The poor souls did not have a prayer. Gus Poyet scored two FA Cup semi-final goals the last time he was dropped for a European tie and he was back with a point to prove yesterday having missed the Barcelona match.

He duly hit the back of the net after four minutes, but that header was disallowed for off-side. There was no saving Middlesbrough six minutes later when he headed in again after Dennis Wise had guided a corner to the near post to set up the Uruguayan's 16th goal of the season.

The ease with which it was achieved took the edge off the match bar the brief excitement of a scintillating Gianfranco Zola shot, which flew just wide, and the moment of Middlesbrough's first attack when Hamilton Ricard had a tame header saved in the 28th minute.

Nothing special there, but it was enough to inspire Middlesbrough to attack more and they equalised eight minutes from half-time, having forced three quick corners. Christian Ziege crossed to the far post, Gianluca Festa headed down and Ricard stepped into a gap three yards out to volley in.

That was Middlesbrough's first goal at Stamford Bridge in 21 years. They would have celebrated their first victory here in a quarter of a century had Paul Ince not hit a post and Ed De Goey not saved spectacularly from Ricard with 18 minutes to go.

This was a day when only a win would do for Chelsea. The frustration of their supporters was almost tangible and it was definitely understandable.

fields.headline: Carrick cues a routine rout
fields.trailText: With Manchester United and Rangers securing their respective championships and Charlton winning promotion, yesterday was not a day of surprises and it was never likely to be a tale of the unexpected here.
fields.body:
With Manchester United and Rangers securing their respective championships and Charlton winning promotion, yesterday was not a day of surprises and it was never likely to be a tale of the unexpected here.

Given Coventry's away record - played 17, won none - and West Ham's home record, which is bettered only by United and Arsenal, the question was not whether the Hammers would win but by how many goals.

Five was the answer, but that scoreline could have been doubled had it not been for Magnus Hedman in the Coventry goal.

Entertaining stuff, but as Gordon Strachan, Coventry's manager, said afterwards: 'I'm sure they'd [the fans] like to have seen a more competitive game - that is what football is all about.'

Competitive it was not, certainly once West Ham had coasted into a 2-0 lead within 15 minutes. Michael Carrick, the latest starlet off the West Ham production line, opened the scoring on his full home debut with a splendid drive from 25 yards after being picked out by Paolo Di Canio. The mercurial Italian had a part in all five goals, taking the 14th-minute corner from which Javier Margas headed home the second.

Di Canio ended any linger ing Coventry hopes of a miracle when he scored a superb goal three minutes after half-time, running from the centre circle before firing in a 25-yard shot that flew off both posts before crossing the line.

The Italian again gave the goalkeeper no chance in the 67th minute when he exchanged passes with Scott Minto and shot into the far corner of goal.

Kanoute completed the scoring 10 minutes from the end with a close-range header after a corner. West Ham's manager Harry Redknapp is hoping to conclude a permanent deal worth around £3.5million for Kanoute, the France under-21 striker currently on loan from Lyon.

With Wanchope back in form and favour, and Di Canio irrepressible, Redknapp has a fearsome forward line. 'The three of them looked unplayable today,' said the Hammers manager.

To complete Coventry's misery, Strachan revealed that Colin Hendry suffered a fractured eye socket and broken nose in a second-half clash. 'We're all hurt, but Colin is physically and mentally hurt,' said Strachan.

fields.trailText: Murkier and murkier. In his interview with Sky Sports, recorded on Wednesday to be broadcast at lunchtime today, Chris Lewis makes more serious allegations, this time directed at the England and Wales Cricket Board. He says that the ECB did nothing for a week on hearing his story last August, which allowed Aushim Kheterpal to leave the country without being interviewed by the authorities. He suggests that it was someone at the ECB, not himself, who leaked the story that Alec Stewart and Alan Mullally were the English players earmarked to be offered bribes.
fields.body:
Murkier and murkier. In his interview with Sky Sports, recorded on Wednesday to be broadcast at lunchtime today, Chris Lewis makes more serious allegations, this time directed at the England and Wales Cricket Board. He says that the ECB did nothing for a week on hearing his story last August, which allowed Aushim Kheterpal to leave the country without being interviewed by the authorities. He suggests that it was someone at the ECB, not himself, who leaked the story that Alec Stewart and Alan Mullally were the English players earmarked to be offered bribes.

The interview also poses this disturbing question: Which Chris Lewis do we believe? The one quoted in last weekend's News of the World or the one who appears on Sky today? When interviewed by Charles Colville, he suggests that the ECB did not wish to know the names of the three English cricketers who are supposed to have received money. 'When I went to the ECB, I told them all there was to tell, including the fact there were three players mentioned. They were not interested. The police were, so the police have the names. The ECB weren't interested so didn't have the names.'

He goes on to say: 'The ECB chose not to hear those names since this information was dismissed as "hearsay".' He says the ECB have been 'playing the deaf and dumb game'. On Sky, Lewis certainly gives the impression that last August he was willing to reveal to the ECB the identity of the three cricketers, but they didn't want to know.

This does not tally with what Lewis said in the News of the World last weekend about his August meeting with the ECB. 'People will say I should have told the ECB their names. But if my name had come out, my career in the sport would be over. I also genuinely would have feared for my life. If I had helped smash a multi-million-pound betting ring, I don't think they would be happy with me. Do you?'

He added: 'I know I'll get serious stick by effectively implicating three England players, but there's no way I'd have ever given their names to the ECB for the reasons I've said.' This sort of discrepancy, added to the fact that he has taken money from the News of the World for his story (even though he claims he revealed nothing new last weekend), harms Lewis' case. Even so his allegations have to be taken seriously, investigated and answered.

If the ECB really were so casual about his allegations, that attitude hardly sits well with Lord MacLaurin's recently announced crusade to cleanse the game. It's hard to believe that any official of the ECB would not want to know the identity of the three players - if only out of curiosity. Tim Lamb, the ECB's chief executive, remains silent, merely reiterating that 'at the appropriate time a full and comprehensive statement will be made about this issue'. It's a pity that uncertainty about who said what to whom and when is deflecting attention from the wider and far more pernicious topic of match-fixing and how to prevent it.
