fields.headline: Subtle changes and less slog
fields.standfirst: In a tighter field, Surrey must be favourites to retain the title
fields.trailText: In a tighter field, Surrey must be favourites to retain the title, argues Vic Marks.
fields.body:
The return of the Benson & Hedges-sponsored Lottery Cup, with the balls drawn out of the cap of John Kettley, the BBC weatherman who obviously dictates where it's going to rain next, has only been a limited success. No, let's be more succinct, it's been an unmitigated cricketing and financial disaster.

However the focus turns this week to the County Championship, which starts on Wednesday, which is 26 April, about the right time to start the cricket season. Perhaps the sun will shine. On the assumption that the outcome hasn't been decided already, the race for the Championship pennant is wide open. But not as wide open as it used to be.

Surrey are defending their title and this year they only have to outstrip eight opponents to do so successfully. Perhaps Chris Lewis has been told who the winners are in a room above a newsagency in north London.

Sadly I have to proceed without insider knowledge, basing my judgment on the potency of the Surrey pace attack, the efficacy of Ian Salisbury's googly and the state of Graham Thorpe's back.

Before telling you who the winners will be, there are some amendments to the Championship to report, which may seem to be of minor importance compared to the swilling of millions of dollars from Mumbai to - who knows? - the Mumbles, but they might adjust the thinking of the counties as they start their campaign. That's certainly what they are designed to do.

Aside from the major change to two divisions (with three up and three down), the points system has been tinkered with. The idea is to ensure that we have proper pitches to play on rather than some of the green and bumpy disgraces that appeared last year, most notably at Trent Bridge.

Those sorts of pitches persuaded batsmen to desert their techniques and to slog for survival; they could also persuade mundane county trundlers that they were the next Richard Hadlee. Now it is possible to accrue five, rather than four, batting points - at 200, 250, 300, 350 and 400 - in the first 130 overs.

Meanwhile only three, rather than four, bowling points are available at the taking of the the third, sixth and ninth wicket. As last year four points can be gained for a draw, 12 for a victory. All of which sounds a bit negative, an encouragement for sides to play for a draw, but there were so many two- and three-day finishes last year that the ECB are trying to redress the balance and to ensure that the best possible pitches are produced. A quick glance at last year's final table emphasises the importance of not losing.

For example Leicestershire, who finished third, and Hampshire, who finished seventh, only won five of their 17 games; Warwickshire and Sussex, who both won six matches, finished tenth and eleventh respectively and were therefore consigned to the second division.

Theoretically it was possible last year for a side to amass 204 points, enough to finish third, if it drew every match, while acquiring maximum bonus points. In addition a pitch police force has been appointed, liaison officers who are to monitor the standard of pitches. The penalties for sub-standard pitches have been reduced, which is actually a good idea. Last year the penalties were so punitive that no one was prepared to impose them. This year a poor pitch prompts a penalty of eight points, another poor one 12 points, an unfit one 20 points.

In the first division Durham and Derbyshire appear to have taken on the mantle of Watford and Bradford; Derbyshire short of resources, Durham short of talent especially in the batting department.

Yet Derbyshire, as they have dodged the rain in the Benson and Hedges Cup, have already hinted that they can surprise us. Surrey are the favourites and it's easy to understand why. They dominated last summer; they only have one player contracted to England (Alec Stewart) when they might have had three or four and there are misgivings about all their rivals.

Lancashire will miss the penetration of Muttiah Muralitharan, though Saurav Ganguly will score plenty of runs; Leicestershire, minus Paul Nixon and Alan Mullally are in transition - and there's always the threat of Lewis strike action.

The prolonged absence of Andy Caddick restricts Somerset's hopes of their first Championship; Kent usually threaten without delivering; so do Yorkshire and while the presence of Shane Warne is wonderful for the game in general, I doubt whether it is enough to take Hampshire to the title. I know it's a very dangerous policy in this day and age, but I'm betting (metaphorically) on the favourites, Surrey, to retain the Championship.

To the second division, which contains the likes of Glenn McGrath, Allan Donald and Shoiab Akhtar - the parallel of Rivaldo turning out for Stockport doesn't seem to fit somehow. Of course the standard there will be almost indistinguishable from division one unless you see Nottinghamshire on a bad day.

Expect Worcestershire lifted by McGrath, one of 12 Aussies playing county cricket this summer, to be one of the promoted sides, maybe alongside Warwickshire - with Bob Woolmer back at the helm and Ed Giddins complementing Allan Donald - and Middlesex, who have handed the captaincy to the single-minded Justin Langer with Angus Fraser as his no-nonsense deputy.

Division One: Surrey, Lancashire, Leicestershire, Somerset, Kent, Yorkshire, Hampshire, Durham and Derbyshire.

Division Two: Warwickshire, Sussex, Essex, Northamptonshire, Glamorgan, Worcestershire, Middlesex, Nottinghamshire and Gloucestershire.

fields.headline: The money man
fields.standfirst: Sports promoter Aushim Khetarpal is the money man named by Chris Lewis. Indian cricket author  Pradeep Magazine recalls a revealing meeting with Khetarpal in Mohali
fields.trailText: Sports promoter Aushim Khetarpal is the money man named by Chris Lewis. Indian cricket author Pradeep Magazine recalls a revealing meeting with Khetarpal in Mohali.
fields.body:
Indian journalist Pradeep Magazine has just updated his 1999 book Not Quite Cricket about corruption in the game in the sub-continent. In it he detailed how he met a Delhi bookmaker who offered him £600,000 to help 'fix' cricket matches. That meeting fired the curiousity of sports promoter Aushim Khetarpal - the man recently named by Chris Lewis in connection with a £300,000 offer to rig England games. Here is magazine's account of his meeting with Khetarpal.

In 1999, I was in Mohali, a town in Punjab bordering Chandigarh, to watch the India-Pakistan one-day match on 1 April. The Mohali stadium is easily the best in India and one of the finest in the world. It shimmered neat and clean in the bright sunlight. The man responsible for its creation, Inderjeet Singh Bindra, former president of the Indian Cricket Board and, until not very long ago, the most powerful man in Indian cricket, is now in grave trouble over it.

Bindra, a high-ranking official in the Punjab government, leased a barren plot of land for the Punjab Cricket Association of which he is president. Subsequently he was charged by the Central Bureau of Investigation with misuse of his position to get the stadium made... the case is being investigated, but whatever the outcome of the probe, Bindra still deserves credit for raising a stadium that offers facilities unheard of in India.

Then I saw a familiar face. It was Aushim Khetarpal (the man named by Chris Lewis last week in connection with a £300,000 'bribe'), a self-styled sports promoter. Having organised several tennis and billiards tournaments, he had switched to veterans' cricket involving former Test players from Pakistan, India, Sri Lanka and South Africa. He was also a man with a special knack for getting into trouble, especially when it came to money.

Khetarpal had bought part of the stadium advertising rights for the India-Pakistan match. 'I have also signed most of the Pakistani cricketers like Saqlain Mushtaq and Wasim Akram. There is very little money in Pakistan cricket. I will get these players good sponsorship deals from India,' he boasted.

In the press box, we were treated to a lavish diet of beer, whisky, snacks and hot food. Late in the evening I went to the club house where Bindra had agreed to meet me for an informal chat. In the lobby I bumped into Khetarpal, his wife and daughter.

He too was waiting for Bindra, to discuss with him the details of buying the rights of an inter-club cricket series that Punjab Cricket Association were planning to host. In the meantime, Bindra's secretary asked me when I was leaving for Delhi. Sensing that my appointment might be in jeopardy, I told him that I could not postpone my departure any longer. Suddenly there was a commotion inside the lobby and someone said: 'Bindra sahib has come.'

Bindra walked in with a few others - guests from Pakistan, he said. He was too busy to talk to me. Not too busy, however, for Khetarpal with whom he spent a good half an hour. Since I had accepted Khetarpal's invitation to travel with him to Delhi, I waited outside for them. The saloon attached to his car was quite comfortable, with a bed, chair, washbasin and fridge neatly arranged inside. I was offered a stiff drink by Khetarpal and our journey to Delhi began.

We soon fell into conversation about his business dealings. Khetarpal brushed a mop of hair from his forehead and said: 'You know, if I had not started it all, sports would not have got the kind of money it has today.'

He started off on a brief history of his exploits. How he had interviewed sportsmen and women and written about them in newspapers. How one day he had thought of starting his own sports promotion company.

'I had no money but I was determined to start a promotion company of my own. As I was walking down the road one day I saw this neon sign glowing in a shop, flashing "Radiant shoes". Then and there I decided to name my company Radiant - Radiant Management Group.

'Next I decided to open a tennis academy. I approached a business house and told them that I needed finances for starting an academy at the Modern School tennis courts. They agreed. My next step was to approach the Modern School authorities and tell them that a big business house was ready to finance a tennis academy and it would be good publicity for the school if the academy was run on their school courts. They agreed.' Khetarpal looked at me triumphantly.

'The tennis academy became the best in India. Luckily for me, in the academy was a son of the Director General of Doordarshan [India's public service TV]. I came very close to this man. He became like my godfather. I tied up the national championship and made arrangement with Doordarshan to show it live. That was the first time a sports meet was live on television. That is why I say I am the man who started it all.'

Later he met Zaheer Abbas, the former Pakistan Test batsman, who in those days was courting an Indian woman (whom he later married) and used to be in Delhi quite often. 'Through Zaheer Abbas I roped in Jansher Khan [the former world squash champion] who agreed to play in Bombay. It was a big show and the photograph of me receiving Jansher at the airport was carried by most of the newspapers.'

I reminded him gently that most of the tournaments he had organised had run into trouble. He had even been accused of not paying the players as promised.

'Look, if that was the case I would not be here. I did suffer drawbacks and some problems had to arise. But all is well now. I am back. Had my dealings not been clean I would not have been accepted. Look, I got Ajay Jadeja his first major break when I got him signed by Liberty Shoes. I was the man who brokered the deal for the Hero Honda Cup in 1994. You have seen me working in the 1996 World Cup. I got Zaheer Abbas to write in the Indian Express. You wait and watch what I am going to do. If I had a bad reputation in the market, do you think Mr Bindra would have allowed me to do a deal?'

All along the drive to Delhi, Khetarpal kept asking about the bookie I had met. Where he lived and how he operated. In between, he told me how betting was essential for the development of cricket. 'It is only when big betting comes to a sport that it becomes big. The only thing wrong here is that players are throwing away matches. They should not sell the nation. Otherwise betting will generate a lot of money for the game. It is not a bad thing. It will do more good than harm.'

webTitle: Chris Lewis, the ECB and  the man with the money

fields.headline: Chris Lewis, the ECB and  the man with the money
fields.standfirst: The England all-rounder speaks out today after claiming he was told that three Test colleagues were being paid by bookmakers
fields.trailText: Last week Chris Lewis was paid a substantial sum by the News of the World - reported to be £30,000 - for his 'revelations' about match-fixing within the England Test team. Not only was he himself offered £300,000, but he claimed he had been told that three England players had been on an Indian bookmaker's payroll.
fields.body:
Last week Chris Lewis was paid a substantial sum by the News of the World - reported to be £30,000 - for his 'revelations' about match-fixing within the England Test team. Not only was he himself offered £300,000, but he claimed he had been told that three England players had been on an Indian bookmaker's payroll.

Lewis was reviled by many within cricket, but now, in an interview with Charles Colvile to be broadcast on Sky this afternoon, he says all the details that appeared in last week's report had been passed on to the English Cricket Board last summer - and they ignored them.

Colvile: When was contact made with you?

Lewis: Well initially it started off with a phone call, being invited by somebody that I've known from time to time, that I got tickets for games. He called me up and said that he had some friends coming over from India, and that he had a business proposition he wanted to discuss, and I think I met with him something like the following week.

And what was the man's name?

Well, for legal reasons I'm not going to say, all the information, is with the police and all the right authorities.

Had you any idea what type of business meeting it was likely to be?

No. I was told that the people involved were in entertainment. It was as simple as that. And I went along with that until I actually had the meeting... Then it became very clear that what the people were actually after was to buy, to organise for me to actually fix an England match versus New Zealand at Old Trafford.

Why do you think you were chosen to broker this deal?

I have no idea. At the time I wasn't involved in the England set-up, I wasn't playing any international cricket. People were trying the best way they could to achieve what they wanted and they thought that via me would have been a good way of doing it.

How much money was on offer?

It was £300,000 I was offered. If I could actually arrange for this match to be sort of fixed.

That was your fee?

No, that was the money they were offering which would have also involved fees of other players.

So, what was your reaction when this business proposition was put to you?

I was obviously shocked. Because at this time I wasn't in the England cricket team. And £300,000 is a lot of money. It's not football we're talking, it's cricket!

And what did you say?

At the time I just listened. The conversation was left where they would call me the following day to see what my reaction was. I then left the meeting and I called my manager and called my solicitor directly after and told them exactly what was happening.

The following morning we called the Board at 9am. I expressed to them exactly what had happened. I gave them full details of everything. I also informed them that the people were still here in the country and which hotel they were staying at. They did nothing about it and it was left for a week or so.

webTitle: Board leaked my story, says Lewis

fields.headline: Board leaked my story, says Lewis
fields.trailText: Chris Lewis today accuses the England and Wales Cricket Board of leaking to the News of the World his claims that Alec Stewart and Alan Mullally were the targets of Indian bookmakers trying to fix a Test match.
fields.body:
Chris Lewis today accuses the England and Wales Cricket Board of leaking to the News of the World his claims that Alec Stewart and Alan Mullally were the targets of Indian bookmakers trying to fix a Test match.

Last summer the paper reported that an Indian sports entrepreneur called Aushim Khetarpal met Lewis in London and offered him £1million to persuade Stewart and Mullally to play poorly in the Test match against New Zealand at Old Trafford (even though Mullally was not in the team). But Lewis now says the story did not come from him - and that the bribe was £300,000.

'The leak came after I told the info to the ECB,' Lewis says in a pre-recorded interview to be broadcast on Sky this afternoon. The Board, who called Lewis to a meeting at Lord's last week after he put his name to further allegations in the News Of The World , refused to comment. They would do so 'at the appropriate time', a spokesman said.

However, the original story did appear shortly after Lewis had gone to the Board in August to tell them about his meeting with Khetarpal, who says he spoke to Lewis only to invite him to play in a charity match. The Observer has since learnt that Khetarpal, who is still operating in Delhi, has links with Doordarshan, the Indian television company who bankroll cricket on the sub-continent. The highest-rating matches are the many meaningless one-day games such as those at the centre of recent match- fixing allegations in which South Africa's Hansie Cronje was implicated.

Last Sunday, the News of the World returned to the Lewis story - and reportedly paid him £30,000. Fresh allegations, which Lewis insists are old, included the claim that three unnamed England players were already on the payroll of Indian bookmakers. Lewis came under fire from former England team-mates Darren Gough and Angus Fraser for revealing this, though he says the Board knew about it last August but did not want to know the names, telling him it was all hearsay.

Lewis withdrew from Leicestershire's match against Yorkshire at Headingley the day after his grilling by the ECB, saying the Board had abandoned him.

In his updated version of the saga, Lewis says, 'The leak ... that came out initially, that the News of the World got hold of ... came from the ECB. This didn't get into the news because of me. It [was] a leak from somewhere else.'

Lewis says he never spoke to the News of the World in August. 'No, no. I did not give them an interview, certainly did not receive any money or anything. That was something they did all on their own. That's why there's a discrepancy now, because it's the first time I've actually spoken.'

With claims - and subsequent backtracking - by Ali Bacher, the chief executive of the United Cricket Board of South Africa, that two matches in the World Cup last year were fixed, India and Pakistan remain at the epicentre of the scandal.

Daily allegations and counter-claims trickled out of magazines and newspapers on the sub-continent all week, some of them bordering on the outlandish. Jagmohan Dalmiya, the Calcutta businessman who is coming to the end of his tenure as president of the International Cricket Council, will have to address all of these when he arrives in London next week to chair an emergency meeting if his investigation is to have any validity. T he game cannot stand any more whitewashes or retreats into silence. It needs a firm dose of leadership and far more candour than has been evident so far.

Last week Dalmiya took particular exception to Bacher's claims. 'He will have to explain why he went public with his allegation,' he said. Among Dalmiya's critics is Inderjeet Singh Bindra, a former president of the Indian Cricket Board and now a high-ranking official in the Punjab government. India's Central Bureau of Investigation has charged Bindra with abusing his position to have a stadium built at Mohali. Among his business associates is the central figure in Lewis' story, Aushim Khetarpal.

webTitle: Life through this Lens had shades of Hillsborough

fields.headline: Life through this Lens had shades of Hillsborough
fields.trailText: The French club had inadequate crowd-control measures for the Uefa Cup semi-final.
fields.body:
At a time when crowd security is a growing concern, how haunting it was for an English club to be confronted with a set of circumstances that summoned dark memories of Hillsborough. A rush of ticketless fans chancing it to barge into a semi-final caused police to panic, a vast metal gate was bolted shut, and the next thing we knew young and old, male and female, tipsy and sober were crushing against metal bars while police ranks looked on passively. If football has learned anything from its own wretched mistakes maybe the shaft of light was that something clicked in the back of the minds of Arsenal supporters surging to get into their seats at Lens with the game already underway.

So it was that enough people backed off and although the pressure was intense enough for some to require first aid and for many to be bruised, squashed, frightened and caught short of breath, a nasty incident passed off without serious injury.

We knew something was up the moment the visitors' entrance at the Stade Felix Bollaert came into view. Forty minutes to go until kick-off and the walkway which would lead the Arsenal ranks towards a tunnel and into the bowels of the stand was sealed by a locked gate reinforced by a line of police. A huddle, some waving match tickets above their heads hoping to persuade police they had the key to advance, pressed against it. Some tried to reason with the authorities, some even beseeched them in fluent French. All to no avail.

It was difficult to believe the lack of basic crowd control procedures for a match at the closing stages of European competition. Simply hoping punters would filter through a broad walkway at a controlled rate is just not good enough for a World Cup venue. There was not a single turnstile. No stewards. No communication or explanation. Instead the police presence was doubled - and rather than easing the crowd they exacerbated the problems. A cordon of police in full riot gear with helmets, batons and shields closed the fans in around this gate. Behind them more police bearing tear gas guns arrived. It was extremely intimidating and - understandably - soured the mood of fans who had, in the majority, been restrained and reasonably patient.

Many decent-minded fans who had spent a lot of money to travel to support their team in peace were amazed to be suddenly treated like potential criminals. One minute they were strolling to the game ticket in hand, the next total anxiety. Tempers were suddenly, and unnecessarily, on a knife edge. Some were so upset they simply left. Frustration got the better of others. Being trapped outside a stadium host ing a crucial match for an hour - gate on one side, CRS on the other - is no fun. When the police began to let those with tickets trickle inside by partially opening the gate, the crush naturally intensified.

Once inside fans hit another barrier. Those with tickets for Block 4 found they were unable to gain access because it was, confusingly, already full of home supporters (allegations that Lens sold a set of tickets twice are being looked into). It wasn't much easier getting into other blocks because late arrivals simply filled the aisles. Eventually, and with considerable difficulty, most supporters found a way into the tribunes by half-time.

Many were separated from their friends and family. The majority ended up in an overspill alongside Lens supporters, virtually unsegregated, and what ensued - good-natured friendship between the opposing fans who shook hands and swapped souvenirs - only underlined how the police had misconstrued the atmosphere entirely earlier on. Meanwhile Uefa regulations for stadiums fit to host European matches rule out certain grounds because of car-parking spaces, top tickets for delegates and media access.

Perhaps it's time reasonable stewarding, better communication, and turnstiles to filter crowds were judged to be a little bit more important.

fields.headline: Education has rich rewards
fields.trailText: David Pleat's comments last week, to the effect that education is wasted on young footballers because most of them are thick, certainly touched a nerve in the game.
fields.body:
David Pleat's comments last week, to the effect that education is wasted on young footballers because most of them are thick, certainly touched a nerve in the game.

I am surprised that something like this should have come from Pleat, who came through the non-League ranks as a manager with Nuneaton Borough and should understand more than most the value of helping players to become more rounded individuals, not least because he is responsible for developing Tottenham Hotspur's youngsters.

I always maintain that coaching is about teaching people new things and communicating ideas and so there are many similarities between coaches and teach ers, especially at youth level.

By the same token, I find that the brighter players or those who have a broader perspective on life are easier to coach because they are better able to grasp new ideas and take them on board. And I firmly believe we have a responsibility to give our young players a general education for two reasons: firstly to help those who make it to the top deal with the trappings of success and, secondly, to give something extra to those who do not make it.

There is a huge drop-out rate among teenage players in this country. It is estimated that 85 per cent of players taken on by clubs at 16 years old are not given full professional status by the age of 18 or 19. That is far too high a figure and something we are working hard to reduce, but in the meantime we can help soften the blow for those who don't make it.

Footballers can lead a very cocooned life, having clubs and coaches do for them many of the things that ordinary young men do for them selves. I've lost count of the number of times players have turned up at the airport without their passports because they had no idea they needed one to travel abroad.

Of course, I am not saying footballers are stupid because that is a sweeping generalisation, which fails to take into account those players and coaches who are well educated. I gained my own qualifications as a chartered surveyor because, after my playing career was ended by a car crash in my early twenties, I was lucky enough to be offered a job in the property business by Sidney Black, then the chairman of Wimbledon.

Black was the driving force when Wimbledon were a power in non-League football over 20 years ago and recognised the value of employing players in his business. He had a lot of players working for his company and they were better people for it.

Nowadays the bigger clubs have caught up with his thinking and all Premier League clubs employ a full- time education officer. At Fulham, we have a very good one in David Burke, who is a key part of our academy.

On the other hand, I have known players who could barely write their name when it has come to signing a contract. Like boxers, they are the ones most likely to be exploited by unscrupulous agents or business 'advisers' when they finally get to the top and the money starts to roll in.

And if, as Pleat suggests, many players are not so sharp, their clubs must take a large part of the blame. They would not dream, for example, of failing to give a foreign player language lessons, so why not help educate their home-grown players - it is not as if they cannot afford to do it.

The problem, as so often, comes back to the point that too many people in football have known nothing but football and are unable to get things into perspective. It can be a very narrow existence, so it is up to us as coaches to try to broaden young players' minds - not write them off.

fields.headline: Brit pack lack the class
fields.standfirst: There's no substitute for quality and both United and Chelsea were found wanting
fields.trailText: There's no substitute for quality and both United and Chelsea were found wanting.
fields.body:
At around five minutes to nine on Wednesday evening, just after Fernando Redondo had embarrassed Henning Berg with his skill and Mickael Silvestre with his cross to leave Raul a simple tap-in for Real Madrid's third goal, Gianluca Vialli and Chelsea must have started to feel a whole lot better about themselves.

It is arguable that Manchester United were going out of the Champions League from the moment Roy Keane turned the ball past his own goalkeeper in the first half. The holders were certainly up against it when Raul made it two from Steve McManaman's delightful pass, but it was the third goal, both in its finality and its breathtaking execution, which confirmed United were just as susceptible as Chelsea to football's oldest and most immutable rule.

There is no substitute for class, and United were outclassed at Old Trafford just as comprehensively as Chelsea had been at the Nou Camp a day earlier. Frankly admitting his own side had been unable to handle Barcelona, Vialli had offered Manchester United as a possible stumbling block when asked whether he thought the Catalans could go all the way.

But Sir Alex Ferguson's players were unable to repay his confidence in front of their own supporters when faced by a supposedly less fearsome Spanish outfit. Had United been in Chelsea's shoes on Tuesday they might have protected a 3-1 lead for longer than Vialli's cautiously selected team, but there is serious doubt over whether they would have fared any better against the whirlwind of the Barcelona attack.

The reasoning is simple. United's defence has not been functioning particularly impressively all season, it is their attack that has been sweeping them to stylish victories. By domestic standards United's attack is state of the art: they rarely encounter teams with players capable of bettering what is seen every week at Old Trafford, but the Spanish commitment to attack is something else again.

Barcelona and Real have higher octane attacks than Manchester United are used to. Rivaldo, Luis Figo and Patrick Kluivert would all get into United's team, Chelsea's team, anybody's team. Real, who attack right down to the full-backs, perhaps have even more covetable players. For once, at Old Trafford on Wednesday, the opposition were not cowering in the dressing room poring over the United teamsheet.

Only Keane, Ryan Giggs and David Beckham could walk into the Real side. There might be cases to be made for Paul Scholes and Jaap Stam, but the probability is that Real would be interested in fewer than half of United's players. Against which United would fancy most of Real, which makes a change from merely admiring a Gabriel Batistuta here or a Sol Campbell there.

Even the teenage stand-in goalkeeper distinguished himself at Old Trafford, and the much-vilified (though not by Ferguson) Steve McManaman was one of the most influential players over the two legs. In short, Real had class in every department, while United were forced to acknowledge they had some catching up to do.

Not that Gary Neville was ever going to catch up with Roberto Carlos, Denis Irwin hold Michael Salgado, or Berg predict that Redondo would use a backheel to beat him on the outside. But the failure of the formula that has served United so well all season, relying on their forward momentum to roll over opposing defences, was the big letdown. In neither leg did Dwight Yorke or Andy Cole give Real anything to worry about. The determined Giggs and Beckham both showed up well on the flanks, but the most likely source of a United goal until Beckham took matters into his own hands seemed to be one of Keane's bullocking runs.

Yorke and Cole's lack of control was not as pronounced as it had been in the first leg, but any telepathy between the two seems to have disappeared. In a contest which Ferguson accepted was going to be all about attack, United trailed a distant second to the clever running and incisive finishing of Raul and Co.

'Paceless and lacking in ability' was how Roberto Carlos had described United's attack after the first leg, and United's immediate purchase of £19m Dutch striker Ruud van Nistelrooy makes further comment unnecessary.

Ferguson said he was shocked by the defeat, perhaps because he had imagined his defence would hold up better, perhaps because he had expected more of his attack, but probably because he thought he had said goodbye to the powerless sense of inadequacy which must have overwhelmed him when United went 3-0 down.

Six years ago in Barcelona was the last time United received such a spanking in Europe, and even then there were extenuating circumstances, such as Eric Cantona's suspension and Peter Schmeichel's absence due to the limit on overseas players. But Barcelona's 4-0 slapping down of a confident United side who were convinced they were on the verge of something big still hurt in the same way that Tuesday's 5-1 result crushed Chelsea, who, because of their first-leg lead more than any reasoned assessment of playing strengths, must have allowed themselves to dream they could go through. Chelsea, if it is any consolation, are approximately where United were in 1994, though their future direction is less clear.

'We did our best but they were too good for us,' said solitary goalscorer Tore Andre Flo. 'At least we have the experience for later.' Yes, but how long will the likes of Marcel Desailly, Gianfranco Zola and Didier Deschamps be sticking around now that Chelsea have explored the limit of how far you can go with Serie A cast-offs?

Even stalwarts like Dennis Wise, Dan Petrescu and Ed de Goey must be aware they are unlikely to get as close to the European Cup again in a Chelsea shirt. It does not take a genius to work out that a period of transition will follow this season's FA Cup final, but what sort of Chelsea will emerge at the other end? Do Ken Bates and the Chelsea Village have the funds and the nerve to redouble their efforts in the transfer market?

As a London club, Chelsea are in some ways better placed than United to attract leading players, but in terms of purchasing power and international kudos they can no more compete with Barcelona than Stamford Bridge can outshout the Nou Camp. Money matters in football, that is why Chelsea are playing Champions League football and Spurs are not, but Bates's wage bill is already eye-watering enough without contemplating what it would take to attract a young Desailly to England or join the bidding when a Kluivert or Rivaldo comes on to the market.

The limit of Chelsea's ambition, or put more prosaically the depth of their pockets, was illustrated when they dropped out of the race to sign Van Nistelrooy to leave the way clear for Manchester United. Should United have the Dutchman and Tottenham's Campbell in place for the start of next season, they will have replicated the Stam-Yorke double signing which underpinned their treble success.

The cost will be roughly double too, but the world's most profitable club can cope with that. Once decidedly niggardly over expenditure, United now appear to have worked out that an extravagant purchase or two keeps the supporters happy and the share price stable, in addition to turning domestic rivals an envious shade of green. This is the continental model, of course, the way Italian and Spanish giants have been conducting their affairs for years. In theory next year's Premiership title should be even more of a formality for United than this season's, though if it was that simple Barcelona, Real or Valencia would be on top of the Spanish League, instead of which Deportivo are five points clear.

The downside of assembling a side studded with world-class superstars is that domestic matters tend to be relegated to the level of any other business, and the manager inevitably loses a degree of control. Louis van Gaal and Vicente del Bosque might be trailing clouds of glory now but have spent most of the season deflecting criticism. Both managers could have been sacked this week, which is why claims that La Liga is now the leading competition in Europe are as spurious as those premature suggestions of a month or so ago that Premiership teams were about to carry off all the prizes. Not least of Ferguson's many achievements at Old Trafford has been his high degree of control, ensured by building a United side in his own image, nurturing a core of home-produced players who share his philosophy and conform willingly to his work ethic.

Sheer tenacity was the element of surprise United successfully utilised in Europe last year - Juventus underestimated their determination in Turin, for example, and Bayern Munich fatally imagined one goal would be enough - but top teams do not fall for the same sting twice. Spirit, as every manager knows, can only get you so far. It took United a long way last season, but the plain truth is that the work ethic does not always win against rich and outrageously gifted Spanish slackers.

United are now too big a concern to revert to domestic disputes, they have little choice but to buy into the European elite, and look as if they have already started. Last year's treble was a fabulous achievement by a reasonably local team who were not all that expensively assembled, but the next time United win the Champions League it will be by more conventional means.

fields.headline: Advancing by degrees
fields.trailText: Your stereotypical Millwall defender doesn't write papers on Charles Bukowski. Does he?
fields.body:
Charles Bukowski and the death of the American Dream : not something you would expect your stereotypical Millwall defender to be able to pronounce, let alone read, let alone write. Yet this was the title of Matthew Lawrence's thesis for his degree course in American Literature at Hartwick College, Oneonte, New York State.

'The conclusion was that for Bukowski there was no American Dream because of the lifestyle he led and what he saw when he was working in the Post Office. The people were 35 to 40 and looked 50 to 60. They literally died on the job.'

'It was so regimented. They had to throw so many letters in an hour or they were sacked. And at the end of the day he would go to the bar in preparation for the next day. Because what else was there to do? It was impossible for them to leave the bleak nature of the job. The Americans said that there was no class system, everyone was middle-class, but from what he saw this was obviously not true.'

Wow. And I'd come to talk about playing against Wrighty at Turf Moor yesterday, and Millwall's big week (their next games are against fellow promotion contenders Gillingham and Preston) and whether he preferred operating in a flat back four or a 3-5-2 system. And what it's like at Millwall. And we're talking about Bukowski.

Which isn't perhaps so strange because if Bukowski had hung around New Cross rather than L.A he would surely have written about Cold Blow Lane. Bukowski, the author of Post Office, Women and Factotum , is perhaps the greatest chronicler of American low-life. He wrote of hangovers, shit stains on his underwear, classical music, horse-racing and whores. He wrote the screenplay for Barfly which provided Mickey Rourke with the role he was born to play. 'Sometimes you just have to roll the potato', is the way Mickey excuses a catalogue of bad behaviour and to this day no one has a clue what he means.

So does Lawrence practise what he reads and live like Bukowski, stumbling from the bar every Saturday afternoon to play right-back for Millwall? 'It's a romantic lifestyle from the outside: the drinking, the smoking and the women. And I had a go at college. But things are rather different now I'm a professional footballer.'

His interest in literature survived studying for an English A-Level. 'Being forced to read your Shakespeare, your Milton, your Pride and Preju dice, The Mayor of Casterbridge . They weren't books that I was interested in. My worst memories are sitting down to study Eng Lit. Shakespeare, God bless him, may be the greatest author but analysing two of his paragraphs in a double lesson lasting an hour and 50 minutes...'

A friend gave him a copy of Kerouac's On the Road who 'was not quite the same as your Shakespeare'. He was soon hooked on the Beats reading all of Kerouac, Ferlinghetti, Ginsberg and Bukowski. At about the same time, while staying at Lillieshall with the England under-18 schoolboys he 'got a call from one of the English coaches saying a fella wanted to talk to me and I met him in the restaurant and he offered me a full scholarship for four years there and then.' One hundred thousand dollars worth of education. '

He enjoyed his time as a College Boy. 'I wouldn't have missed it for the world. It's important to broaden your horizons and widen your knowledge.'

fields.headline: Sounds a bit phoney
fields.standfirst: Director plans to shoot an entire film inside a phone box
fields.trailText: Director plans to shoot an entire film inside a phone box
fields.body:
The man responsible for Batman Forever and Batman and Robin can hardly claim to be a cinematic visionary, but Joel Schumacher has other ideas. His latest film is a thriller with a difference. Phone Booth is shaping up to be one of the most bizarre high concept movies Hollywood has ever agreed to make.

The premise is that a man enters a New York phone box to make a quick call. The phone rings. He picks it up and then an anonymous voice informs him that he'll be shot dead if he hangs up. A sniper's rifle is trained on him and the moving infra-red dot on his forehead is proof that this isn't just a crank call.

So what happens next? Ideally, the hero, let's say for argument's sake Bruce Willis (his forehead does present an irresistible target, after all), somehow escapes the booth and embarks on a frantic adventure to search out and destroy America's latest menace to society - disgruntled telecom employees.

In fact, that's not it at all. The whole film takes place in the phone booth. Now, Screen supports experimental cinema, but a two -hour film set in a phone box sounds, frankly, ridiculous. Schumacher has proved he's got clout but this one is unlikely to get them jamming the aisles in Iowa. It's hard to see how this will appeal to anyone other than Schumacher's immediate family and friends.

Apparently Schumacher, who has worked with many major stars, is looking for a bankable name for Phone Booth . His proposed schedule sounds bizarre, though - a week's rehearsal followed by an unusually short location shoot. He is also toying with the idea of using the Internet to make footage from rehearsals and the actual filming available to film students. Although what budding Scorseses can hope to learn from the man responsible for 8MM is debatable.

The whole project smacks of hubris. Schumacher is a blockbuster director, most of whose films can be described as, at best as, extended pop promos. He obviously wants a piece of the action at a time when Hollywood storytelling is increasingly offbeat and non-linear. But he's forgotten one of the golden rules: real heroes get changed in phone boxes- they don't make movies in them.

webTitle: How Leo became a principle boy

fields.headline: How Leo became a principle boy
fields.standfirst: Fame and fortune is no longer enough. Now stars need a burning issue too. But who benefits, asks  Tim Adams - the cause or the star?
fields.trailText: Fame and fortune is no longer enough. Now stars need a burning issue too. But who benefits, asks Tim Adams - the cause or the star?
fields.body:
On American prime-time TV last night, Leonardo DiCaprio interviewed President Clinton. The ABC interview concerned issues that have recently grown close to the cherubic actor's heart: coral bleaching in Key Largo, Florida, and earth warming in Kotzebue, Alaska. For DiCaprio is no longer the floppy-haired teen star that the headlines had 'boozing, brawling and chasing girls'. These days he is president of Global Earth Day 2000. Leo has a Cause.

The New York Times recently suggested that to the modern film star a Cause is as essential as an agent or liposuction. Susan Sarandon has the abolition of the death penalty; Richard Gere has Tibet; Tom Hanks has World War II veterans; and now Leo has, well, the planet.

The depth of the Titanic star's concerns are demonstrated by the fact that he has found himself agonising over whether to order a burger on room service. 'I shouldn't be eating hamburgers because the methane gas cows release is the number one contributor to the destruction of the ozone layer,' he has been at pains to explain. 'The number one reason they destroy the rainforest is to make grazing ground for cattle. So,' he concluded, tortured, 'it's very ironic that I eat beef, being the environmentalist that I am.'

In Jay McInerney's satire on the celebrity industry, Model Behaviour, his journalist narrator, a hagiographer to the stars, has quick commands installed on his computer. Thus [alt- Baby] gives him: 'There's nothing like being a parent to tell you what matters in life'; while [shift- Me?sexy?] calls up the quote: 'Actually I've always been insecure about my looks. ' In future, he might add [ctrl- new dawn] as in: 'Now we have entered the new millennium I am realising there is great deal more to care about in this world than simply cranking out product.'

DiCaprio's personal assault on global warming has been orchestrated by his aptly named PR consultant Ken Sunshine. Sunshine is a grown-up version of what the film industry has taken to calling 'P-girls', political assistants to the stars. P-girls know their way round Washington and spend their days working to find the perfect 'fit' between a star's profile and a charity or campaign.

Sunshine approached DiCaprio not long after the ecological protests that surrounded the making of his most recent film, The Beach, when a portion of the Thai coastline was somewhat remodelled. 'Leo,' says Sunshine solemnly, 'reads more scientific magazines and books than anyone I know, and knows more about global warming than most reporters covering it. I've worked with phoneys trying to use issues to enhance their images, but Leo isn't one of them.'

One of the curious things about DiCaprio's emergence as a matinée idol Swampy is that he has hidden his soul-searching for so long. The current issue of George (the magazine set up by the late John F. Kennedy Jnr) is devoted to a kind of academy awards for seasoned single-issue celebs. On its cover a tousle-haired Michael Douglas has 'No Nukes' written across his face. Inside we are invited to applaud everyone from Charlton Heston, embattled campaigner for the American right to bear arms, to Gillian Anderson, spokesperson for the Feminist Majority Foundation, promoting equality. 'I'm not much of a public person,' says Anderson, photographed in a dress apparently made from exotic feathers, 'and I have mixed feelings about the celebrity aspect of the business I am in. The only true benefit is when one can be of service.'

George, whose proprietor was a connoisseur of the vanishing dividing line between celebrity and politics, was established to bridge the gap between glossy magazine culture and serious debate. We are used to the concept of celebrities selling things, ran the editorial thinking, so why not have them sell ideas and news? This concept was by no means a new one - witness the way British broadsheets have long peppered their mastheads with this week's B-listers as desperate offerings to the gods of circulation, or the furore that was provoked in America when Roseanne Barr was invited to edit an issue of the New Yorker. (John Seabrook, a New Yorker writer, in his new book Nobrow , takes Tina Brown's arrival at the magazine as the point when America traded its soul to shallowness.)

DiCaprio's audience with the President is simply the latest example of this trend, and the storm it has provoked in the past two weeks among American journalists shows how justifiably paranoid parts of the news-gathering establishment are about celebrities encroaching on their field. Clinton, never one to miss an opportunity to show his Hollywood credentials, jumped at the chance of a light grilling on his environmental record from Hollywood's principal boy. When rumours of the DiCaprio audience filtered out, David Westin, head of ABC News, declared in a memo to reporting staff that no one was 'that stupid' as to send an actor to interview the President for the network. The following day it turned out that Westin's superiors were indeed 'that stupid'.

ABC anchormen Sam Donaldson and others promptly protested against any use of the DiCaprio interview on the channel. Sunshine laughs off the very public internal wrangling. 'In truth, it probably helped. Controversy is good. A lot of people know he [DiCaprio] is chairman of Earth Day now.'

And presumably the organisers of Earth Day would concur. The argument for using celebs to raise the profile of issues is that it is a shorthand way to get a serious cause on the front of a newspaper.

A case in point is Michael Douglas's recent trip to Britain to argue the case against nuclear proliferation. Douglas, a UN ambassador, was afforded many of the trappings of a state visit; an audience with the Foreign Secretary and a chance to lecture the Commons on disarmament. Foreign Office Minister Peter Hain gushed over Douglas in the manner of an Oxford Union president revealing his latest coup: 'You reach a part of public opinion which MPs, Ministers and nuclear anoraks have no chance of reaching,' he told Douglas. 'Can I congratulate you for inspiring a mass turn-out of MPs. They would not have come to hear me.'

Did the arrival of Douglas really raise the issue of disarmament - or was its effect, however altruistically intended, simply to add a caring, committed layer to the actor's profile? Sting, a veteran of such arguments, who once appeared on Wogan in the company of a Yamomamo Indian, has argued: 'Celebrity is often a lead weight around your neck. It's like pointing at the moon, but people are looking at your finger.'

Dennis Hayes, who has co-ordinated Earth Day 2000 in the 30 years since its inception, suggested that his only reservations about DiCaprio were that 'he is the best actor of his generation, and you always wonder, is this the real thing, or another performance?'

It seems the great actor's skills let him down during his afternoon at the White House. His performance was so inept he was given the chance to 're-ask' his questions to camera at a later date (the role of the President was, apparently, taken by an ABC production assistant named Stephanie Soechtig). And it was this farce that reporters dwelt on.

For the record, Earth Day 2000 was yesterday. The issues it was designed to publicise include the facts that 'one in four vertebrate species is on the verge of extinction or is now extinct' and that 'one person in six alive today is chronically hungry'. In Britain, in case you missed it, the day was marked by a huge inflatable whale inside the Millennium Dome where visitors were treated to music from the pop group Black Lace who wittily 'recycled more old rubbish' including their hit 'Agadoo'.

Perhaps there is something to be said for the approach of the refugee body UNHCR, which phased out the use of celebrities and stunts to publicise its work several years ago. At the time a spokesman said: 'We tend to believe the issues speak for themselves.' But who wants issues when they can have Leo?

Susan Sarandon, Abolishing the death penalty

Mira Sorvino, Breast cancer

David Schwimmer, Rape treatment centre

Sarah Jessica Parker, Unicef

Michael Douglas, Nuclear disarmament

Gillian Anderson, Political and economic equality for women

Charlton Heston, The right to bear arms

Geri Halliwell, UN Goodwill Ambassador

webTitle: Face of Chanel, mind of her own

fields.headline: Face of Chanel, mind of her own
fields.standfirst: French film star Carole Bouquet has learnt to take the rough with the smooth - and that includes Gérard Depardieu
fields.trailText: French film star Carole Bouquet has learnt to take the rough with the smooth - and that includes Gérard Depardieu
fields.body:
Smart apartments good clothes, gallery openings... the only British films set against this sort of backdrop tend to be lightweight comedies starring Hugh Grant, which are immediately picketed by Socialist Worker. But wise French film-makers know that smart apartments and good clothes do not automatically condemn the characters that possess them to frothy plots involving farcical weddings, or runaway Hollywood stars. The French understand that some bourgeois window-dressing does not preclude the possibility of edgy human drama.

In All Innocence, adapted from a novel by Georges Simenon, is the latest addition to the genre. It's about Cecile, a scrubberish teenager (played by Virginie Ledoyen), and the effect she has on a smart Parisian lawyer (Gérard Lanvin). So far, so May to December. But thanks to Carole Bouquet, who plays the lawyer's wife Viviane, an extra dimension is added.

If one scene sticks in your head afterwards, it will be the scene in which Viviane - who at the beginning of the movie is coolly, wryly indulgent of her husband's interest in the girl - recognises that her 18-year marriage is over. Perhaps my view has been unfairly influenced by Bouquet's other role as a 'face' of Chanel, or by her stint as a Bond girl, but she is astonishing in this scene: raw, untethered, and terribly disturbing.

Bouquet, 42, is much heartier in person than you might imagine from her gallery of reserved, porcelain-pale roles. 'My characters always start well in movies,' she says, in her energetic and idiosyncratic English, her long gold earrings pirouetting with every shrug.

'Almost every movie I've done starts with a happy marriage, it's all beautiful, wealthy, whatever... and then of course my husband leaves me, and everything falls apart.' She laughs, boisterously. 'They've been doing it to me for 20 years.'

Perhaps the most memorable example came in Trop Belle Pour Toi, when she played Gérard Depardieu's impossibly beautiful wife. In the end, alienated by her perfection, the Depardieu character runs off with his fat secretary. 'I didn't give a damn, I was just loving it. Three films a day. I was so bored at that time. Dreaming, dreaming, all the time, of how life could be. Through those years, it was movies who taught me things. Most of it was very good wisdom, to tell you the truth, because that's what you have in movies. Most of them are very moral, in fact. And they're about dreams coming true, which is always good for a teenager: "Yes, it is possible." '

Perhaps because of this, she seems to have a very straightforward approach to fame. It means that politicians pay attention when she campaigns for children's rights, and 'it gets me a table in a restaurant when I want it, for Christ's sake'.

Years ago, when she was pregnant with her second son, strangers with machine guns broke into her apartment. 'They were asking for the jewels that they'd seen me wearing on the cover of a magazine. I think they were expecting a Visconti house, with gold dripping from the ceiling. I started to argue with them. I was trying to explain that it was not me. "It's my work! I pretend!" '

Similarly, she does not begrudge people who stare, or pore over fuzzy photographs of her in Paris-Match: she understands the impulse only too well. For that reason, she likes London. There are fewer curtains here. 'At night, I love to look in the houses. When I was little, I did that much more, when I was so bored. It might be awful in those houses, of course, but I still speculate about them in a romantic way. It's the same if you are famous: you are in the light, and most people have fantasies about you, but these fantasies have nothing to do with reality.'

 In All Innocence opens on Friday

fields.headline: My fellow Un-Americans
fields.standfirst: Tim Robbins promotes the overthrow of capitalism with help from Orson Welles and a Mexican revolutionary
fields.trailText: Philip French: Exhilarating... entertaining ...Robbins works on as vast a canvas as Rivera's tendentious political mural, and with a comparably sharp, visual shorthand, caricaturing and glorifying in a similarly provocative manner
fields.body:
Orson Welles began creating his own legend as a teenage genius and since his death it has been further burnished by biographers and filmmakers. He appeared as a tutelary figure in Tim Burton's Ed Wood . There has been a TV movie built around his notorious 1938 radio version of War of the Worlds that persuaded thousands of listeners that America was being invaded by Martians, and a few months ago there was another TV film about the scandals attendant on his first Hollywood film, Citizen Kane , in 1941.

Now with the exhilarating Cradle Will Rock, Tim Robbins tells what the credits call 'A [Mostly] True Story' about the sensational production of Marc Blitzstein's Brechtian agitprop musical, The Cradle Will Rock, in 1937 by the federally subsidised theatre company called Project 891 that Welles and John Houseman ran in New York. It's for people who wince at the implications of the phrase 'he's history'.

The film is a sort of dialectical mosaic that attempts to do for the 1930s what E.L. Doctorow's Ragtime did for the decade before the First World War. To achieve this, Robbins brings together three key events of the decade. The first is the commissioning in 1932 by enlightened plutocrat Nelson Rockefeller (John Cusack) of a vast mural for the Rockefeller Center by the revolutionary Mexican artist Diego Rivera (Ruben Blades). In early 1934, before being unveiled, the work known as Man at the Crossroads Looking with Hope and High Vision to the Choosing of a New and Better Future was ground to dust because of its inflammatory radical character, though Rivera later re-created it in Mexico City.

The second event is the appearance in December 1938 of Hallie Flanagan (Cherry Jones), the formidable head of the Federal Theatre, before the newly formed House Committee on Un-American Activities (Huac), a philistine organisation. This hearing, in which Flanagan ran rings around her Red-hunting interrogators, helped bring about the end of federal funding for the arts that had been launched as part of President Roosevelt's New Deal in 1934.

Robbins has moved the Rivera affair ahead in time by three years, and the Huac hearings back by 18 months so that they exactly coincide with the extraordinary first performance of The Cradle Will Rock at a rundown Broadway theatre, the Venice. Project 891's own theatre had been suddenly closed and sealed by security guards following a federal economy drive aimed at radical artists. Because the actors' and musicians' unions refused to sanction a performance elsewhere, Houseman and Welles - in the ultimate realisation of the show-must-go-on ethos - mounted it as a one-man show with the composer Marc Blitzstein (Hank Azaria) at the piano. Members of the cast, wearing rehearsal clothes, gradually joined in from their seats in the audience following the courageous example of the inexperienced young actress Olive Stanton, a figure so amazing and so affectingly played by Emily Watson that one might suppose that Robbins invented her. He did not.

Robbins works on as vast a canvas as Rivera's tendentious political mural, and with a comparably sharp, visual shorthand, caricaturing and glorifying in a similarly provocative manner. Rockefeller, Hearst and their oligarchic circle, buying up Old Masters, encouraging Nazis and fascists as a bulwark against communism, scheming to prevent a second American Revolution, are mocked.

Hallie Flanagan, the sane non-communist with a vision of creating a genuine national theatre, is the heroine of the piece, along with Olive Stanton and an anti-fascist Italian-American actor played by John Turturro. Somewhere in between, the haughty Houseman (Cary Elwes) product of an English public school, and the histrionic Welles (Angus MacFadyen), in search of glory, are treated with a gentle humour.

Over dinner at a fashionable restaurant after rehearsing a gritty musical about the overthrow of capitalism, the pair bicker like a married couple. Blitzstein's mentor, Bertolt Brecht, has a walk-on part, appearing in the composer's imagination to criticise and advise, and there is a touching, presumably fictitious character, an alcoholic vaudeville ventriloquist played brilliantly by Bill Murray, whose dummy takes over from him, making left-wing jokes and singing the 'Internationale'. The Huac politicians are given the rope of their official transcript with which to hang themselves.

Cradle Will Rock closes with an image of the tame, unchallenging, neon-lit Times Square of today. It opens with a wonderful sequence announcing both a new dawn and a backstage story set against the background of a turbulent era.

First seen stretched out behind a cinema screen, the homeless, unemployed Olive Stanton is literally awoken from sleep and figuratively awakened to politics. As she dresses, a newsreel carries items about the Italian invasion of Abyssinia, the Nazis' exhibition of Decadent Art in Germany, Roosevelt opening a dam as part of the Tennessee Valley Authority, a fashion parade in Florida. Going out into the world, she washes her face at a fire hydrant as the camera pans up to the apartment where Blitzstein is struggling with his opera.

The movie continues with a similar fluidity, cutting between its different narrative strands, introducing a vast array of people, vividly recreating a point in American life as the Depression is moving into the pre-war era. It's a time of hope and despair and the movie's final sequence cuts between a mock funeral, a theatrical celebration, and a party of capitalists in fancy dress discussing how to hang on to power.

In an entertaining, if at times simplified manner (Robbins makes too light of communism), the picture examines the relationship between art and society. It dramatises the tug creative people feel between their need to adopt adversarial positions and the wish to be part of the community; and it confronts the perennial problem of pipers having to give account to those who pay for the tunes.

fields.headline: When they talk, Spielberg listens
fields.standfirst: Kathleen Kennedy and her husband Frank Marshall have produced plenty of blockbusters - from  ET to  The Sixth Sense. So what, asks  Akin Ojumu,  makes them dislike the Hollywood system  so much?
fields.trailText: Kathleen Kennedy and her husband Frank Marshall have produced plenty of blockbusters - from E.T. to The Sixth Sense. So what, asks Akin Ojumu, makes them dislike the Hollywood system so much?
fields.body:
You've probably never heard of Kathleen Kennedy and Frank Marshall. But you've certainly seen some of their movies. The husband-and-wife producing team are Steven Spielberg's long-time collaborators. So if you've seen ET, Raiders of the Lost Ark, Back to the Future, Schindler's List or The Sixth Sense, for instance, you're familiar with their work.

In the Seventies they hung out with the Movie Brats, working for the likes of John Milius and Peter Bogdanovich before graduating to become Spielberg's partners. In 1981 Spielberg told 28-year-old Kennedy, then his PA, that she would produce his next movie, a relatively low-budget fantasy about a boy and an alien called ET.

During the Eighties they quietly made enough blockbusters to rival über-producers Don Simpson and Jerry Bruckheimer. The couple left Spielberg's Amblin Entertainment team in 1991, but wisely have kept their association with Hollywood's most successful director.

So are they the only people in Hollywood who can to say no to Spielberg? 'Umm, yeah,' hesitates Kennedy. 'I don't look at it as saying no. The producer is there to create the director's vision...' Marshall says: 'Everyone needs a sounding board, a person you can trust and whose opinions you can trust.'

Today, if this personable middle-aged couple, who finish each other's sentences, return your calls, you must be a player.

'At first people expected and offered us similar blockbuster movies to the ones we had made with Steven, but we were not interested in trying to make the same movie over and over again,' says Kennedy. 'It's still difficult for us to raise the money. I think it's easy to get backing for an $80 million tentpole movie than a $8m small one.' The pair have gravitated towards 'riskier' films of late, but balance their slate. Next year Kennedy will take charge of Jurassic Park 3, while Marshall will direct his fourth film, an action-adventure film called The Expendables - ' Dirty Dozen under the sea'. But the project that will keep Internet chat rooms buzzing is AI, the Kubrick sci-fi project that Spielberg will now head and Kennedy produce.

The Sixth Sense 's Haley Joel Osment and Jude Law have signed up and Kennedy is excited. 'It's going to be a very interesting kind of collaboration. Stanley commissioned a load of artwork to design the look of the film and Steven will use that. Their vision of the film was very similar and they did correspond a lot. I remember when we were shooting Indiana Jones and The Temple of Doom 15 years ago and Stanley was really impressed by Steven's ideas about the film.'

Last year they pulled off the classic double - huge grosses and Oscar nominations for The Sixth Sense . Writer-director M. Night Shyamalan's clever script was one of the most sought-after in town. But he decided to go with Kennedy-Marshall because he grew up on their films.

'Night told us he had posters on the wall of his office from ET and Raiders . He said he always wanted to work with the people with their names on those posters.' They didn't win any Oscars but Bruce Cohen, a protégé and godfather to their daughter, produced American Beauty. 'We knew we had no chance but it was nice to keep it in the family,' says Marshall. In London to attend the Baftas ceremony they saw their rival triumph again. However, the morning after they're only upset because presenter Jack Docherty revealed the surprise ending to The Sixth Sense.

They're unhappy too about the fate of their latest film, Snow Falling on Cedars , a deliberately paced drama set during a shameful period of US history, the internment of Japanese-Americans during the Second World War. Directed by Scott Hicks (Shine) and starring Ethan Hawke, it got lukewarm reviews and its US box-office failure clearly rankles. 'The film never got a chance. It didn't catch on in the first weekend and so it didn't stay long enough in the cinemas,' says Marshall. 'These days it's like an election. You know the morning after whether you've won or not.'

An ambivalent attitude towards Hollywood emerges. They feel at odds with the establishment to which they obviously belong. They speak of a new breed of executives who number crunch but don't recognise references to classic movies.

'These days movies are made by people who don't really like films,' says Kennedy. 'It can be very depressing.' Ironically, the type of blockbuster films they are famous for are often blamed for the decline in Hollywood's standards. Their response? 'I don't know how to evaluate that criticism,' laughs Kennedy. 'People like to look at all different kinds of movies,' says Marshall. 'People want to go and be entertained so there is room for both Raiders and American Beauty .

'They are all different kinds of movies, but whatever we do I want to make movies that people go and see.'

 Snow Falling on Cedars opens on 12 May

fields.headline: Apocalypse then
fields.standfirst: A quarter-century after the end of the Vietnam War, three American film documentaries explore its complex legacy. Report by  Kurt Jacobsen
fields.trailText: A quarter-century after the end of the Vietnam War, three American film documentaries explore its complex legacy. Report by Kurt Jacobsen
fields.body:
The final frenetic scenes of the Vietnam War were branded in public memory a quarter of a century ago when a daisy chain of helicopters ferried frantic refugees from the American Embassy rooftop in Saigon to aircraft carriers bobbing in the South China Sea. On 30 April, a few hours after the last chopper fled, North Vietnamese tanks crashed the Presidential Palace gates and seized what was left of a terribly mutilated but reunited country. In the US the twenty-fifth anniversary of the fall of Saigon might be slipping by quietly in official circles. But documentary film-makers have certainly been paying attention.

Three fine new documentaries neatly illustrate the range of views that the war now provokes. Return With Honor , bankrolled by arms contractor Boeing-McDonnell, celebrates 'top guns' who literally were above it all until a flak burst or missile picked them off. 'We were flying Sir Lancelots,' one rueful pilot muses. 'All of a sudden you're not that any more and you're scared.' The film-makers opted to tell the saga based on 'the PoWs' mindset at the time,' which was (and is) staunchly militaristic. Yet Return reverberates with stunning little ironies.

Navy pilot Everett Alvarez debunks the 1964 Tonkin Gulf incident (which triggered US escalation), attesting that he was in the air and saw no torpedo boats attacking US vessels, as was claimed. Soon, in an undeclared war, Alvarez found himself captured, labelled a criminal and under torture for eight and a half years.

Such experiences did not foster dissent. As film-maker Terry Sanders explains, captivity was hardly the time for macho officers to re-examine whether America ought to be there: 'If the President said to do this or that, then that was the thing to do.' So US fliers, who come across as brave and sincere, endured excruciating cruelties to force them to say far less, as one resentfully remarks, than sceptical politicians were saying out loud at home. (Some startled PoWs would discover on release that even their families had turned against the war.) The film-makers' decision to embrace the PoWs' point of view pays off with a claustrophobically intense narrative.

Conduct was no daintier down South. Vietcong captives were shoved out of helicopters without parachutes and tens of thousands of political prisoners suffered gruesomely at the hands of the corrupt regime. In Regret To Inform, a Vietnamese survivor attests that in the mangled multitude of free-fire zones: 'If you were not dead, you were not safe.' Another Vietnamese widow remembers her shock at her family home being obliterated by bombs, her six-year-old cousin killed by a nervous US soldier (and the soldier's horrified expression), and her self-hating bar-girl life afterwards. Writer-director Barbara Sonneborn, on her mournful but gripping train journey across Vietnam, explores 'the point of view of Vietnam war widows from both sides of the conflict' in hope of prying further open her audience's compassion.

Vietnam is not just a war but a country and a beautiful one at that. In Vietnam - Long Time Coming , the task that the makers of Hoop Dreams, the documentary about aspiring basketball players, set themselves was to show how jittery veterans come to terms with this emotionally healing fact. The documentary tracks US and Vietnamese war veterans pedalling bicycles (for the intact), hand cycles (for paraplegics) and tandem bikes (for the blind) 1,200 miles from Hanoi to the city formerly known as Saigon. 'It could have been worse,' a grinning vet remarks. 'Someone could have been shooting at us.'

For army nurse Diane Evans, the airliner's descent into Hanoi evoked 'the same gut-wrenching feeling as when I first flew into Tan Son Nhut 30 years ago. Vietnam was like a year-long hallucination.' This time the passengers were greeted by pretty girls offering flowers. 'It was the perfect gesture,' said Jerry Stadtmiller, a blinded ex-Marine. 'The [flower] gave me something to hold, other than my white cane. When you first came here you were handed an M-16.'

The party visit a school, a hospital and Hanoi's tomb of the unknown soldier. 'We discussed the wreath [for the tomb] beforehand,' said Wade Sanders, who commanded a Swift Boat on the Mekong River in 1968-69 and later was Assistant Secretary of the Navy. 'We had no problem doing it in the spirit of veteran honouring veteran.'

Pigeonholing vets such as Sanders is a perilous enterprise. In a seemingly strident screen moment he states that he was not ashamed of anything he did in Vietnam. So is he a rabid hawk ? 'I didn't approve of the war,' Sanders, who is running for a congressional seat in San Diego, says. 'I was saying that I didn't do anything I was ashamed of. Everyone I killed was trying to kill me.' As for the legacy of Vietnam, Evans said the government, 'sent 18- and 19-year-olds to Vietnam and it mistreated them after the war. I think it's unhealthy and harmful to trust your government. You should always question their agenda and their decisions. We were led like sheep in the 1960s.'

Kartemquin films, makers of Long Time Coming, hope their documentary will be shown in secondary schools and 'open up space for students to ask relatives who were Vietnam vets about how they felt'. 'There is a certain way society has processed this hero stuff so that the people, who are much more complex, felt constricted about how they expressed how they really felt about it,' Gordon Quinn, founder of Kartemquin, notes. 'We go to war so lightly. Before Clinton bombs Iraq or Serbia or any place else he ought to stand in front of the Vietnam memorial wall in Washington. It's a very powerful place.'

 The three documentaries will preview at film festivals later this year.

webTitle: Ewen Bremner of Trainspotting fame emerges as an unlikely hero

fields.headline: Ewen Bremner of Trainspotting fame emerges as an unlikely hero
fields.trailText: Ewen Bremner of Trainspotting fame emerges as an unlikely hero
fields.body:
'I'd love to do a normal character,' Ewen Bremner once confessed. Who could blame him? At the time he was probably tired of the freaks and geeks that populated his CV. Since he played the hapless Spud in Trainspotting, typecasting has been a bit of an issue for an actor who invariably looks in need of a sunny holiday and a square meal.

He probably jumped at the chance to play the hero - albeit unconventional - in Channel 4's The Secret Life of Michael Fry , a beguiling two-part drama by Paul Abbott who, following recent successes including Clocking Off , has emerged as a formidable TV dramatist.

Bremner reluctantly ditched his native Edinburgh accent to play a naïve town planner in a small Welsh seaside town. A timid single parent in love with an Internet porn actress, Michael Fry becomes an impassioned crusader when he discovers corruption in the localcouncil.

The small town dystopia familiar in David Lynch films is revisited here to good effect.

Bremner, though, will remain best known for Trainspotting . Especially for those Elton John specs and the unforgettable scene when he accidentally flings an excrement stained bedsheet at his soon-to-be ex-girlfriend's parents over breakfast. Earlier, Bremner had played Renton in the stage play of Irving Welsh's novel and, though Ewan McGregor won the lead in the film, Bremner had impressed enough on stage to win a part. Post Trainspotting , the shy and introspective Bremner ignored the hype and opportunities, instead taking a year off to decide whether to continue acting.

Bremner was first spotted at 17 when a theatre workshop play he appeared in transferred to the Royal Court in London.

An agent thought he could have a bright future and recommended he moved to the capital. After a succession of failed auditions he started getting film roles. He appeared in Naked and Judge Dredd before the call came to head back north for Trainspotting .

After Trainspotting he appeared in hyped Brit-flicks such as The Acid House and Mojo , which failed to catch fire.

When indie renegade Harmony Korine wanted a schizophrenic for his Dogma 95 movie julien donkey-bo y, he instinctively turned to Bremner. For an actor who glimpsed the zeitgeist in 1996, he has been conspicuously absent from headline making films until recently.

Last year he snagged a key role in Snatch , Guy Ritchie's forthcoming follow-up to Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels . Now he has signed up to play Ben Affleck's pal in the $145 million Second World War epic Pearl Harbor . The director is Michael Bay ( Armageddon ), whose movies epitomise Hollywood bombast.

Still, he's unlikely to settle in LA - he'd miss his house in south London and probably even pine for the lousy weather. This Brixton Boy is staying put.

Five things you should know about Ewen Bremner

1: A critic called his film The Life of Stuff 'Scotland's goriest movie ever'.
2: On being Scottish: 'I'm not very Scottish. I should be into football, be a big drinker and be patriotic.'
3: After Trainspotting Zoe Ball invited him round to her house for a cup of tea but he refused.
4: His parents are both art teachers.
5: When he isn't working, he spends most of his time at home in his recording studio playing guitar.
