webTitle: Hail the new all-conquering American sport of soccer

fields.headline: Hail the new all-conquering American sport of soccer
fields.trailText: Charting the swift rise of soccer in the US.
fields.body:
In The Simpsons episode The Cartridge Family , in which soccer comes to Springfield and Homer ends up buying a gun, the story opens with a man in a cowboy hat appearing on the Simpsons' TV screen, barbecuing a soccer ball and screaming, 'Open wide for soccer!'

It turns out that the Continental Soccer Association is coming to Springfield. 'It's all here - fast-kicking, low-scoring and ties? You bet!' says the announcer. 'This game will determine once and for all which nation is the greatest on earth: Mexico or Portugal.'

So the Simpsons troop over to Springfield Stadium, where the sign reads: 'Tonight: Soccer, Tomorrow: Monsters of Poetry.' Homer is very excited. 'Oh, I'll kill myself if Portugal doesn't win,' he says. The game starts and one side passes the ball interminably around midfield.

The Hispanic commentator grows hysterical with excitement, but the Springfield crowd is gripped by tedium. To give themselves something to do, people start fighting. Soon there are riots all over town, the mayor declares a state of emergency, and Homer buys a gun.

The episode originally ran in 1997, but was apparently made sometime earlier, and the remarkable thing is how dated it now seems. In the last few years, the game that turned the Simpsons off has invaded American popular culture. Some examples: last year's high school movie She's All That , in which the school hero transforms a geeky girl into the Prom Queen, is traditional except for the fact that the school hero is the soccer captain. In The Sopranos , the TV mafia soap opera, a centrepiece of the plot is a girls' soccer match. In The Simpsons itself, Bart has been revealed as a soccer goalkeeper.

How swift the rise of soccer has been is best illustrated by Matt Damon's recent career. In the 1997 film Good Will Hunting , Damon shoots hoops. Two years later, in Dogma , the only sport mentioned is soccer (Damon, a renegade angel, says it is more exhausting than genocide).

Politics, which in the US is above all a branch the entertainment industry, has also been swamped by soccer. This began at the 1996 election,where the main debate was about which way the Soc cer Moms would vote, and peaked last summer when Clinton all but adopted the US women's soccer team. Oscar Goodman, a veteran mafia lawyer, ran for mayor of Las Vegas last year with a television advertisement that showed pictures of his four children, and ended with a shot of Goodman and his wife above the caption: 'We never missed a soccer game.' He was elected.

The strange thing is that while soccer makes its way into TV and the movies, the professional game in the US remains unwatched. On Wednesday I went to see the New York/New Jersey MetroStars play the Kansas City Wizards in Giants Stadium. When I got there, I found Lothar Matthäus, Mo Johnston and the Colombian Adolfo Valencia playing before a crowd of less than 8,000. Yet it is precisely because professional soccer has remained a joke that the sport could conquer America. The Soccer Moms, Oscar Goodman's voters, the kids who watched She's All That, like the fact that soccer is not a big professional game like basketball or American football.

Many Americans are getting fed up with big professional sports. In Britain we think our football stars are spoiled and overpaid because Stan Collymore lets off a fire extinguisher. In America, sports stars murder people. The Moms like soccer, because, in their eyes, it is a little game. It is not violent, not drenched in money, and not very black. Many professional players earn barely enough to keep themselves (to some, the daily allowance on road trips is a godsend), and most of them are middle-class white college boys and girls. That plays well in places like Springfield

And so, amazingly, soccer has become an emblem of America. Twenty years ago, when I was a child in California listening to baseball matches on the radio, that seemed unthinkable. Between innings they used to play an advertising jingle that went, 'Baseball, hot dogs, apple pie and Chevrolet - life the American way!'

Today the equivalent ad would be for Volvo, would probably rhyme 'American way' with 'decaf latte', and would feature soccer.

webTitle: Hapless Celtic gift title to Gers

fields.headline: Hapless Celtic gift title to Gers
fields.trailText: Clearly seeing no reason to kick a well-established habit, Rangers made another league championship triumph official without the need even to remove their jackets.
fields.body:
Clearly seeing no reason to kick a well-established habit, Rangers made another league championship triumph official without the need even to remove their jackets.

Celtic's latest uninspired performance against a contrastingly lively and enterprising Hibs left them 17 points adrift with only five matches remaining. The Ibrox side will travel to St Johnstone tonight purely to party.

Far from evincing the inferiority complex which has marked their previous visits to Celtic Park and Ibrox this season, Hibs spent most of the time imposing a new-found authority on a home side who appeared largely incapable of resistance. It was as though the visitors realised from the start that Celtic's league 'challenge' had been dead for some time and that they could be the latest in a recently formed queue of scavengers to feast on the carcass.

While Celtic invariably impart the impression of players who anticipate victory as a matter of course, teams such as Hibs have long since learned that, in the Premier League - to which they were promoted only at the end of last season - only undiluted commitment and energy will bring rewards. Hibs also lace their endeavours with skill, most notably from Russel Latapy in midfield. The little Trinidadian had already caused some alarm in the home defence by the time the Edinburgh side took the lead.

Curiously, Latapy played no part in the goal, which started with Grant Brebner's pass to Paul Lovering on the left. Lovering's deep cross to the far post was met by Dirk Lehmann, whose header broke from Paul Lambert towards Stuart Lovell, whose lunging header sent the ball over the line from four yards.

Celtic fans continue to be shocked by these develoments but, based on what they have been seeing for weeks and on what had unfolded in the 30 previous minutes of this match, a goal for the visitors should have been the least surprising development of the day. In reply, Celtic had only a misshapen clumsiness to offer, with passes over- or under-hit and crosses aimlessly drifting over the heads of intended recipients.

Lubomir Moravcik and Eyal Berkovic both had good opportunities - Moravcik's venomous left-foot drive curling and dipping just over and Berkovic somehow driving the ball against Nick Colgan with only the goalkeeper to beat - but these were isolated moments during that unimpressive first half. It was not until after Gould had made another good save from Miller's sweetly struck volley that the home side showed anything like the will that was required to retrieve an unpromising situation. There was little marked improvement in their style, but they mustered the effort required finally to break down a resolute Hibs defence, characteristically inspired by veteran John Hughes.

Mjallby began the move with a long ball from defence out to the substitute, Stephen Crainey, on the left and the young full-back quickly nodded the ball into the path of Mahe. The Frenchman strode purposefully past two defenders before rifling a right-foot shot past Colgan from eight yards.

fields.headline: Hearts take a knock
fields.trailText: Hearts and Motherwell both experienced a blow to their Uefa Cup ambitions as they went down 2-1 against Dundee United and Aberdeen respectively.
fields.body:
Hearts and Motherwell both experienced a blow to their Uefa Cup ambitions as they went down 2-1 against Dundee United and Aberdeen respectively.

That Hearts were defeated was particularly hard for them to take for them, given that they were at home and that, at the time Gary Wales gave them a 67th-minute lead, they seemed totally in control. Their failure to translate their superiority into a more emphatic scoreline rebounded on them when Alex Mathie, who has spent much of the season away from United on loan, steered the visitors to victory with two goals in the last 17 minutes. The winner, Mathie's third goal in four days , came three minutes from the end when he raced on to a through-ball from substitute Jim Hamilton and bravely nodded it past the advancing keeper ,Antti Niemi.

In addition to Mathie, United's manager, Paul Sturrock, was also particularly enthusiastic about his veteran midfielder Maurice Malpas. Sturrock said: 'He brought an authority and composure into the midfield. If I could transfer Maurice's brain into the other players I would have some side.'

Aberdeen owed their win over Motherwell to a late headed goal by Thomas Sjolberg. Andy Dow had put the Dons ahead on 31 minutes, only to see Ged Brannan equalise from the spot after Don Goodman had been bundled off the ball by Russell Anderson.

But after a poor start to the second half, the home side gradually took over and were rewarded with Solberg's winner from Andy Dow's free-kick. Aberdeen's manager, Ebbe Skovdahl, said: 'We have been unlucky in the last couple of games we have played so it was good to have the belief to come back and it was nice to do the same as what's been done to us. '

Kilmarnock also won 2-1, at Dundee, courtesy of two goals - including a debatable penalty - from Paul Wright. Dundee's manager, Jocky Scott, said: 'Both goals were soft and I felt we caused our own problems rather than them causing us problems.'

fields.headline: Advocaat's leaf from Fergie's chequebook
fields.trailText: Among managers of relentless ambition, the constant quest for progress is never likely to be satisfied by the mere winning of a championship. As Sir Alex Ferguson demonstrated with his £16.5 million capture of Ruud van Nistelrooy from PSV last Thursday night, even six titles in eight seasons is not sufficient to extinguish the flame.
fields.body:
Among managers of relentless ambition, the constant quest for progress is never likely to be satisfied by the mere winning of a championship. As Sir Alex Ferguson demonstrated with his £16.5 million capture of Ruud van Nistelrooy from PSV last Thursday night, even six titles in eight seasons is not sufficient to extinguish the flame.

Manchester United's reason for investing in the 23-year-old Dutch striker at a time when most observers would have thought Ferguson should be paying attention to his defence is an indicator of his capacity for looking into the future and preparing the ground for challenges yet to come - and to be repelled.

Ferguson is aware that Teddy Sheringham is 34 and unlikely to remain at Old Trafford beyond this season and that Andy Cole and Dwight Yorke are both approaching 29. Young strikers of international quality are a very rare commodity and Ferguson, with his plunge, has ensured that the strength of a crucial position in the team has been secured for some years - beyond, even, his own retirement in 2002.

In the past decade, Rangers have been even more prolific than the English champions, but their 11 league triumphs from the last 12 are virtually meaningless in terms of Dick Advocaat's unremitting search for improvement. Having secured two in succession, the Dutchman, like Ferguson, gives the impression that he will consider himself a failure if he has not extended the sequence to four by the time his present contract expires, also in 2002. And, in common with his counterpart at Old Trafford, Advocaat considers performances and achievement in the most demanding competition of all, the Champions League, to be the true gauge of progress.

Whatever tinkering he brings to his squad in the summer - and, with a new rights issue in the offing, he is expected to be put in possession of funds - will be carried out with advancement in Europe uppermost in his mind. A serious challenge in the domestic game is difficult to envisage; even if Celtic do secure Advocaat's compatriot, Guus Hiddink, as their new head coach, the latter will have to achieve an utterly exceptional regeneration at Parkhead if the gap that exists between them and the champions is even to be narrowed, far less closed, in his first season.

Advocaat has already secured the Scotland forward, Allan Johnston, on a pre-contract agreement and has concluded an arrangement with AZ Alkmaar to take their full-back, Fernando Ricksen, to Ibrox for £3.5 million at the end of the season. One or two others will follow and some players will certainly be jettisoned as the manager keeps faith with his obsession.

Curiously, Advocaat seemed uncharacteristically pleased on Friday, when he reflected on the past year and the strides Rangers have made under his stewardship. He has good reason, having done an extraordinary job since succeeding Walter Smith in 1998. When he arrived, the championship had gone to Celtic Park. But, within a year, Rangers had not only retrieved it, but had begun to pull away once again from their most serious rivals.

'Where I think real progress has been made,' said Advocaat, 'is that we now have players who can come in and do a good job when others are injured. At various times throughout the season, we have been missing quite a number of first-team regulars.

'Michael Mols, of course, was out the longest, but we also at one point were without three of our first-choice back four and the deputies kept the momentum going. There has also been improvement in individual players and that is always satisfying. Barry Ferguson, Tony Vidmar and Craig Moore would come into that category.'

The huge turnover in personnel during his first season left some people with the impression that Advocaat was quite cavalier in the matter of spending his chair man's money, but he is, in fact, very mindful of the need to buy wisely. He even owned up to having made mistakes in that direction, most notably with the £4 million purchase of the Argentine striker, Gabriel Amato, from Real Mallorca. He was sold to Gremio of Brazil in January.

'It wasn't that Amato was a poor player, simply that he wasn't suited to the game here,' he explained. 'That happens, but you've no way of knowing it until they're here. Amato is apparently doing very well in Brazil and I'm not surprised. He just wasn't made for the British game. But you have to be careful that you don't waste money.'

Not many of his signings could be said to have been failures (even the most expensive of all, Andrei Kanchelskis, has begun to show some form), but he is clearly now at the stage of recruiting players of a standard that will take Rangers beyond the first group phase of next season's Champions League.

Even while considering his side a little unlucky to have finished behind Valencia and Bayern Munich in their section in December, he is realistic enough to acknowledge that Rangers were a little short of quality. 'That was a tough group and we outplayed PSV at Ibrox and beat them in Eindhoven,' he said. 'We also outplayed Bayern for much of the time both home and away, but nonetheless went out to them. It was experience, a case of quality. We have to get to that point of knowing how to do what must be done to take you to the next stage.'

fields.headline: United by a common cause
fields.trailText: It's time to reassess our attitude to Manchester United.
fields.body:
When Manchester United played Benfica at Wembley in the European Cup final in 1968 I was just a kid but I do remember supporting Benfica because they could preserve Tottenham's record of being the only English club to have won a European trophy. As a slightly more mature adult, last year I watched United in the European Champions League final and wanted them to win because I liked their style.

This week, along with millions of others I watched Real Madrid tear United to pieces and to be honest, while I started out wanting United to win, in the end I was happy that the better side went through.

United completely failed to adapt to Real's tactics and Gary Neville played like a Spurs defender on a bad day. It also seemed that the Old Trafford fans knew that they were going to lose because at first you could hear the rustle of crisp packets above the singing. It was only at the end, when they knew they were defeated, that they really got going. Contrast that with the atmosphere the night before in the Nou Camp where the Catalans willed their team to victory over a shell-shocked Chelsea.

What actually turned me and million of others against United was the booing of Steve McManaman every time he touched the ball. This, we assume, was because he comes from Liverpool. You might have thought that since United have completely overshadowed Liverpool over the past few years McManaman would be ignored. Not at all.

The United fans still have a chip on their shoulder when it comes to Liverpool. They know deep down that Liverpool's record in Europe is far better than theirs.

Manchester United may be out of Europe but now they have won the Premiership yet again I think it's time to reassess our attitude to them. I have reassessed mine: I simply don't care about them any more. They are on a different planet to the rest of England's teams, but you have to say it's not their fault they are more ambitious than half a dozen other clubs put together. No other club could afford to spend more than £30 million on summer signings, but it looks as though that's what they're going to do.

They already have easily the best team in the country and when they add Ruud van Nistelrooy from PSV and Sol Campbell from Spurs, as they undoubtedly will, they will be even better (and at last they'll have someone half-decent to play alongside Jaap Stam). I can't even dislike United for taking the best player from the team I love. You can't blame United for having ambition. You can only blame the Spurs management for having none.

When Spurs beat United at White Hart Lane this season we enjoyed laughing at our United-supporting mates in the pub afterwards. I thought: 'This is the highlight of the season.' I know that's pathetic, especially as we beat Arsenal too, but now I think, so what? It didn't do Spurs any good and United have won the league at a canter.

Manchester United will win the title again next season and, like this one, the only interest will be in who can qualify for the Champions League behind them. But if United can't get to the final what chance do the other British teams have?

webTitle: On the golden trail of Brazil's Michelangelo

fields.headline: On the golden trail of Brazil's Michelangelo
fields.standfirst: Daniel Whitaker  visits the mountain  churches where Aleijadinho, 'the little cripple' struck by leprosy, created works of genius in stone
fields.trailText: Daniel Whitaker visits the mountain churches where Aleijadinho, 'the little cripple' struck by leprosy, created works of genius in stone
fields.body:
I drove through a heavy mist up into the Espinhaço mountains in search of what Aleijadinho - the 'Brazilian Michelangelo' - had left behind. Most people are drawn towards these blue-tinged peaks for what they can dig out of them. It was profits from one of the world's richest gold strikes here that financed Aleijadinho's acclaimed sculptures. And two centuries later, mining still dominates life in this Brazilian state, as big as France, whose name, Minas Gerais, means 'General Mines'.

But I was pulled here by Aleijadinho's life story. I had heard it was 'perfectly South American', which I took to mean both heroic and tragic, but never far from surreal.

The same outpouring of gold had created my first destination, his birthplace: Ouro Preto (black gold), a town which began as a lawless mining camp, clinging to the steep rocks which held the metal.

Ouro Preto's miners set high standards in quaffing the national firewater, cachaça , scrapping with cutlasses and lusting after the Western Hemisphere's greatest congregation of prostitutes. But afterwards they fell on their knees before God, with a devotion that echoes in Brazilians today.

The miners formed brotherhoods, competing to commission the most spectacular church. Artists heard the call of patronage and flocked from all points of the compass to create barroco mineiro style - creamy white exteriors, the churches framed by twin bell towers and filled with a lavish explosion of gilded decor. Ouro Preto blossomed into a baroque architectural feast.

Three centuries later, Ouro Preto is still clinging on, and is so perfectly preserved that the United Nations has named it a site of World Cultural Heritage. Inevitably, the seams that for decades gave the world half its new gold ran dry. The population slumped from more than 100,000 (then twice the size of New York) to 20,000. But back in the Thirties the Brazilian President, knowing a national monument when he saw one, ordered that nothing be touched.

Its time-frozen appearance and its people's quiet demeanour make this a Brazil far from Copacabana beach or the Amazon, a reminder of how varied this vast country is. Not just Ouro Preto, but any of the three neighbouring colonial towns - Mariana, Sabará or Congonhas - are well worth the journey of between five and six hours by car or bus from Rio or São Paulo. Or you could trust yourself to taxi driver, Fatimo Valerio, who told me: 'Give me four hours and you will arrive rested and content.'

Rudely peeling bells woke me the next day, but the compensation was a view of Our Lady of Carmo, a church where Aleijadinho spent 40 years adding touches such as the lined face of St Simon transfixed by celestial ecstasy.

I was a guest at the Pouso do Chico Rei, a small eighteenth century guesthouse, where a night in a room with original furnishings and a severely sloping floor costs about £35. You may also make friends in the shared bathroom and practise your Portuguese, as both Elba, the 93-year-old owner, and her assistants, pride themselves in not speaking any foreign languages.

Luckily, they spoke slowly enough to give me the basic elements of the story of Ouro Preto's most famous son. Aleijadinho means 'the little cripple'. He was born as António Francisco Lisboa to a Portuguese mason and a black slave woman some time around 1730.

Leprosy struck him as a young man, 'but this didn't shake him in his faith - he knew God wanted him to sculpt', Elba's cook, Janete, told me, in a matter-of-fact way that suggested everyone should have such a sense of vocation. When the affliction claimed his toes and the use of his legs, he demanded to be wheeled on a wooden trolley into the churches where he worked. When it took his fingers, he had his tools strapped to his wrists.

Aleijadinho was f&234;ted and in spite of his low birth his work commanded enormous fees. But when the gold ran out, Brazil's Michelangelo declined alongside his town, eventually dying in the tradition of great artists, penniless and blind. He is buried a few yards from where he was born, a simple headstone by the altar in Conceição church.

That evening I wandered off into the steeply cobbled streets, perfumed by wood smoke, in search of entertainment. Ouro Preto is quiet, apart from the barking dog that seems to inhabit every South American small town. But I discovered that it is in fact home to several thousand students from the national mining university.

In tucked away basement bars, the devotees of the Escola de Minas couldn't have been friendlier. Over cachaça, they relished trying out their English on me, inquired after our coal mines and told me a story to rival Aleijadinho for magical realism. It was the tale of Chico Rei, after whom Elba named her guesthouse, the king of an African tribe sold in its entirety as slaves to an Ouro Preto mine owner.

With Chico Rei as foreman, the tribe eventually amassed enough gold to purchase their freedom. The official version puts the amassing down to the mine owner paying out minuscule bonuses, which they saved over many years. 'Not true,' said João, a 22-year-old would-be mining engineer from nearby Belo Horizonte, emphatically. 'The female miners kept gold dust in their hair, and later washed it out for Chico Rei.'

Chico's people went on to buy the Encardadeira mine, struck a lucky seam and soon enjoyed their own fountain of wealth. The mine can still be visited, but João's friend Dorotea warned: 'The roof may fall sometimes and there are also problems with ghosts.'

The tribe gave thanks for their fortune by building a church dedicated to Efigênia, a Nubian queen. (Checking up on the story the next morning I ducked into Santa Efigênia's dimly lit interior, and picked out wooden carvings of African-looking fauna, before noticing that I was being watched over by a smiling black pope from the ceiling.)

But by reverting to African dress and customs, Chico's tribe outraged the King of Portugal so much that he prohibited slaves from buying their freedom. Chico Rei is still a folk hero to poor Brazilian blacks today.

The following day I set off on the meandering 20 miles to the town of Congonhas, hoping to see Aleijadinho's most famous work, the Twelve Prophets . In a reverse of anywhere else, while the old gold towns are stopped in time, the countryside rushes towards 'progress'.

Today's mining is the strip version, ripping giant chunks of iron-laden red earth out of the hillside. Stopping for a view of the carnage, I met Gilberto Ribeiro, a stocky ex-miner in his forties. 'These mountains will have disappeared in 20 years,' he said, while we watched hand-painted lorries groaning under the weight of their ore.

I thought that might be an exaggeration, but that was no reason not to hear some of Gilberto's mining tales over mineira cooking, which was delivered to us with quiet mountain cordiality at a roadside stall. The cuisine has the weight of high-altitude food, but thankfully includes tasty indigenous vegetables such as spinach-like couve and quiabe beans. Vegetarians should not experiment with feijão tropeiro (mule drivers' black beans), which may be livened up with pigs' ears, tails and snouts.

'I worked on a smaller scale, chasing topaz with my pick,' Gilberto recounted, 'never dynamite - I've lost too many friends through accidents.' What Gilberto chased most was imperial topaz, which he was pleased to tell me could only be found here or in a town in Russia whose name was 'too hard to pronounce'.

But he had no Chico Rei stories of good fortune. 'In my mining days I never knew anyone who started poor and ended up other than equally poor or injured.' Now he is happier working in construction.

Gilberto's new trade is booming. One new development, not far from the stall where we ate, showed more of the changing face of Minas Gerais. Alphaville is an enclave of identical modern houses behind a high wall and a bored armed guard. The rich no longer try to spend their way into public respect or heavenly entrance, as in the days when they poured fabulous sums into putting up Ouro Preto's 32 churches, the colonial sobrado mansions of Mariana or the grandeur of Sabará's opera house.

They won't be likely to encourage another Aleijadinho, preferring their culture to come on satellite television or shopping trips to Miami. At Congonhas the morning clouds departed the sky on cue to reveal Aleijadinho's Twelve Prophets, standing guard life-size outside the deserted Bom Jesus de Matozinhos church.

In fact these figures, staring menacingly out over a broad valley, have faces not from the Old Testament but those of a band of mineiros that rebelled against Portuguese rule in Aleijadinho's time, for which they were all beheaded or exiled. Their leader was Tiradentes ('the Toothpuller'), commemorated as a patriot with a grand column in Ouro Preto's main square.

The rebel resemblances don't deter the half a million Catholic pilgrims who trek to Bom Jesus in the second week of every September to make promises and do penance. Finally meeting the Prophets after generous helpings of rebellion stories back at Ouro Preto and with my Old Testament knowledge a little hazy, for me the link with the toothpuller actually improved them.

All 12 carry messages, six of love, six of threat. They are eerily alive, petrified in mid-rant but still quite able to instil the fear of something like God into those who view them. At the same time, misspelled Latin phrases (taught to Aleijadinho by a local ex-Jesuit bandit) seem for some reason to breathe more life into their making.

The Prophets were cut by Aleijadinho when his leprosy was at its worst. Records say the pain was so severe that the sculptor would sometimes hack away at the offending limb with his chisel until his loyal assistants stayed his hand.

We can only be grateful for his perseverance, fuelled by his Bible and anatomy books and by the effect that these mountains seem to have in driving people to extremes. Perhaps it was the altitude, but I found that, despite all I heard beforehand, the grace, realism and power of what remains of Aleijadinho's creations does indeed still take the breath away. They are certainly right for this land of greed and faith.

Fact file

Getting there: BA (0345 222111) return fares from £429; Varig (020 7287 1414) to Belo Horizonte via São Paulo starts at £715. Trailfinders (020 7938 3939) has fares from £299 with Aerolíneas Argentinas via Madrid. STA Travel (020 7361 6185) has a return of £383 in June on TAP, via Lisbon.

Visas: Britons don't require visas.

Internal connections: VASP and Tram Meridional fly from Rio and São Paulo to Belo Horizonte; from £203 if booked from the UK, less in Brazil. A bus from Rio to Ouro Preto takes seven hours and costs around £9.50

Staying in Ouro Preto: Pouso Chico Rei (address: Rua Brigadeiro Mosqueira, 90; 00 55 31 551 1274) from £35 B&B per night. For luxury-lovers: the colonial Pousada do Mondego (address: Largo de Coimbra, 38; 00 55 31 551 2040) from £47.

Not just Ouro Preto, but any of the three neighbouring colonial towns - Mariana, Sabará or Congonhas - are well worth the journey of between five and six hours by car or bus from Rio or São Paulo. Or you could trust yourself to taxi driver, Fatimo Valerio, who told me: 'Give me four hours and you will arrive rested and content.' Rudely peeling bells woke me the next day, but the compensation was a view of Our Lady of Carmo, a church where Aleijadinho spent 40 years adding touches such as the lined face of St Simon transfixed by celestial ecstasy. I was a guest at the Pouso do Chico Rei, a small eighteenth century guesthouse, where a night in a room with original furnishings and a severely sloping floor costs about £35. You may also make friends in the shared bathroom and practise your Portuguese, as both Elba, the 93-year-old owner, and her assistants, pride themselves in not speaking any foreign languages. Luckily, they spoke slowly enough to give me the basic elements of the story of Ouro Preto's most famous son. Aleijadinho means 'the little cripple'. He was born as António Francisco Lisboa to a Portuguese mason and a black slave woman some time around 1730. Leprosy struck him as a young man, 'but this didn't shake him in his faith - he knew God wanted him to sculpt', Elba's cook, Janete, told me, in a matter-of-fact way that suggested everyone should have such a sense of vocation. When the affliction claimed his toes and the use of his legs, he demanded to be wheeled on a wooden trolley into the churches where he worked. When it took his fingers, he had his tools strapped to his wrists. Aleijadinho was f&234;ted and in spite of his low birth his work commanded enormous fees. But when the gold ran out, Brazil's Michelangelo declined alongside his town, eventually dying in the tradition of great artists, penniless and blind. He is buried a few yards from where he was born, a simple headstone by the altar in Conceição church. That evening I wandered off into the steeply cobbled streets, perfumed by wood smoke, in search of entertainment. Ouro Preto is quiet, apart from the barking dog that seems to inhabit every South American small town. But I discovered that it is in fact home to several thousand students from the national mining university. In tucked away basement bars, the devotees of the Escola de Minas couldn't have been friendlier. Over cachaça, they relished trying out their English on me, inquired after our coal mines and told me a story to rival Aleijadinho for magical realism. It was the tale of Chico Rei, after whom Elba named her guesthouse, the king of an African tribe sold in its entirety as slaves to an Ouro Preto mine owner. With Chico Rei as foreman, the tribe eventually amassed enough gold to purchase their freedom. The official version puts the amassing down to the mine owner paying out minuscule bonuses, which they saved over many years. 'Not true,' said João, a 22-year-old would-be mining engineer from nearby Belo Horizonte, emphatically. 'The female miners kept gold dust in their hair, and later washed it out for Chico Rei.' Chico's people went on to buy the Encardadeira mine, struck a lucky seam and soon enjoyed their own fountain of wealth. The mine can still be visited, but João's friend Dorotea warned: 'The roof may fall sometimes and there are also problems with ghosts.' The tribe gave thanks for their fortune by building a church dedicated to Efigênia, a Nubian queen. (Checking up on the story the next morning I ducked into Santa Efigênia's dimly lit interior, and picked out wooden carvings of African-looking fauna, before noticing that I was being watched over by a smiling black pope from the ceiling.) But by reverting to African dress and customs, Chico's tribe outraged the King of Portugal so much that he prohibited slaves from buying their freedom. Chico Rei is still a folk hero to poor Brazilian blacks today. The following day I set off on the meandering 20 miles to the town of Congonhas, hoping to see Aleijadinho's most famous work, the Twelve Prophets . In a reverse of anywhere else, while the old gold towns are stopped in time, the countryside rushes towards 'progress'. Today's mining is the strip version, ripping giant chunks of iron-laden red earth out of the hillside. Stopping for a view of the carnage, I met Gilberto Ribeiro, a stocky ex-miner in his forties. 'These mountains will have disappeared in 20 years,' he said, while we watched hand-painted lorries groaning under the weight of their ore. I thought that might be an exaggeration, but that was no reason not to hear some of Gilberto's mining tales over mineira cooking, which was delivered to us with quiet mountain cordiality at a roadside stall. The cuisine has the weight of high-altitude food, but thankfully includes tasty indigenous vegetables such as spinach-like couve and quiabe beans. Vegetarians should not experiment with feijão tropeiro (mule drivers' black beans), which may be livened up with pigs' ears, tails and snouts. 'I worked on a smaller scale, chasing topaz with my pick,' Gilberto recounted, 'never dynamite - I've lost too many friends through accidents.' What Gilberto chased most was imperial topaz, which he was pleased to tell me could only be found here or in a town in Russia whose name was 'too hard to pronounce'. But he had no Chico Rei stories of good fortune. 'In my mining days I never knew anyone who started poor and ended up other than equally poor or injured.' Now he is happier working in construction. Gilberto's new trade is booming. One new development, not far from the stall where we ate, showed more of the changing face of Minas Gerais. Alphaville is an enclave of identical modern houses behind a high wall and a bored armed guard. The rich no longer try to spend their way into public respect or heavenly entrance, as in the days when they poured fabulous sums into putting up Ouro Preto's 32 churches, the colonial sobrado mansions of Mariana or the grandeur of Sabará's opera house. They won't be likely to encourage another Aleijadinho, preferring their culture to come on satellite television or shopping trips to Miami. At Congonhas the morning clouds departed the sky on cue to reveal Aleijadinho's Twelve Prophets, standing guard life-size outside the deserted Bom Jesus de Matozinhos church. In fact these figures, staring menacingly out over a broad valley, have faces not from the Old Testament but those of a band of mineiros that rebelled against Portuguese rule in Aleijadinho's time, for which they were all beheaded or exiled. Their leader was Tiradentes ('the Toothpuller'), commemorated as a patriot with a grand column in Ouro Preto's main square. The rebel resemblances don't deter the half a million Catholic pilgrims who trek to Bom Jesus in the second week of every September to make promises and do penance. Finally meeting the Prophets after generous helpings of rebellion stories back at Ouro Preto and with my Old Testament knowledge a little hazy, for me the link with the toothpuller actually improved them. All 12 carry messages, six of love, six of threat. They are eerily alive, petrified in mid-rant but still quite able to instil the fear of something like God into those who view them. At the same time, misspelled Latin phrases (taught to Aleijadinho by a local ex-Jesuit bandit) seem for some reason to breathe more life into their making. The Prophets were cut by Aleijadinho when his leprosy was at its worst. Records say the pain was so severe that the sculptor would sometimes hack away at the offending limb with his chisel until his loyal assistants stayed his hand. We can only be grateful for his perseverance, fuelled by his Bible and anatomy books and by the effect that these mountains seem to have in driving people to extremes. Perhaps it was the altitude, but I found that, despite all I heard beforehand, the grace, realism and power of what remains of Aleijadinho's creations does indeed still take the breath away. They are certainly right for this land of greed and faith. Fact file Getting there: BA (0345 222111) return fares from £429; Varig (020 7287 1414) to Belo Horizonte via São Paulo starts at £715. Trailfinders (020 7938 3939) has fares from £299 with Aerolíneas Argentinas via Madrid. STA Travel (020 7361 6185) has a return of £383 in June on TAP, via Lisbon. Visas: Britons don't require visas. Internal connections: VASP and Tram Meridional fly from Rio and São Paulo to Belo Horizonte; from £203 if booked from the UK, less in Brazil. A bus from Rio to Ouro Preto takes seven hours and costs around £9.50 Staying in Ouro Preto: Pouso Chico Rei (address: Rua Brigadeiro Mosqueira, 90; 00 55 31 551 1274) from £35 B&B per night. For luxury-lovers: the colonial Pousada do Mondego (address: Largo de Coimbra, 38; 00 55 31 551 2040) from £47.

webTitle: Schmeichel eyes a champion's medal with no regrets

fields.headline: Schmeichel eyes a champion's medal with no regrets
fields.standfirst: Victor Vago finds an old Manchester United hero on course for Europe
fields.trailText: As his old team-mates crash out of Europe, Peter Schmeichel, Manchester United goalkeeping legend, is helping another, less celebrated club on their way to glory. Sporting Lisbon of Portugal, where Schmeichel went after playing a key role in United's treble last season, are now enjoying an unprecedented run inspired by his goalkeeping.
fields.body:
As his old team-mates crash out of Europe, Peter Schmeichel, Manchester United goalkeeping legend, is helping another, less celebrated club on their way to glory. Sporting Lisbon of Portugal, where Schmeichel went after playing a key role in United's treble last season, are now enjoying an unprecedented run inspired by his goalkeeping.

In 30 league matches he has conceded just 20 goals and Sporting are just four matches away from winning the league, with a two-point lead over champions Porto, having overhauled Benfica on the way. Sporting's remaining matches are away to Rio Ave and Maritimo, at home to deadly rivals Benfica and finally away to lowly Salgueiros. The team have also reached the Portuguese cup final where they face Porto on 21 May.

But life at Sporting is not like Manchester United: Schmeichel has had three coaches already - Manuel Jose was sacked before Schmeichel unpacked and Augusto Inacio was appointed soon after, following the brief reign of Italian Giuseppe Materazzi.

Apart from Schmeichel, now 36, the team boasts Argentine striker Alberto Acosta, who is top scorer with 19 goals, Portuguese internationals Roberto Beto and Jose Vidigal, who have both been in good form, and Ghanaian international striker Kwame Ayew, brother of Abedi Pele and a pre-season recruit from Boavista at the start of the season, while Brazilian midfielder Edmilson Gancalves has the experience of having won the title when he was at Porto.

Schmeichel retains a fondness for his old club, yet does not miss them. He said: 'I'm enjoying myself here. I watch the United games on TV and wish them well, but what's past is past. I have no regrets about leaving and I don't miss being at United at all. I do keep in touch with some of the players there and with Sir Alex, but that is all.'

Why did he leave? 'I was finding it hard to keep going match after match. I was worn out and was even thinking of hanging up my boots. I needed a new challenge and wanted to go somewhere warm where my family and I could enjoy a good lifestyle. I realise more and more that it was the right decision. During the negotiations I found an atmosphere of honest and ambitious people. They were the right people for what I was looking for.'

Schmeichel sees parallels between United and Sporting. 'When I arrived at Manchester United, the club hadn't won the league for 26 years and then in my first year they won the championship. Sporting haven't won the league for 18 years.'

Does he envisage European glory with Sporting, too? 'Let's think about the Portuguese championship first,' he says. 'But Sporting are building a very good team and it's just the start. We've got good players and it's a very promising team. My signing for them may make other famous names come.'

Schmeichel has no thoughts of retiring, especially if the Champions League beckons. 'I want to stay at least another season at Sporting Lisbon. If I don't feel well, I'll quit, but I'm really enjoying my football. I feel fresh in the mornings and have no aches. As long as I have that feeling, I'll keep playing.

'We're going to do a lot to win the championship. We'll do whatever it takes to win it.'

And what of United's failure against Real Madrid? Was he surprised they could not retain the Champions League?

'It's a shame.,' said Schmeichel. 'They made mistakes and paid for it dearly. But they are still a great team and will come back from it.'

fields.headline: Said & Done
fields.trailText: David Hills on scrapes involving Lothar Matthäus and David Mellor.
fields.body:
Mr Popular: Lothar fame spreads

Lothar Matthäus hasn't been in America long - but already US Major League fans have developed a healthy dislike for him.

Matthäus joined struggling New York/New Jersey MetroStars in March on a massive contract, but has failed to make any sort of impact on the club's dreadful form. And now, after a mid-game row with a linesman, matters have come to a head.

The incident happened last week during a game against Kansas City Wizards when Matthäus was denied what he thought should have been a free-kick. Racing over to the touchline, he threw his captain's armband at linesman Chip Reed, who picked it up and threw it back. The pair then spent several minutes arguing the case with the game in full flow. Matthäus later turned on Kansas coach Bob Gansler before storming out of the ground, telling reporters: 'I am very angry.'

'It's something we're not going to accept,' warned general manager Nick Sakiewicz afterwards. 'No matter who the player is, whoever does something like that, we're not going to tolerate it.'

So is Lothar's lucrative swansong in tatters? It looks like the last chance saloon.

Mellor: Izzet was asking for it

David Mellor been reported to the Press Complaints Commission and the Commission for Racial Equality after his latest outburst in the London Evening Standard . Mellor's focus this time was the abuse Leicester's Muzzy Izzet received from Everton fans a fortnight ago after the deaths of two Leeds supporters in Istanbul. Izzet was targeted by the group because of his Turkish parentage - and according to Mellor, he deserved everything he got. 'He was the author of his own misfortune,' wrote the Voice of the Fans. 'Izzet chose to parade around Filbert Street after Leicester's Worthington Cup semi-final win [a month earlier] draped in a Turkish flag. I pointed out on Five Live how unusual this was. I've never seen any other foreign Premiership player do it'. Next week, Mellor on asylum detention camps for players of questionable ethnicity.

Matildas go topless - again

The Australian women's football team is ready to strike another blow for feminism in football by launching their second topless calendar. The first version, produced last year to coincide with the Australia Cup, drew huge interest, with striker Amy Taylor (left) claiming 'I did it to promote soccer and the women's side of things.' The first two print runs sold out quickly, with over 50,000 shipped around the country and abroad - providing 'The Matildas' with AS$5,500 (£2,150) a player to spend on preparations for the Sydney Olympics. But now, with no sponsorship deal arranged for the rest of the year, they're planning a repeat performance. According to former striker Moya Dodd, the advantages outweigh the sacrifices. 'Sure, it's oppressive, but so are stilettos - and there is still the occasional good reason for putting them on. At least these days the camera has taken the hard work out of the world's oldest profession.'

World Cup: Fifa appoint dead ref

An awkward week for Fifa, with two embarrassing referee-related incidents making headlines in Africa. The first involved the appointment of a dead referee to officiate a World Cup qualifier between South Africa and Lesotho: 'We were only informed last week that he had died in November,' said a Fifa spokesman. 'We're looking for a replacement.' The second came in Angola, where, according to the state-run Angop news agency, a referee launched a brutal attack on a journalist who criticised his officiating. Referee Jose Mundila laid into Radio 5 reporter Pepe Antonio after he repeatedly aired criticism of Mundila's handling of matches at a pre-season tournament, and suggested he took bribes. The reporter was saved from serious injury after stadium security men stepped in.

Win: Premier Manager 2000

A new version of the 'Premier Manager' Playstation series has been launched by Kevin Keegan. 'Premier Manager 2000' features 300 teams, plus 3D animation and a big transfer market. Infogrames have sent us 10 copies to give away: to win one, answer this: which hairstyle did King Kev make famous? a) The Afro b) The Perm c) The Mullet . Write to: Premier Manager 2000, Observer Sport, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER

fields.headline: Days of wine and poses
fields.standfirst: On a leisurely wine-tasting tour of France's beautiful Loire Valley,  Kate Mikhail chooses to sip rather than to spit
fields.trailText: On a leisurely wine-tasting tour of France's beautiful Loire Valley, Kate Mikhail chooses to sip rather than to spit
fields.body:
To spit or not to spit? Wine tasting has always conjured up two overriding images: either you spit, or you get embarrassingly drunk. Tucked away in the dark, cavernous depths of a wine cellar, however, with glass held appreciatively to nose, and a spittoon lurking in the shadows, flashbacks to the Ab-Fab excesses of Patsy and Edina, as they lurched, legless from vineyard to car with wine-splattered faces, helped me decide. Today, I resolved, would be a day of sipping.

Marie-Claire, wife of Jean and mother of Christophe, whose names appear alongside that of Le Domaine de la Perrière vineyard, was chattering about the history of the place, which has been in the family for five or six generations; the difficulty of finding workers for the harvest season - 'It's hard work. They would rather stay unemployed than work here' - and the nuances of the different wines, two of which have been named after her grandchildren.

Jean Baudry, the head of the family which owns the vineyard just east of Chinon, had made a brief appearance - long enough to take off his cap and issue a gruff welcome before striding off to get on with the business of growing grapes. At which point, Marie-Claire stepped forward to take on the role of front of house. Thousands of wine bottles stretched temptingly into the distance. Marie-Claire ceremoniously lined up three wine glasses to carry three different vintages and, suddenly, what was a grey, rainy day in the Loire Valley took a turn for the better.

The British have a bad name when it comes to wine tasting, or at least they used to have. After downing the free wines on offer, they would buy one bottle and walk, earning them the shameful nickname 'the one bottles'. Rule number one: if you're visiting a vineyard, you should expect to carry away at least half a dozen bottles. Other basic tips include: always phone beforehand to check opening hours; avoid lunchtime (noon-2pm); and try to put the odd French sentence together. It will be appreciated.

You can't walk 10 paces without tripping over a vineyard in the Loire and the chance of stumbling across a good one par hasard is far from guaranteed. So, before heading off blindly in the direction of this wine-drenched belt, do some research. Ask someone in the know, or buy a decent wine guide such as the Guide Hachette des Vins.

Driving down from northern France had been a pleasure in itself: straight Roman roads slicing ahead to the horizon, flanked by picture-postcard villages, busy allotments, tiny vineyards, fields of sunflowers and maize and regimented tree farms with their unnatural, though dramatic, measured grids.

I'd chosen five vineyards strung out between Chinon and Angers, which I thought could be visited in a day, but was being over optimistic. Wine tasting is all about knowing what exactly is in the bottle and this, of course, takes time. And there are the distractions en route. Churches, chateaux and farm signs left and right with tempting adverts for fresh farm produce: fruit, veg, flowers and trout ready to be stunned and gutted on demand.

It is also easy to get waylaid while tootling through medieval villages. Troglodyte homes beckon from the rocky hills above Montsoreau, outside Saumur, and cafes, restaurants and ancient village centres all make a play for your attention. Candes-St-Martin is particularly picturesque, with its milky white stone buildings and its twelfth-century church, set back from the narrow main road up a sweeping flight of broad, shallow cobblestone steps. A restaurant sits to the left of the arched entrance, while the air is alive with house martins which have stuck their mud huts in the nooks of the porch's vaults. Inside, canned Gregorian chants lend a slightly cheesy air to what is otherwise a beautiful interior built on the site where Saint Martin died in 397.

The fourteenth-century chateau in Saumur could also lure you, attention-grabbing as it is hovering above town, perched high on sixteenth-century fortifications. Part fortress and part turreted fairytale castle, the chateau, which has served as both barracks and prison, has a great panorama over the river and gardens that are worth a visit.

Worryingly for the local economy, the popularity of the chateaux of the Loire Valley has plummeted in the past decade. Since 1989, visitors have dropped by up to 35 per cent, and only the really enterprising chateaux that put on pageants and son et lumières are attracting enough visitors. This is why, or so I was told, the narrow, winding roads that weave through Loire villages are now often blissfully empty, when in times past tourist-filled cars crawled nose to tail.

Vineyard number two, Couly-Dutheil, in the centre of Chinon, had clearly been recommended for its wine rather than its ambience. More cash-and-carry than a characterful family-run business, the only reminder that this was a family affair was a large black-and-white photograph on the wall of all the male members of the family, down to the youngest sitting in a basket of grapes, and the face of the young toddler once again superimposed on a bottle of wine on the counter. Driving into the courtyard, I had been relieved to see two Brits stashing box after box into their boot - no 'one-bottles' here, thank God.

Time was running out, and driving round in circles in Chinon asking passers-by for directions had not helped, which meant that the list of five had to be slashed to three. Luckily, the Domaine de Nerleux, south-east of Saumur, proved to be a good vineyard to end on.

An imposing stone gateway welcomes you into an immaculate, spacious courtyard. Head towards the eighteenth-century converted barn on your right and you'll be met by a simple, wooden bar and a list of the wines on offer. If your written French is up to scratch, there's a helpful board with 'les trois étapes pour déterminer et apprécier les qualités des vins' - these being the look of it, the smell of it and the taste of it.

Owner Régis Neau, was dealing with an order for several thousand bottles for export. He is a handsome, happy man who clearly loves his job, and is at one with his comfortable surroundings where he was born, as were his father and grandfather. His family history and that of the vineyard are inextricably linked. And the labyrinthian cellars under the courtyard with its ancient wine press, where his grandfather worked without electricity or running water, is an evocative time capsule - history made tangible.

The 100-acre vineyard has been in the family for eight generations and is a modest affair with eight full-time members of staff. Valerie, the secretary, is one minute behind the bar and the next back stage feeding bottles into the labelling machine.

Wine tasting has a lot to recommend it. It's an enjoyable day out, you avoid the hit-or-miss quality of buying blind and once you've found what you like you can re-order over the phone and have the wine delivered.

The busiest months for wine-buying visitors are May to June and October to December, and there are a lot of English doing the rounds these days. So, are we still a nation of 'one bottles', I ask? 'I met one once,' Valerie concedes, 'but he was on a bicycle.'

 Jean and Christophe Baudry, Domaine de la Perrière, Cravant-les-Coteaux, 37500 Chinon (00 33 247 93 15 99); Couly-Dutheil, 12 rue Diderot, 37502 Chinon (00 33 247 97 20 20); Domaine de Nerleux, 4, rue de la Paleine, Saint-Cyr-en-Bourg (00 33 241 51 61 04)

Tucked away in the dark, cavernous depths of a wine cellar, however, with glass held appreciatively to nose, and a spittoon lurking in the shadows, flashbacks to the Ab-Fab excesses of Patsy and Edina, as they lurched, legless from vineyard to car with wine-splattered faces, helped me decide. Today, I resolved, would be a day of sipping. Marie-Claire, wife of Jean and mother of Christophe, whose names appear alongside that of Le Domaine de la Perrière vineyard, was chattering about the history of the place, which has been in the family for five or six generations; the difficulty of finding workers for the harvest season - 'It's hard work. They would rather stay unemployed than work here' - and the nuances of the different wines, two of which have been named after her grandchildren. Jean Baudry, the head of the family which owns the vineyard just east of Chinon, had made a brief appearance - long enough to take off his cap and issue a gruff welcome before striding off to get on with the business of growing grapes. At which point, Marie-Claire stepped forward to take on the role of front of house. Thousands of wine bottles stretched temptingly into the distance. Marie-Claire ceremoniously lined up three wine glasses to carry three different vintages and, suddenly, what was a grey, rainy day in the Loire Valley took a turn for the better. The British have a bad name when it comes to wine tasting, or at least they used to have. After downing the free wines on offer, they would buy one bottle and walk, earning them the shameful nickname 'the one bottles'. Rule number one: if you're visiting a vineyard, you should expect to carry away at least half a dozen bottles. Other basic tips include: always phone beforehand to check opening hours; avoid lunchtime (noon-2pm); and try to put the odd French sentence together. It will be appreciated. You can't walk 10 paces without tripping over a vineyard in the Loire and the chance of stumbling across a good one par hasard is far from guaranteed. So, before heading off blindly in the direction of this wine-drenched belt, do some research. Ask someone in the know, or buy a decent wine guide such as the Guide Hachette des Vins. Driving down from northern France had been a pleasure in itself: straight Roman roads slicing ahead to the horizon, flanked by picture-postcard villages, busy allotments, tiny vineyards, fields of sunflowers and maize and regimented tree farms with their unnatural, though dramatic, measured grids. I'd chosen five vineyards strung out between Chinon and Angers, which I thought could be visited in a day, but was being over optimistic. Wine tasting is all about knowing what exactly is in the bottle and this, of course, takes time. And there are the distractions en route. Churches, chateaux and farm signs left and right with tempting adverts for fresh farm produce: fruit, veg, flowers and trout ready to be stunned and gutted on demand. It is also easy to get waylaid while tootling through medieval villages. Troglodyte homes beckon from the rocky hills above Montsoreau, outside Saumur, and cafes, restaurants and ancient village centres all make a play for your attention. Candes-St-Martin is particularly picturesque, with its milky white stone buildings and its twelfth-century church, set back from the narrow main road up a sweeping flight of broad, shallow cobblestone steps. A restaurant sits to the left of the arched entrance, while the air is alive with house martins which have stuck their mud huts in the nooks of the porch's vaults. Inside, canned Gregorian chants lend a slightly cheesy air to what is otherwise a beautiful interior built on the site where Saint Martin died in 397. The fourteenth-century chateau in Saumur could also lure you, attention-grabbing as it is hovering above town, perched high on sixteenth-century fortifications. Part fortress and part turreted fairytale castle, the chateau, which has served as both barracks and prison, has a great panorama over the river and gardens that are worth a visit. Worryingly for the local economy, the popularity of the chateaux of the Loire Valley has plummeted in the past decade. Since 1989, visitors have dropped by up to 35 per cent, and only the really enterprising chateaux that put on pageants and son et lumières are attracting enough visitors. This is why, or so I was told, the narrow, winding roads that weave through Loire villages are now often blissfully empty, when in times past tourist-filled cars crawled nose to tail. Vineyard number two, Couly-Dutheil, in the centre of Chinon, had clearly been recommended for its wine rather than its ambience. More cash-and-carry than a characterful family-run business, the only reminder that this was a family affair was a large black-and-white photograph on the wall of all the male members of the family, down to the youngest sitting in a basket of grapes, and the face of the young toddler once again superimposed on a bottle of wine on the counter. Driving into the courtyard, I had been relieved to see two Brits stashing box after box into their boot - no 'one-bottles' here, thank God. Time was running out, and driving round in circles in Chinon asking passers-by for directions had not helped, which meant that the list of five had to be slashed to three. Luckily, the Domaine de Nerleux, south-east of Saumur, proved to be a good vineyard to end on. An imposing stone gateway welcomes you into an immaculate, spacious courtyard. Head towards the eighteenth-century converted barn on your right and you'll be met by a simple, wooden bar and a list of the wines on offer. If your written French is up to scratch, there's a helpful board with 'les trois étapes pour déterminer et apprécier les qualités des vins' - these being the look of it, the smell of it and the taste of it. Owner Régis Neau, was dealing with an order for several thousand bottles for export. He is a handsome, happy man who clearly loves his job, and is at one with his comfortable surroundings where he was born, as were his father and grandfather. His family history and that of the vineyard are inextricably linked. And the labyrinthian cellars under the courtyard with its ancient wine press, where his grandfather worked without electricity or running water, is an evocative time capsule - history made tangible. The 100-acre vineyard has been in the family for eight generations and is a modest affair with eight full-time members of staff. Valerie, the secretary, is one minute behind the bar and the next back stage feeding bottles into the labelling machine. Wine tasting has a lot to recommend it. It's an enjoyable day out, you avoid the hit-or-miss quality of buying blind and once you've found what you like you can re-order over the phone and have the wine delivered. The busiest months for wine-buying visitors are May to June and October to December, and there are a lot of English doing the rounds these days. So, are we still a nation of 'one bottles', I ask? 'I met one once,' Valerie concedes, 'but he was on a bicycle.'  Jean and Christophe Baudry, Domaine de la Perrière, Cravant-les-Coteaux, 37500 Chinon (00 33 247 93 15 99); Couly-Dutheil, 12 rue Diderot, 37502 Chinon (00 33 247 97 20 20); Domaine de Nerleux, 4, rue de la Paleine, Saint-Cyr-en-Bourg (00 33 241 51 61 04)

webTitle: How to find a storybook  pot of gold

fields.headline: How to find a storybook  pot of gold
fields.standfirst: Sally Varlow throws a lifeline to parents by giving chapter and verse on this year's top literary events for junior bookworms
fields.trailText: Sally Varlow throws a lifeline to parents by giving chapter and verse on this year's top literary events for junior bookworms
fields.body:
The boom in children's literature has brought a shelf of book events for kids. There isn't a Harry Potter festival so far, but more organisers are including a young people's programme within adult festivals and a few are kids only. They're fun events where you can meet favourite authors, join in storytelling, create a comic book, write a poem.

If literacy hour doesn't work, maybe a weekend break at a book bash will turn youngsters into bookworms. To find a bed at book-time, access www.visitBritain.com; and for more events search British Arts Festivals Association website www.artsfestivals.co.uk

Shrewsbury
Children's Bookfest (28 April - 1 May)

One of the few created specially for children. It was new-kid-on-the-block last year and now has another pace-setting line-up of distinctly different activities (organisers say they make up 'programme policy' as they go - hoorah for that) often linking words with music, dance, craft or art.

Birmingham Royal Ballet is running workshops on the theme of King Arthur. Steve Holland and 'The Voice Stealer' invite upper-age 'primaries' to bring whatever helps them make weird and wonderful sound. Michael Morpurgo gives six-to ll- year-olds a chance to try creative writing with a master of the art. And family events include Jacqueline (The Suitcase Kid) Wilson, back by overwhelming demand, and Nicholas Parsons on the life and nonsense of Edward Lear. It's the same broad range you'd expect from the birthplace of Charles Darwin and 'Brother Cadfael'. Booking and information tel: 01743 355159, or write to The Gateway Education and Arts Centre, Chester Street, Shrewsbury SY1 1NB.

Cheltenham
Book It! Spring Weekend (6-7 May)

New this year, a short, spring version of 'Book It!', the 'daddy bear' of children's lit-fests (it's been part of Cheltenham's big autumn book bash for more than 20 years). Known for high standard storytelling and letting youngsters roar around one bit of the Town Hall, while adults get serious elsewhere. This time the adults get poet laureate Andrew Motion and Sir Malcolm Bradbury et al, while children get Pongwiffy with Kaye Umansky, rap workshop with Tony Mitton and the Numberlies with Colin Hawkins. Joined-up family event is Anthony (Bear Hunt) Browne talking about his latest, My Dad. The autumn festival (13-22 October) is still the big one, but 'baby bear' is bound to be popular. Brochure hotline is 01242 237377; e-mail: Festivalbrochure@cheltenham.co.uk; website www.cheltenhamfestivals.co.uk

Derbyshire
Millennium Literature Festival (6 May to end July)

Opening chapter in this three-month epic (a one-off to mark the millennium) is a Great Literature Picnic at four separate sites. On 6 May, Bolsover Castle, The Slopes in Buxton, Elvaston Castle and Shipley Country Park are putting on 'a carnival of storytelling and street theatre'. Each month has different themes and events, including stories for under-fives, Book2K for teenagers, ghost walks, exhibitions and poetry readings. But the hot ticket is sure to be an exhibition, walks and talks on The Railway Children at New Mills in the High Peak (during May) backing up recent claims that E. Nesbit originally based her children's classic here. Information from Libraries and Heritage Department, County Hall, Matlock, Derbyshire DE4 3AG. Tel: 01629 580000, email ann.wright@derbyshire.gov.uk website www.derbyshire.gov.uk Festival details are on libraries and heritage pages.

Birmingham
Young Readers' UK Festival (20 May-3 June)

Peaks at bank holiday weekend (28/29 May) with a free Big Bonanza Book Fair at Aston Hall. Lots of hands-on activities, meet-the-author sessions, poetry and storytelling, plus the inimitable John Byrne, cartoonist-cum-stand-up-comic, and poet-puppeteer Nick Toczek. First and last days in the festival are also public: Terry - The Terrible Tudors - Deary (20 May) and dramatisations of Roald Dahl (3 June) at the Library Theatre. Otherwise it's mostly school and library based, linked to this year's Carnegie and Kate Greenaway medals for children's books. Information line tel: 0121 303 3368, email anne.everall@birmingham.gov.uk or write to Young Readers UK, Literature Office, Central Library, Chamberlain Square, Birmingham B3 3HQ.

Hay-on-Wye
Children's Festival (27-30 May)

Expands to a fourth day this year, in 'Celebration of Children's Literature 2000', though this arts-science-crafts-film programme has some book-based workshops and events every day. Storybox Theatre is back with a new Little Mermaid. Actor Martin Jarvis performs Just William and Vivian French does a spell-binding version of story-time. A good place for youngsters to park parents at the adults' do (famously spread all over Hay-on-Wye) and spend the day (£12 tickets) in their own tent-city at the Community Centre. Website www.hay-on-wye.co.uk/cfestival details events by age range. Ticket hotline: 0113 230 4661. For a brochure write to HFCA, 15 Knowle Avenue, Leeds LS4 2PQ.

Edinburgh
International Book Festival (12-28 August)

Has more than 150 happenings for young readers during Edinburgh's annual artskrieg. New this year is a regular evening slot for young adults (aimed at stemming the drop-out rate among late-teen readers). More firsts include a chance to try letterpress printing, set up with the National Trust's historic printworks; and the launch of Blue Mammoth Scottish stories for children.

Lots of interactive workshops. Many 'book circuit' appearances, but some 'exciting exclusives too' - yet to be announced. All held in tents in Charlotte Square, one of the city's finest (full disabled access). To get on the mailing list (from 27 Apri) e-mail admin@edbookfest.co.uk; the website www.edbookfest.co.uk has the new programme from June. Or write to Edinburgh International Book Festival, 137 Dundee Street, Edinburgh EH11 1BG.

Swansea
Wordplay (2-7 October)

The biggest book bash for kids in Wales, it wins hands down on price. Maximum charge for children is 50p per event; several of the 80-odd readings, games, workshops (some in Welsh) and competitions are free. Youngsters love it: more than 1,000 a day pack the Dylan Thomas Centre, though he's not on the agenda (he gets his day later in October). 'It's about living writers and illustrators; getting children to meet them, find out they're normal, like football, had trouble with spelling at school,' say the organisers. Illustration is a major theme: lead show this year is by Jan (Mr Wolf's Pancakes) Fearney. Booking from September. Dylan Thomas Centre, Somerset Place, Swansea SA1 1RR. Tel: 01792 463980.

Durham
Northern Children's Book Festival Gala Day (18 November)

This Gala Day, open to everyone, adds a huge happy-ever-after ending to the North East's annual fortnight of school and library events. This year the free jamboree takes place in Durham County Hall (plenty of parking and good public transport). More-than-ever space for book activities, story sessions, games and sideshows means organisers are planning a record-breaking (8,000-plus visitors) event. Invited authors include award-winning local David (Skellig) Almond, Redwall creator Brian Jaques and Judith Kerr with Mog's thirtieth birthday. Postal-booking (from September) is advised for ticket-holder events, one third available on the day. All inquiries: 0191 200 8223. Detailed programme from July. Access www.ncbf.org.uk

fields.headline: Bargain-hunters book breaks on Net
fields.trailText: Travellers booking on the Internet prefer city breaks and activity holidays while those who use a high street travel agent head for the Mediterranean, according to research released last week. It also showed that online bookers are more bargain-conscious and spend longer researching their holidays than those booking through traditional channels.
fields.body:
Travellers booking on the Internet prefer city breaks and activity holidays while those who use a high street travel agent head for the Mediterranean, according to research released last week. It also showed that online bookers are more bargain-conscious and spend longer researching their holidays than those booking through traditional channels.

The Online Travel Report, released by Expedia, which claims to be Britain's fastest-growing travel website, is based on an ICM telephone poll of offline customers and a questionnaire completed by the site's own users. It showed that one-third of conventional customers took a traditional Mediterranean package compared with only 15 per cent of online bookers.

Two-thirds of the 1,047 Expedia customers spent less than £500 - their average spend was £477 - while more than half of the sample of 526 offline travellers spent more than £500. This reflects the mix of short city breaks and airline tickets bought on the web.

The survey reveals that online bookers spent an average of 36 minutes making a purchase compared with the 29 minutes spent flicking through brochures at a travel agent. Although Monday is the busiest day for hits on travel websites, one-third of the online sample booked at weekends while 47 per cent booked in the evening.

The reasons given for booking on the Net included control (51 per cent), speed (41 per cent) and breadth of choice (39 per cent). Forty per cent of those who did not book online cited lack of access as the reason.

 Barcelona has slipped from third place to sixth in the first quarter of 2000 in a city break survey. Paris and Amsterdam retain the top two positions in sales through Crystal Cities, followed by New York, Dublin and Rome. Bruges is the only newcomer in the top 10.

fields.headline: Bedtime reading at Hilton hotels
fields.trailText: Guests at Hilton hotels will soon have more to read in their rooms than the Gideon Bible. Citron Press, the 'indie' publisher, is launching a joint initiative with the hotel group to place a complimentary 'book for bedtime' on every pillow. In addition, a selection of Citron titles will be available for sale in the rooms and in the hotel foyers.
fields.body:
Guests at Hilton hotels will soon have more to read in their rooms than the Gideon Bible. Citron Press, the 'indie' publisher, is launching a joint initiative with the hotel group to place a complimentary 'book for bedtime' on every pillow. In addition, a selection of Citron titles will be available for sale in the rooms and in the hotel foyers.

The initiative is being tested in Hilton hotels in Islington, Watford, Bristol and Bracknell, where guests will be given a complimentary copy of The Forces In by Citron author Alan David Price.

There will be four other Citron titles in their room. These are cellophane-wrapped and will be added to the guest's bill only if the seal is broken.

It remains to be seen whether The Forces In, taken from The Other Side of the Mirror, will be a popular bedtime read. The title page warns: 'Prepare yourself for a journey into a dark and frightening landscape where vampires refuse to shun the daylight and the Dracula legend is deconstructed to offer a new and terrifying definition of the "living dead".'

If the scheme is successful, the books for bedtime short stories will be available in all 6,000 rooms at all 79 hotels of the Hilton chain in Britain reaching five million guests over the year.

Hilton and Citron also plan to hold a fiction weekend with seminars and lectures featuring Citron writers.

Citron Press was founded to showcase new writers and to provide a challenging choice of fiction which might not otherwise be published. It was the first publisher to use print-on-demand technology to reduce initial costs such as stock and storage charges.

fields.headline: Explain... PSV's magic strikers
fields.trailText: Forty-three years ago, the first season of Holland's new-look first division, the Eredivisie, was coming to an end. Ajax won it, for the first time in a decade, but the season will best be remembered for another reason: the league's top scorer, Coenraad Hendrik Dillen scored 43 goals, still a national record. fields.body:
Forty-three years ago, the first season of Holland's new-look first division, the Eredivisie, was coming to an end. Ajax won it, for the first time in a decade, but the season will best be remembered for another reason: the league's top scorer, Coenraad Hendrik Dillen scored 43 goals, still a national record. Dillen played for PSV Eindhoven, the first and perhaps still the greatest of their long line of superior strikers. In all he scored 182 goals in 195 league matches, and 20 goals in 11 cup ties.

Dillen was unusual, among the great PSV strikers, in that they didn't sell him at a huge profit. He spent his entire career there, retiring in 1961 at the age of 35. Still, since the mid-Eighties, PSV have seen a succession of the world's best strikers come, catch the covetous eye of Europe's richest clubs, and leave in record-breaking deals - making PSV one of Europe's best transfer dealers (and that's without mentioning Jaap Stam).

Ruud Gullit was the first export, having enjoyed two seasons at the club, both of which ended in a championship, and both saw him named Dutch Footballer of the Year. In 1987 he moved to Milan for a world-record £6.5million. In 1988, PSV's scouts at the Olympic football tournament spotted, and quickly signed, a young striker playing for the eventual runners-up, Brazil. His name was Romario. In five seasons, Romario (pictured) scored 98 goals, before a £3million move to Barcelona in 1993. PSV reinvested the money, spending £4million on Brazil's latest prodigy Ronaldo, who had scored 58 goals in 60 games for Cruzeiro. Three years later he too moved to Barcelona, for £12.9million. Then, in 1998, PSV invested £5m in Ruud Van Nistelrooy.

Clubs across Europe will again be casting envious glances towards Eindhoven and their unbeatable transfer record, and they will be paying attention again this summer. Van Nistelrooy's departure, along with that of his strike partner, Luc Nilis, who will join Aston Villa at the end of the season, leaves PSV without a recognised striker. The questions are: who will they sign next, and how much will they sell him for? Whoever it is, you probably won't have heard of him yet. But you will soon.
