fields.headline: Mandy's coming home
fields.standfirst: Kamal Ahmed reports on growing speculation that the next piece in the complex jigsaw of the Northern Ireland Secretary's career is on the point of being slipped into place by Tony Blair
fields.trailText: He is the spinmeister extraordinaire. He is the strategist's strategist. Tall, slim with an air of imperiousness that has led his enemies in Northern Ireland to name him 'the Viceroy', Peter Mandelson is a man with a mission. And that mission is London.
fields.body:
He is the spinmeister extraordinaire. He is the strategist's strategist. Tall, slim with an air of imperiousness that has led his enemies in Northern Ireland to name him 'the Viceroy', Peter Mandelson is a man with a mission. And that mission is London.

The rumour mill started to grind in earnest last Wednesday. A story in the Sun suggested that Mandelson was on his way back to the Department of Trade and Industry. Tony Blair wanted him back, the story said.

'Twaddle' was the single-word response emanating from the Prime Minister's official spokesman, Alastair Campbell.

Then Mandelson made a speech. Not on the thorny issue of reviving the Northern Ireland Assembly, nor on the vexed issue of decommissioning or the problems with the IRA.

No, Mandelson spoke about the euro. 'Whether we like it or not, our future is in Europe,' he told a business seminar.

There was astonishment in many government circles. 'I assume there was a line about Northern Ireland in it,' said a disgruntled source, making it clear that the euro was the Chancellor Gordon Brown's business, not Mandelson's.

The two events seemed to point in one direction. Mandelson was planning his return and Blair was on his side. The Prime Minister has already announced that Mandelson will head the general election campaign along with Brown. How Mandelson is supposed to do that and spend three days a week in Belfast is anybody's guess.

Blair still relies heavily on Mandelson for advice about the way forward for the Labour Government, the broad themes that will keep the bandwagon rolling and the support on board.

Speculation increased on Friday when senior Unionist sources revealed that David Trimble believes Mandelson will quit his post in July. At Sinn Fein, it was pointed out that it was the Unionists who first suggested Mandelson would replace Mo Mowlam as Northern Ireland Secretary last autumn. It was true.

Sources close to Bertie Ahern's team in Dublin also said that they had 'received messages' that Mandelson was going. 'It's funny that at exactly this time of year a story does the rounds that Mandelson is moving on,' said a government source.

There was more. Over the past three weeks Jonathan Powell, Tony Blair's chief of staff, has been taking a closer interest in the details of the Northern Ireland negotiations. The Prime Minister himself travelled to Northern Ireland last week to try to move the process along.

'Sidelined would be too strong a word,' said an Irish government source. 'Maybe back seat would be closer.'

One problem remains before the latest piece of Mandelson's complicated life-jigsaw is slipped into place. The Northern Ireland Assembly has to be up and running again if he is to be seen as a success. And he hates being seen as anything else.

There is movement. On 2 May, the British and Irish governments are expected to launch a major diplomatic initiative, a last stab at resuscitating the Assembly before the 22 May deadline for decommissioning. When Mandelson was appointed last autumn it seemed Blair was desperate to bring his éminence grise back from purdah, and did so with undue haste, according to the Tories. It was in December the previous year that Mandelson had resigned over his home loan from fellow Minister Geoffrey Robinson.

When Mandelson arrived, his big problem was his reputation as the Prince of Darkness, the Spin Doctor Uber Alles. How would he be able to deal with the sensitivities of a conflict that goes back generations?

He seemed determined to show his mettle, and did so with two issues which he inherited: the setting up of the Assembly and the Patten report on the RUC. Mandelson got the glory for piloting through the former and is still struggling with the latter. Mandelson's contribution was devising a 'sequence', a series of statements from US peace broker George Mitchell, General Sir John de Chastelain, Sinn Fein, the UUP and the IRA, designed to ease suspicions among both Trimble's and Adams's supporters.

Trimble still had to get the Mitchell deal past the 860-member Ulster Unionist Council. Mandelson jumped in with an alacrity which alarmed Trimble's aides. He expressed an evangelistic desire to sell the deal to every Unionist association in the province, and was quietly dissuaded by veteran Unionists who warned him that the UUC delegates are immune to the hard sell.

Not that this advice stopped Mandelson. He delivered a scathing attack on Ian Paisley's DUP in the House of Commons, accusing it of 'blatant hypocrisy'. He unilaterally announced the award of the George Cross to the RUC, and was effusive about its history - which led Unionists to question that, if he thought the RUC were so honourable, why did he later agree with Patten and strip the police of their 'Royal' title?

Naturally, there was a multi-constituency which would always be hostile, and Mandy met it in Portadown where he tried to sell the Mitchell deal with Trimble in Edenderry Orange Hall. He was sneered at and heckled by supporters of the DUP and Drumcree Orangemen in the hall, and faced a barrage of hate-filled abuse as he left.

According to civil servants, Mandelson later confessed that the short run from the door of the Orange hall to his bullet-proof Daimler gave him the most terrifying seconds of his life, as police struggled to hold back the flag-waving mob baying 'traitor!' and 'queer!'

Having lost Paisley and company as he started, he lost many more Unionist supporters when he delivered the coup de grace to the RUC. Nationalist Ireland was always wary of his reputation, but was really taken aback by the ruthlessness and, it is argued, mendacity with which he moved to end the Executive and save David Trimble from his own party.

Sinn Fein is the only party which now disputes the fact that, if Mandelson had not done it, then Trimble would have been forced to collapse the Executive permanently, or be deposed as UUP leader. Either would have meant the end of the Agreement.

Last Tuesday's visit to Northern Ireland and Dublin by Tony Blair was an attempt to patch up relations with Ahern's government. Last Thursday, in Downing Street, the two governments managed to cobble together something close to a joint statement, their first properly co-ordinated action since suspension 10 weeks ago.

In the midst of this chaos, Mandelson still has time for his hobby. He regularly telephones and personally briefs Westminster's lobby correspondents about matters outside his portfolio, such as Ken Livingstone and the London mayoral election, as well as taking a keen interest in the fate of Mo Mowlam, according to friends of the embattled (and increasingly embittered) former Secretary of State.

Mandelson's other hobby is Bobby, a cute gold puppy, which he has taken to bringing with him on his engagements. At one conference he arrived 20 minutes early, and it was suggested that he might like to chat to some young people present. He declined, saying he would rather play with his dog.

The bemused organisers gaped as Bobby was released from the back of the Daimler, and man and dog played 'fetch' in the car park.

Perhaps Mandelson was following Gordon Gekko's advice in the film Wall Street: 'If you want a friend, get a dog.' But even the name of his pooch was a tribute to his real best friend.

'Bobby' was the code word used for Mandelson by Blair's team during the 1995 Labour leadership contest.

He regularly telephones and personally briefs Westminster's lobby correspondents about matters outside his portfolio, such as Ken Livingstone and the London mayoral election, as well as taking a keen interest in the fate of Mo Mowlam, according to friends of the embattled (and increasingly embittered) former Secretary of State. Mandelson's other hobby is Bobby, a cute gold puppy, which he has taken to bringing with him on his engagements. At one conference he arrived 20 minutes early, and it was suggested that he might like to chat to some young people present. He declined, saying he would rather play with his dog. The bemused organisers gaped as Bobby was released from the back of the Daimler, and man and dog played 'fetch' in the car park. Perhaps Mandelson was following Gordon Gekko's advice in the film Wall Street: 'If you want a friend, get a dog.' But even the name of his pooch was a tribute to his real best friend. 'Bobby' was the code word used for Mandelson by Blair's team during the 1995 Labour leadership contest. Northern Ireland: special report

webTitle: New British empire of the dammed

fields.headline: New British empire of the dammed
fields.standfirst: Bolivia's water supply is the latest acquisition of thirsty British firms in the service of Uncle Sam
fields.trailText: Bolivia's water supply is the latest acquisition of thirsty British firms in the service of Uncle Sam, says Gregory Palast
fields.body:
With the front pages jammed with photographs of two dead white farmers in Zimbabwe, the news from Bolivia - 'Protests claim two lives' - was pushed into a tiny World in Brief in the Guardian, and not mentioned elsewhere.

What a shame. While Zimbabwe is partially about an imperial past, Bolivia is the story of Britain's imperial future.

First, let's correct the arithmetic. The count in Bolivia is now six dead after the military fired at demonstrators opposing the 35 per cent hike in water prices imposed on the city of Cochabamba by the new owners of the water system, International Waters Ltd of London.

IWL, like many of Britain's multinational operators, is controlled by a larger US corporation, in this case San Francisco-based construction giant Bechtel. Best known here as builder of the London Underground Jubilee Line extension, Bechtel recently set off on a quest to own and operate water systems worldwide. United Utilities, originally co-owner of IWL is now merely 'strategic partner' in the venture.

Following the Cochabamba killings, Hugo Banzer (once Bolivia's dictator, now elected President), declared a nationwide state of siege, abolishing civil liberties. On 12 April, just after the martial law declaration, World Bank director James Wolfensohn told reporters: 'The riots in Bolivia, I'm happy to say, are now quieting down.'

I contacted Oscar Olivera, a trade union official and leader of the protests, to ask him how he had organised the riots. On 6 April, Olivera - with a coalition of 14 economists, parliamentarians, lawyers and community leaders - accepted a government invitation to discuss the IWL price hikes. After entering the government offices in Cochabamba, Olivera and his colleagues were arrested.

With Olivera in chains, the riot outside the building could only have been directed by the leader of the 500 protesters, Cochabamba's Roman Catholic Archbishop.

There is, of course, the possibility that Wolfensohn had got it wrong, and that the people he called rioters were in fact innocent victims of deadly repression. Olivera, one of five protest leaders released, flew to Washington to try to speak with Wolfensohn. But the director is a busy man and Olivera left without having a meeting.

The price hikes that triggered the water war were driven by IWL's need to recover the cost of the huge Misicuni dam project. Water from the dam system will cost roughly six times that of alternative sources. Why would IWL want water from a ludicrously expensive source? Just possibly because IWL owns a part of the Misicuni dam project.

The public had one other problem with IWL's charging for the dam project: there is no dam. It has not yet been built.

It is a basic tenet of accounting that investors, not customers, fund capital projects. The risk-takers then recover their outlay, with profit, when the project produces a product for sale. This is the heart, soul and justification of the system called 'capitalism'. That's the theory. But when a monopoly operator gets its fist around a city's water spigots, it can pump the funds for capital projects from captive customers rather than shareholders.

Samuel Soría, the Bolivian government's former consultant on the water projects, said he was unable to extract from IWL evidence of it having put any funds at all into the operation. Water prices could, he fears, eventually rise by 150 per cent.

Luis Bredow, publisher of the newspaper Gente told me 'no money was shelled out by anybody' for Cochabamba's water company. His own investigation concluded that the operators grabbed the entire system for nothing. He attributes these exceptionally favourable terms to IWL's partnership with former Bolivian President Jaime Paz Zamora, leader of a political party allied to Banzer.

IWL's London spokesman said little more than: 'How did you find out that IWL was involved in Cochabamba?' (The company's Bolivian group is called Aguas de Altuni.) In fact, the British company's involvement is getting to be ' misterioso '. President Banzer, to quell the spreading demonstrations, announced cancellation of the water privatisation on 5 April.

But the next day, word leaked that IWL was back in the saddle at the water company and people nationwide took to the streets again.

On 10 April, the panicked government declared that the foreign consortium had 'abandoned' its franchise when its British chief executive supposedly fled the country. But last Thursday we tracked the IWL executive to a hotel in La Paz where, his associates told me, they were about to open negotiations with the Banzer government.

From its US headquarters, Bechtel issued a statement denying that the upheaval in Bolivia had anything to do with its water price hikes.

It can't be said that the British-American operators brought misery to Cochabamba; they found plenty already there. Intestinal infection leading to diarrhoeal illness is Bolivia's number one child killer - the result of water hook-ups and sanitation reaching only 31 per cent of rural homes.

World Bank director Wolfensohn has a solution to the lack of water: raise the price. So pay up, he demanded of the protesting Bolivian water users. But this contradicts the internal counsel of his own experts. In July 1997, at a meeting in Washington, the Bank's technocrats laid before the Bolivians the case against Misicuni, and even warned about social upheaval if prices rose. According to a World Bank insider, the Bank's hydrologists and technicians devised a water plan for Cochabamba at a fraction of Misicuni's bloated cost.

So why did Wolfensohn attack protests against a project the World Bank itself found dodgy? Because there are larger plans not discussed with the Bank's low-level minions. Long before ministerial limousines clogged the US capital, the big policy decisions were settled in far-flung 'sectoral' meetings. In the case of water, nearly 1,000 executives and bureaucrats gathered in The Hague last month to review and refine a programme to privatise the world's water systems.

But private operators can turn profits only if prices rise radically and rapidly. IWF secured from Bolivia a 16 per cent real guaranteed return. This profit boost is itself enough to account for the initial 35 per cent hike in rates.

To assist such 'reform', the IMF, World Bank and Inter- American Development Bank have written sell-offs into what they term national 'master plans'. Consortia such as IWL were formed to capture these cast-off public assets.

The justifiable basis for the sell-offs was that privateers committed to deliver capital for desperately needed system repairs and expansion. But the promises rapidly wilted. Cochabamba's protest organisers knew that just across the border in Buenos Aires, the region's first privatisation consortium eliminated 7,500 workers, whereupon the system bled from lack of maintenance and prices jumped. The new owners of the Buenos Aires system notably include Anglian Water.

Britain is re-establishing imperial reach through rapid low-capital takeovers of former state assets, concentrated in infrastructure where monopoly control virtually guarantees an outsized profit. It all seemed a riskless romp - until a few thirsty, angry peasants decided they could stop it.

fields.headline: On the brand wagon
fields.standfirst: Believe it or not, Blue Nun is big business. But are branded wines the bargain they're made out to be?
fields.trailText: Believe it or not, Blue Nun is big business. But are branded wines the bargain they're made out to be?
fields.body:
I've been trying to think of a collective noun for press releases this week. A recycle? A vacuum? An Alice Band? Every morning my letterbox is full of the things. Most are unremarkable, not to say pointless - 'Add a touch of sparkle to your summer cooking with Champagne Duval-Leroy' is pretty typical - but occasionally, just occasionally, something stands out.

Take the release I received from the importer of Blue Nun, the historic German Liebfraumilch brand, last week. Now if you were the importer of this sweet concoction, you'd probably keep quiet. But Ehrmanns has some remarkable news to impart: Blue Nun is making a comeback. So successful was it in the run-up to Christmas that it's currently the 12th biggest seller in the country. This summer sees the launch of a Blue Nun Merlot (of all things) from the south of France. Mmm, I can't wait.

What is happening here? For those who hoped that branded wines were on a very steep slide to oblivion, the news is not good. According to the trade magazine Harpers, which held a 'brand storm' recently, branded wines account for 20 per cent of all bottles purchased in the UK, up from one in seven in 1998. In other words, the more wine we buy as a nation, the more likely we are to plump for the reassurance of a well-known name. That's why Le Piat d'Or, Black Tower, Mateus Rosé and good old Blue Nun still sell far more bottles than they should do.

The branded market has changed a lot. The 'classics' are still hanging on, but only Le Piat d'Or and Stowells of Chelsea are in the top 10. Mateus and the Liebs have been supplanted by New World brands: Gallo, Jacob's Creek, Lindemans, Rosemount, Penfolds, Blossom Hill and Banrock Station. I wouldn't cross an empty phone booth to drink a bottle of Blossom Hill, and I'm none too crazy about Gallo's cheaper offerings, but the picture is brighter than it used to be. Remember Veuve du Vernay?

Branded wines are no longer regarded with scorn. Educated friends of mine are quite happy to serve, say, Lindemans' Bin 65 at a dinner party and I don't blame them. All the same, I can't help thinking branded wines are an easy option. It doesn't take much more effort to buy something interesting for the same money.

The whole point of branding is to 'add value'. Translated from marketing speak, this means charging more for something than it's worth. Otherwise, how do you pay for all the advertising, price promotions and T-shirts? Brands play on our lack of confidence, our need to conform. They are blandness in liquid form.

Someone at the brand storm compared branded wines to package holidays. Not everyone, he said, wants to go trekking in the Atlas Mountains; some people are happy to lie on a beach in Benidorm. To me, the analogy is amusing but false. Package holidays sell because they offer sunshine at cheap prices. Branded wines offer sunshine, too, but all too often the prices are a rip off. Personally, I'd also like to see a few more wine lovers heading for the vinous equivalent of the Atlas Mountains. However, two branded wines I would recommend are the 1998 Caliterra Cabernet Sauvignon, Valle Central (£5.49, Wine Rack) and the 1999 Rosemount Shiraz/Cabernet (£6.45, Asda).

fields.headline: World wine web
fields.trailText: Chilean Sauvignon Blanc
fields.body:
Chilean Sauvignon Blanc

What's the bottle? 1999 35 Sur Sauvignon Blanc, Viña San Pedro

Price and stockist? £4.49 from Sainsbury's, Safeway, Asda, Morrison's and Waitrose

What's interesting about the wine? Most Chilean Sauvignon Blanc isn't made from the grape of Sancerre and Pouilly-Fumé. Sauvignon Blanc has been confused, often deliberately, with the inferior Sauvignon Vert in Chile's vineyard. The good thing about this wine, made by Kiwi Brett Fleming in the Lontue Valley, is that it's pure Sauvignon Blanc. It's also made with a lot of skill. Indeed, for a sub-£5 white, this has an awful lot of flavour. Ironically, it's as good as many New Zealand Sauvignons priced at £7 or more. Viña San Pedro is Chile's second-largest producer, which proves that quality and quantity don't have to be incompatible.

What does the wine smell and taste like? Pungent aromas of gooseberry, green beans and grapefruit give way to rich, uncompromising, extremely modern flavours. The wine is crisp, bright and fizzing with character. It has an attractive tropical-fruit undertone, making it a neat stylistic stepping stone between the Loire Valley and New Zealand. The balance between acidity, fruit flavour and alcohol is exceptional for a sub-£5 white.

What does it go with? Good as an apéritif, but try it with salads and pasta. Also good with creamy sauces.

Serving temperature? 8 -10 C. Serve well chilled.

Will it keep? Not really. Drink within the next six months.

What are we tasting next? 1998 Podium Late Harvest Verdicchio (£5.99, Tesco)

Send your views to tim.atkin@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Nigel Slater's pistachio recipes
fields.standfirst: Nothing goes better with beer than a bag of pistachios... and they're not bad in desserts
fields.trailText: Nothing goes better with beer than a bag of pistachios... and they're not bad in desserts
fields.body:
Twenty minutes walk south from Marrakech's Place Djemaa el Fna, past the derelict swimming pool, its walls festooned with roses and where, incidentally, I was once robbed at knife-point, you come to an old olive grove. A secret place. I hope it remains - there was much peace and shade there, and none of the interminable hassling of the hashish boys. It was here, several years ago, that I spent every afternoon for three weeks, hiding from Morocco's searing heat, sprawled out under the olives, shelling bag after bag of pistachios. This is not a nut to open with nutcrackers and to munch by the handful, but a nut that seems designed for lazy days, held in a tight shell that you can open only with your fingernails.

A couple of Saturdays ago, the first day warm enough to sit in the garden, I perched on the back steps with a beer and a bag of salty, white-shelled pistachios - fat Iranian ones they were, and the juiciest I have ever had. These little nuts seem to go hand in hand with the sun, with long cold drinks, ashtrays piled up with their hard oval shells. They fray your nails, of course, but teasing the rose-skinned nuts from their cases is part of the fun. Anyone who has ever bought a bag of ready-shelled pistachios will know how much of this nut's magic seems lost.

The pistachios I knew as a child were not pistachios at all but dyed almonds, chopped as fine as tea leaves and sprinkled on the trifles that came in little waxed cartons that we brought back from the bakers on a Saturday. It wasn't until I went to Greece on a package holiday that I met a real one in its shell, and since then I have associated them with the sun. Unlike our indigenous nuts, the hazel and the cob, the pistachio needs hot, dry conditions and poor soil in which to grow.

I welcome not having to find the nutcrackers, for once. The little nuts are always open, waiting patiently for someone to slide in a thumb and prise the shells apart. They get this way not because of some cottage industry that partly cracks each nut for us before exporting them (this guy actually believed that for years), but as a result of being left in the shade to dry, when their pinky skin flakes off and the shell cracks open. A little miracle. Those who have ever tried to open a tightly shut pistachio with a pair of nutcrackers - and who must surely have been desperately at the end of their bag but not the end of their beer - will know that it doesn't really work. The nut crumbles.

Although I toss them from time to time into rice pilaf or use them to decorate a proper trifle, pistachios are really associated with the pastries of the Middle East. The Turkish shops around Newington Green in north-east London sell filo pastries filled with the pulverised nuts and smothered in honey syrup. They cut them from battered tin trays, and you eat them with sticky fingers from a paper plate.

They occasionally turn up in French charcuterie, but the pistachio is more at home in little pastries and dipped into impossibly sweet syrups flavoured with rose-water and orange blossom. It is here they are at their most elegant, and to be eaten, surely, with a glass of mint tea or a tiny, shockingly strong and murky coffee. In Paris, I sometimes spend a lazy afternoon at the hammam in the mosque behind the Jardin des Plantes and slip into its tea rooms. Freshly scrubbed and minus a layer of skin, I make up for it with mint tea and sweet pastries.

A pistachio is the most beautiful of nuts, its beige skin blushed with purple, the bright-green flesh peeping through. If you eat the nut straight from its shell, then the skin is perfectly edible, but if the nuts are to end up in cakes, pastries or ice cream, then I think it worth peeling them. The bits of skin can get stuck in your teeth.

This doesn't really apply to the nuts that are eaten as part of the pistachio ritual. And it is a ritual: the cold beer being poured, the shells being tweaked open, the little nut teased out, then the shells discarded in a shambolic heap. Am I the only person who sometimes licks the salt from the empty shells?

As with any nut, you need to buy them from somewhere with a fast turnover. Look out for pistachios that are cleanly packed. Old, dusty bags with much loose skin in the bottom are bound to be dry and possibly rancid. This is not a nut for keeping. I regularly visit a shop in west London that has piles of them, loose and in bags, in every possible state from white-shelled and unsalted to those that have been ready-peeled and chopped.

In India, I have come across pistachio brittle flavoured with cardamom, the little nuts embedded in crisp caramel and flecked with saffron. I bring as much back as I can carry. Pistachio ice cream is worth trying, too, though it is exceedingly difficult to find. The Italians and the Lebanese make it, and you sometimes see it in Middle Eastern shops. It is delicious with chocolate of any sort. Rowley Leigh of Kensington Place Restaurant in London's Notting Hill sometimes adds a spoonful to his hot chocolate soufflé. But first find your pistachio ice cream - or for that matter your shady olive grove.

Pistachio yogurt cheesecake
A nutty, sharp-tasting, soft-textured cheesecake, far away from what I call 'claggy' cheesecake, and substantially less sweet. It is more of a dessert than a cake, really. There is a little sweetness from the sugar and dried fruit, but this is a clean-tasting cheesecake, barely firm enough to cut, though it will stiffen up if left in the fridge overnight.

Serves 8.

for the biscuit base
10 digestive biscuits
50g butter

for the cheesecake

75g butter
75g caster sugar
500g mascarpone
2 egg yolks
6 heaped tbsps thick yogurt
a drop of vanilla extract
3 tsps rose-water
60g pistachio nuts (shelled weight)
30g dried cherries or sultanas
50g ready-to-eat dried apricots, finely chopped

Crush the biscuits so they resemble coarse breadcrumbs. Melt the butter in a small pan and stir in the biscuit crumbs. Tip them into a 23cm diameter cake tin and press them down, then refrigerate while you make the filling.

Cream the butter and sugar together until light and fluffy, then beat in the mascarpone, eggs and yogurt. Stir in a little vanilla extract and the rose-water. Whiz the pistachio nuts briefly in a food processor so they are as fine as fresh breadcrumbs, but not as fine as ground almonds.

Fold the ground pistachios into the mascarpone mixture with the dried cherries and apricots, then tip on top of the biscuit crumbs and refrigerate for 3 or 4 hours. It will not set as such, but should be soft and creamy.

Pistachio pastries
Little pastries to eat with mint tea or coffee - a sweet treat indeed. For how to skin the nuts, see below. Makes 8 small pastries.

175g pistachio nuts (shelled weight)
1 egg, beaten
grated zest of a lemon
orange-blossom water
rose-water
5 tbsps plain flour
2 sheets of filo pastry
melted butter

for the syrup
150g caster sugar
100ml water
2 tbsps honey
2 tsps each orange-blossom water and rose-water

Blitz the nuts to a coarse powder in a food processor, tip them into a mixing bowl, then mix them with the beaten egg, sugar, grated lemon zest and 1 tsp or so of rose-water and orange-blossom water. Stir in the flour. The consistency should be that of a stiffish cake mixture.

Open out the sheets of filo pastry - one at a time so they do not dry up - and cut each piece into four long strips. Brush each piece generously with melted butter, then turn them so the short edge is facing you. Put a generously heaped tablespoon of the mixture at the bottom of each strip. Fold the right-hand bottom corner over to cover the filling, pressing the edges down around it to form a triangle, then continue rolling the parcel over until the filling is completely enclosed. Brush with butter to seal.

Continue with the other strips. You should end up with eight triangular parcels. Place them on a baking sheet and bake for 15-20 minutes at 200°C/gas mark 6 until they are golden and crisp.

While they are baking, melt the sugar and water together over a moderate heat and add the honey and orange-flower water and set it aside. When the little pastries come out of the oven, brush them very generously with the honey syrup. Set them aside to cool slightly. They are best eaten warm.

To skin the pistachios
You really do need to skin pistachios for some recipes such as those above, so here are two ways to do this. You should soak the shelled nuts in warm water, then rub off the skins with your fingers, discarding the purple skins. Before they are ground, the nuts should be allowed to dry, otherwise they will simply clog the grinder. I tend to take a slightly less perfectionist view and rub the dry, freshly shelled nuts roughly together in my hands so they rub off each other's skins. It is no quite as successful as the soaking and drying method, but it works well enough.
fields.bodyText: Twenty minutes walk south from Marrakech's Place Djemaa el Fna, past the derelict swimming pool, its walls festooned with roses and where, incidentally, I was once robbed at knife-point, you come to an old olive grove. A secret place. I hope it remains - there was much peace and shade there, and none of the interminable hassling of the hashish boys. It was here, several years ago, that I spent every afternoon for three weeks, hiding from Morocco's searing heat, sprawled out under the olives, shelling bag after bag of pistachios. This is not a nut to open with nutcrackers and to munch by the handful, but a nut that seems designed for lazy days, held in a tight shell that you can open only with your fingernails. A couple of Saturdays ago, the first day warm enough to sit in the garden, I perched on the back steps with a beer and a bag of salty, white-shelled pistachios - fat Iranian ones they were, and the juiciest I have ever had. These little nuts seem to go hand in hand with the sun, with long cold drinks, ashtrays piled up with their hard oval shells. They fray your nails, of course, but teasing the rose-skinned nuts from their cases is part of the fun. Anyone who has ever bought a bag of ready-shelled pistachios will know how much of this nut's magic seems lost. The pistachios I knew as a child were not pistachios at all but dyed almonds, chopped as fine as tea leaves and sprinkled on the trifles that came in little waxed cartons that we brought back from the bakers on a Saturday. It wasn't until I went to Greece on a package holiday that I met a real one in its shell, and since then I have associated them with the sun. Unlike our indigenous nuts, the hazel and the cob, the pistachio needs hot, dry conditions and poor soil in which to grow. I welcome not having to find the nutcrackers, for once. The little nuts are always open, waiting patiently for someone to slide in a thumb and prise the shells apart. They get this way not because of some cottage industry that partly cracks each nut for us before exporting them (this guy actually believed that for years), but as a result of being left in the shade to dry, when their pinky skin flakes off and the shell cracks open. A little miracle. Those who have ever tried to open a tightly shut pistachio with a pair of nutcrackers - and who must surely have been desperately at the end of their bag but not the end of their beer - will know that it doesn't really work. The nut crumbles. Although I toss them from time to time into rice pilaf or use them to decorate a proper trifle, pistachios are really associated with the pastries of the Middle East. The Turkish shops around Newington Green in north-east London sell filo pastries filled with the pulverised nuts and smothered in honey syrup. They cut them from battered tin trays, and you eat them with sticky fingers from a paper plate. They occasionally turn up in French charcuterie, but the pistachio is more at home in little pastries and dipped into impossibly sweet syrups flavoured with rose-water and orange blossom. It is here they are at their most elegant, and to be eaten, surely, with a glass of mint tea or a tiny, shockingly strong and murky coffee. In Paris, I sometimes spend a lazy afternoon at the hammam in the mosque behind the Jardin des Plantes and slip into its tea rooms. Freshly scrubbed and minus a layer of skin, I make up for it with mint tea and sweet pastries. A pistachio is the most beautiful of nuts, its beige skin blushed with purple, the bright-green flesh peeping through. If you eat the nut straight from its shell, then the skin is perfectly edible, but if the nuts are to end up in cakes, pastries or ice cream, then I think it worth peeling them. The bits of skin can get stuck in your teeth. This doesn't really apply to the nuts that are eaten as part of the pistachio ritual. And it is a ritual: the cold beer being poured, the shells being tweaked open, the little nut teased out, then the shells discarded in a shambolic heap. Am I the only person who sometimes licks the salt from the empty shells? As with any nut, you need to buy them from somewhere with a fast turnover. Look out for pistachios that are cleanly packed. Old, dusty bags with much loose skin in the bottom are bound to be dry and possibly rancid. This is not a nut for keeping. I regularly visit a shop in west London that has piles of them, loose and in bags, in every possible state from white-shelled and unsalted to those that have been ready-peeled and chopped. In India, I have come across pistachio brittle flavoured with cardamom, the little nuts embedded in crisp caramel and flecked with saffron. I bring as much back as I can carry. Pistachio ice cream is worth trying, too, though it is exceedingly difficult to find. The Italians and the Lebanese make it, and you sometimes see it in Middle Eastern shops. It is delicious with chocolate of any sort. Rowley Leigh of Kensington Place Restaurant in London's Notting Hill sometimes adds a spoonful to his hot chocolate soufflé. But first find your pistachio ice cream - or for that matter your shady olive grove. Pistachio yogurt cheesecake A nutty, sharp-tasting, soft-textured cheesecake, far away from what I call 'claggy' cheesecake, and substantially less sweet. It is more of a dessert than a cake, really. There is a little sweetness from the sugar and dried fruit, but this is a clean-tasting cheesecake, barely firm enough to cut, though it will stiffen up if left in the fridge overnight. Melt the butter in a small pan and stir in the biscuit crumbs. Tip them into a 23cm diameter cake tin and press them down, then refrigerate while you make the filling. Cream the butter and sugar together until light and fluffy, then beat in the mascarpone, eggs and yogurt. Stir in a little vanilla extract and the rose-water. Whiz the pistachio nuts briefly in a food processor so they are as fine as fresh breadcrumbs, but not as fine as ground almonds. fields.headline: A tale of two cities
fields.standfirst: Just yards from the glittering towers of Canary Wharf lie some of the most deprived estates in the country. But for both the rich and poor of the Isle of Dogs, the chasm which separates them may never be bridged
fields.trailText: Just yards from the glittering towers of Canary Wharf lie some of the most deprived estates in the country. But for both the rich and poor of the Isle of Dogs, the chasm which separates them may never be bridged
fields.body:
You are not meant to walk to Canary Wharf. It's not what it was built for. You are meant to get there by car or by Docklands Light Railway or, since late last year, by the Jubilee Line extension. It fizzes along beneath the clutter and decay of London's East End to deliver you, calm and unflustered, to this Gotham City of glass and steel and marble and money. This kind of money demands a more graceful approach. To get to this kind of money you should glide.

Stand on the pedestrian overpass at Poplar's DLR station and you could be forgiven for thinking that it is literally impossible to reach Canary Wharf on foot. Every potential route appears to disappear amid a tight knot of concrete shadows. Whoever wins the first election for Mayor of London in 10 days time might like to come and have a look for themselves. Nowhere in the city will they get a better sense of the challenges that face them. For here they will be standing on an urban fault line; the gap between rich and poor made asphalt and concrete; a chasm that might as well be a mile deep as a mere quarter of a mile wide. From here you can see both the best and worst of places.

Behind, to the north, is the low-rise smudge of Tower Hamlets, one of London's poorest boroughs. Canary Wharf is also part of Tower Hamlets but, in truth, all they share is the name. In areas of Bow and Mile End, Stepney and Poplar, unemployment is four times or more the London average. It has some of Britain's highest rates of mental illness, heart disease, alcohol and drug dependency. There, in the impoverished Bengali communities, tuberculosis is no longer a vanquished foe. It is a real killer, coaxed from its deep-tissue hiding place by damp and overcrowded housing.

Turn to look south again and the view changes dramatically. First you see the Tarmac scar of Aspen Way, widened to accommodate the glossy cars that now come out this far east. Beyond that is a broad stretch of undeveloped ground currently used as a car park and further still, the dark, oily waters of what used to be the old docks before they were closed down in 1980 when cargo shipping deserted these lower reaches of the Thames. Finally, the northern flank of the Canary Wharf development rises vertiginously skywards, like some gilded cliff. However impressive the view, no footpath immediately presents itself. It's as if the whole multi-billion-pound edifice was designed to keep the locals out.

As it happens, there is a way to get there on foot, tucked away beneath the DLR line that runs overhead. Behind it a narrow footbridge leads from the quayside to land you right in the heart of the Canary Wharf estate. Go across to the neatly manicured Cabot Square, turn left and down through the underground shopping malls, bulging with Mont Blanc shops and Starbucks coffee bars and places selling expensive chrome stuff to boys in suits. Eventually you will come to the base of 1 Canada Square, at 800ft the tallest building in London. Take the express lift to the 30th floor and there, in the marketing suite of the Canary Wharf Group plc, which owns the entire estate, you will find a three-dimensional illustration of the gross schism that defines this part of London.

They have built a relief model of the capital, over 20ft long and 10ft wide, the individual buildings across the city picked out in little blocks a few centimetres square. At its heart, proudly tumescent beneath an overhead spotlight, stands the Canary Wharf development. The rest of Tower Hamlets is cast in its shadow. John Pagano, the youthful vice-president for construction, stands beside his pride and joy pressing buttons. 'Here comes the DLR,' he says, and a river of yellow lights marking the route streams in across the map towards where we are standing. 'And here's the Jubilee Line. And now the road system. And of course City Airport.' The map pulses with pretty coloured lights, all pouring towards us, as if the critical mass of Canary Wharf were a black hole sucking in everything around it.

Pagano leads me through to the next room. It houses a fabulous model village in Perspex and balsawood showing every building on the 85-acre estate, and those still to come. 'Here we have a residential scheme of 310 apartments going up,' he says, pointing to the western end. 'There will be a health club and, of course, the Four Seasons Hotel is already there. 'Over here' he moves further along, 'is a complex of three different buildings. In here Texaco, in here Reader's Digest and'

He continues, evangelising for floor space: at one end, the new HSBC world headquarters now being built; nearby a skyscraper that will house Citigroup and Solomon Smith Barney. There are landscaped parks, atriums for winter gardens providing a 'pleasant temperate environment', and shops and more health clubs and more shops and more apartments. This is large-scale construction.

The statistics are extraordinary. Already there is 5.8 million sq ft of office space here and a further 3.2 million is under construction. When the project is completed there will be 11 million sq ft in all. From a working population of 8,000 people in 1994 it now houses 27,000. Eventually 100,000 people are expected to work here on banking floors and in newspapers and oil companies. More money flushes through these buildings every day than some nation states see in a year. The Canary Wharf Group plc is valued at between £2.6 and £2.9 billion, though the overall cost of the development, including transport infrastructure, is billions more.

How can any of this chrome and marble excess, this intense Manhattan-on-Thames, ever mean anything to the less enriched residents of Tower Hamlets either side? It is not a question for Pagano. He is simply a real estate salesmen, albeit one overseeing one of the greatest slabs of real estate in the world. It is a question for Robert John, a softly spoken Welshman who is a director of the company, but who has no job title. He has an office with a broad view of the Isle of Dogs to the south and hung with fine abstract art. John was one of the first people to be hired by Canadian developer Paul Reichman whose company, Olympia & York, began the work at Canary Wharf before it went bust during the recession of the early 90s. (Reichman subsequently bought the company back from the administrators and renamed it the Canary Wharf Group.)

'Paul Reichman said to me right at the beginning that we must always remember that we are new members of an old community,' John says. The key, he explains, is getting local people to work here, so the company has invested cash in skills-match programmes and sent ambassadors out into local schools. 'Yes, we need investment bankers, but we also need chefs,' he says. 'Yes, we need tax inspectors, but we also need taxi drivers. What we need to do is get this message out there.'

And, he says proudly, it's working. They have a survey that shows an increase in the number of workers at Canary Wharf who live in Tower Hamlets from 4.5 per cent in 1997 to 8.4 per cent in 1999. 'Clearly we're getting two things,' John says. 'We're getting old locals finding jobs here and we're getting people with jobs here who are moving into the area to become new locals.' There has, after all, been a massive boom in expensive wharf-apartment developments. The problem is that, at the moment, John doesn't know how many of the 8.4 per cent are the old locals he wants. Still, he says, they are trying. They care. They give a damn.

It would be easy to be cynical about this professed commitment to the local community by both Robert John and the Canary Wharf Group. Capital doesn't care about the little people, does it? Capital cares about profit and margins. Capital exists to serve the demands of the Great God Mammon, and if it does not, it has no purpose at all.

Perhaps, but to dismiss their efforts altogether would be unfair, according to John Eversely, a lecturer in social policy at London University's Queen Mary and Westfield College on the nearby Mile End Road. 'As socially aware developers go, they are right up there with the Cadburys and the Rowntrees,' he says. 'They really do mean it. But the amount they put in is still chicken-feed compared to the size of the problem.' So is the gap between these two Londons, existing here side by side, at all bridgeable? 'If it is bridgeable,' Eversley concludes, 'it's only by the longest bridge in the history of the world.'

The Alpha Grove Community Centre should, by rights, be the richest community centre in Britain. It sits on the edge of the Barkantine council estate on the Isle of Dogs just a few hundred yards south of Canary Wharf. From here, you can practically smell the money, hear it clanking through the tills. In theory, some of that cash should have found its way to the centre.

It hasn't. The roof leaks. The heating system has broken down and there isn't the cash to fix it. The mini-bus, used to pick up kids after school when their parents are still working, is grinding to a halt. 'Funders love to fund individual projects,' says Anna Palm, a former music teacher who now runs the centre. 'But they won't come up with core funding. My salary is only sorted for the next two months. After that, who knows?'

It's not supposed to be this way. When development of the Docklands area began in the early 80s, the Conservative government set up the London Docklands Development Corporation. It spent £3.9 billion of public money regenerating the area to match the £9 billion spent by the private sector, before it was wound up in 1998. Some of that cash did find its way to the Barkantine. The dilapidated tower blocks received new facades and walkways were given a makeover.

'The result was more graffiti and vandalism,' says Anna Palm, 'because you can't paint over a basic grass-roots problem. There are serious issues of poverty on this estate and the kids just see this huge development to all sides and think "there's nothing here for me".' The LDDC was replaced by the Isle of Dogs Community Foundation which has received seven-figure grants of government regeneration money, but that doesn't seem to be finding its way to Alpha Grove either. Palm picks up a map and points out the site of a new business and residential development, the Millennium Quarter, which will bear down on them from the north. 'We're going to be squished in between it and the river,' she says. All around them are £250,000 apartments.

The Canary Wharf Group donates two hours of a business manager's time to come down and help the centre apply for grants, for which she says she is grateful. But it clearly frustrates her that there is so much wealth so close by and yet they can't get the relatively small amounts they need to secure the vital services for the elderly or after-school kids' clubs that the community relies upon. Sometimes that frustration breaks through. Recently some of the children from the centre put on a show in Cabot Hall at Canary Wharf. 'Everybody from the companies up there said how great it was so I tried to follow it up, tried to get donations from them but nothing happened. These cute little kids from the Isle of Dogs dancing around free for the businessmen at Canary Wharf and what do we get for it? Sod all.'

Karen Earp has not heard of the Barkantine Estate. She can be forgiven. She has been very busy launching the new Four Seasons Hotel at Canary Wharf, where she is general manager. She also lives here, in an apartment just around the corner. She readily enthuses about what Wharf living means to her: 'I love it. I love the vibrancy of Canary Wharf during the day contrasted with the calming views of the river. Everything is out here and there isn't the traffic. It's just so compact. You haven't got the razzmatazz of the West End, of course, but you can go and get it. And now on weekends all the bars and restaurants are open so it doesn't die. It's a little oasis. You've got everything you need.'

She, like Robert John, talks about a desire to employ local people, which she says she has done, in house-keeping, maintenance and in the kitchens. She also proclaims a love for the old East End pubs with their old East End 'characters', although she says she doesn't really go south on the Isle of Dogs much, which perhaps also explains why she has never come across the Barkantine.

She takes me up to the presidential suite, a confection of blonde wood floors and sofas upholstered in shades of chocolate and caramel (brown, the new black). She shows me the Bang & Olufsen system and the marble clad bathroom and the pantry and the dining room. The suite costs £1,400 a night. Finally she shows me the view. It looks westwards down the curving river, towards Tower Bridge and the London Eye millennium wheel beyond. By one of those clever twists of geography you can see neither the impoverished districts to the north, nor to the south from here. But then, if you're paying £1,400 a night, you'll expect a good view.

The Ocean Estate. It's a nice name, isn't it? Oceans teem with life. They swell and flow with the tides. They wash us clean.

The Ocean Estate isn't a particularly nice place and it isn't clean. It is just a mile and a half to the north-east of Canary Wharf in Stepney, but it is an area that the billions of LDDC money was never designed to reach. Recently, John Eversley's research team from Queen Mary and Westfield College conducted research for Tower Hamlets Council as part of an ongoing bid for £50 million of Government regeneration money. The findings were startling: 51 per cent of households live on under £10,000 a year; only 25 per cent of adults are in full time paid work; 84 per cent of households are on some kind of state benefit; 36 per cent suffer from health problems; 44 per cent of households contain someone suffering from a long term illness or disability.

I visit in the company of Jasmin, a 19-year-old Bangladeshi student who has agreed to translate. The vast majority of the residents are immigrants from Bangladesh who arrived here in the 70s and, for much of the older generation, Bengali remains their first language.

The Ocean is a depressing place to end up. Most of it is glowering, 30s, red-brick blocks, now turned a dirty brown by years of decay. Some of the buildings have had makeovers, been fitted with entry phones to increase security or double glazing. But others appear not to have been touched for decades. In places, water from broken gutters streams down the sides of buildings, leaving stains of green algae. Rubbish and old mattresses pile up in and around stairwells. Some of the flats are disused, their windows and doors shuttered off with slabs of steel.

Mohammed Ismael, a 66-year-old Bangladeshi, has lived here since 1983. He shows us into one of the bedrooms of his ground floor flat in Ionian House. Black mould is climbing the walls and ceiling and below, at floor level, paper is beginning to peel off from the damp. We move on to the bathroom which looks like something from a different era, something that ought to be photographed in sepia. The same damp and mould is everywhere and the paint is peeling and flaking away. 'There are people who come from the council. They use a machine to test it but they say there's nothing wrong,' he explains to Jasmin. Ismael is recovering from a heart bypass operation so he can't redecorate. 'And in any case,' he says, 'what's the point? The paper would only peel away with the damp.'

The same story is repeated in flats across the estate. One woman complains about the green mould that she keeps having to scrape off the window frames. Another talks about the kids who hang around in the stairwells taking drugs. Heroin smoking is rife among the 18 to 25 -year-olds here. Only recently has the Bengali community begun to face up to the severity of the problem. They are finally making contact with local addiction charities. That will start to solve the problem, but everybody here knows what is really required. People need jobs. They need better housing. They need opportunities. They need prospects.

More than anything they need a way out.

We are modern. We do not despise Canary Wharf for being a place awash with wealth. We see it as a wealth producer. We do not begrudge Karen Earp her shiny lifestyle, even while there are others nearby who do not have what she has. That reductive approach is from another era when thinking on the left was based on the assumption that big business was only a force for bad and had to be brought to heel by regulation or taxation. But it still offends that such extremes can exist in such close proximity.

So we want Canary Wharf and we want Karen Earp. But we also want the damp in Mohammed Ismael's flat dealt with, and the hole in the roof of the Alpha Grove Community Centre fixed. This is the real challenge that will face whoever is elected mayor of London on May 4. We will expect them to close up the gaps - all of them.

The Canary Wharf Group plc is valued at between £2.6 and £2.9 billion, though the overall cost of the development, including transport infrastructure, is billions more. How can any of this chrome and marble excess, this intense Manhattan-on-Thames, ever mean anything to the less enriched residents of Tower Hamlets either side? It is not a question for Pagano. He is simply a real estate salesmen, albeit one overseeing one of the greatest slabs of real estate in the world. It is a question for Robert John, a softly spoken Welshman who is a director of the company, but who has no job title. He has an office with a broad view of the Isle of Dogs to the south and hung with fine abstract art. John was one of the first people to be hired by Canadian developer Paul Reichman whose company, Olympia & York, began the work at Canary Wharf before it went bust during the recession of the early 90s. (Reichman subsequently bought the company back from the administrators and renamed it the Canary Wharf Group.) 'Paul Reichman said to me right at the beginning that we must always remember that we are new members of an old community,' John says. The key, he explains, is getting local people to work here, so the company has invested cash in skills-match programmes and sent ambassadors out into local schools. 'Yes, we need investment bankers, but we also need chefs,' he says. 'Yes, we need tax inspectors, but we also need taxi drivers. What we need to do is get this message out there.' And, he says proudly, it's working. They have a survey that shows an increase in the number of workers at Canary Wharf who live in Tower Hamlets from 4.5 per cent in 1997 to 8.4 per cent in 1999. 'Clearly we're getting two things,' John says. 'We're getting old locals finding jobs here and we're getting people with jobs here who are moving into the area to become new locals.' There has, after all, been a massive boom in expensive wharf-apartment developments. The problem is that, at the moment, John doesn't know how many of the 8.4 per cent are the old locals he wants. Still, he says, they are trying. They care. They give a damn. It would be easy to be cynical about this professed commitment to the local community by both Robert John and the Canary Wharf Group. Capital doesn't care about the little people, does it? Capital cares about profit and margins. Capital exists to serve the demands of the Great God Mammon, and if it does not, it has no purpose at all. Perhaps, but to dismiss their efforts altogether would be unfair, according to John Eversely, a lecturer in social policy at London University's Queen Mary and Westfield College on the nearby Mile End Road. 'As socially aware developers go, they are right up there with the Cadburys and the Rowntrees,' he says. 'They really do mean it. But the amount they put in is still chicken-feed compared to the size of the problem.' So is the gap between these two Londons, existing here side by side, at all bridgeable? 'If it is bridgeable,' Eversley concludes, 'it's only by the longest bridge in the history of the world.' The Alpha Grove Community Centre should, by rights, be the richest community centre in Britain. It sits on the edge of the Barkantine council estate on the Isle of Dogs just a few hundred yards south of Canary Wharf. From here, you can practically smell the money, hear it clanking through the tills. In theory, some of that cash should have found its way to the centre. It hasn't. The roof leaks. The heating system has broken down and there isn't the cash to fix it. The mini-bus, used to pick up kids after school when their parents are still working, is grinding to a halt. 'Funders love to fund individual projects,' says Anna Palm, a former music teacher who now runs the centre. 'But they won't come up with core funding. My salary is only sorted for the next two months. After that, who knows?' It's not supposed to be this way. When development of the Docklands area began in the early 80s, the Conservative government set up the London Docklands Development Corporation. It spent £3.9 billion of public money regenerating the area to match the £9 billion spent by the private sector, before it was wound up in 1998. Some of that cash did find its way to the Barkantine. The dilapidated tower blocks received new facades and walkways were given a makeover. 'The result was more graffiti and vandalism,' says Anna Palm, 'because you can't paint over a basic grass-roots problem. There are serious issues of poverty on this estate and the kids just see this huge development to all sides and think "there's nothing here for me".' The LDDC was replaced by the Isle of Dogs Community Foundation which has received seven-figure grants of government regeneration money, but that doesn't seem to be finding its way to Alpha Grove either. Palm picks up a map and points out the site of a new business and residential development, the Millennium Quarter, which will bear down on them from the north. 'We're going to be squished in between it and the river,' she says. All around them are £250,000 apartments. The Canary Wharf Group donates two hours of a business manager's time to come down and help the centre apply for grants, for which she says she is grateful. But it clearly frustrates her that there is so much wealth so close by and yet they can't get the relatively small amounts they need to secure the vital services for the elderly or after-school kids' clubs that the community relies upon. Sometimes that frustration breaks through. Recently some of the children from the centre put on a show in Cabot Hall at Canary Wharf. 'Everybody from the companies up there said how great it was so I tried to follow it up, tried to get donations from them but nothing happened. These cute little kids from the Isle of Dogs dancing around free for the businessmen at Canary Wharf and what do we get for it? Sod all.' Karen Earp has not heard of the Barkantine Estate. She can be forgiven. She has been very busy launching the new Four Seasons Hotel at Canary Wharf, where she is general manager. She also lives here, in an apartment just around the corner. She readily enthuses about what Wharf living means to her: 'I love it. I love the vibrancy of Canary Wharf during the day contrasted with the calming views of the river. Everything is out here and there isn't the traffic. It's just so compact. You haven't got the razzmatazz of the West End, of course, but you can go and get it. And now on weekends all the bars and restaurants are open so it doesn't die. It's a little oasis. You've got everything you need.' She, like Robert John, talks about a desire to employ local people, which she says she has done, in house-keeping, maintenance and in the kitchens. She also proclaims a love for the old East End pubs with their old East End 'characters', although she says she doesn't really go south on the Isle of Dogs much, which perhaps also explains why she has never come across the Barkantine. She takes me up to the presidential suite, a confection of blonde wood floors and sofas upholstered in shades of chocolate and caramel (brown, the new black). She shows me the Bang & Olufsen system and the marble clad bathroom and the pantry and the dining room. The suite costs £1,400 a night. Finally she shows me the view. It looks westwards down the curving river, towards Tower Bridge and the London Eye millennium wheel beyond. By one of those clever twists of geography you can see neither the impoverished districts to the north, nor to the south from here. But then, if you're paying £1,400 a night, you'll expect a good view. The Ocean Estate. It's a nice name, isn't it? Oceans teem with life. They swell and flow with the tides. They wash us clean. The Ocean Estate isn't a particularly nice place and it isn't clean. It is just a mile and a half to the north-east of Canary Wharf in Stepney, but it is an area that the billions of LDDC money was never designed to reach. Recently, John Eversley's research team from Queen Mary and Westfield College conducted research for Tower Hamlets Council as part of an ongoing bid for £50 million of Government regeneration money. The findings were startling: 51 per cent of households live on under £10,000 a year; only 25 per cent of adults are in full time paid work; 84 per cent of households are on some kind of state benefit; 36 per cent suffer from health problems; 44 per cent of households contain someone suffering from a long term illness or disability. I visit in the company of Jasmin, a 19-year-old Bangladeshi student who has agreed to translate. The vast majority of the residents are immigrants from Bangladesh who arrived here in the 70s and, for much of the older generation, Bengali remains their first language. The Ocean is a depressing place to end up. Most of it is glowering, 30s, red-brick blocks, now turned a dirty brown by years of decay. Some of the buildings have had makeovers, been fitted with entry phones to increase security or double glazing. But others appear not to have been touched for decades. In places, water from broken gutters streams down the sides of buildings, leaving stains of green algae. Rubbish and old mattresses pile up in and around stairwells. Some of the flats are disused, their windows and doors shuttered off with slabs of steel. Mohammed Ismael, a 66-year-old Bangladeshi, has lived here since 1983. He shows us into one of the bedrooms of his ground floor flat in Ionian House. Black mould is climbing the walls and ceiling and below, at floor level, paper is beginning to peel off from the damp. We move on to the bathroom which looks like something from a different era, something that ought to be photographed in sepia. The same damp and mould is everywhere and the paint is peeling and flaking away. 'There are people who come from the council. They use a machine to test it but they say there's nothing wrong,' he explains to Jasmin. Ismael is recovering from a heart bypass operation so he can't redecorate. 'And in any case,' he says, 'what's the point? The paper would only peel away with the damp.' The same story is repeated in flats across the estate. One woman complains about the green mould that she keeps having to scrape off the window frames. Another talks about the kids who hang around in the stairwells taking drugs. Heroin smoking is rife among the 18 to 25 -year-olds here. Only recently has the Bengali community begun to face up to the severity of the problem. They are finally making contact with local addiction charities. That will start to solve the problem, but everybody here knows what is really required. People need jobs. They need better housing. They need opportunities. They need prospects. More than anything they need a way out. We are modern. We do not despise Canary Wharf for being a place awash with wealth. We see it as a wealth producer. We do not begrudge Karen Earp her shiny lifestyle, even while there are others nearby who do not have what she has. That reductive approach is from another era when thinking on the left was based on the assumption that big business was only a force for bad and had to be brought to heel by regulation or taxation. But it still offends that such extremes can exist in such close proximity. So we want Canary Wharf and we want Karen Earp. But we also want the damp in Mohammed Ismael's flat dealt with, and the hole in the roof of the Alpha Grove Community Centre fixed. This is the real challenge that will face whoever is elected mayor of London on May 4. We will expect them to close up the gaps - all of them.

fields.headline: May days
fields.standfirst: It's only on the trees for a few days, but blossom heralds the real arrival of summer
fields.trailText: It's only on the trees for a few days, but blossom heralds the real arrival of summer
fields.body:
Is it worth planting trees for their blossom, when the flowers only last for a few days, often bear no fruit, and in many cases do not make particularly attractive trees? Blossom works on us in a way that few other flowers do. It is partly promise (that froth of flower is as life-confirming as anything your eyes will set on for another year), partly surprise (trees in flower are scarce in this country and it continues to amaze us that it happens at all), partly sheer beauty (I still find the combination of May blossom and cow parsley on a lovely spring day the most achingly beautiful thing in the world), and partly the hint towards fecundity, because all blossom is merely a precursor to possible fruit.

So many different messages riding on little white or pink flowers! But all arriving at the same place - that heart-lurch when you come across the first blossom of the year in the sunshine - what Dennis Potter, dying in front of our eyes and swigging morphine from a hip flask, called 'the blossomest blossom'. What was really remarkable about that remark was not just the blithe courage or the glimpse of the daily world made infinitely precious in the jaws of death, but that each of us experiences this intensity daily for perhaps a week a year courtesy of blossom.

As one who has never studied even the most rudimentary botany (at this point certain members of the horticultural world splutter apoplectically on their coffee, but a slap - on the back - should sort them out), very elementary botanical facts provide the kind of insight that a nine-year-old has already got the T-shirt of. Here goes: all roses are mere blossom and all blossom are roses, sap-brothers under the bark. The rosaceae family includes all our blossoming trees. It explains a lot. If you see a cross section of an apple, plum and dog-rose flower, they all look remarkably similar, with the fruit waiting to swell just behind the petals. For years, the fat apples or swollen-hipped pears that appear from these flowers seemed to me to have an element of transmutation about them, rather than just being stages along the same journey. The flowers are the fruit becoming.

In this part of the world, the becoming happens as a procession, moving slowly through the countryside like the gorgeous retinue of a benign emperor. First is the blackthorn, Prunus spinosa, more often playing a minor role in a roadside or field hedge than planted in a garden, although it is a plum of sorts and the tiny white flowers convert into sloes that wither the inside of your mouth with their astringency, although they make sloe gin, which is the best winter-warming drink there is. My grandmother used to murmur forebodingly, 'Blackthorn winter' when it flowered, and it does often seem to coincide with a sharp spell of icy weather. It has the wickedest thorns to be found in this country and, if trimmed, makes an impenetrable hedge.

Just after the blackthorn, comes the damson blossom, also pure white, sitting on scruffy little trees dotted along the hedgerows between the cathedral cities of Hereford and Worcester like crenellations. The other day I was driving by and I thought it had begun to hail, before realising that in fact it was thousands of damson flowers swept off the branches by the wind.

As a plant, the damson is not worth its place in any garden, but as a flower and fruit, no sane gardener should be without it. So the answer is to put it in a hedge or orchard, to scramble honeysuckle, clematis and perhaps a small rose up it, and to relish the blossom for a week or so at the end of March and the fruit in September. The plums follow just after the damson, overlapping by a few days, the baton passing from hedgerow to orchard, just as the fruit is changed from strong and small to full and sweet by the process of breeding and hybridisation. Plum blossom sits on the trees thinly, measured as much by the sky between the flowers as the massing of the blooms themselves. Check this in 11 months' time.

Not long after the plum is the wild cherry, the gean, Prunus avium. This is often found in numbers at the edge of a wood, creating a wall of blossom set against the leafless branches of the trees behind it. They make large trees (up to 70ft) so are not suitable for a small garden, but they are incredibly decorative at every stage of the year. The bark is almost as good as the Tibetan cherry, and I remember a friend's father making his pipes from wild cherry wood, polishing the bark to a patent-leather shine on the side of his nose. Prunus avium 'Plena' is much heavier with flower and probably the one to plant in your garden. It also flowers a month later than the fully wild version, along with the sweet cherries. Ornamental cherries are the most popular of all flowering trees, on account of their range of blossom, from the almond-like Prunus x subhirtella to the hanging white flowerbells of 'Taihaku', but for me they do not fit the emotional bill of blossom because they are not producing any edible fruit. For the same reason, I would not include hawthorn in this list despite the power it has to jumble up my heart like an emotional spin-dryer. But the sweet cherries get a look-in, flowering like candyfloss (and almost as overpoweringly saccharine to the eye) at the end of this month. Then the flowers drop and blow around like brown litter for days.

Morello cherries (Prunus cerasus), crab apples (Malus pumila), quinces (Cydonia vulgaris) and pears (Pyrus communis) all come into flower at around the same time, according to variety. Certainly they always precede the earliest apple blossom. Quince blossom is one of my favourites, having flowers with a delicacy and sublime fragrance. Quinces had a bad time of it last year, suffering from a fungal disease that browned and withered their leaves, but mine seem to have recovered. I have four varieties, all planted near each other, and 'Lescovaz' proved to be entirely resistant to this fungus.

Crab apples are also wonderful in a much more cheeky-chappy kind of way. I don't know quite how they create that effect, as they have perfect pink and white flowers that can fill the air with their scent, but compared to the bone-china refinement of quince, or the purity of pear blossom, that is the result for me.

Pear is my favourite blossom, either in a great tree with the blossom piled up, cumulus-like, or stretched out along espaliers. The main problem with these early blossoms, as with peaches and apricots, is that they are prone to damage by late frosts. The answer is to plant them either against a west-facing wall or shaded from the early morning sun, as it is not the frost that does the damage but the bright morning sunshine which causes rapid thawing of the frozen cells.

The first apples, like 'Gravenstein', which has magnolia-pink flowers, start in mid-April, and the last, like the very old variety 'Court Pendu Plat', finishes a month later. This is an indication of their harvesting time, although unfortunately the fruit do not ripen exactly in the same sequential order that they flower. Thus in Roseanne Saunders's wonderful book The English Apple (sadly out of print), the earliest apple to ripen is Emneth Early, which is group 3, and the last is Granny Smith, which is in the same group. The real difference between pear and apple blossom, other than the pure whiteness of pear and strawberries-and-cream pink of most apples, is that apple blossom is borne as the leaves start to emerge, whereas pear adorns naked branches. This gives apple a fullness and softness that epitomises the fecundity of blossom-time.

By the time the last apple blossom is coming out, the grass is growing strongly, the buttercups are out and the swallows are turning around in the sky. Go and find an orchard of old standard apple trees some time in the coming week, and lose yourself beneath the branches. You will then know that we have arrived at the best of times at last. There is no going back. And that, above all else, is why you plant blossom in the garden.

fields.headline: Bellow's betrayal blots his copybook
fields.standfirst: Nobel laureate forced to repent over the 'outing' of Thatcher's favourite author
fields.trailText: The literary storm which has blown up around  Ravelstein, Saul Bellow's intimate portrait of the influential writer Allan Bloom, is moving quickly across the Atlantic.
fields.byline: Ed Vulliamy, New York, and Vanessa Thorpe
fields.body:
'I'm sorry for exposing him. I don't like the feeling it brought with it, and the recklessness on my part because I didn't mean any harm to Allan' - Bellow

The literary storm which has blown up around Ravelstein, Saul Bellow's intimate portrait of the influential writer Allan Bloom, is moving quickly across the Atlantic.

British friends and acolytes of the two writers, both Titans of American conservativism, are now being called on to take sides. Was it fair for Bellow, the Nobel-prizewinning novelist, to reveal so much about his dead friend's private life? And, if so, should he have disguised a personal memoir by changing Bloom's name to Ravelstein?

Bloom was reported to have died of liver cancer aged 62, in 1992, but Ravelstein is about a brilliant man who, though a moral, academic and cultural conservative, is a closet homosexual who contracted Aids.

For some time both these men of letters have had such status that even their political opponents have grudgingly admired them. And yet suddenly, one has betrayed the other. What is more, this week Bellow has started to admit it.

Perhaps, he has conceded, he should not have allowed his Ravelstein to die because he had Aids when he does not know for sure. Perhaps, too, he should not have given such intimate details of Ravelstein's homosexuality since Bloom had not declared his own sexuality.

Bloom, admired by both Margaret Thatcher and Ronald Reagan, was famous because of his book - a jere miad - called The Closing of the American Mind . It came out in 1987 and was a passionate, enraged defence of classical culture and virtue against what Bloom believed to be the ravages of mediocrity and iconoclasm in the 1960s. It hit America like a cold shower that froze the heat of the Woodstock generation.

Bloom's great friend at the end of his life was Bellow -one of the most acclaimed novelists of our time and a guardian at the gates of the American-English lexicon. Bellow is now the 84-year-old proud father of a baby daughter by his fifth wife, but self-doubt, a hallmark of his fictional characters, appears to have taken hold.

This week he has spoken of regret and there are reports that he is re-editing the book before its next print run to remove allusions to, among other things, Ravelstein's homosexual fantasies.

In an interview in the New York Times, the Nobel laureate admits he underestimated the sensitivity over homosexuality and Aids. 'You know,' he says, 'I've discovered this is a very itchy subject and people carry over attitudes more appropriate to the Middle Ages.' Bellow says he is sorry he 'exposed' Bloom. 'I don't like the feeling it brought with it... and the sense of recklessness on my part.'

Whatever Bellow's motives and affections, his literary indiscretion joins those of, among others, John Le Carré whose A Naïve and Sentimental Lover reveals the love triangle between Le Carré and James and Susan Kennaway, and Paul Theroux's Sir Vidia's Shadow, on V.S. Naipaul. Bellow has approached the territory before in his Pulitzer Prize-winning Humbolt's Gift, said to be a life of of his one-time mentor Delmore Schwartz. Americans call it 'betrayal chic'.

George Walden, the maverick former Tory Education Minister, knew both Bloom and Bellow and introduced them to Thatcher in the late 1980s. 'I don't believe that Bellow has diminished Bloom in this portrayal,' he told The Observer. 'It is not a hagiography, though. It is the kind of true picture that Bellow is so good at, although perhaps with some of the sparkling humour missing.'

When The Closing of the American Mind was published, Walden took Bloom to Chequers to meet Thatcher. 'It was amazing. She had stayed up until 2.30am, according to Denis, reading the book. For once she was listening and asking questions.'

In real life, it was Bellow who first urged Bloom to put his ideas into words. He also wrote the foreword. The first line is not very affectionate: 'Professor Bloom,' he writes 'has his own way of doing things.'
