fields.headline: Elian seized at gunpoint
fields.standfirst:
President orders dawn raid on relatives of six-year-old Cuban boy
Cuba after Castro - Observer special
fields.trailText: President orders dawn raid on relatives of six-year-old Cuban boy
fields.body:
Cuban shipwreck survivor Elián González was snatched in a dramatic dawn raid by heavily armed officers yesterday on the orders of President Clinton after anti-Castro relatives in Miami refused to hand him over to be reunited with his father.

The six-year-old boy, who was rescued by fishermen from the Straits of Florida five months ago after spending two days in the water, was taken by armed officers of the US immigration service from a cupboard in the house where he was being hidden.

A few hours later he was reunited with his father at Andrews airforce base just outside Washington. '[Elián] looked very happy and [his father] Juan Miguel was crying,' a Justice Department official said. Caught napping by the raid, enraged Cuban exiles in Miami who had demanded that Elián remain in the US took to the streets yesterday, setting fires and confronting lines of riot police who had sealed off several blocks around the house.

By early afternoon, the protests were turning into an embryonic riot. Police units in riot gear mounting a sudden show of force and crowds in the 'Little Havana' neighbourhood were cleared with a volley of tear gas.

Battle lines were also being drawn politically yesterday. The Mayors of both Miami and Dade County led the challenges to the government's heavy-handedness, meanwhile quelling the riots in support of their stance.

The climactic raid, which lasted only three minutes, was ordered by President Clinton himself - awoken before first light to be told that negotiations had broken down with the Miami family who had kept the boy for five months.

Attorney General Janet Reno unleashed the team which then smashed its way into the house with a battering ram. Elián was found in the arms of the fisherman who had rescued him from the sea.

He was grabbed at gunpoint, wrapped in a blanket, bundled into a van, whisked to a helicopter and then flown by special plane to Washington and his waiting father, Juan Miguel.

Elián had been pulled out of the Straits of Florida by the fisherman on Thanksgiving Day. Clinging to a tyre, the boy was the lone survivor of a doomed raft escape from Cuba in which his mother had drowned.

Since that day he had been held - as a hostage according to the government - by his uncle, Lazaro González, and cousin, 21-year-old Marisleysis, who hailed the boy's survival as a divine miracle.

At 4am, after negotiations had broken down, Janet Reno concluded that time had run out. 'At that moment I gave the go-ahead for the operations,' she said. Speaking in Washington two hours after the snatch, Reno said she had 'commenced an operation with paramount concern for the safety of Elián, the agents and the others'.

Defending the heavy-handed display of weaponry, Reno said 'there were guns, perhaps in the crowd, perhaps in the house. When law enforcement goes in for a situation like that, it must go in for the unexpected.'

The raid is a triumph for Reno, who had put her political reputation and legacy on the line over the Elián case.

It later emerged that Elián's uncle, Lazaro, had tried to put in another offer - too late - as the snatch squad was already on its way.

Meanwhile, having landed at Andrews Air Force base near Washington, Elián was said to be in buoyant form. He was greeted with a bear-hug embrace by his father.

Back in Miami, his cousin Marisleysis claimed that the government agents had smashed Elián's bed during the raid and threatened her with a gun to the chest.

fields.headline: Three shades of green
fields.standfirst: The IRA's Easter message hardly varies. But  John O'Farrell  finds that the views of leading republicans reflect a rift in the movement
fields.trailText: Easter Sunday is the most sacred day in the republican calendar. It is their Twelfth of July and Remembrance Sunday combined. It exemplifies a dynamic nationalism once identified by Tom Nairn as 'the Modern Janus' - remembering and gaining strength from the past while simultaneously facing the future.
fields.body:
Easter Sunday is the most sacred day in the republican calendar. It is their Twelfth of July and Remembrance Sunday combined. It exemplifies a dynamic nationalism once identified by Tom Nairn as 'the Modern Janus' - remembering and gaining strength from the past while simultaneously facing the future.

Around lunchtime today, republicans of different hues will reiterate their beliefs in the ending of partition, and justify that belief as an historic inevitability underwritten by the sacrifices of past republicans, from Padraig Pearse in 1916 to Diarmuid O'Neill in 1996.

The rhetoric rarely changes, and yet the emotions are real and sincere. Republican families will gather to mourn with pride their sons and brothers who died 'for the cause', while thousands are expected to turn out in Belfast, Derry and Dublin, with big-name Sinn Fein speakers leading the orations.

At all the Sinn Fein-organised commemorations at dozens of graveyards around Ireland, a hush will fall as a young man, masked or barefaced, will read the annual Easter message from the IRA. Apart from a couple of paragraphs at the end, it never varies. The IRA greets its supporters, remembers its fallen and their families; 'extends solidarity' to the remaining IRA prisoners; 'commends this steadfast commitment and discipline' of the current IRA membership; and 'reaffirms our commitment to our republic objective'.

Sinn Fein leaders such as Gerry Kelly have stressed the importance of the line in today's IRA statement that they 'want to see a permanent peace in our country', a deliberate echo of last November's statement which led to the 10- week executive with Sinn Fein sharing power in Stormont with the Ulster Unionists, SDLP and DUP.

Unionists have expressed disappointment, or anger - depending on whether they are pro- or anti-Agreement - at the absence of any mention of decommissioning. But Easter statements are not meant for a wider audience. It is when republicans speak to themselves, of themselves.

Naturally, this involves strict segregation from those republicans who have 'fallen' from the true path. In Belfast, there will be four parades along the same route, the Falls Road, to Milltown cemetery.

Republican Sinn Fein will go first, to hear party president Ruairi O Bradaigh castigate Gerry Adams and the 'Provisionals' sell-out'. Then the Irish Republic Socialist Party, said now to number 30 members, will hear Paul Little orate at the INLA memorial, which bears the names of more dead volunteers than the IRSP has active members.

Cavan TD Caoimhgin O Caolain will reassure Sinn Fein at what will be by far the largest gathering today, with the Workers' Party bringing up the rear at perhaps the strangest grave in Milltown, the Official IRA plot. This huge plot was designed to hold dozens of dead volunteers but only three are buried there, as the Official IRA called off its armed campaign in 1972.

This public schism of republicanism is reflected by the subtler changes within republicanism's main force, Sinn Fein. Put bluntly, Sinn Fein and the IRA are badly split, but the 'breakaways' are themselves disparate. Some have remained constant to the old certainties, supporting armed struggle and rejecting constitutionalism. Others argue for a radical yet peaceful, republicanism, mindful of the political realities of the global economy.

The tight ghetto mentality of Irish republicanism is breaking down, thinking for itself. Thanks to the peace process, republicans are exploring the chances of being political on their own terms.

Where then, is republicanism now? For answers, The Observer turned to three people who are proud to be called republicans, but have left Sinn Fein to pursue a political space of their own. All were asked the same seven questions with the aim of gaining an audit of where republicanism stands as an ideology.

Rory Dougan is a member of the 32 County Sovereignty Movement, which split from Sinn Fein in 1998 and is believed to be the political wing of the Real IRA. Originally from Co Armagh, Dougan now lives in Dundalk, where he will be commemorating the 1916 Rising this afternoon.

Mairtin O Muilleoir is a former student activist who became a Sinn Fein councillor in Belfast. He left the party in 1997 and became a journalist. He is now managing editor of the Andersonstown News , the most influential publication in west Belfast. His recent book of reminiscences as a councillor, Belfast Dome of Delight, was a local bestseller.

Tommy McKearney will spend this morning at a quiet family commemoration, remembering his two brothers, both IRA members, both shot dead by the security forces. McKearney almost died in 1980 after going 53 days without food in the first H-Block hunger strike. He is now working with former prisoners, helping them find jobs. He is also a member of the Irish Republic Writers Group and co-edits its journal Fourthwrite .

Asked firstly if republicanism has a role in the twenty-first century, Dougan said it has the 'same role as in the twentieth and late-nineteenth century, that is to activate for an all-Ireland Republic, free from outside military and political interference'.

O Muilleoir said that the role of republicans was 'to advance on every imaginable front to improve the quality of life for their people and to build up the communities they serve'.

McKearney pointed out that 'there is no such thing as a republican catechism, there are no 39 Articles'. Republicanism, he believes, is 'constantly under review' and has continually changed over 100 years. At its best, it is the struggle to build democracy in Ireland and it has the potential to be a radical democratic movement.'

Which, then, was most important - republicanism or nationalism? McKearney said that 'republicanism has to break free from nationalism, particularly the nineteenth-century form of Irish nationalism which at it best is outdated and at worst dangerous. It justifies itself in enhancing an exclusive community which leads to the exclusion of others.'

Likewise, Dougan believes that 'in the past five years the republican movement has become more nationalist than republican'. He is concerned that the present Sinn Fein leadership 'will settle for less than the republic'.

O Muilleoir, on the other hand, observes a 'new nationalism which is pro-peace process, is aggressively demanding equality for all and is unapologetically pro-active for its Irish identity'.

All three stated that they believed that republicanism has an agenda which encompasses all of Ireland, not just the North. Dougan argues that Ireland can never achieve its proper sovereignty while divided in 'two partitionist states'.

O Muilleoir relishes the 'prospect of being in government on both sides of the border' while McKearney is concerned that 'Sinn Fein are developing the party for the sake of the party.' He sees unnerving similarities between 'new Sinn Fein' and New Labour under Blair, with Gerry Adams preparing his party to go into coalition with 'right-wing' parties like Fianna Fail.

All three also agreed that republicans need to grasp the realities of membership of the EU and the global economy. According to McKearney, globalisation, despite its problems for impoverished people, has got 'good things about it, such as the worldwide web which enhances democracy'.

There was much sucking in of air when asked what the legacy of Gerry Adams would be. McKearney credited Adams with reorganising Sinn Fein, but 'at a certain stage, Adams created a position where he took republicans beyond their radical base, his analysis began to go fuzzy, and we now have no break in the stampede towards a reformist parliamentary system'.

O Muilleoir cagily quoted Chou En-lai: 'It's too early to say.' Dougan said that Adams was 'probably the most pragmatic leader republicanism had since the 1920s, but squandered the chance of British withdrawal.' Dougan believes that the series of IRA 'spectaculars' such as the 1993 Baltic Exchange bomb had the British desperate for a peace settlement.

Asked then if armed struggle will ever be justified, Dougan responded that 'If armed struggle is wrong now, it was wrong for 30 years.'But if armed struggle is right now, then the Sinn Fein strategy is wrong.'

Dougan emphasises, though, that republicans should not show 'blind loyalty' to violence, and should condemn 'armed action' which do not 'ensure that civilians are never put at risk'.

O Muilleoir declined to answer the question, while McKearney was very careful about his answer, stating that 'armed struggle can only be justified if there are a clear majority of people supporting it. But if a minority are trying to justify their will then it cannot be justified.'

The three republicans were finally asked if they can see a day when republicans can share a meaningful political dialogue with unionists. Dougan said that republicans have 'no problem' entering meaningful discussions with unionists', but believes that as long as there is partition, unionists, like nationalists and republicans, 'can never achieve their full potential'.

O Muilleoir says that 'that day has already arrived' and cites his experience on Belfast City Council, where he worked in committees with unionist councillors who are vocally opposed to the Good Friday Agreement. McKearney believes it is possible, but appreciates the difficulties in that 'republicanism and unionism are diametrically opposed philosophies'. Therefore, 'one will have to give way'.

However, McKearney sees hope in the newer forms of politics emerging particularly among working class Protestants and speaks highly of some individuals in their Progressive Unionist Party.

McKearney is, despite his misgivings about the Agreement, optimistic about the future: 'The potential exists for what may be the first time in more than a century for real change to happen.'

fields.headline: Blair promises to end delays over adoption
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is to demand a major shake-up of Britain's beleaguered adoption services following a report exposing the lottery facing those who want to adopt.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is to demand a major shake-up of Britain's beleaguered adoption services following a report exposing the lottery facing those who want to adopt.

The Prime Minister wants applications speeded up and a national register to record local authority performances, and will consider new legislation to stop potential adopters being blocked by 'politically correct' councils.

'I believe that the interests of the child should come first, second and third,' the Prime Minister says in an interview with the women's magazine Red, to be published this week. 'I want to make it easier for children to be placed quickly. The most important thing is that children are living in a loving family rather than a care home, however well it is run.'

A report published at the beginning of the month revealed that a hard core of social workers are refusing to process adoption applications quickly enough. Although 1,300 approved adopters are still waiting to have children placed with them 2,400 children remain in care despite being available for adoption.

Many potential adopters are black, Asian or of mixed race and, while many of the children are from similar backgrounds, the adopters are often turned down because they are not 'racially aware' enough.

One senior employee at the BBC who is black with a white partner was turned down for that reason.

The investigation by the Social Services Directorate also found that 29 local authorities were breaking the law by failing to review adoption policies every three years. It also found wide disparities in the time prospective adopters have to wait before their applications are approved and large variations in the percentage of children who are successfully placed. In some authorities delays can last for well over a year.

'There is a huge disparity even between next-door boroughs,' Blair said. 'Hartlepool places 11 per cent of kids up for adoption, for example, while Darlington places only 1 per cent. I'd want to make sure people who want to adopt don't go through such an agonising set of hurdles often with unsatisfactory results. Some of the rules such as age limits are very arbitrary.'

The Government will hold an adoption summit on Tuesday which will look at drafting national policy guidelines against which authorities will be judged. Ministers will be told to draw up a campaign strategy to recruit adopters. It is thought an advertising blitz will be planned along with leaflets encouraging new adopters to come forward.

There will also be a discussion about sanctions that could be taken against authorities, which could require new legislation.

Sally Brampton, editor of Red, which is aimed at the 30-plus market, says a sixth of couples have problems conceiving. Yet figures released recently show a substantial decline in the number of children being adopted. In 1970, 20,300 children were adopted, of which 2,183 came from care. By 1999, the number adopted had fallen to between 4,000 and 6,000, with about the same number coming from care homes.

Kamal Ahmed@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Take race out of asylum
fields.standfirst: Honouring Bernie Grant reminds us that much has been done to achieve racial equality. But, says the Home Secretary, there is still more to do to keep alive his crusading work and spirit.
fields.trailText: Jack Straw defends the government's record on asylum and immigration and says they need to be detached from race.
fields.body:
Two and a half thousand people attended Bernie Grant's funeral last Tuesday. I have been to countless church funerals and the occasional humanist one, but this was for me, a white Protestant, extraordinary.

Bernie was uncompromising to the end. He didn't believe in God. He believed in life. So the funeral was this wonderful, sad and exuberant celebration of what Bernie has given the rest of us - his wife Sharon, his family, his constituents and fellow Members of Parliament, the black community and British society more generally.

Bernie's particular contribution to racial understanding was to the self-confidence of the British Afro-Caribbean community. Their right to be treated exactly the same as the white community did not mean that they had to act exactly the same as the white community.

He added the big factor of respect for diversity to the equation of racial equality. It was that celebration of the Afro-Caribbean cultures, which these communities have as much to give as to receive, which made last Tuesday's commemoration so striking.

Bernie remembered, and was revolted, by that pernicious Conservative poster from the 1983 general election. It had on it the face of a black man with the legend: 'Labour says he's black. We say he's British.'

Bernie knew you did not have to choose one or the other - you could be both. And you could remain proud of where you came from, too (in his case Guyana, and in his forebears' case, as slaves from West Africa). His generation, which came to Britain from the West Indies in the Fifties and Sixties, could not help but be defined, at least in the early days, by the fact of their and their family's immigration.

Their grandchildren, however, have a very different perspective. Born third- generation British, for them the links between race and immigration must seem all but irrelevant.

Race relations have come a long way since many of Bernie's generation arrived in this country. In the early Sixties, notices in lodging houses saying 'No dogs, no Irish, no blacks' were not uncommon, nor even unlawful. Conservatives in the Smethwick constituency in 1964 fought on the doorsteps with the message: 'If you want a nigger for a neighbour, vote Labour', although such sentiments were never officially endorsed.

The changes since then have not, however, happened by accident. Three successive Race Relations Acts - in 1965, 1968 and 1976 - were passed by Labour governments to help create a moral climate as well as a legal regime in which racist actions and words were put beyond the pale.

But after the lip-service years of the Eighties and early Nineties, it took the appalling murder of Stephen Lawrence and the subsequent inquiry report to be a wake-up call for the rest of us about what more needs to be done.

The Lawrence inquiry made 70 recommendations. We are getting on with implementing them all, not least with the Race Relations Amendment Bill which is now before Parliament. This extends the laws against direct and indirect discrimination to the whole public sector and imposes a positive duty to promote racial equality on all public authorities. Targets for recruitment, retention and promotion of ethnic minority staff across the public service are now being set.

But as well as its forensic effect, the Lawrence inquiry has revealed the profound ambiguity of some of those on the Right about how we tackle racism. Some of those who campaigned vigorously for an inquiry have then backed away from the logical consequences of some of its recommendations.

Beyond them, of course, are those of the lip-service brigade, who may mouth the words about racial justice but who are ever ready to press the button marked 'prejudice' when their backs are against the wall.

Andrew Lansley, then head of the Conservative Research Department (and now MP for Cambridgeshire South), notoriously wrote in The Observer in September 1995 that 'immigration [was] an issue which we raised successfully in 1992 and again in the 1994 European election campaign. It played particularly well in the tabloids and has more potential to hurt'. But for Lansley, advising his party on how to avoid defeat, immigration was merely code for race, and Labour 'a soft touch'.

But if the Tories have been able to play this card, it is in part because some sections of the Left have shown less clarity than they should on immigration, its benefits and its limits.

Our society has been built on wave after wave of immigration. There are few in the UK who will not have some immigrant blood in their veins.

And in the main, there has been mutuality about the immigration that has taken place. The Asians who came to my constituency in the Sixties arrived there not because of a sudden outbreak of altruism in Blackburn, but because mill owners had been advertising for workers on the Indian subcontinent. There are similar stories for the origins of almost every black and Asian community in Britain today. Enoch Powell, of all people, as Minister of Health in the Fifties, famously advertised for NHS nurses and doctors in the West Indies, as did London Transport for bus drivers and conductors.

A failure to attract sufficient immigration at key points in our history, including the decades immediately after the Second World War, would have led to economic stagnation and the breakdown of some of our key public services. In most cases, the mutual benefits have been economic. There is an interesting reverse fit between net migration flows to and from the UK and unemployment in the UK.

In other cases, the mutual bene fits to our society of inward migration have derived from the moral imperative of sustaining a world order that is based upon the rule of law. We signed up to the 1951 Convention on Refugees and have implemented it because we wanted to ensure that there were places of safety for those fleeing from a well-founded fear of persecution.

But it is where mutuality, whether moral and economic, breaks down that the limits to immigration have to be set. This, I suggest, is where, first, we have to facilitate family reunion - as I have done by abolishing the 'primary purpose rule' in June 1997, and legislating to restore the right of appeal for family visitors.

Second, we are pulling together the more positive aspects of immigration control on students, work permits, business establishment and tourism to ensure that these controls work with the grain of our economic needs and of our labour market.

Third, we are improving the asylum process, to make it work more swiftly and fairly. In March, more than 11,000 applications were decided - four times the level at the end of last year. The new support system is on-stream. A 'one-stop' appeal system starts in October. So will controls against unscrupulous immigration advisers - against whom Bernie waged a campaign inside Parliament and outside.

If limits and controls are accepted as necessary, then enforcement of those limits has to take place. That does not require the Tories' callous and cynical chimera of incarceration for every asylum-seeker. It does, however, require controls, like the new civil penalty on those who bring illegal migrants hidden in vehicles, a support system which is not itself an incentive to claim asylum, and the sensible and proportionate use of detention.

If we can secure a broad consensus for this approach, then at long last we may finally be able to detach race and immigration as political issues. It's what Bernie, I think, would have wished. Indeed, the only ones who will regret this disconnection are those who wish to maintain the potential of immigration 'to hurt' and who fail to celebrate, as we did last Tuesday, the riches that a multi-cultural society bring to us all.
